div2.p: Vs. 1-7. Prooemium: The wrath of Achilles, from its very beginning, and the destructive consequences which followed in accordance with the will of Zeus. This is the principal theme of the Iliad. The First Book serves as an introduction to the whole poem; it narrates the story of the strife between Achilles and Agamemnon, and the decree of Zeus, which is made on the intercession of Thetis. — The events narrated in A occupy 21 days.
mh=nin: wrath, lasting anger, the memorem iram of Verg. Aen. i. 4; cf. vs. 81, 247, 488. This receives prominence as being most important for the subject of the poem.
qea/: cf. a)/ndra moi e)/nnepe mou=sa a 1; see on 2.484. For the following caesural pause, see § 40 c.
*phlhia/dew: for the patronymic, see § 21 d; for the synizesis, see § 7.

*)axilh=os: for the single l, see § 41 fh. Achilles was the son of Peleus and the sea-goddess Thetis (see vs. 351 ff.). He was the mightiest warrior of the Greek leaders before Troy (v. 280, 2.769), although one of the youngest (9.438 ff.). His home was in Phthia (2.681 ff.) of Thessaly. See on v. 488.

ou)lome/nhn: destructive, deadly; cf. Milton Par. Lost i. 2
forbidden fruit . . .
whose mortal taste
Brought death into the world. The thought is amplified in the following rel. clause, cf. v. 10, 2.227; see § 1 h, t.
muri/a: countless; not a numeral in Homer, see § 23 i. — For the hiatus, allowed when the final vowel has been elided, see § 9 e.
a)/lgea: i.e. the defeats caused by the absence of Achilles from the conflict.
e)/qhken: caused (as 3.321, see § 2 v), nearly equiv. to teu=xe below.

polla/s: the second clause of the rel. sent. is closely connected with the first by the anaphoric relation of polla/s to muri/a (cf. Od. 1.1-3); while the third clause is added in the form of a contrast, au)tou\s de\ ktl.
i)fqi/mous: the fem. form i)fqi/mas is used by Homer only of persons; see § 20 a.

*)/ai+di proi+/ayen: sent off to Hades, a vigorous expression for a violent death, as *e 190, *z 487, *l 55; cf. *)ai/da| proi+a/yai doro\s a)/gran Aesch. Sept. 309, multos Danaum demittimus Orco Verg. Aen. ii. 398. For the use of pro/, cf. pro\ h(=ke v. 195.
*)/ai+di: a metaplastic form of *)ai/dhs (§ 19 f.), which in Homer is always the name of a person, the ruler of the nether world (§ 2 v.).
h(rw/wn: did not have the later meaning of heroes in the Eng. sense (§ 2 v).

au)tou/s: themselves, i.e. their bodies as contrasted with their souls, as *y 66, z 329, l 574, 602. They would have cared less about the rites of burial, if they had not considered the body to be the man himself.

e(lw/ria: booty, cf. kusi\n d) e)/peiq) e(/lwra ka)pixwri/ois | o)/rnisi dei=pnon Aesch. Supp. 808 f., canibus date praeda Latinis | alitibusque Verg. Aen. ix. 485 f. For the preceding hiatus, see § 9 b.

teu=xe ku/nessin: since the bodies often had to lie unburied, cf. *b 393, *q 491, *l 395, *s 271, 283, *x 66 ff., 339. Dogs are the scavengers of the East. cf. ‘Him that dieth of Ahab in the city the dogs shall eat; and him that dieth in the field shall the fowls of the air eat’ 1 Kings xxi. 24, ‘And the Philistine said to David, “Come to me and I will give thy flesh unto the fowls of the air, and to the beasts of the field”’ 1 Sam. xvii. 44. To be left unburied was a dreaded fate; so Hector at the point of death besought Achilles, mh/ me e)/a para\ nhusi\ ku/nas katada/yai *)axaiw=n *x 339.
teu=xe: for the omission of the aug., see § 25 a, e.
dai=ta: of the food of brutes, as 24.43; cf. 2.383.

*dio\s . . . boulh/: instead of *dio\s mega/lou dia\ boula/s, as Od. 8.82, is joined paratactically (§ 3 n f.) to the preceding rel. clause; the will of Zeus was accomplished in the consequences of the wrath of Achilles. cf. ‘Such was the will of heaven’ Milton Par. Lost ii. 1025.
e)telei/eto: for the form, see on 2.536, § 29 i.

e)c ou(= ktl.: since first, since once; the starting-point for mh=nin ou)lome/nhn. This expression takes the place in Homer of the prose e)pei\ a(/pac, e)pei\ ta/xista, cf. v. 235, e)pei\ dh\ to\ prw=ton d 13. prw=ton and prw=ta are used adv. with little difference of meaning, cf. vs. 276, 319.
ta/: for the short vowel lengthened before the following consonants, see § 41 h.
diasth/thn e)ri/sante: were divided (lit. separated) in strife.

*)atrei+/dhs: tetrasyllabic, § 21 f.; for the use of the patronymic, see § 21 b. Agamemnon, son of Atreus, and grandson of Pelops (2.104 ff.), reigned at Mycenae (2.569 ff.). As the leader of the expedition against Troy, he is prominent through the whole poem. The first part of the Eleventh Book is devoted to his brave deeds in war (*)agame/mnonos a)ristei/a). He is described by Helen as ‘a good king and a brave warrior’ (3.179).
a)/nac a)ndrw=n: elsewhere precedes a proper name; only here is it found after a patronymic. It is generally applied to Agamemnon, § 1 q. For the apparent hiatus, see §§ 9 f, 14 a.

di=os: godlike, glorious (eu\genh/s), a standing epith. of Achilles and of Odysseus. No special excellence of character is implied. Obs. the metrical adaptation to the names of these two heroes, allowing the bucolic diaeresis, at the close of the verse, see § 40 i; cf. *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, *palla\s *)aqh/nh. di=os *)axilleu/s closes the verse more than 50 times; di=os *)odusseu/s, more than 100 times.

Vs. 8-52. The injured Chryses. The avenging Apollo. The scene opens in the 9th year of the war before Troy (2.295). During their siege of the city, the Greeks supported themselves by marauding expeditions. On one of these forays they captured Thebe (vs. 366 ff.) and brought away as part of the booty the daughter of Chryses, priest of Apollo (v. 370). She was assigned to Agamemnon, to be his slave, as his ge/ras, prize of honor. See on vs. 124 f.

ti/s t) a)/r: and who then? question from the standpoint of the hearer, suggested by v. 6. cf. ‘Who first seduced them to that foul revolt? — Th' infernal serpent’ Milton Par. Lost i. 33. Some god must have decreed the calamity; the Homeric theology recognized no blind chance.
e)/ridi cune/hke: brought together in strife, cf. qew=n e)/ridi cunio/ntwn g 66 as the gods came together in strife, qeou\s e)/ridi cunela/ssai g 134.
cune/hke: for the augment, see § 25 h.

ma/xesqai: sc. e)pe/essin, cf. v. 304, 2.377 f. Inf. of result, where w(/ste might have been used in prose, cf. manteu/esqai v. 107, a)/gein v. 338, a)na/ssein *b 108, e)rize/menai *b 214. Some of these examples may be taken as infs. of purpose, which cannot always be clearly separated from the inf. of result in Homer.
*lhtou=s: cf. v. 36. Apollo was the mediate cause of the trouble, since the pestilence occasioned the quarrel.
o(: for the dem. use of the art., see § 24 i.
basilh=i: Agamemnon, a)/nac a)ndrw=n.
xolwqei/s: see on v. 18.
nou=son: Att. no/son, § 5 e; it is called loimo/s v. 61.
a)na\ strato/n: up through the camp (cf. kata\ strato/n v. 318), as the plague spread from tent to tent; cf. v. 53.

kakh/n: the adj. is explained by the following (paratactic consecutive) clause, the first word of which takes up the thought of the adj. For the order of words, connecting kakh/n with what follows, see § 1 h.
laoi/: soldiery, cf. 3.186 and Agamemnon's epith. poimh\n law=n, *b 243, shepherd of the people.
to\n *xru/shn: that Chryses, well known to the hearers from stories or other songs. Nowhere else in Homer is the art. used with a proper name; cf. 2.595.
h)ti/masen: slighted.
a)rhth=ra: receives prominence from its rhythm and position, almost equiv. to “though he was” etc. He is called i(ereu/s below.
qoa/s: cf. nhusi\ w)kupo/roisin v. 421; a standing epith. of the ships even when they were on shore, § 1 p.
e)pi\ nh=as: i.e. to the camp, where the ships were drawn up on land, cf. 2.688. — For the position of the prep. between the adj. and noun, cf. v. 15; see § 1 l.
luso/menos: to release for himself, to ransom. The act. is used of him who receives the ransom, vs. 20, 29.
qu/gatra: Homer knows her only by her patronymic *xrushi/s (v. 111, see § 21 g) daughter of Chryses.
fe/rwn: bringing with him, prob. on a wagon. cf. 24.275 ff., 502.
a)perei/si) a)/poina: bullion, either of gold, silver, or copper, as *z 48, *x 340; or vessels of precious metal, as 23.741 ff.; or clothing, as 24.229 ff.

ste/mmat) *)apo/llwnos: cf. Apollinis infula Verg. Aen. ii. 430. This ribbon, or chaplet, of white wool, marked the priest's official character; he came under the god's protection, but as a suppliant carried the fillet, instead of wearing it. cf. laurumque manu vittasque ferentem
e(khbo/lou: he was the Archer Apollo. For similar epiths., see § 4 c. — For the loss of quantity in the final diphthoug before an initial vowel, cf. v. 17; see § 41 o.
*)apo/llwnos: for the length of the first syllable, as vs. 21, 36, etc., see § 41 f.
xruse/w|: it was adorned with golden studs, see on v. 219, 2.45; cf. v. 246. So the soul of the seer Teiresias had a xru/seon skh=ptron in Hades, Od. 11.91. — For the synizesis, see § 7.

a)na\ skh/ptrw|: on a staff; const. with ste/mmat) e)/xwn. Princes, judges, priests, and heralds carried skh=ptra as symbols of authority. A skh=ptron was placed in the hands of him who was about to address the assembly, as a sign that he “had the floor,” cf. v. 245, *g 218, sth= de\ me/sh| a)gorh=|: skh=ptron de/ oi( e)/mbale xeiri\ | kh=ruc b 37 f. The Spartans also carried stout staffs, and Athenian gentlemen carried canes.
pa/ntas: the bard's hearers easily made for themselves the necessary limitations for such general expressions.

*)atrei+/da du/w: for du/w with the dual, cf. *ai)/ante du/w *b 406, *g 18, le/onte du/w, *e 554. This dual form is infrequent. Menelaus, king of Sparta (2.586), as husband of Helen, is associated with his brother Agamemnon; cf. *b 408, *k 25 ff., *)axaiw=n di/qronon kra/tos Aesch. Ag. 108, dikratei=s *)atrei=dai Soph. Aj. 252.
kosmh/tore: kosme/w is used in the sense of the later ta/ssw, cf. *b 554, *g 1, § 2 v.
17 = 23.272, 658; cf. *h 327, 385, *y 236, — The usual introduction to a speech (§ 1 w) is omitted. — For the use of the speaker's very words, instead of indir. disc., see § 1 c.
e)uknh/mides: a standing epith. of the Achaeans (§ 1 q); in historical times, Herodotus (vii. 92) mentions greaves as worn by the Lycians in the army of Xerxes.
qeoi/: monosyllable by synizesis, see § 7 a, d. — Cf. di tibi dent capta classem deducere Troia Hor. Sat. ii. 3. 191.
po/lin: for the length of the ultima, see § 41 p.
oi)/kade: homeward, always of the return to Greece, not like oi)ko/nde into the house; see § 15 g.
pai=da de/: made prominent because of his love for his daughter; instead of the e)moi\ de/ which is expected in contrast with u(mi=n me/n v. 18.

lu=sai: corresponds to doi=en. “As I pray that you may be victorious and have a safe return, so may ye restore to me” etc.; cf. the prayer of Priam for Achilles, su\ de\ tw=nd) a)po/naio, kai\ e)/lqois | sh\n e)s patri/da gai=an *w 556 f., where the return of Hector's body is the condition implied for the prayer. The inf. is used for the opt., as Od. 7.313; cf. the inf. and imv. in parallel clauses, vs. 322 f., 3.459.
ta/ t) a)/poina: he points to the gifts which he brought with him.

a(zo/menoi ktl.: a prime motive for granting the request; the Achaeans were to honor the god in the person of his priest. For the apparently neglected *v of e(khbo/lon, see § 14 e. The spondee in the fifth foot (see § 39 h f.) gives an emphatic close to the sentence, cf. vs. 11, 157, 291, 600.
The first hemistich = a 11, b 82.

e)peufh/mhsan: for the usual e)ph/|nhsan (7.344), because of the religious fear which was required by the priest. It is followed by the inf. as being equiv. to e)ke/leusan e)peufhmou=ntes they bade with pious reverence; cf. *b 290, ou)k e)leai/reis a)/ndras . . .
div2.l: misge/menai kako/thti u 202 f. “thou dost not in pity hinder men from suffering misery.” The sacral meaning of eu)fhme/w favere linguis seems to be later than Homer.

div2.p: ai)dei=sqai: repeats a(zo/menoi.
a)glaa/: important epith., introducing a motive for the action.
de/xqai: 2 aor. inf. from de/xomai, see § 35.
a)ll) ou)k ktl.: a sharp contrast to a)/lloi me/n, giving prominence to the neg.; but not to the son of Atreus.
qumw=|: local, in heart; see § 1 v.
kakw=s: harshly; cf. the use of kakh/n v. 10.

a)fi/ei: for the form, as from a verb in -e/w, see § 34 a; for the omission of the aug., see § 25 a. Homer is fond of using the impf. to describe an action as in progress (see § 3 j), cf. teu=xe v. 4.
kratero/n: strong, stern.
e)pi\ mu=qon e)/tellen: laid upon him his command.
e)pi/: const. with e)/tellen, §37 a, b.
mu=qon: had not yet received the idea of fiction which is contained in the Eng. myth. lo/gos is found but twice in Homer.
26-32. Agamemnon first rejects the admonition to fear the god and then refuses the request itself.
mh\ ktl.: see to it that I do not, let me not, etc. This prohibitive use of mh/ with the 1 pers. sing. is very rare.
kixei/w: kixw=, 2 aor. subjv. from kixa/nw, § 34 d.
au)=tis i)o/nta: returning, cf. pa/lin plagxqe/ntas v. 59, do/menai pa/lin v. 116.
mh/ nu/ toi ktl.: lest perhaps etc., adds to the preceding command the result that was to be feared if the command were disregarded, cf. *g 414, *w 568 f.
ou) xrai/smh|: ou) is used, not mh/, since the neg. and the verb form but one idea, be useless, of no avail; cf. v. 566, 3.289. — skh=ptron ktl.: “thy priestly dignity.”
pri/n: sooner, adv. with e)/peisin, as *s 283, g 117; with strengthening kai/ even, as *w 551, l 330; almost much rather. — For the animated adversative asyndeton, see § 2 m.
e)/peisin: shall come upon.
h(mete/rw|: the familiar our of the household.

e)n *)/argei+: i.e. in Peloponnesus (which name is not found in Homer), *)/argos *)axaiiko/n, not *pelasgiko\n *)/argos (Thessaly, 2.681), nor the city *)/argos where Diomed ruled (2.559). In *z 456, *)/argos seems to stand for all Greece, as *)argei=oi is interchangeable with *)axaioi/, cf. v. 79.
i(sto\n e)poixome/nhn: going to and fro before the loom, plying the loom; the Greek women stood as they wove at their upright looms. Weaving was the principal occupation of the female slaves.
le/xos: acc. of limit of motion, only here with a)ntia/w, approach, share the couch; cf. e)pei\ to\ so\n le/xos sunh=lqon Soph. Aj. 491.
i)/qi, e)re/qize: for the explanatory asyndeton, see § 2 m f.
saw/teros: more safely, sc. than if thou shouldst refuse to go. This independent use of the comp. is freq. in Homer.
w(s: in order that, here follows the emphatic word (§ 1 k); so o(/ti, o(/, u)/fra, and i(/na may have the second place in the clause; cf. 2.125. — For ke/ with the subjv., see G. 216, 1 N. 2; H. 882.
e)/deisen: “fear came upon him.” For the quantity of the antepenult, cf. vs. 406, 568, 3.418; see § 41 j b, l b. — o( ge/rwn: o( geraio/s v. 35.
bh=: set out, cf. 2.183. For the accent, cf. fh= *b 37; see § 25 b.
a)ke/wn: in terror at the harsh words. The fem. a)ke/ousa is found v. 565, but a)ke/wn is generally indeclinable.
polla/: earnestly, cognate acc. used as adv. with h)ra=to, see § 38 b, and on v. 78.
a)pa/neuqe kiw/n: i.e. as he left the Achaean camp.
to/n: rel. pron., see § 24 l.

f. a)rguro/toce: the use of the epith. instead of the name gives a touch of intimacy to the address, as glaukw=pi n 389 addressed to Athena by Odysseus; Athena addresses Apollo as e(ka/erge *h 34 (cf. v. 110). — The gods' instruments are of precious metal even where the metal is not best adapted to the work, cf. *e 724, 731, *w 341, and on v. 611.

*xru/shn, *ki/llan: Mysian cities, seats of the worship of Apollo, on the gulf of Adramyttium. They disappeared before the classical period. Cilla is mentioned also Hdt. i. 149. Chrysa was the home of the priest, who received his name from it.

a)mfibe/bhkas: “dost guard.” The figure is taken from a beast standing over its young to protect it, cf. *e 299, a)mfi\ d) a)/r) au)tw=| bai=n), w(/s tis peri\ po/rtaki mh/thr *r 4, w(s de\ ku/wn . . . peri\ skula/kessi (whelps) bebw=sa | … u(la/ei (barks) me/mone/n te ma/xesqai u 14 f. cf. Gradivumque patrem Geticis qui praesidet arvis Verg. Aen. iii. 35.
*tene/doio: cf. est in conspectu Tenedos, notissima fama
div2.l: insula, dives opum, Priami dum regna manebant Verg. Aen. ii. 21 f.
div2.p: a)na/sseis: in its original meaning, art protecting lord. basileu/w is not used of the gods in Homer.
*sminqeu=: *sminqeu/s is a short, familiar form (§ 21 e) for *sminqofqo/ros, epith. of Apollo as the averter of the plague of field mice.
ei)/ pote: if ever, a form of adjuration.
xari/enta: proleptic, to thy pleasure, lit. as a pleasing one.

e)pi\ e)/reya: roofed over, i.e. completed, built. The suppliant believes that he has made the god his debtor by his services, and he claims favors in return; cf. vs. 503 f., 8.238 ff., *o 372, d 763. The gods themselves recognized this obligation, *x 170, *w 68; in Od. 1.60 f. Athena reproaches Zeus for his neglect of Odysseus in spite of the latter's burnt offerings.
nho/n: Homer follows the so-called Attic second declension in but a few words, § 17 f.
dh/: nearly equiv. to h)/dh.
kata/: const. with e)/kha. — pi/ona: as covered with fat, cf. v. 460.

mhri/a: these and the synonymous mh=ra are the thigh pieces, with more or less flesh, as cut from the mhroi/ (v. 460) thighs of the victims, and sacrificed to the gods as burnt offerings. For the details of a sacrifice, see vs. 458 ff., 2.421 ff.

to/de moi ktl.: a formula, after which ‘this desire’ is expressed by the opt., as here; by the imv., as vs. 456, 505, 8.243; by w(s with the opt., as Od. 17.243; cf.
*zeu= pa/ter, ai)\ ga\r tou=to teleuth/seias e)e/ldwr:
w(s e)/lqoi me\n kei=nos a)nh/r, a)ga/goi de/ e( dai/mwn f 200 f.
krh/hnon: imv. from kraiai/nw.
ti/seian: the verb is placed first, as containing the sum of his desire.

*danaoi/: used only of the Greek army in the Trojan war. But in the Iliad the poet uses *)axaioi/ (the most frequently recurring designation of the Greeks), *)argei=oi or *danaoi/, to suit the convenience of his verse; see on v. 79, § 4 b.
bh=: set out; the motion is continued in o( d) h)/ie v. 47.

*ou)lu/mpoio: Olympus in Homer is always the Thessalian mountain as home of the gods (not heaven itself) as is indicated by its epiths., a)ga/nnifos v. 420 snow-capped, nifo/eis *s 616, makro/s v. 402, poludeira/s v. 499, polu/ptuxos *q 411; while ou)rano/s is a)stero/eis *d 44, eu)ru/s *g 364, me/gas *e 750, polu/xalkos *e 504, sidh/reos o 329, xa/lkeos *r 425. cf. on v. 195. But see
a)pe/bh glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh
*ou)lumpo/nd) o(/qi fasi\ qew=n e(/dos a)sfale\s ai)ei\
e)/mmenai. ou)/t) a)ne/moisi tina/ssetai … ou)/te xiw\n e)pipi/lnatai Od. 6.41 ff.
karh/nwn: const. with kata/. For its use for the summits of mountains, cf. *b 167, 869. — kh=r: acc. of specification, as h)=tor, qumo/n, fre/na, all freq. with verbs of emotion (§ 1 v).
w)/moisin: dat. of place, see § 3 d.

a)mfhrefe/a: i.e. closed both above and below as it hung on the shoulder, see on 2.389. The explanation of the lengthened ultima is uncertain. Apollo as god of the bow always carries bow and quiver, cf. his words su/nhqes a)ei\ tau=ta basta/zein e)moi/ Eur. Alc. 40; so he is represented in works of art.
e)/klagcan: seems to represent to the ear the sound of the bow and string, cf. li/gce bio/s *d 125. cf. tela sonant humeris Verg. Aen. iv. 149.
au)tou= kinhqe/ntos: au)tou= contrasts the god with his arrows (§§ 1 h, 24 g). For the gen. abs., see § 3 f.
nukti/: a time of dread, cf. e)/sqore fai/dimos *(/ektwr | nukti\ qoh= a)ta/lantos u(pw/pia *m 462 f., l 606, u 362, ‘He on his impious foes right onward drove,
div2.l: Gloomy as night’ Milton Par. Lost vi. 831 f. Comparisons are a notable characteristic of Homer's style. They are less frequent in this First Book of the Iliad than elsewhere. cf. v. 359, 2.87 ff., 146 ff., 337 ff., 394 ff., 455-483. See § 2 e ff.

div2.p: meta/: into the midst of the camp.
i)o/n: an arrow.
deinh/: attrib. with klaggh/. cf. horrendum stridens sagitta Verg. Aen. ix. 632.
ge/neto: arose, was heard, cf. a)/sbestos de\ boh\ ge/neto *l 50, *y 688.
bioi=o: from the bow, ablatival gen. (§ 3 d), cf. kapno\s | gi/gnetai e)c au)th=s *x 149 f.
ou)rh=as kai\ ku/nas: mules and dogs in the baggage train of the army.
e)pw/|xeto: attacked with his deadly missiles.
a)rgou/s: swift, cf. tw=n a)rxai/wn a)rgo\n to\ taxu\ prosagoreuo/ntwn Diod. iv. 42.
au)ta/r: stronger than de/, correl. with me/n v. 50. See on au)= *b 768, § 3 r.
au)toi=si: the Greeks themselves, contrasted with their domestic animals; more emphatic than brotoi=si.
be/los: for the quantity of the ultima, see § 41 m.
e)xepeuke/s: biting, sharp, cf. pikro\n o)isto/n *d 118.
e)fiei/s: iterative in meaning, like ba/lle following.
ba/lle: shot, with emphatic position at the close of a sent. and beginning of a verse; cf. vs. 143 f., 241, 296, 501, 506, 523, 526, Od. 9.196.
purai/: pl. since a new pyre was built each day.
neku/wn: so-called gen. of material. — This is a poetic form of the statement that multitudes perished from the pestilence.
Vs. 53-100. Assembly of the Greeks. Speeches of Achilles and Calchas.

e)nnh=mar: e)nne/a is a round number in Homer, as *z 174, *m 25, *w 107, 610, 664, 784, h 253, i 82, k 28, m 447, c 314. cf. ‘Nine times the space that measures day and night | To mortal men’ Milton Par. Lost i. 50.
w)/|xeto: the arrows are personified, cf. a)=lto d) o)isto\s | o)cubelh/s, kaq' o(/milon e)pipte/sqai meneai/nwn 4.125 f. eager to fly into the throng, *l 574, *f 70.

th=| deka/th|: the art. calls attention to this as the decisive day. The adj. agrees with h(me/rh| or h)oi= implied in e)nnh=mar. cf. the omission of xeiri/ v. 501, boulh/n *b 379, dora/n *g 16, xlai=nan *g 126, pule/wn *g 263; and the use of neut. adjs. as substs., see on v. 539.
de/: may stand after the second word in the clause since the first two words are so closely connected.

a)gorh/nde: The agora of the Achaeans was at the centre of their camp, a little removed from the sea, by the ships of Odysseus; cf. 8.222 f., with 11.806 f., 2.208. The a)gorh/ in Homer was not yet degraded to the name of market place, see § 2 v; it corresponds to the meeting place of the Athenian e)kklhsi/a.
kale/ssato: caused to be summoned, cf. 2.50. Other princes than the commander-in-chief had authority to call an assembly of the people.
tw=|: equiv. to Att. au)tw=|, lit. for him.
e)pi\ fresi\ qh=ke: put into (lit. upon) his heart, as 8.218. The Homeric Greeks did not think of the head as the seat of the intellect.
leukw/lenos: freq. epith. of Hera (§ 1 q), not often of women, as 3.121; cf. bow=pis v. 551.
r(a/: you see, with reference to the scene depicted in vs. 51 f.

o(ra=to: the act. and mid. forms, o(rw= and o(rw=mai, ei=don and i)do/mhn, i)/dw and i)/dwmai, are used in Homer without appreciable difference of meaning (§ 32 a); cf. vs. 203, 262, 587, *b 237, *g 163.

57 = *w 790, b 9, q 24, w 421. — h)/gerqen ktl.: the two verbs are thought to express the beginning and the completion of the act; but we may compare the ‘assemble and meet together’ of the Prayer Book. For the fulness of expression, see § 1 s.
h)/gerqen: aor. pass. from a)gei/rw. For the form, see § 26 v.
de/: for its use in the apodosis, see § 3 n; cf. vs. 137, 194, 280, 3.290.
a)nista/menos: The members of the assembly are seated (2.99), the speaker stands in their midst holding a staff (see on v. 15).
*)atrei+/dh: he addresses Agamemnon as chief in command.
nu=n: i.e. as things now are.
a)/mme: Aeolic form for h(ma=s (§ 24 a).
pa/lin plagxqe/ntas: driven back, i.e. unsuccessful, without having taken Ilios. cf. 2.132.
ei)/ ken fu/goimen: the opt. is used instead of the subjv., because escape is thought of only vaguely.
qa/nato/n ge: contrasted with a)ponosth/sein. “If indeed we may expect to return, and are not rather to die here.”
ei) dh/: if now, as seems likely.
dama=|: fut., see § 30 b.
a)/ge: has become a mere interjection, and is used with the pl., as *b 331, *g 441; but a)/gete also is used, as 2.72, 83.
ma/ntin: a soothsayer, augur, who foretold the future chiefly from the flight of birds.
e)/reiomen: let us ask; 2d aor. subjv., as if from e)/rhmi (§ 34 d).

i(erh=a: a priest of a definite divinity and sanctuary who predicted from the observation of sacrifices, cf. quosko/os x 318. Here some Trojan priest seems to be meant, since a priest could not desert the sanctuary of which he had charge, and so there were no priests in the Greek camp before Troy. The kings performed the sacrifices and offered prayers for the army; cf. 2.411 ff., 3.275 ff.
o)neiropo/lon: dream-seer. A dream-oracle is described by Vergil, Aen. vii. 86-91. — kai\ ga\r ktl.: for a dream also, as well as other signs.
ga/r te: closely connected, like namque.
e)k *dio/s: Zeus sends to Agamemnon (2.6) a dream that calls itself *dio\s a)/ggelos. Athena also sends a dream to Penelope (Od. 4.795).
o(/s k) ei)/poi: potential opt. in final sense, since the end aimed at is considered as a possible result of the principal action (e)rei/omen), cf. *h 342, *w 149.
o(/ti: wherefore.
to/sson e)xw/sato: conceived such heavy anger; inceptive aor.
to/sson: for the doubled s, see § 12 a.
*)apo/llwn: Achilles assumes that the pestilence was sent by the god of health and disease.
ei)/ te . . . ei)/ te: indir. questions explaining the previous verse, as Od. 3.90 f.; cf. 2.349.
o(/ ge: for the repetition of the subj., see on v. 97.

eu)xwlh=s, e(kato/mbhs: because of an unfulfilled vow or a hecatomb which has not been offered, cf. i(rw=n mhni/sas *e 178 angry on account of the omission of sacrifices, misqou= xwo/menoi, to\n u(posta\s ou)k e)te/lessen *f 457. — For the gen. of cause, cf. v. 429, *b 225, 689, 694, th=sd) a)pa/ths kote/wn *d 168. — Homer does not hold strictly to the original meaning of hecatomb, cf. v. 315; a hecatomb of 12 heifers is mentioned 6.93, 115, and one of rams in 4.102.
ai)/ ken ktl.: if perchance, in the hope that, he may please. H. 907.
a)rnw=n: part. gen.

telei/wn: constr. with both nouns. Only unblemished victims were well pleasing to the gods. Thus the heifers offered to Athena were ‘sleek, untouched by the goad, upon whose necks the yoke had never rested,’ *z 94, *k 293.
bou/letai: for the short modevowel in the subjv., see §27 a, c. — a)ntia/sas ktl.: to partake of the sacrifices and ward off from us (lit. for us, see § 3 g).
68 = 101, *b 76, *h 354, 365, b 224. — For such stereotyped verses, cf. vs. 73, 201; see § 1 w.
a)/ra: here refers to the partic., like ei)=ta in prose, as *b 310, a 441.
toi=si: dat. of interest, for them, see § 3 g; cf. vs. 247, 450, 571.

oi)wnopo/lwn: soothsayers, in a general sense, as oi)wno/s is used for omen. This expression is used of Priam's son Helenus, 6.76, and Calchas is qeopro/pos oi)wnisth/s *n 70. He was a warrior as well as a seer; see on 2.832.
o)/xa: used only as a strengthening prefix with forms of a)/ristos. e)/coxa pre-eminent is more common.

o(/s: long by position, since h)/|dh once began with vau, cf. 2.38; see § 41 q. — h)/|dh: for the Homeric forms of oi)=da, see § 34 k. — This verse describes the seer's power in its full extent, cf. novit namque omnia vates
div2.l: quae sint, quae fuerint, quae mox ventura trahantur Verg. Georg. iv. 392 f.; 3.109.
div2.p: pro/ t) e)o/nta: and which were before, i.e. past.
e)o/nta: forms of ei)mi/ in Homer regularly retain the e of the stem (§ 34 g).

h(gh/sato: he led the way, guided; here metaphorically of the seer who interpreted the portents relating to the voyage; cf. 2.322 f. So on the Argonautic expedition, the seer Mopsus gave the word for setting out. No expedition was complete without a soothsayer, even in the time of the Persian war, cf. Hdt. ix. 37.
*)/ilion ei)/sw: concludes the verse, as *r 159, 163, *s 58, 439, *w 145, t 182, 193.
*)/ilion: here like *troi/h, of the kingdom of Priam, not the city itself.
ei)/sw: only with verbs of motion; much like ei)s. It follows its acc.
h(/n: possessive pron., see § 24 a.
dia/: by the help of. For the thought, see on 2.832.
*)apo/llwn: the sun god, the god of physical and intellectual light, — the prophet of Zeus and the patron of prophecy; cf. *polufei/dea ma/ntin *)apo/llwn | qh=ke brotw=n o)/x) a)/riston o 252 f.
sfi/n: constr. with a)gorh/sato.
e)u\ frone/wn: fi/la frone/wn *d 219, a)gaqa\ frone/wn a 43.
a)gorh/sato: “took the floor.”
ke/leai/ me: Calchas as ma/ntis felt himself called to speak by the words of Achilles, v. 62.
dii/file: cf. a)rhi/filos *g 21; for the length of the antepenult, see § 18 a.
muqh/sasqai: interpret, as o)/rniqas gnw=nai kai\ e)nai/sima muqh/sasqai b 159.

toi/gar e)gw/n: always at the beginning of a verse. — e)re/w ktl.: *z 334, o 318, p 259, s 129, w 265, I will speak etc., solemn form of introduction; cf. ‘Behold now I have opened my mouth, my tongue hath spoken in my mouth’ Job xxxiii. 2.
h)= me/n [mh/n]: surely and truly, as *k 322, *c 275, *t 109.
pro/frwn: const. with a)rh/cein. It is always used predicatively, where the Eng. idiom would prefer an adv.; see § 38 a; pro/froni qumw=| and profrone/ws are used with the same general force.
e)/pesin kai\ xersi/n: equiv. to the prose lo/gw| kai\ e)/rgw| by word and deed; cf. v. 395.
a)rh/cein: for the fut. inf. after words of promising or hoping, cf. me/masan … | tei=xo/s te r(h/cein kai\ e)niprh/sein puri\ nh=as *m 197 f., e)ph=lqe perhse/menai memaw=sin *m 200.
a)/ndra: obj. of xolwse/men shall enrage.
me/ga: used adv. with krate/ei, cf. v. 103, pollo/n v. 91, polu/ v. 112; it strengthens all three degrees of comparison in Homer, cf. 2.274, 239, 480; see § 38 b.

kai/ oi(: for kai\ w(=|. The rel. const. is abandoned as often in later Greek; cf. vs. 3 f., 162, 506; see § 1 d, G. 156, H. 1005. The last half of the verse repeats the same thought in reverse order.

*)axaioi/: used here without distinction of meaning from *)argei/wn at the beginning of the verse, see on v. 42; cf. 3.226 f. *)argei=oi is never used at the close of a verse, while *)axaiw=n could not begin the verse.
ga/r: introduces a further explanation of his special need (cf. pro/frwn v. 77) of protection.
o(/te xw/setai: Att. o(/tan xw/shtai, whenever his wrath is roused. For the short mode vowel, see § 27 a. For the hypothetical rel. sent. without a)/n or ke/, cf. vs. 230, 543, 554, Od. 1.352.
xe/rhi: a subject, man of low degree; a positive to the comp. xerei/wn v. 114 (Att. xei/rwn).
ei)/ per ktl.: for even if, with the subjv., as h( d) ei)/ pe/r te tu/xh|si ma/la sxedo/n, ou) du/natai/ sfin | xraismei=n *l 116 f., 22.191 on v. 82.

xo/lon: a burst of anger, while ko/tos is the lasting grudge which plans for revenge, and the mh=nis of Achilles led him simply to withdraw from the fight (see on v. 1). xo/lon is emphasized in contrast with ko/ton by ge/ and by its chiastic position (§ 2 o).
katape/yh|: digest, suppress; cf. *)axileu\s . . . e)pi\ nhusi\ xo/lon qumalge/a pe/ssei *d 512 f.

a)lla/: after ei)/per, as Lat. at after si, yet; the apod. is really contrasted with the prot. (§ 3 n). The reciprocal relation of the thoughts is marked by the te/ . . . te/ (§ 3 o), cf. v. 218, 3.12, 33 f., to\n (sc. a hound) d) ei)/ pe/r te la/qh|si (sc. a fawn) katapth/cas u(po\ qa/mnw|,
div2.l: a)lla/ t) a)nixneu/wn qe/ei e)/mpedon *x 191 f.
div2.p: e)/xei: holds fast, cherishes.
o)/fra: temporal, until.
tele/ssh|: sc. ko/son, accomplishes his wrath, i.e. does what he plans in his wrath.
e)n sth/qessin: not capriciously, nor for the sake of the verse, separated from e)/xei ko/ton, but added with greater emphasis than it could have at the close of the verse.
fra/sai: aor. mid. imv., make clear to thyself, consider; fra/zw in Homer does not mean tell.
ei): whether.
84 = *i 307, 606, 643, *l 607, *t 145, 198, *f 222, *y 93, cf. v. 215, *s 187, *w 138. The first hemistich (with th/n occasionally for to/n) is used in Homer more than 100 times.
qa/rshsas: cf. v. 92.
ma/la: const. with the imv., as v. 173.

ou) ma/: no, in truth; ma/ is a par ticle of swearing with the acc., which prob. depends upon a verb implied. In affirmative asseverations vai\ ma/ is used, as v. 234. The neg. is repeated in v. 88 for greater earnestness, as 23.43 f., Od. 3.27 f.
dii/filon: only here as epith. of a divinity.
w(=| te eu)xo/menos: he prayed to Apollo as his patron, the god of prophecy who revealed to him what he declared to the Greeks.
*ka/lxan: voc. like *ai)=an *h 288.
qeopropi/as: a collateral form to qeopro/pion v. 85, see § 19.
a)nafai/neis: art wont to reveal, cf. fai=ne a)oidh/n q 499.

e)meu= zw=ntos: while I live; in a threatening tone. — e)pi\ xqoni\ ktl.: a poetic expression for zw=ntos, cf. o(ra=| fa/os h)eli/oio *s 61, e)pi\ xqoni\ si=ton e)/dontes q 222, vivus vidensque Terent. Eun. i. *i. 28. For the fulness of expression, see § 1 s; cf. vs. 57, 99, 160, 177, 288 f., 553, *g 71, *ce/rchs me\n au)to\s zh\ te kai\ ble/pei fa/os Aesch. Pers. 297, ‘as sure as I live and breathe.’
barei/as: heavy, i.e. violent.
xei=ras e)poi/sei: cf. xei=ras e)fei/w v. 567.
ou)d) h)/n: not even if, generally as here after a neg. “This promise will hold even if.”
*)agame/mnona: Calchas had indicated him clearly in vs. 78 f.
pollo/n: for its inflection, see § 20 f.; for its adv. use, cf. me/ga vs. 78, 103; polu/ v. 112.

a)/ristos: mightiest, as commander-in-chief of the army; cf. 2.82, 580, see on 2.108. — The Homeric heroes were always frank of speech; Achilles calls himself a)/ristos *)axaiw=n vs. 244, 412; Odysseus says that his fame reaches to the heavens, kai/ meu kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei i 20; Hector challenges the bravest of the Achaeans to fight *(/ekt<*> di/w| *h 75. cf. sum pius Aeneas fama super aethera notus Verg. Aen. i. 378 f. But the formula eu)/xomai ei)=nai often contains no idea of boasting, and may mean only claim to be, affirm himself to be.
kai\ to/te dh/: and so then (temporal).
qa/rshse: took courage, inceptive aor.; cf. vs. 331, 349, 517.
a)mu/mwn: refers generally to nobility of birth, or to beauty or strength of person.
93 = v. 65, with the change of ou)/te for ei)/te.
e(/nek) a)rhth=ros: const. with e)pime/mfetai. The prep. is used here, perhaps, because of the remoteness of the noun from the verb, but the poet was free.
ou)d) a)pe/luse ktl.: a more definite statement of h)ti/mhse, abandoning the rel. const., cf. v. 79. In later Greek, partics. would be expected, instead of the indic.
kai\ ou)k: is used, not ou)de/, since the neg. is construed closely with the verb; cf. on v. 28.
tou/nek) a)/ra: on this account then (as I said). This repeats emphatically v. 94, and adds a prediction of the results of the god's anger. — For the crasis, see § 8.

o(/ ge: emphatic repetition of the subj., cf. vs. 65, 496, polla\ d) o(/ g) e)n po/ntw| pa/qen a)/lgea a 4 which Vergil copied in multum ille et terris iactatus et alto Aen. i. 3. — *davaoi=sin ktl.: cf. v. 67.
a)pw/sei: metaphorically, of a heavy burden, cf. xersi\n a)pw/sasqai li/qon o)/brimon i 305.
pri/n: is found elsewhere as here in both principal and subordinate clauses, cf. 2.348, 354 f., ou)de/ tis e)/tlh | pri\n pie/ein, pri\n lei=yai (pour a libation) u(permene/i *kroni/wni *h 480 f.
a)po\ do/menai: cf. do/menai pa/lin v. 116. The subj. of the verb is easily supplied from *danaoi=sin.
e(likw/pida: quickeyed.
a)pria/thn a)na/poinon: for the asyndeton, see §2 l, cf. 2.325.
i(erh/n: standing epith. of the hecatomb, as vs. 431, 443.

i(lasso/menoi: for the manner of propitiation, cf.
streptoi\ de/ te kai\ qeoi\ au)toi/ …
kai\ me\n tou\s que/essi kai\ eu)xwlh=|s a)ganh=|sin
loibh=| te kni/sh| te paratrwpw=s) a)/nqrwpoi
lisso/menoi 9.497 ff.
pepi/qoimen: for the reduplication of the 2d aor., see § 25 j.
Vs. 101-187. Quarrel between Agamemnon and Achilles.
eu)ru\ krei/wn: standing epith. of the king, as vs. 355, 411, 3.178; see § 4 c; cf. 2.108. For the adv. use of eu)ru/, <*> ee on pollo/n v. 91.
me/neos: with rage, cf. me/neos d) e)m<*> h/sato (sc. Achilles) qumo/n *x 312.

a)mfime/lainai: darkened on all sides. The mind is dark with passion, which is thought of as a cloud enveloping the fre/nes. cf. *g 442, qa/rseus plh=se fre/nas a)mfimelai/nas *r 573, a)/xos pu/kase fre/nas ktl. *r 83, melagxi/twn frh/n Aesch. Pers. 117 black-robed heart, of a mind foreboding ill.
oi(=: dat. with the verb, instead of a limiting gen. with o)/sse, see § 3 g.
lampeto/wnti: in contrast with a)mfime/lainai. — cf. v. 200.
For the asyndeton, see § 2 l.f.
prw/tista: for the form, see on 2.228.
ka/k) o)sso/menos: looking evil, i.e. with look that boded ill; cf. o)/ssonto o)/leqron b 152, kako\n o)ssome/nh *w 172. For the accent of ka/k) (for kaka/) see § 10 d.

ma/nti kakw=n: ill-boding seer. Some of the ancients thought this referred to the seer's words at Aulis, where he showed that Artemis demanded the sacrifice of Agamemnon's daughter Iphigenia in return for an insolent word of the king (Soph. El. 566 ff.). — cf. ‘But I hate him; for he doth not prophesy good concerning me, but evil’ 1 Kings xxii. 8.
to\ krh/guon: equiv. to e)sqlo/n v. 108, in contrast with kakw=n. For the generic use of the art., cf. ta\ kaka/ v. 107, and see on ta\ xerei/ona v. 576.
ai)ei): he exaggerates in his anger. cf. soi\ d) ai)ei\ kradi/h sterewte/rh e)sti\ li/qoio y 103.
ta\ kaka/: subj. of the verb of which fi/la is pred.
manteu/esqai: explanatory inf., cf. e)/nqa fi/l) o)ptale/a kre/a e)/dmenai ktl. *d 345. — “Always is it pleasing to thee to prophesy calamity.”
te/lessas: brought to pass, cf. a(/ma mu=qos e)/hn tete/lesto de\ e)/rgon *t 242.
kai\nu=n: aspecial instance under ai)ei/ v. 107, cf. d 193, k 43.
e)n: in the presence of, before.
qeoprope/wn a)goreu/eis: as *b 322, b 184.
dh/: ironical, like the later dh=qen, scilicet; const. with tou=d) e(/neka, evidently on this account.
e(khbo/los: for the epith. used as a proper name, cf. v. 37.
teu/xei: see on e)/qhken v. 2.

e)gw/: Agamemnon speaks only of the rejection of the ransom, not of the slight offered to the priest; but gives prominence to the odious charge that he, their king, was the cause of the sufferings of the Danaï.
kou/rhs *xrushi/dos: gen. of price, cf. dw=k) ui(=os poinh\n (as a price for his son) *ganumh/deos *e 266, l 327. For the patronymic, see on v. 13.
e)pei/: introduces the explanation of ou)k e)/qelon was not inclined; cf. v. 156.
bou/lomai: contains the idea of choice, preference (sc. h)\ a)/poina de/xesqai), which is here strengthened by the adv. polu/ (acc. of extent). cf. v. 117.
au)th/n: the maiden herself, contrasted with the ransom. — To his accusation against Calchas, the king adds at once his own defence.
oi)/koi e)/xein: i.e. to retain in my possession, cf. oi)/koqen *h 364 from his own possessions, Od. 17.455.
kai/: even, constr. with *klutaimnh/strhs.
ga/r r(a: for, you see.

*klutaimnh/strhs: acc. to the later story, daughter of Tyndareüs and Leda, and thus half-sister of Helen. The ancient Greek on hearing these lines remembered well that Clytaemnestra proved unfaithful to Agamemnon, and slew him on his return to his home (Od. 11.411 ff.). She was herself slain by her son Orestes (Od. 3.306 ff.). The deaths of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra formed the theme of famous tragedies by the three greatest tragic poets of Greece, — the Agamemnon and Choëphoroe of Aeschylus, the Electra of Sophocles, and the Electra of Euripides.
probe/boula: with pres. signification, cf. dei/dia fear d 820, e)/olpa hope Od. 2.275.
oi)/ e(qen: for the hiatus, see §§ 9 f., 14. The neg. receives emphasis from its position.

ou) de/mas: not in build, prob. refers to her stature, as the Greeks always associated height and beauty, cf. *g 167, kalo/s te me/gas te *f 108, kalh=| te mega/lh| te kai\ a)glaa\ e)/rga i)dui/h| n 289, *tudeu\s mikro\s me\n e)/hn de/mas *e 801.
ou)de\ fuh/n: has reference to her fair proportions. — With these two qualities of her person are contrasted by asyndeton two mental characteristics, neither in mind nor in accomplishments.
kai\ w(/s: even thus, “altho' Chryseis is so beautiful and accomplished,” cf. 3.159.
do/menai pa/lin: restore, cf. a)podou=nai vs. 98, 134.
to/ g) a)/meinon: the copula is here omitted in a cond., as *g 402, *e 184.
For the asyndeton, see § 2 m.
bou/lomai h)/: see on v. 112. cf. *l 319, *r 331, *y 594, g 232.

au)ti/x) e(toima/sate: the unreasonableness of the demand provokes the quarrel with Achilles and elicits the epith. filokteanw/tate v. 122. — ge/ras ktl.: made more definite later, cf. vs. 138, 182 ff.
e)/w: for the form, see § 34 g.
ou)de\ e)/oiken: it is not even seemly, to say nothing of its unfairness.
o(/: like quod equiv. to o(/ti that; cf. gignw/skwn o(/ o<*>au)to\s u(pei/rexe xei=ras *)apo/llwn *e 43<*> *q 32, 140.
e)/rxetai a)/llh|: i.e. lea<*>s me. e)/rxetai is used of the imm<*>iate future, as *l 839, *c 301.
ki/diste: a<*>nding epith. of Agamemnon, cf. *b 434, *i 96, 163, 677, 697. The following epith. is contrasted bitterly with this.
pw=s ktl.: the question implies the absurdity of the proposition, cf. 4.26 where Hera asks Zeus pw=s e)qe/leis a(/lion (fruitless) qei=nai po/non h)d) a)te/leston;
ga/r: introduces the explanation of some gesture of surprise or vexation; its force may often be given by the excl. ‘what.’

cunh/ia ktl.: undisturbed treasures lying in abundance, from which the king could be recompensed easily for the loss of his prize. This again refers to Agamemnon's au)ti/ka v. 118. — Booty taken on their marauding expeditions was the common property of the army after the several prizes of honor (ge/ra, v. 185) had been selected for the chiefs, cf. vs. 368 f., e)k po/lios d) a)lo/xous kai\ kth/mata polla\ labo/ntes | dassa/meq) w(s mh/ ti/s moi a)tembo/menos ki/oi i)/shs i 41 f.; moi=ran kai\ ge/ras e)sqlo\n e)/xwn l 534 of Achilles's son returning from Troy, tw=n e)caireu/mhn menoeike/a (satisfying my heart), polla\ d) o)pi/ssw | la/gxanon c 232. These prizes were sometimes selected by the leaders themselves, as 9.129 f., 11.696 f., 704; but are often spoken of as the gift of the people, vs. 276, 369, 392, *l 627, *p 56, *s 444, h 10, i 160, 550 f. Doubtless they were distributed by the general, with the approval of the army. Thus, 9.367, Agamemnon is said by Achilles to have given Briseis to him.
ta/, ta/: strictly both are dems. (§§ 3 n f., 24 l), the second repeating the first, although the first may be translated as a rel.
ta\ me/n: the thought contrasted with this, is implied in vs. 127 ff.

poli/wn: cities near Troy, of which Achilles had sacked 12 with his fleet and 11 with a land force, 9.328 f. Homer mentions the sack of Lesbos 9.129, of Lyrnessus 2.690, of Pedasus Od. 3.92, of Scyrus 9.668, of Tenedos 11.625, of Thebe *z 415, *i 188. cf. Nestor's words, cu\n nhusi\n e)p) h)eroeide/a po/nton
div2.l: plazo/menoi kata\ lhi/d), o(/ph| a)/rceien *)axilleu/s g 105 f. . . . wandering for booty wherever Achilles led. The gen. depends upon the following prep. in composition.
div2.p: e)cepra/qomen: equiv. to e)cei/lomen pe/rsantes.
de/dastai: the tense marks that the matter has been settled and is not to be reconsidered.
laou/s: receives emphasis from its position, while the contrast lies in de/dastai and pali/lloga e)pagei/rein collect again what has been distributed.
pali/lloga: proleptic, “so as to be together.”
qew=|: in honor of the god, for the god's sake, dat. of interest; cf. *mene/laos w(=| dh\ to/nde plou=n e)stei/lamen Soph. Aj. 1045 Menelaus, for whose sake we undertook this voyage.
triplh=| tetraplh=| te: for the copulative conj., see § 3 s, and cf. *b 346, *g 363.
a)poti/somen: will recompense.
dw=|si. for the ending, see § 26 a.
po/lin *troi/hn: the Trojan city, the city of Troy. Cf. *troi/hs i(ero\n ptoli/eqron e)/persen (sacked) Od. 1.2.
e)utei/xeon: Poseidon built the walls (21.446).
mh\ dh/: with imv. as 5.218; with inf. used as imv., as 17.501; with subjv. used as imv., *e 684, *y 7.
dh\ ou(/tws: for the synizesis, cf. vs. 340, 540; see § 7 a.

kle/pte no/w|: have secret thoughts in mind, be deceitful, — an accusation most hateful to the outspoken Achilles (see 9.312 f.); cf. ei) mh\ tw=| xro/nw| kekle/mmeqa Soph. Ant. 681 if we have not been deceived etc., w(\s ou)k e)/sti *dio\s kle/yai no/on ou)/te parelqei=n Hes. Theog. 613. cf. Eng. steal and stealth.
me/: const. with both verbs.

h)= e)qe/leis ktl.: dost thou wish indeed that thou thyself shouldst have a prize of honor (referring to v. 126) while (lit. but) I etc. He replies to the charge of covetousness (v. 122) by the assertion that Achilles has a selfish end in view in urging him to give up Chryseis.
o)/fr) e)/xh|s: instead of the customary inf. or an obj. clause with o(/ti, cf. qumo\s e)pe/ssutai o)/fr) e)pamu/nw *z 361.
au)ta/r: for the use of the adversative conj., see § 3 q.
au)/tws: explained by deuo/menon, see § 24 h.
h(=sqai: with a partic. marks the continuance of a state, esp. where a person is given up to sadness or misfortune, cf. *b 255, o)duro/menos kai\ a)xeu/wn | h)=mai c 40 f.
a)/rsantes ktl.: suiting it to my mind, i.e. choosing one which will be satisfactory.

a)nta/cion: sc. *xrushi/dos. — The conclusion of the sent. is omitted (aposiopesis); it would be perhaps eu)= e)/xei, kalw=s a)\n e)/xoi. When two mutually exclusive cond. sents. stand side by side, the conclusion of the first may be omitted. 7.904 a.
e)gw\ de/: for de/ in apod., see on v. 58.
e(/lwmai: for the subjv. used almost like a fut., see § 3 b; cf. vs. 184, 324, 3.417.
teo/n: sc. ge/ras.

*ai)/antos: son of Telamon, from Salamis (2.557), the mightiest of all the Greeks except Achilles (2.768, and note). He is not to be confounded with the swiftfooted leader of the Locrians, Ajax son of Oïleus (2.527). Telamonian Ajax is always meant when no distinguishing epith. is used. F<*> committed suicide because the <*>ms of Achilles, after that hero's de<*>h, were given to Odysseus rather th<*> to him (Od. 11.543 ff.).

i)w/n: cf. i)w\n kl<*>i/hnde v. 185. Homer is fond of <*> partic. which completes the pict<*> but is not strictly necessary to the sense, as a)/gwn v. 311, e)lqw/n v. 401, e(lw/n v. 139, i)dw/n v. 537, i)w/n, labw/n *b 261, parasta/s *b 189, fe/rousa *g 425, a)mfie/pontes *b 525, eu)xo/menos *b 597. These partics. are commonly intr. in this use.

*)odush=os: the hero of the Odyssey, the wise Ithacan prince (2.636) by whose device of the wooden horse Ilios was captured (Od. 22.230). He is sent in charge of the expedition to restore Chryseis to her father, v. 311. He restrains the Achaeans from following a mad impulse to set out for home, 2.169 ff.; he chastises Thersites, 2.244 ff. His personal appearance as an orator is described, 3.191 ff. He is sent as an envoy to Achilles in the Ninth Book. He enters the Trojan camp as a spy, with Diomed, in the Tenth Book. He is the special favorite of Athene, see on 2.169. — Agamemnon expresses his sovereignty in an arbitrary way, declaring his absolute authority over the three mightiest princes of the army.
a)/cw e(lw/n: shall seize and lead away. The return to the principal thought (e(/lwmai) betrays the king's passionate excitement.
ken kexolw/setai: he will be angry, I think; the tone is sarcastic.
i(/kwmai: for the hypothetical rel. sent., see G. 233, H. 914 B.
tau=ta: i.e. what is to be my recompense.

metafraso/mesqa: meta/ afterwards is repeated more definitely in kai\ au)=tis. — Here the speaker adopts a more quiet tone (interrupted only by an echo of his anger, in v. 146) and enters into the details of the ship's equipment.
me/lainan: for the color of the ships, see on 2.637.
e)ru/ssomen: aor. subjv.
e)s de/: adv., as v. 309, see § 37 a; proleptic, “so that they shall be therein.”
qei/omen: cf. e)rei/omen v. 62.
a)/n: up, on board; adv. with bh/somen.
au)th/n: herself, as the person principally concerned.
bh/somen: 1st aor. from bai/nw, trans.; H. 500.
a)rxo/s: pred.
a)nh\r boulhfo/ros: in appos. with ei(=s tis.

*)idomeneu/s: leader of the Cretans (2.645), son of Deucalion, grandson of Minos, great-grandson of Zeus and Europa (13.450 ff.); highly esteemed by Agamemnon, see 2.405 and note. He was one of the older leaders, cf. mesaipo/lios *n 361 grizzled. He reached home in safety, after the war (Od. 3.191).
146 = 18.170, except h)e\ su/ for o)/rseo.
h(mi=n: dat. of interest.
e(ka/ergon: for similar epiths. of Apollo, see vs. 14, 75, 370, 385; § 4 c.
i(la/sseai: agrees in person with the nearest subj.
148 = *x 260, 344, *w 559. The first hemistich occurs 16 times elsewhere.
u(po/dra i)dw/n: Vergil's torva tuentem Aen. vi. 467.

e)pieime/ne: clothed with; of the two accs. which the verb governs in the act., one is retained in the pass., G. 197, N. 2; H. 724 a. cf. *ai)/antes qou=rin (impetuous) e)pieime/noi a)lkh/n *h 164, g 205. — kerdaleo/fron: cunning minded, as 4.339, referring to v. 146. Achilles thinks that the king wishes to send him to Chrysa in order to rob him in his absence of what he would lack the courage to take in his presence.
toi/, e)/pesin: dats. of the whole and part, cf. soi\ ga/r te ma/lista/ ge lao\s *)axaiw=n | pei/sontai mu/qoisi *y 156 f. See § 1 u, H. 625 c.
pro/frwn: see on v. 77.
pei/qhtai: deliberative subjv. in the 3d pers., as ti/ nu/ moi mh/kista ge/nhtai e 299 “what will become of me.” — For the alliteration of p, cf. v. 165; see § 2 a.
o(do/n: cognate acc. (G. 159, H. 715 b); journey of an embassy like that suggested for him in v. 146; cf. Od. 3.316, e)cesi/hn pollh\n o(do\n h)=lqen *)odusseu/s f 20.

ga/r: the reasons for the preceding question (which is equiv. to a neg. assertion) continue through v. 162. “Thou dost repay with base ingratitude us who are fighting not for our own cause but only for thee.”
e)gw/: sudden transition from the indef. ti\s of v. 150; cf. e)pei\ ou)/ tina dei/dimen e)/mphs,
div2.l: ou)/t) ou)=n *thle/maxon ma/la per polu/muqon e)o/nta b 199 f.

div2.p: deu=ro: const. with h)/luqon.
ai)/tioi/ ei)sin: are to blame for me, have done me wrong, cf. *g 164, a 348.
bou=s: fem., of the herds.
h)/lasan: drove off.

ou)de\ me/n: nor in truth, cf. v. 603. — This verse and the next indicate the common causes of war in the heroic period, as between the English and the Scotch in the time of the border troubles. cf. w(s o(po/t) *)hlei/oisi kai\ h(mi=n (Nestor and the Pylians) nei=kos e)tu/xqh | a)mfi\ bohlasi/h| *l 671 f.
*fqi/h|: the later Phthiotis (2.683), not the city, as is shown by the epith. e)ribw/laki. — bwtianei/rh|: cf. kourotro/fos as epith. of Ithaca, Od. 9.27.
polla\ metacu/: much lies between; explained by the following verse. metacu/ is found only here in Homer; elsewhere meshgu/ is used (§ 2 y).
skio/enta: full of shadows.
h)xh/essa: only here as epith. of the sea; for the other epiths., see § 1 p; cf. polufloi/sboio v. 34, 2.209.
me/ga: see on v. 78.
xai/rh|s: subjv. in a final sent. after the aor., as *b 206, *z 357 f.

timh/n: retribution, satisfaction, esp. the return of Helen and the treasures carried away by Paris; cf. *g 286, *e 552, c 70. — a)rnu/menoi: striving to gain, as a 5, *x 160. — kunw=pa: the dog was to the oriental the personification of shamelessness, cf. v. 225. Helen in self-reproach applies to herself the epith. kunw=pis, *g 180, d 145; cf. da=er e)mei=o (addressing Hector), kuno\s kakomhxa/nou o)kruoe/sshs *z 344. The highest impudence was indicated by kuna/muia *f 394 dog-fly. In the Odyssey, however, the dog seems to be in better favor. Argus, the old hunting dog of Odysseus, remembers his master during the twenty years of his absence, and alone recognizes him on his return, dying as he welcomes him to his home (Od. 17.291 ff.).
tw=n: neut., referring to the various details included in the preceding thought, vs. 158 f.
kai\ dh/: and now, nearly equiv. to kai\ h)/dh, as in Att.; cf. *b 135, kai\ dh\ e)/bh oi)ko/nde *d 180.
moi/: dat. of disadvantage with a)fairh/sesqai, as o( toi=sin a)fei/leto no/stimon h)=mar a 9 he took away from them the day of their return, cf. *glau/kw| *kroni/dhs fre/nas e)ce/leto *zeu/s *z 234.
ge/ras: see on v. 124.
au)to/s: of thine own will, arbitrarily, as v. 137.
w(=| e)/pi: for which. For the anastrophe of the accent, see § 37 c.
do/san de/: the rel. const. is abandoned, as v. 79.
ou) me\n [mh\n] ktl.: yet never have I, a present expression of past experience. This thought increases the unfairness of Agamemnon's present course.

soi/: i.e. like to thine, for tw=| sw=| ge/rai+, the person instead of the attribute being compared; cf. ko/mai (hair) xari/tessin o(moi=ai *r 51, o(moi=a noh/mata *phnelopei/h| b 121 thoughts like to Penelope. G. 186, N. 2; H. 773 b.
*trw/wn ptoli/eqron: a city of the Trojans, as 2.228; see on v. 125.
to\ me\n: the principal thought follows, v. 167. The Eng. idiom prefers the subord. const., “although my hands . . . yet”; see § 3 q.
to\ plei=on: the greater part.

to\ ge/ras: the art. is used almost as in Att., the usual gift of honor. — o)li/gon te ktl.: the thought is adversative, though the conjs. are copulative, cf. do/sis o)li/gh te fi/lh te z 208; see § 3 q. Cf. ‘an ill-favored thing, but mine own’ Shakspere As you like it v. 4. 60.

e)/rxomai e)/xwn: go off to my tent with, more picturesquely descriptive than e)/xw v. 163; cf. *b 71, w(s mh/ ti/s moi a)tembo/menos ki/oi i)/shs i 42. — e)pei/ ke ktl.: when I have fought myself weary. This gives renewed prominence to the thought of insufficiently recompensed effort.
nu=n de\ ktl.: contrast with his previous activity in battle.
i)/men: inf., see § 35 f.
ou)de/ soi: const. with a)fu/cein. For the elision, see § 10 a.
o)i/w: think, intend, as v. 296.
a)fu/cein: heap up, as a)mfi\ de\ fu/lla | h)fusa/mhn h 285 f.
feu=ge: odious expression for the return to his home which Achilles had announced, v. 169.
ma/la: by all means, cf. v. 85.
e)pe/ssutai: perf. from seu/omai. cf. 6.361, on v. 133.
e)moi/ ge: with self-assertion.
alloi: sc. ei)si/n.
me timh/sousi: will gain me honor, referring to v. 159.

mhti/eta: a standing epith. of Zeus, see § 1 q; cf. *dii\ mh=tin a)ta/lanton *b 169. For the ending, see § 16 b. — In this confidence is seen the poet's irony, when the later course of Zeus is remembered, which brought defeat and humiliation to Agamemnon.
e)/xqistos: most hateful; for its formation, see § 22 b.

diotrefe/wn: the royal power had its source in Zeus, the patron god of princes; cf. diogene/s v. 337, *b 173, law=n e)ssi\ a)/nac kai/ toi *zeu\s e)ggua/licen | skh=ptro/n t) h)de\ qe/mistas *i 98 f., e)k de\ *dio\s basilh=es Hes. Theog. 96. Kings are called qera/pontes *dio/s (Od. 11.255) as warriors are qera/pontes *)/arhos (2.110). Reverence for royal blood is expressed in deino\n (a dreadful thing) de\ ge/nos basilh/io/n e)stin | ktei/nein p 401.

fi/lh: the pred. adj. regularly agrees with the preceding noun, and the rest of the verse is in a sort of appos. with e)/ris. — po/lemoi/ te ktl.: in his anger, the king counts these the result of mere e)/ris.
The asyndeton here and below shows the speaker's excitement. — ei) ma/la ktl.: cf. vs. 280, 290.
kartero/s: refers to v. 165. — qeo/s pou ktl.: “it is not thy merit.”
su\n nhusi\ ktl.: Agamemnon returns to the thought of v. 173. The circumstantial fulness of the expression, as of v. 183, marks the complete separation of the two forces.

*murmido/nessin: cf. 2.684; dat. of advantage, see § 3 g. This word is made prominent since the thought is before the speaker's mind that Achilles, in the consciousness of his strength, desires to rule all the Achaeans, cf. vs. 287 ff.
se/qen kote/ontos: “thy anger,” cf. v. 160.
se/qen: for this form of the gen., see § 15 e.

w(s: just as; the corresponding thought of the apod. is found in e)gw\ ktl. v. 184. The interposed clause, th\n me\n ktl., has properly only the value of a subord. clause, though with the form of a principal sent., see § 3 q; cf. 8.269.
a)fairei=tai: here followed by two accs., as v. 275; cf. v. 161.
su\n nhi/ t) e)mh=|: with a ship of mine, cf. teo\n bwmo/n *q 238 an altar of thine.
*brishi/da: only her patronymic is used by Homer, see on v. 13. In the sack of Lyrnessus by Achilles, her husband and her three brothers had been slain. cf. 2.690 ff., 19.291 ff.
to\ so\n ge/ras: emphatic contrast, that prize of thine.
o(/sson: how much; acc. of extent where the Att. might have used o(/sw|, dat. of degree of difference, cf. on v. 78.
fe/rteros: as commander of the entire army and powerful king, cf. v. 281, 2.108.
a)/llos: i.e. every other.
i)=son: masc., with e)moi\ fa/sqai assert himself my equal, as 15.167.
fa/sqai: for the const., cf. the inf. after mi/shsen *r 272.
o(moiwqh/menai a)/nthn: liken himself to me, to my face, as Od. 3.120.
Vs. 188-222. Intervention of Athena.
a)/xos ge/neto: cf. kai/ sfin a)/xos kata\ qumo\n e)gi/gneto *n 86, *)atrei+/dhn d) a)/xos ei(=le *n 581.
e)n de/: within, adv., defined more exactly by the local sth/qessin.
oi(=: dat. of interest.
lasi/oisi: a shaggy breast was thought to indicate manliness and courage, cf. 2.743, 851 (and note), au)xe/na te stibaro\n kai\ sth/qea laxnh/enta (of Hephaestus) 18.415.
h)/: for h)/ . . . h)=e (v. 192) in double indir. question, see § 3 m.
tou\s me/n: the other princes, who were seated (see on v. 58) between him and Agamemnon (cf. v. 247).
a)nasth/seie: should rouse from their seats, and drive away, as he sprung at the king.

o( de/: anaphoric, repeating the last subject; almost equiv. to au)to\s de/. cf. e)gw\ de/ v. 184. This either makes prominent the identity of subject in a contrast of actions, or marks the progress of the action by calling renewed attention to the doer of the deed.
e)nari/zoi: the opt. represents the deliberative subjv. of direct discourse, cf. 3.317.
193 = *l 411, *r 106, *s 15, d 120, e 365, 424, cf. 10.507. — kata\ fre/na ktl.: in mind and heart.
e(/lketo: he was drawing; the act was interrupted (cf. v. 220).
h)=lqe de/: for de/ in apod., see on v. 58.
ou)rano/qen: but she returns *ou)lumpo/nde v. 221; the peaks of Olympus tower above the clouds into heaven, see on v. 44.
pro\ h(=ke: sent forth, i.e. sent hither, as 18.168, cf. v. 442. Athena often acts as subordinate to Hera; cf. *b 156, *e 713, *q 351. — Hera is patron goddess of the Atridae.

a)/mfw: obj. of file/ousa, to which khdome/nh is added in a freer relation; cf. *b 27, th\n au)tou= (sc. gunai=ka) file/ei kai\ kh/detai *i 342, ei) de\ kai\ *(/ektora/ per file/eis kai\ kh/deai au)tou= *h 204.
qumw=|: see on v. 24.
sth= d) o)/piqen: she stepped up behind.
canqh=s: epith. of Menelaus, as 3.284; of Meleager, 2.642; of Rhadamanthys, Od. 4.564; of Demeter, 5.500. The canqai\ tri/xes of Odysseus are mentioned Od. 13.399.
ko/mhs: gen. of the part touched. G. 171, H. 738.

oi)/w|: Homeric divinities appeared only to single persons; not to companies of men, except when disguised in human form; cf. d 367, p 161, where Athena is seen by Odysseus but not by Telemachus. Only to the people of the fairy-land Phaeacia were the gods wont to appear visibly, cf. Od. 7.201 ff. — tw=n d) a)/llwn ktl.: the thought of the first word of the verse is repeated in neg. form.
qa/mbhsen: at being thus seized.
meta\ d) e)tra/peto: since Athena stood behind him; literally, not as v. 160.
deinw/: pred.; they were the eyes of glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh (v. 206).
de/: for the use of the adversative instead of a causal conj., cf. vs. 228, 259; see § 3 q.
oi(=: for the dat. of interest, see § 3 g.

fa/anqen: for e)fae/nqhsan from faei/nw. For the ending, see § 26 v. — o)/sse as a neut. dual may have a verb in the pl. as here; or in the sing., as de/rketai u)/sse *y 477; or in the dual, as o)/sse | lampe/sqhn *o 607 f.
An often (not less than fifty times) repeated verse, see § 1 w.
mi/n: obj. of proshu/da.
fwnh/sas: lifted up his voice, cf. § 1 s; not equiv. to ei)pw/n, which in Homer is used only of what has just been related.
ptero/enta: for the final vowel here short though before two consonants, see § 41 i b.

ti/pt) au)=te: “What now! why art thou come?” au)=te is here not equiv. to au)=tis, and does not imply that she had been there before, but is uttered in a tone of vexation; cf. w)/ moi e)gw/, te/wn au)=te brotw=n e)s gai=an i(ka/nw; Od. 6.119 O woe is me, to the land of what mortals do I come now?
ti/pte ei)lh/louqas [e)lh/luqas]: for this greeting, cf. te/knon, ti/pte lipw\n po/lemon qrasu\n ei)lh/louqas; *z 254, e 87.
ai)gio/xoio . . . te/kos: ten times repeated in Homer, cf. § 1 q.

This verse contains several metrical peculiarities. For the hiatus after the first foot, see § 9 b; for that after i+\dh|, see § 9 c. — h)= i(/na ktl.: he answers the question himself by a conjecture, cf. *z 255, *h 26, *r 445.
h)=: generally expresses emotion in Homer; it is not yet the mere sign of a question (§ 3 m b).
i)/dh|: for the voice, see on v. 56.
kai/: also, const. with tele/esqai (fut.); “this will not be a mere prediction.”

u(peropli/h|si: for the long penult, see § 41 b; for the pl. (esp. in the dat., most freq. in the Odyssey), cf. proqumi/h|si *b 588, podwkei/h|si *b 792, a)nalkei/h|si *z 74, a)tasqali/h|sin a 7. — ta/xa ktl.: a covert hint at his murderous thoughts.
a)/n: const. with o)le/ssh| (§ 3 b).

glaukw=pis: gleaming-eyed, cf. deinw\ ktl. v. 200. The Homeric Athena is the fierce-eyed, courageous goddess of war; cf. tau=ta (sc. polemh/ia e)/rga) d) *)/arhi qow=| kai\ *)aqh/nh| pa/nta melh/sei *e 430. Her name is coupled with that of Ares also 13.127 ff. Her epith. *palla/s belongs to her as wielding the lance (cf. pa/llein *p 142). She became *)aqhna= *ni/kh and *)aqhna= *promaxos at Athens.
h)=lqon: not equiv. to the perf. ei)lh/louqa, but presenting the same act from a different point of view.
pau/sousa: to cease, to allay, cf. v. 192.
to\ so\n me/nos: this thy rage, this rage of thine; cf. fqi/sei se to\ so\n me/nos *z 407. — ai)/ ke ktl.: see on v. 66.
e)/ridos: i.e. the contest of force to which he is inclined.
e(/lkeo: pres. imv., continue to draw; cf. v. 194.
a)ll) h)= toi: after a neg. idea emphasizes the affirmative thought.
w(s e)/setai: “as opportunity shall offer.”
212 = *q 401, *y 672, t 487, f 337; cf. *b 257, b 187, r 229, s 82, *q 454, *y 410, p 440. A set verse, often with a sharp threat.
tetelesme/non e)/stai: will be a thing accomplished, i.e. shall surely be done.

kai/ pote ktl.: affords the motive for v. 210, and recalls Achilles from his decision to return to his home. “Thou hast no need to wreak bloody vengeance on him, for thou shalt at some time receive etc.
kai\ tri/s: even threefold, proverbial; cf. tri\s to/sson e(/len me/nos *e 136, tri\s to/sa doi=en a)/poina *w 686.

pare/ssetai: the gifts offered to Achilles as an atonement for the wrong are enumerated 9.121 ff. (seven tripods, ten talents of gold, twenty caldrons, twelve racehorses, seven slaves etc.), in a passage closing tau=ta me\n au)ti/ka pa/nta pare/ssetai *i 135. These treasures were delivered 19.243 ff.
i)/sxeo: check thyself, as 2.247.
h(mi=n: not enclitic (h(/min) since it is contrasted with his anger.
me/n: indeed.
sfwi/teron: of you two, Athena and Hera. The emphasis given by ge/ marks the reverence felt for these goddesses.
e)/pos: word, command.
ei)ru/ssasqai: protect, observe, by obedience, as 21.230.
kai\ ktl.: “however much enraged.”
o(/s ke ktl.: i.e. if any one. “Whoever obeys the gods is himself heard by them.” cf. e)a/n tis qeosebh\s h)=| kai\ to\ qe/lhma au)tou= poih=|, tou/tou a)kou/ei (sc. d qeo/s) St. John ix. 31.
ma/la: surely, readily.
te/: for its use in marking the reciprocity of the two clauses, cf. § 3 o; see on v. 82.
e)/kluon: gnomic aor. G. 205; H. 840.
au)tou=: himself. The prominence given to the obj. of the verb which is also the subj. of the previous clause, makes prominent the identity of the two, and contrasts the man with qeoi=s.
h)= kai/: he spake and, as v. 518, 3.292, 310, 355, 369, 447; always used after a speech which is reported, where the same subj. is continued.
a)ogure/h|: adorned with silver nails or studs, see on 2.45.
sxe/qe: kept, held, as *d 113, *h 277.
ou)d) a)pi/qhsen: litotes, see § 2 g; cf. v. 536 f., 2.166, 807.

*)aqhnai/hs: *)aqhnai/h is to *)aqh/nh as a)nagkai/h and gai=a to a)na/gkh and gh=. In early Att. inscriptions, the name appears as *)aqhnai/a, from which the later forms *)aqhna/a and *)aqhna= are derived.
bebh/kein: had set out, was gone; plpf. t<*>ark her immediate departure. For the n of the ending, see §§ 13 n, 26 e.
meta/: into the midst of, among, as v. 423, 3.264.

dai/monas a)/llous: these assembled daily in the palace of Zeus as nobles in the hall of their feudal lord; cf. oi( de\ qeoi\ pa\r *zhni\ kaqh/menoi h)goro/wnto | xruse/w| e)n dape/dw| *d 1 f., oi( de\ dh\ a)/lloi (sc. qeoi/ | *zhno\s e)ni\ mega/roisin *)olumpi/ou a(qro/oi h)=san a 26 f. All were members of his family although they had separate mansions (v. 607). — Homer does not distinguish between dai/mones and qeoi/, but see on 3.420.
Vs. 223-305. Renewal of the quarrel. Nestor endeavors to calm the angry princes.
223-246. Speech of Achilles.
e)cau=tis: anew, after the interruption by Athene which no one had noticed.

oi)nobare/s: cf. oi)/nw| bebarho/tes g 139. This was a grievous reproach in the eyes of the temperate Greek<*>, cf. oi)=no/s se trw/ei melihdh/s, d(/s te kai\ a)/llous | bla/ptei, o(\s a)/n min xando\n (greedily) e(/lh| mhd) ai)/sima pi/nh| f 293 f.
kuno\s o)/mmata: see on v. 159.

e)la/foio: the deer was the personification of cowardice; cf. *d 243, fuzakinh=|s (timid) e)la/foisin e)oi/kesan *n 102; *f 29, *x 1. The poet shows in his story that these epiths. were undeserved by Agamemnon; cf. *h 162, 180, *q 261, *l 91 ff.
e)s po/lemon: for (lit. into) battle; for the lengthened ultima before the caesura, as v. 491, see § 41 p. — The last three feet of the verse are spondees, cf. 2.190.

lo/xonde: cf. e)s lo/xqn e)/nqa ma/list) a)reth\ diaei/detai a)ndrw=n *n 277 where especially the valor of men is discerned. The knights of the Middle Ages were the first to count ambush dishonorable.
a)risth/essin: mark the contrast with law=|.
te/tlhkas: hast had the courage; cf. v. 543.
kh/r: cf. 3.454, ‘'Tis death to me to be at enmity,’ Shakspere Rich. III. ii. 9.60.
h)=: in truth, yes: the speaker pretends to recognize his opponent's motives.
a)poairei=sqai: pres. inf. in iterative sense; the following clause supplies its obj. For the hiatus between the prep. and the verb, see on v. 333.
se/qen: gen. after the adv.
a)nti/on ei)/ph|: oppose.
dhmobo/ros ktl.: emphatic excl. of vexation. cf. dhmofa/gon tu/rannon Theognis 1181. — e)pei\ ktl.: this does <*>he reason for the excl., but <*>why Agamemnon's course is <*>cf. on v. 112.
ou)tidanoi=- <*>terpreted by Achilles vs. 293 f. <*>ds the Greeks in part respon<*>nce they did not oppose the <*>
<*>2.242. — h)= ga\r ktl.: for else, <*>with aor. opt. as potential of <*>where in Att. we should ex<*>st tense of the ind. with a)/n, <*>see § 3 c e; G. 222 N. 3; H.
cf. *i 132, u 229. — e)pi\ o)mou=mai the contrary is a)po/mnumi, cf. grh=us de\ qew=n me/gan o(/rkon a)pw/mnu b 377.

to/de skh=ptron: by this sceptre here, which he had just received from a herald; see on v. 15. For oaths by this symbol of power, see w(\s ei)pw\n to\ skh=ptron a)ne/sxeqe pa=si qeoi=sin *h 412, o( d) e)n xersi\ skh=ptron la/be kai/ oi( o)/mossen *k 328. So King Richard swears ‘Now, by my sceptre's awe, I make a vow’ Shakspere Rich. II. i. I. 118.

to\ me/n: anaphoric. dem. — “As surely as this staff shall never put forth leaves, so surely shall the Achaeans miss me sorely.” This is imitated by Vergil (Aen. xii. 206 ff.), ut sceptrum hoc . . . nunquam fronde levi fundet virgulta nec umbras,
div2.l: cum semel in silvis, imo de stirpe recisum,
matre caret, posuitque comas et brachia ferro;

div2.p: e)pei\ dh\ prw=ta: see on v. 6.
ga/r r(a: see on v. 113.
e(/: the living shoot, while mi/n below is the skh=ptron made from it.
xalko/s: i.e. the tool of bronze; cf. the Eng. poetic use of steel for sword. See on 2.417.
fu/lla ktl.: e)/leyen as a ‘verb of depriving’ is followed by an acc. of the thing taken away.
nu=n au)=te: now on the other hand, but now; au)=te in this use differs little from au)ta/r, cf. *d 321, *x 172; see on 2.768.
dikaspo/loi: appos., as guardians of justice, cf. oi( de\ ge/rontes . . . i(erw=| e)ni\ ku/klw| | skh=ptra de\ khru/kwn e)n xe/rs) e)/xon *s 503 ff.; for its position, see §1 h, cf. v. 10.
pro\s *dio/s: under the direction of Zeus, in the name of Zeus, cf. pro\s a)/llhs i(sto\n u(fai/nois *z 456.
ei)ru/atai: defend, cf. v. 216, (*)/ektwr) ei)/ruto de\ a)/stu kai\ au)tou/s *w 499.
o( de/: attracted to the gender of o(/rkos, cf. 2.5, 73.
h)=: repeats the nai/ of v. 234; cf. on v. 86.

*)axillh=os: instead of e)mou=, with feeling; cf. *b 259, *g 99, and Hector's challenge to the bravest Greek to fight *(/ektori di/w| *h 75, *p 833. Edmund says ‘Yet Edmund was beloved’ Shakspere King Lear v. 3. 239; Antonio says ‘Tell her the process of Antonio's end’ id. Merchant of Venice iv. 9.274.
su/mpantas: for the prominence of its position, see on v. 52.
xraismei=n: avail, help; without oblique case, as v. 589.

u(f) *(/ektoros qnh/skontes: u(po/ is used since the verb is passive in sense, and act. only in form, cf. 3.61, 128; see H. 820. — For the epith. of Hector, cf. homicidam Hectorem Hor. Epod. xvii. 12.
pi/ptwsi: for the subjv., cf. i(/kwmai v. 139.
e)/ndoqi: “in thy breast.”
xwo/menos: full of rage (sc. at thyself).
o(/ te: o(/ti te, that; cf. o(/ vs. 120, 412.
ou)de/n: acc. of specification instead of the simple ou).
a)/riston: strictly true, see v. 2<*> and note. See on di=os v. 7.
poti\ . . . gai/h|: as Od. 2.80<*> a sign of anger.
poti/: ad<*> ba/le. It is followed by the <*> cause of the state of rest that<*> the action. See on 2.175.
peparme/non: studded,<*> ration. The same expression<*> of Nestor's great goblet, 11.63<*>
247-284. Speech of Ne<*> endeavors to reconcile the hero<*>
e(te/rwqen: see on<*> e)mh/nie: w<*> raging, continued his rage; see on v. 1.
toi=si: for the dat., see on v. 68.

*ne/stwr: the oldest and wisest of the Achaeans before Troy. He often gives good advice, as 2.76 ff., 336 ff., 6.66 ff., 7.324 ff., 9.94 ff. He was the most skilled of the Greeks in marshalling the army for battle, cf. *b 555, *d 297 ff. He is fond of relating his exploits, as his defeat of Ereuthalion 4.318 ff., 7.132 ff. He tells a long story of his first battle against the Eleans, 11.670 ff. The Third Book of the Odyssey is devoted to the visit of Telemachus, Odysseus's son, to Nestor, at his home in Pylos. — For his interposition here, cf. Nestor conponere lites
div2.l: inter Peliden festinat et inter Atriden:
hunc amor, ira quidem communiter urit utrumque.
quidquid delirant reges, plectuntur Achivi Hor. Epist. i. 2. 11 ff.

div2.p: *puli/wn: see on *b 591. — a)gorhth/s: equiv. to Att. r(h/twr. a)gorh/ in Homer is used only of an assembly and its place of meeting (§ 2 v).
tou=: rel., limiting glw/sshs.

kai/: also, belongs to the whole sent., referring to h(dueph/s which is explained by the comparison; cf. v. 406, 2.827, 866, 872. — For the comparison, cf. [xo/los] polu\ gluki/wn me/litos kataleibome/noio *s 109. — Cicero translates, ex eius lingua melle dulcior fluebat oratio de Sen. 10; cf. Homerici senis mella tibi profluere Pliny Ep. iv. 3, glukerh/ oi( a)po\ sto/matos r(e/ei au)dh/ Hes. Theog. 97.
tw=|: for the dat. of interest with e)fqi/ato, cf. 2.295; see § 3 g.

geneai/: generations, reckoned as of about 30 years each. Since Nestor was now in the middle of the third generation, he is to be thought of as about ‘three score and ten’ years old. cf. ter aevo functus senex Hor. Carm. ii. 9. In Od. 3.245, ten years after this scene, he is said to have reigned tri\s ge/ne) a)ndrw=n. — mero/pwn ktl.: cf. 3.402.
e)fqi/ato: e)fqime/nai h)=san, § 26 t.
oi(/: const. according to sense, referring to a)nqrw/pwn rather than to geneai/.
oi(=: dat. of accompaniment with a(/ma. — tra/fen ktl.: for the ‘hysteron proteron,’ see § 2 u. The more important or obvious element is mentioned first. For the form, see on v. 273.
meta/: cf. su\ met) *)argei/oisin a)na/sseis *c 94. — trita/toisin: i.e. of the third generation.
254 = *h 124. — *)axaii/da gai=an: i.e. the Achaeans. For the acc. of limit of motion, see § 3 i, G. 162, H. 722.
The thought of the preceding verse is repeated in different form; hence the lack of connective, see § 2 m.
ghqh/sai: sing. to agree with the nearest subj.; contrasted with pe/nqos i(ka/nei. The aor. is inceptive; G. 200, 13.5 b; H. 841. — For the chiastic arrangement of verbs and their subjs., see § 2 o.
*pri/amos . . . pai=des: as *g 288, *d 31, w)mo\n (raw) bebrw/qois (sc. Hera) *pri/amon *pria/moio/ te pai=das *d 35; cf. *au)to/luko/s te kai\ ui(e/es *au)tolu/koio t 414.

sfw=in marname/noiin: de vobis rixantibus, gen. after puqoi/ato, cf. ou)de\ pe/pusto . . . ui(=os e(oi=o peso/ntos *n 522 f. nor had he learned that his son had fallen, *r 379, 427, ou)d) ei)/ ken tou= patro\s a)pofqime/noio puqoi/mhn *t 322, 337. The partic. is supplementary.
ta/de: dir. obj. of the verb, cf. o(/ssa peu/qomai g 186 f., e)ph\n e)u\ pa/nta pu/qhai d 494.
peri\ me/n, peri\ de/: const. with e)ste/, superior to; with the gen., as v. 287, cf. Od. 1.66.
boulh/n: as to counsel, in council.

ma/xesqai: in battle, like ma/xhn. So eu)=xos a)re/sqai *h 203 is parallel with ni/khn, cf. [a)mei/nwn] h)me\n po/das h)de\ ma/xesqai *o 642, e)lafro/tatoi qei/ein kai\ ka/rtos a)/ristoi g 370. — For the thought, cf. *g 179, *tudei+/dh, peri\ me\n pole/mw| e)/ni kartero/s e)ssi,
div2.l: kai\ boulh=| . . . e)/pleu a)/ristos *i 53 f. “First in war and first in peace,” vs. 490 f., 2.202, 273.

div2.p: de/: see on v. 200.

h)e/ per u(mi=n: i.e. h)e/ per u(mei=s e)ste/. The pron. is attracted to the case of a)rei/osin, cf. oi(=on ktl. v. 263 for oi(=os *peiri/qoos h)=n. — Nestor here reckons himself with the former generations, in praising the past in contrast with the present.
kai\ ou)/ pote: the contrast might have been marked by a)lla/, but is only implied in the context.
oi(/ ge: emphasized with reference to a)rei/osin.
ga/r: refers to a)rei/osin v. 260.
i)/dwmai: for the subjv. as fut., cf. 2.488; see § 3 b, G. 213, 2 R.; H. 868. For the mid. voice, see on v. 56.

f. *peiri/qoon . . . *polu/fhmon: Lapithae, a Thessalian mountain-folk famed for its conflict with the centaurs. This strife began at the wedding feast of Peirithous (a friend of Theseus) because of the insolence of the intoxicated centaurs; cf. 2.741 ff., Od. 21.295 ff. The battle furnished subjects for the sculptures in the west pediment of the temple of Zeus at Olympia, for the metopes on the south side of the Parthenon at Athens, for the frieze of the temple of Apollo at Phigalia, and for the frieze of the tomb of Mausolus (the Mausoleum) at Halicarnassus, as well as for vases and other works of art.
265 = Hesiod Shield 182. — Theseus, king of Athens, was the most famous ally of the Lapithae.
e)piei/kelon: the hiatus between the prep. and the adj. is only apparent, see i)/kelos § 14 a.

ka/rtistoi: pred. “these were the mightiest ever born on earth”; cf. *b 216, 673, karti/sthn dh\ th/n ge ma/xhn fa/to du/menai a)ndrw=n *z 185 “he said that this was the hardest fight he ever had,” tou= dh\ kalli/stous i(/ppous i)/don *k 436 “his horses were the most beautiful I ever saw,” *h 155, l 309, 421, m 258. — For the repetition of ka/rtistoi, cf. that of pei/qesqai, vs. 273 f.; see § 2 p.
dh/: doubtless, strengthens the superlative, as often.
me/n: without corresponding de/, as v. 269 and freq. In such cases, it is equiv. to mh/n.

fhrsi/n: cf. fh=ras *b 743. fh/r is the Thessalian form of qh/r (cf. fera); it is used by Homer only of the centaurs, whose homes were in Thessaly. The centaurs are not described by Homer, but their dual nature (half man, half horse) seems to have been not yet developed in the story.
a)po/lessan: a)pw/lesan.
kai/: even; const. with toi=sin. The new thought is introduced by kai/ also vs. 271, 273, with increasing emphasis. — The thought returns to v. 261.
toi=sin: the Lapithae. The dat. is governed by meta/ in composition; see on poli/wn v. 125.
e)c a)pi/hs gai/hs: from a distant land, explaining thlo/qen.
a)pi/hs: cf. 3.49.

kale/santo: called to their aid, cf. au)toi\ ga/r sfeas (Locrians and Phocians) oi( *(/ellhnes (at Thermopylae) e)pekale/santo Hdt. vii. 203. — Nestor relates other achievements of his youth and strength, 4.318 f., 7.133 ff., 11.670 ff., 23.629 ff.
kat) e)/m) au)to/n: by myself alone, i.e. as a single champion; cf. kata\ sfe/as *b 366. e)mauto/n is not found in Homer as a single word (§ 24 c).
kei/noisin: the centaurs.
oi(\ nu=n ktl.: who now live as mortals upon the earth.
e)pixqo/nioi: equiv. to e)pi\ xqoni\ o)/ntes. H. 588. cf. a)ne/res . . . e)pi\ xqoni\ si=ton e)/dontes i 89.
maxe/oito: pres. opt. from maxe/omai, a collateral form of ma/xomai, cf. ai)dei=sqai v. 23 with ai)dome/nw v. 331.
cu/nien: cuni/esan, cf. tra/fen v. 251 for e)tra/fhsan, §§ 26 w, 34 e. — Note the parallelism of the two halves of the verse, cf. v. 79.
a)gaqo/s per e)w/n: as v. 131.
a)poai/reo [a)fairou=]: syncopated from a)poaire/eo, § 29 h. It is followed by two accs., as v. 182.
e)/a: sc. kou/rhn.
w(s prw=ta: as once, cf. v. 6.
do/san: Att. e)/dwkan. See on v. 124.
mh/te qe/le: noli, cf. *b 247, mhde\ qeoi=sin | i)=s) e)/qele frone/ein *e 440 f., 7.111.
basilh=i: used esp. of Agamemnon, as v. 9.
a)ntibi/hn: originally cognate acc., sc. e)/rida, cf. 3.435; the adv. receives emphasis from its position.
ou)/ poq) o(moi/hs: i.e. a greater. The Greek idiom leaves to the connection the determination of the exact meaning. cf. post mihi non simili poena commissa luetis Verg. Aen. i. 136.
e)/mmore: has share of, has received.
w(=| te *zeu\s ktl.: see on v. 176.

ei): not cond. in thought here, cf. ei) to/te kou=ros e)/a, nu=n au)=te/ me gh=ras o)pa/cei *d 321. — kartero/s: as v. 178. — qea\ de\ ktl.: second clause of the protasis, explaining the first “being son of a goddess.”
qea/: Thetis, cf. vs. 351 ff.
a)lla/: for its use in the apod., see on v. 82.
fe/rteros: more powerful.
pleo/nessin: see 2.108, 576 ff.

*)atrei+/dh, su\ de/: the voc. often precedes the pron.; it has no const. in the sent. and thus cannot be followed immediately by de/. cf. *b 344, *(/ektor, a)ta\r su/ moi/ e)ssi path\r kai\ po/tnia mh/thr *z 429, a)/tta, su\ d) e)/rxeo qa=sson p 130.
pau=e: cf. vs. 192, 207.
au)ta\r e)gw/ ge: “And I also on my part beg thee.”

li/ssomai: sc. de/. — *)axillh=i: for the dat. of opposition, cf. *q 449, *n 517, *c 50. For the long i of the dat. sing., see § 18 a. This may be explained also as before the caesural pause (§ 41 p). The name is used with special emphasis, cf. v. 240, instead of the pron. (vs. 275, 281).
meqe/men: meqei=nai, § 34 e; cf. meqh/mwn *b 241. — o(\s me/ga ktl.: gives the motive for the request.
e(/rkos pole/moio: as 4.299, cf. e(/rkos a)ko/ntwn *d 137, e(/rkos bele/wn *e 316; for the ablatival gen., see § 3 d. With another use of the gen., Ajax is called e(/rkos *)axaiw=n *g 229.
pa/nta: is not to be urged in meaning; it refers esp. to v. 284. Agamemnon admits no fault on his part but throws all the blame on Achilles, cf. a)lla/ below.
peri\ pa/ntwn: see on v. 258.
For the asyndeton, see § 2 m; this verse repeats the thought of the foregoing, in a different form. The speaker's passion is shown by the accumulation of synonymous expressions, § 1 s.
a(/: in which, acc. of specification.
tina/: some one, esp. Agamemnon himself.
pei/sesqai: from pei/qw.
ai)xmhth/n: pregnant, for kratero\s ai)xmhth/s *g 179.
e)/qesan: equiv. to Att. e)poi/hsan, see on e)/qhken v. 2.
ai)e\n e)o/ntes: cf. qew=n ai)eigeneta/wn *b 400.
proqe/ousin: a form not found elsewhere from the stem qe-, for protiqe/asin, i.e. commission him, allow him. The word seems chosen here with reference to e)/qesan.
u(poblh/dhn: interrupting, cf. u(bba/llein *t 80.
h)= ga/r: he gives at once the reason for his course.

kaleoi/mhn: should be called, i.e. should be; cf. *b 260, *g 138, ai)\ ga\r e)moi\ toio/sde po/sis keklhme/nos ei)/h z 244 would that such a man might be (called) my husband, e)mh\ gunh\ mo/nh keklh/sei Eur. Alc. 329 f. thou alone shalt be (called) my wife.
