From Agamemnon's complaint, vs. 287 ff., Achilles infers that he is expected to obey in everything (pa=n e)/rgon).
ei) dh/: “in case that I actually.”
pa=n e)/rgon: only here before the formula o(/tti ken ei)/ph|s (cf. *b 361, *e 421, a 158, 389, b 25, 161, 229).
u(pei/comai: the form of the cond. is changed, and the fut. ind. is used in the protasis instead of the opt. with a)/n.
dh/: const. with the imv., as v. 131.
tau=ta: pa=n e)/rgon u(pei/kesqai.
mh\ ga\r e)moi/: in contrast with a)/lloisin.
ou): const with e)/ti, as in prose they are united, ou)ke/ti, § 37 b g.
o)i/w: with the fut. inf., as v. 170. — This verse is parallel with v. 289.

297 = *d 39, *e 259, *i 611, *p 444, 851, *f 94, l 454, p 281, 299, r 548, t 236, 495, 570. — Used when the speaker changes the subject in the middle of his speech; it is followed by the new thought without a conj. — cf. accipite ergo animis atque haec mea figite dicta Verg. Aen. iii. 250.
me/n: correl. with de/ v. 300; the contrast is changed from that between action and heart, to one between kou/rhs and tw=n a)/llwn.
kou/rhs: would have the art. in prose.
a)fe/lesqe: the aor. assumes that Agamemnon's threat has been executed, and the 2d pers. holds the Achaeans responsible because of their acquiescence (cf. v. 231).
do/ntes: ye who gave; cf. Achilles's words, ge/ras de/ moi o(/s per e)/dwken | au)to\s e)fubri/zwn e(leto krei/wn *)agame/mnwn *i 367 f.
qoh=|: for such standing epiths., see § 1 p.
para\ nhi/: i.e. in my tent, cf. v. 329. — For the position of the adjs., see § 1 m.
tw=n: anaphoric, repeating tw=n a)/llwn.
ou)k a)/n ti fe/rois: the opt. with a)/n and a neg. often expresses a confident expectation, and sometimes approaches a threat, as here, 9.375 f., Od. 22.325.
fe/rois a)nelw/n: cf. a)/cw e(lw/n v. 139.
ei): retains its original force as an interjection; “up then, come.”
a)/ge: see on v. 62.
gnw/wsi: shall recognize it, perceive it, referring to the following verse; cf. vs. 185, 333. For the form, see § 34 d.
303 = Od. 16.441. — The preceding pei/rhsai represents a prot. to which this would be the apod.; cf. v. 583.
maxhsame/nw: cf. ma/xesqai v. 8.
a)nsth/thn: stood up, rose from their seats. The speeches of vs. 285303 were uttered informally, while sitting, cf. v. 246.
Vs. 306-347. Purification of the camp. Chryseis is returned to her father. Briseis is led from the tent of Achilles.
h)/ie: from ei)=mi, see § 34 f.

*menoitia/dh|: Patroclus was so well known to the hearers of Homer, from old stories and songs, that he needed no more exact designation here; cf. the use of *)atrei+/dhs v. 7. See § 21 b. When a boy in Opus he killed a comrade in a fit of anger and was taken by his father to Phthia where Peleus received him kindly (23.84 ff.), and brought him up with Achilles. He attended Achilles on this Trojan ex pedition as his warmest and most faithful friend and squire (qera/pwn, *s 80 ff., 24.4 ff.). The narrative of his exploits fills a large part of the Sixteenth Book of the Iliad. He was slain by Hector (16.818 ff.). To avenge his death, Achilles ends his quarrel with Agamemnon. Most of the Twenty-third Book is occupied with an account of the funeral games in his honor.
*)atrei+/dhs ktl.: as he had planned (a)/ra), vs. 141 ff.
proe/ russen: caused to be drawn down from its position on shore, cf. v. 486, 2.152 f.
e)s de/: as v. 142. All four advs. (e)s, e)s, a)na/, e)n) refer to nh=a, supplied from v. 308.
e)s de/: into it, adv. with bh=se.

e)ei/kosin: ships for other purposes than war generally have twenty oarsmen in Homer. cf. nh=) a)/rsas e)re/th|sin e)ei/kosin . . . e)/rxeo peuso/menos patro/s a 280 f., d 669, i(sto\n nho\s e)eikoso/roio i 322.
bh=se: for the causative use of this tense of bai/nw, cf. bh/somen v. 144.
a)na/: adv. with ei(=sen (aor. from i(/zw).
a)/gwn: see on v. 138.
a)rxo/s: cf. v. 144.
*)odusseu/s: as polu/mhtis, polumh/xanos, he was often sent on embassies, cf. *g 205, *i 169, *l 767.
The story which is here broken off, of the voyage to Chrysa, is resumed v. 430.

a)polumai/nesqai: they were to purify themselves symbolically from the sin of Agamemnon which had brought upon them the pestilence. cf. the action of the children of Israel, after their idolatry: ‘And they gathered together to Mizpeh, and drew water, and poured it out before the Lord, and fasted on that day, and said there, We have sinned against the Lord,’ 1 Sam. vii. 6. They trusted that the pollution would depart from them into the sea, where they washed themselves.
telhe/ssas: cf. on v. 66.
para\ qi=na: as v. 34. The line of people was stretched out along the strand.
a)truge/toio: epith. of the sea and the aether (17.425).
peri\ kapnw=|: around, in the smoke; for the adv. use of peri/, cf. *x 95, q 426; see § 37 a. Cf. kni/shn d) e)k pedi/ou a)/neuoi fe/ron ou)rano\n ei)/sw *q 549.
Transition to another scene, which fills the blank during the jour ney of the embassy to Chrysa.
kata\ strato/n: (down) through the camp, cf. a)na\ strato/n vs. 10, 53, kata\ nh=as *b 47, kata\ bwmou/s *b 305.
e)/ridos: as v. 210.
prw=ton: once, see on v. 6.
e)phpei/lhse: vs. 181 ff.

*talqu/bion: the principal herald of Agamemnon, cf. *g 118, *d 192, *h 276, *t 196, 250, 267, *y 897. According to Herodotus (vii. 134), he had a sanctuary at Sparta, and his family lived there long as heralds.
*eu)ruba/thn: only here as herald of Agamemnon; to be distinguished from Odysseus's herald of the same name, see on 2.184.
prose/eipen: is regularly followed by the direct address in the next verse, but occasionally some incidental remark intervenes by way of parenthesis, as here and Od. 17.342 ff.
qera/ponte: companions, squires. Patroclus is qera/pwn of Achilles (18.152), brave warriors are called qera/pontes *)/arhos (2.110), and kings qera/pontes *dio/s (Od. 11.255, see on v. 176).

e)/rxesqon: here followed by the acc. of limit of motion, without a prep.; see § 3 i. This const. is freq. with i(/kw, i(ka/nw, i(kne/omai, but rare with bai/nw, ei)=mi, e)/rxomai. — Agamemnon does not go in person (au\to/s v. 185) since Achilles had declared (v. 298) that he would make no resistance.
xeiro/s: gen. of the part touched, with e(lo/nte, cf. ko/mhs v. 197, podo/s v. 591.
a)ge/men: inf. for the imv., parallel with e)/rxesqon, see on de/xesqai v. 20. — This contains an explanation of the preceding imv. and hence is not connected with it by a conj. (§ 2 m), cf. v. 363.
324 = v. 137, with dw/h|sin for dw/wsin.
kai/: strengthens r(i/gion.
r(i/gion: for its formation, see § 22 b.
i(/ei . . . e)/tellen: as v. 25.
mu=qon: the preceding command.
a)e/konte: because of their dread and reverence for Achilles, cf. v. 331. For the form, see § 6 a.
ba/thn [e)bh/thn]: dual forms generally have no aug. in Homer.

para\ qi=na: cf. v. 347. The quarters of Achilles were at the extreme right of the camp, cf.
e)p' *ai)/antos klisi/as … h)d' e)p' *)axillh=os, toi/ r() e)/sxata nh=as e)i/sas
ei)/rusan, h)nore/h| pi/sunoi kai\ ka/rtei+ xeirw=n 11.7 ff.
cf. *k 74, *n 267. — to/n: refers back to v. 322.
ou)d) a)/ra: but naturally not.
gh/qhsen: inceptive aor., cf. vs. 92, 255; “did joy enter his heart.”
tarbh/sante: seized by fear (the opposite of qarsh/sas v. 85), while the present ai)dome/nw expresses the continued attitude of their minds, cf. 2.374.
o( e)/gnw: for the hiatus, cf. v. 532, *b 105, a)/stude e)/lqwmen z 296; see § 9 b.
e)/gnw: sc. their errand; cf. v. 302.

xai/rete: the customary greeting. — *dio\s a)/ggeloi ktl.: as 7.274; inviolable servants of diotrefe/wn basilh/wn (on v. 176); hence they are dii/filoi *q 517. Hermes is not the patron god of heralds in Homer.
e)pai/tioi: sc. e)ste/, to blame, cf. v. 153.
kou/rhs: kou=ros and kou/rh are used esp. of young men and women of noble families; but kou=roi *)axaiw=n (v. 473) does not differ materially except in metrical form from ui(=es *)axaiw=n (v. 162).

a)/gein: final inf., cf. ma/xesqai v. 8, a)ge/men v. 443, *b 477, *g 117. — tw\ d) au)tw/: these two themselves. The very men who executed the unjust order are to be witnesses of its injustice and of Achilles's justification in withdrawing from active service.
pro/s: in the sight of, before. For the anaphora of the prep., cf. that of e)k vs. 436 ff.
qew=n, a)nqrw/pwn: for a strong “all persons”; cf. the words of Zeus, to/sson e)gw\ peri/ t) ei)mi\ qew=n peri/ t) ei)/m) a)nqrw/pwn *q 27.
kai/: after te/ . . . te/, gives special prominence to this clause.

pro\s tou= basilh=os a)phne/os: before that king, the cruel king, equiv. to pro\s tou/tou tou= basile/ws tou= a)phnou=s. For the order of words, cf. v. 11, to\n lwbhth=ra e)pesbo/lon *b 275, ta\ teu/xea kala/ *f 317, tou= paido\s a)gauou= l 492, to\n cei=non du/sthnon r 10. Since the art. is still a dem. in Homer, the foregoing are merely apparent exceptions to the rule that the attributive adj. stands between the article and its noun.
dh\ au)=te: for the synizesis, cf. v. 131.
au)=te: not again, marking a repetition; but indicating a situation opposed to the present, cf. v. 237.

xreiw\ ge/nhtai: this happens in the Ninth Book, cf. 9.230 ff. — The object before the speaker's mind is Agamemnon; hence at the close of the sent., toi=s a)/llois is used instead of the general word *)axaioi=s.
toi=s a)/llois: dat. of interest with a)mu=nai, cf. v. 67.
ga_/r: lengthened, as 2.39, for an unknown reason.
ou)de/ ti: and not at all. — noh=sai ktl.: proverbial expression for prudence, cf. *g 109, *s 250, w 452. For the inf. with oi)=de knows how, cf. 7.238, 240.
o(/ppws: for the doubled p, see § 12 a.
oi(=: ethical dat. with so/oi maxeoi/ato.
maxeoi/ato: that they should fight; the pres. of the principal sent. is followed by the opt., since the purpose is presented as a mere conception of the speaker's mind.
a)/gein: as v. 338.
Vs. 348-430. Achilles tells his grief to his mother. She promises to secure satisfaction for him from Zeus.

a)e/kousa: this indicates that she was more than a mere ge/ras to Achilles, and that his anger arose not simply from the insult offered to his dignity but also from wounded love; cf. 9.343 f. In 19.287 ff., she mourns bitterly for the dead Patroclus on her return to the tent of Achilles.

gunh/: explanatory appos. with h(. — The scene ends at the bucolic diaeresis (§ 40 h), cf. vs. 318, 430. au)ta\r *)axilleu/s is thus used 17 times in the Iliad in the last two feet of the verse, to mark a transition, while au)ta\r *)odusseu/s is thus used 27 times in the Odyssey. — au)ta\r *)axilleu\s ktl.: simple description of the effect which the loss of Briseis had upon the hero, without depicting his feelings in modern fashion.
dakru/sas: fell to weeping. Burst into tears is perhaps too strong a translation.
e(ta/rwn: const. with no/sfi liasqei/s.
a)/far: const. with liasqei/s, cf. v. 594.
qi=n) e)/f) a(lo/s: i.e. e)pi\ qi=na ktl., with e(/zeto.
e)/f) is accented, in spite of the elision, in order to prevent ambiguity (§ 37 c b).
a(lo/s: a(/ls and qa/lassa are the general words for sea; po/ntos, the high, deep sea (often with reference to a particular tract, cf. 2.145); pe/lagos, the open sea.
polla/: as v. 35.

o)regnu/s: not a)nasxw/n (xei=ras a)nasxw/n v. 450), since while invoking the sea divinity he stretched out his hands toward the deep; cf. 9.568, where Althaea beats upon the ground as she calls upon the nether gods; palmas ponto tendens utrasque . . . Di, quibus imperium est pelagi Verg. Aen. v. 233 ff.
e)/teke/s ge: the prominence given by ge/ emphasizes the fact as responsible for the inference which is drawn from it.
minunqa/dion: equiv. to w)ku/moros v. 417.
pe/r: in its original use, very.
timh/n per: honor at least, placed first with emphasis; chiastic with minunqa/dion (§ 2 o).
o)/fellen: the past tense of verbs of obligation is used to imply that the obligation was not complied with.
*)olu/mpios: is used in the sing. only of Zeus, as v. 589, 2.309; in the pl. of all the gods, as v. 399.
u(yibreme/ths: cf. deino\n de\ bro/nthse path\r a)ndrw=n te qew=n te | u(/yoqen g 56.
nu=n de/: but as it is, marking a return to the reality from a merely hypothetical case, cf. v. 417, *b 82, a 166, 219, 241.
ou)de\ tutqo/n: not even a little.

e(lw\n e)/xei: differs from ei(=le chiefly in giving prominence to the possession as still continued; cf. (of the same act) ei(/let) e)/xei d) a)/loxon *i 336. This approaches a periphrasis common in tragedy, even where the partic. is intrans., and often differing little from the aor. ind. h)ti/mhse, etc.; cf. Soph. O. T. 731, Ant. a)tima/sas e)/xei 22, 32, 77, e)gklh/|sas e)/xei 180, khru/cas e)/xw 192, e)/xeis tara/cas 794, 1058, 1272.
a)pou/ras: partic. of a)phu/rwn v. 430; epexegetical of e(lw/n. For the strengthening by au)to/s, cf. vs. 137, 161, 185, 324, 19.89.
w(\s fa/to ktl.: cf. sic fatur lacrimans Verg. Aen. vi. 1.

patri\ ge/ronti: Nereus, who is not named by Homer but only designated as a(/lios ge/rwn (v. 538). His home is in the Aegean sea, cf. 24.78. With him is Thetis, who has deserted her aged husband Peleus. The daughters of Nereus are enumerated 18.38 ff.
a(lo/s: ablatival gen., from the sea, as a)nedu/seto li/mnhs e 337; see § 3 d.
h)u/t) o)mi/xlh: the comparison is esp. fitting for a sea-goddess; like a mist, which rises easily and quietly from the water. For the Homeric comparison, cf. v. 47; see § 2 e ff.
pa/roiq) au)toi=o: before him (self); the intensive pron. contrasts Achilles himself with his voice which his mother had just heard, cf. v. 47. See § 24 g.
da/kru xe/ontos: the repetition of these words from v. 357 is characteristic of the fulness of Epic style.
361 = *e 372, *z 485, *w 127, d 610, e 181. — For the Epic fulness, cf. vs. 57, 88; see § 1 s.
362 = 18.73, where Thetis visits her son in his grief at the death of Patroclus.
se/, fre/nas: accs. of the whole and part, cf. v. 150, *b 171, *g 35, 438, 442.
363 = 16.19, cf. 18.74. — e)cau/da ktl.: the second imv. repeats the thought of the first, hence the asyndeton, cf. v. 323; see § 2 m.
no/w|: as in v. 132.
ei)/domen: from oi)=da, subjv. with short mode-vowel, cf. vs. 141 ff.; see § 27 a.
baru/: cf. eu)ru/ v. 355, and see on v. 78.
oi)=sqa: cf. vs. 355 f.
h)=: is not a simple sign of a question in Homer, and hence can be joined with ti/, see § 3 m.

i)dui/h|: i.e. ei)dui/h| (with the short form of the stem, § 31 g); intrans., as *k 250, *y 787. Though his mother knows all, Achilles tells the story. A man in suffering finds relief in rehearsing his ills, and this recital was followed by the sympathy of the poet's hearers. The repetition is more natural because the consequences of these events continue through the whole poem.
a)goreu/w: subjv. of deliberation.—For the verbal repetition, cf. 2.10-15, 23-34, 60-70.
w)|xo/meqa: on his marauding expeditions in the neighborhood of Troy; see on v. 125.
*qh/bhn: a city of the Cilicians, in Mysia, at the foot of Mt. Placus, an eastern spur of Mt. Ida. Eetion, father of Andromache, Hector's wife, reigned there, 6.394 ff.
i(erh/n: since the gods were worshipped there. — For the simple order of words, see § 1 f.
h)/gomen e)nqa/de: Andromache tells of the sack of the city, of her father's death and her mother's captivity, in 6.414 ff.
eu)=: properly, so that each received his due share.
da/ssanto: cf. de/dastai v. 125, dasmo/s v. 166.

e)k d) e(/lon: as ge/ras (e)cai/reton, cf. 2.227), besides his share of the spoils, see on v. 124. — The capture of Chrysa (v. 37) on the same expedition is assumed here. 2.690 ff. shows that Lyrnessus was sacked, and Briseis taken captive, on the same voyage.
pa/lin: back; cf. pa/lin plagxqe/ntas v. 59, do/menai pa/lin v. 116.
fi/los h)=en: sc. o( ge/rwn. This was shown by the event.
e)p) *)argei/oisi: e)pi/ with dat. of the person, in Homer often implies hostility, cf. v. 51; see § 3 h b.
be/los: as v. 51.
e)passu/teroi: in quick succession, cf. v. 52.
a)/mmi: Att. h(mi=n (§ 24 a), for us.
qeopropi/as: as v. 87.
e(ka/toio: of the Far Darter. e(/katos is a short, pet form of e(kathbo/los (as *(eka/th was a name of the moon goddess); cf. on *sminqeu= v. 39. For similar epiths. of Apollo, see § 4 c.
kelo/mhn: cf. v. 62 ff. and on v. 74.
*)atrei+/wna ktl.: equiv. to *)atrei+/wn e)xolw/qh, cf. xolwqei/s v. 9.
h)pei/lhsen mu=qon: the Eng. idiom reverses the const., he uttered the threat.
th\n me/n: contrasted with th\n de/ v. 391.
su\n nhi/: with a ship, almost equiv. to by ship. This expression seems more instrumental than where the comrades also are mentioned, cf. vs. 179, 183.
pe/mpousin: escort (§ 2 v). The pres. is used since the act is not completed. The ‘historical pres.’ is not Homeric.
a)/gousi de/: a subord. member of the sent., with chiastic relation to pe/mpousin (§ 2 o).
a)/nakti: Apollo, cf. vs. 36, 444.
th\n de\ ktl.: contrasted with v. 389.
ne/on: adv. with e)/ban a)/gontes.

e)/ban [e)/bhsan] a)/gontes: cf. e)/ban fe/rousai *b 302, bh= feu/gwn *b 665. oi)/xomai is more freq. thus used with a partic., cf. *b 71, oi)/xesqai profe/rousa qu/ella *z 346, oi)/xetai i(/ppon a)/gwn *y 577. See on vs. 138, 168.
do/san ktl.: as v. 162, see on v. 124.

paido\s e(h=os: thy valiant son. For e(h=os, see § 20 e. It seems part of the poet's naïveté that the heroes apply such epiths. to themselves; but the phrase is part of the poet's stock, and he hardly thinks whether he is applying the epith. himself or is putting it in the hero's mouth.
*di/a_: for the length of the ultima before li/sai, see § 41 j.
ei)/ pote: cf. v. 39, also vs. 503 ff.
e)/pei, e)/rgw|: emphatically placed in contrast, at the beginning and the close of the verse.
kradi/hn *dio/s: for the periphrasis, see § 2 s.
h)e\ kai/: or also.
polla/ki: for the omission of final s, see § 12 o.
se/o: gen. of source with a)/kousa.

patro/s: i.e. of Peleus, in Thessaly, where Thetis seems to have remained after her marriage until the outbreak of the Trojan war; cf. 16.221 ff. (where mention is made of the chest of Achilles that Thetis had packed for him). See on v. 358.
eu)xome/nhs: supplementary partic. with se/o, cf. v. 257. — o(/te ktl.: explains eu)xome/nhs, see § 1 h.
a)eike/a ktl.: as v. 341, cf. v. 67.
o(/ppote: when once upon a time. — Thetis makes no use of this suggestion in her interview with Zeus.
e)lqou=sa: see on v. 138.
qea/: marks her power to accomplish.

u(pelu/sao desmw=n: didst loose from under the chains, didst free from the pressure of the chains, cf. e)/lusan u(po\ zugou= *q 543. — Transition to dir. disc. from the inf. const. of v. 398, cf. 2.12, 126; see § 1 c.
e(kato/gxeiron: cf. centimanus Gyas Hor. Carm. ii. 17. 14, belua centiceps ib. ii. 13. 34.
kale/sasa: by calling, coincident in time with u(pelu/sao.

*bria/rewn: by transfer of quantity for *bria/rhon, § 5 d. The name (Heavy-handed, cf. briaro/s) marks his strength and character. He is called *ai)gai/wn (Stormy, cf. ai)gi/s, *ai)gai/, *ai)/gina) in the popular speech, as a sea divinity. He is the personified might and roar of the sea. Hesiod (Theog. 714) makes him aid Zeus against the Titans. — Homer attributes to the language of the gods names which are going out of use (but which may seem clearer in meaning than the others), cf. 2.813 f., *c 291, potamo\s baqudi/nhs, | o(\n *ca/nqon kale/ousi qeoi/, a)/ndres de\ *ska/mandron g 73 f., k 305, m 61.
au)=te: for his part.
ou(= patro/s: Poseidon, the mighty god of the sea. All of Poseidon's sons are represented as violent and strong.
o(/s r(a: so he; for the dem. use of the rel., see § 24 p.
ku/dei+ gai/wn: delighting in the fulness of his might.
kai/: also, marks the effect corresponding to ku/dei+ gai/wn, as 5.394; see on v. 249.
u(pe/deisan: for the length of the antepenult, see on v. 33. u(po/ with verbs of fearing, fleeing, yielding, marks the superiority on the side of the person who is the efficient cause.
te/: indicates the close connection of the two clauses, cf. vs. 82, 218, 2.179.
tw=n: see on v. 160.
mi/n: const. with mnh/sasa, — pare/zeo would govern the dat.
gou/nwn: for the gen., cf. xeiro/s v. 323. For the inflection, see § 18 f. — This was the attitude of a suppliant, cf. vs. 500 ff.
ai)/ ke/n pws: cf. v. 66.
e)pi\ a)rh=cai: come to the aid of; cf. the force of e)pi/ in v. 345.
kata\ pru/mnas: the ships were drawn up with their sterns toward the land; cf. tei=xos e)pi\ prumnh=|sin e)/deiman *c 32, *o 385, *s 76.

a)mf) a(/la: about the sea, i.e. on the shore between the promontories Sigeium and Rhoeteium. Until now they had fought on the plain, far from the ships; cf. Achilles's words, u)/fra d) e)gw\ met) *)axaioi=sin pole/mizon, | ou)k e)qe/leske ma/xhn a)po\ tei/xeos o)rnu/men *(/ektwr *i 352 f. as long as I was fighting among the Achaeans, Hector was not willing to rouse the battle away from the wall (of the city).
e)pau/rwntai: may come to enjoy; ironical, as *z 353, *o 17. cf. quidquid delirant reges plectuntur Achivi Hor. Epist. i. 2. 14.
kai/: also, as well as the other Greeks.
h(\n a)/thn: his blind infatuation, his blindness, made more definite by o(/ te ktl. (i.e. o(/ti te), as v. 244. cf. 2.111.
413-427. The answer of Thetis.
kata\ xe/ousa: cf. ka\d de\ pareiw=n | da/kruon h(=ke xama=ze p 190 f.
ti/ nu: why now, to what end, acc. of specification.
ai)na/: cognate acc. with tekou=sa, dreadfully, to sorrow; adv. as 22.431. cf. kakh=| ai)/sh| v. 418; Thetis calls herself dusaristoto/keia *s 54 mother of an unhappy hero.
a)da/krutos ktl.: i.e. full of joy and happiness; this thought receives the emphasis.
ai)=sa: sc. e)sti/, here like ai)w/n term of life.

mi/nunqa: adv. modifying the e)sti/ to be supplied, which is sometimes modified by an adv. in Homer (§ 3 j); cf. a)kh\n e)ge/nonto siwph=| *g 95, diagnw=nai xalepw=s h)=n e(/kaston *h 424, ou)d) a)/r) e)/ti dh\n | h)=n *z 139 f. “nor did he live long.”
ou)/ ti ma/la dh/n: the preceding thought is repeated in neg. form. — For the length of the ultima of ma/la, see § 41 j b.
nu=n de/: as v. 354.
te/: its position is free, cf. 2.281. For the thought, cf. 18.59 ff., 95 f.
e)/pleo: thou art, lit. thou becamest by decree of fate ordered at thy birth; cf. e)ni\ fresi\ tou=to no/hma | e)/pleto this thought came into thy mind Od. 2.363 f.
tw=|: therefore; she infers from the foregoing, not the fact but the justification of the expressions ai)na\ tekou=sa, kakh=| ai)/sh|.
ka/kh| ai)/sh|: to an evil lot, as 5.209; cf. a)/ndra qnhto\n e)o/nta, pa/lai peprwme/non ai)/sh| *p 441, i)h=| a)/ra geino/meq) ai)/sh| *x 477.
tou=to e)/pos: vs. 407 ff.
toi/: dat. of interest, cf. toi/ vs. 425 f.
e)re/ousa: fut. partic., expressing purpose. — For the two hiatus in this verse, see §§ 9 f, 14.
*)/olumpon a)ga/nnifon: see on vs. 44, 195, 497.
su\ me/n: correlative with v. 426; the interposed explanation makes it natural to change the form of the apod. from e)gw\ de/. — nu=n: i.e. until her visit to Zeus.
parh/menos: as v. 488; inactivity is implied, cf. 2.688, 694. — Thetis does not encourage his son to carry out his threat of v. 169, to return to Phthia.
mh/nie: pres. imv., continue to rage, see on v. 210. See on mh=nin v. 1.
*zeu\s ga\r ktl.: gives the reason for the preceding direction, esp. for nu=n, showing why his request cannot be granted at once.

e)s *)wkeano/n: cf. ei)s *)agame/mnona *h 312; to the abode of Oceanus, near which was the home of the Aethiopians. There were Aethiopians in the southeast and southwest of the Homeric world, e)/sxatoi a)ndrw=n, a 22 ff. They are represented as a godfearing people, enjoying the personal intercourse of the divinities, 23.205 ff., Od. 5.282; cf. the presence of the gods at the sacrifices of the Phaeacians, Od. 7.201 ff.
meta/: as v. 222.
*ai)qioph=as: for the form, see § 19 e.
xqizo/s: pred. adj. instead of adv., as vs. 472, 497, *b 2, *g 7; see § 38 a.
kata\ dai=ta: cf. kata\ prh=cin g 72 for trade, plazo/menoi kata\ lhi/da g 106 wandering for plunder.
a(/ma pa/ntes: cf. v. 495.
e(/ponto: apparent contradiction of vs. 195, 221 f., where Athena and Hera are thought of as on Olympus.
dwdeka/th|: cf. v. 54; reckoned from the day on which Thetis is speaking. For this use of 12 as a round number, cf. *f 46, *w 31, 667.

xalkobate/s: with bronze threshold, an epith. applied four times to the home of Zeus, once to that of Hephaestus, and once to the palace of Alcinous. The threshold of wood was prob. covered with a plate of bronze. The floor of the hall of Zeus was covered with gold, 4.2; cf. ‘and the floor of the house he overlaid with gold, within and without,’ 1 Kings vi. 30, of Solomon's temple.
kai/ min, kai/ min: for the animated repetition, cf. kai/ min ba/lon w)=mon . . . kai/ min e)gw/ g) e)fa/mhn *)aidwnh=i proi+a/yein *e 188, 190.
gouna/somai: cf. labe\ gou/nwn v. 407.
a)pebh/seto: only in this place in the verse, before the bucolic diaeresis (§ 40 h); elsewhere, a)pe/bh, see § 32 b. — to\n de\ ktl.: also 2.35.
au)tou=: intensive when adv. (not very freq.) in Homer, as well as when a strict pronoun.
gunaiko/s: gen. of cause, with xwo/menon, see on v. 65.
bi/h| ktl.: by force, against his will, as Od. 4.646; cf. me bi/h| a)e/konta kaqe/cei *o 186.
a)e/kontos: sc. e(/qen, gen. of separation.

Vs. 430-487. Chryseis is conducted to her home. The scene in Chrysa naturally intervenes between the promise of Thetis and its fulfilment, and thus seems to fill up in part the 12 days' delay; see on 3.121.
au)ta\r *)odusseu\s ktl.: cf. vs. 311 ff. For the beginning of the narrative, see on au)ta\r *)axilleu/s v. 348.
i(/kanen a)/gwn: cf. e)/rxom) e)/xwn v. 168, h(=ke *tissafe/rnhs e)/xwn th\n e(autou= du/namin Xen. An. ii. 4. 8. a)/gwn with is used because the hecatomb was composed of live animals.

i(sti/a stei/lanto: they took in their sails; the mid. takes the place of a possessive pron., cf. a)/nta pareia/wn sxome/nh a 334 holding before her cheeks; but the act. also is used, g 11, i(sti/a te ste/llontas p 353. cf. v. 480.
proto/noisin: forestays, the ropes leading from the prow to the top of the mast; e)pi/tonoi, backstays, were stretched from the stern (Od. 12.423); both together served to hold the mast in place.
u(fe/ntes: lowering.
proe/ressan: cf. i 73, spoudh=| d) e)s lime/na proere/ssamen n 279. When near their haven, they reefed their sails and rowed the boat to land.
e)k de/: for the anaphora, cf. vs. 339 f., 2.671 ff., 10.228 ff., 12.417 ff., 23.315 ff.
eu)na/s: large stones which served as anchors. These were cast from the prow, while the prumnh/sia (v. 476) held the stern. When the boat was to remain long, it was drawn up on land.
bai=non: for the descriptive impf., see on v. 25.
e)pi/: for the length of the ultima, see §41 j, l.
bh=san: 1st aor., trans.; cf. vs. 144, 310, e)/sthsan v. 448.
The rhythm has been thought to imitate the maiden's measured steps, § 2 b.
e)k: adv. as above, but more exactly defined by nho/s.
de/: for the short vowel lengthened before two consonants, see § 41 h g.
pontopo/roio: cf. *g 283, w)kupo/roisin v. 421.

e)pi\ bwmo/n: the god is thus made a witness of the return; thus in a Boeotian inscription a man emancipates his slave e)nanti/on *)asklhpi/ou. The priest dwelt in the sacred enclosure (te/menos, a)/lsos) of the god, cf. Od. 9.200.
e)n xersi\ ti/qei: placed in the arms. For xei/r as arm, cf. *z 81, 482, nu/ce (pierced) de/ min kata\ xei=ra me/shn, a)gkw=nos e)/nerqen (below the elbow) 11.252, (e)/qane) fi/lwn e)n xersi/n a 238.
ti/qei: see on a)fi/ei v. 25.
pro\ e)/pemyen: cf. pro\ h(=ke v. 195.
For the chiasmus, see § 2 o.
a)ge/men: for the inf., cf. a)/gein v. 338.
e(kato/mbhn r(e/cai: cf. i(era\ r(e/cas v. 147.
u(pe\r *danaw=n: in behalf of the Danaï; this figurative use of u(pe/r, freq. in later Greek, hardly appears elsewhere in Homer.
446 = 23.624, 797, cf. Od. 15.130. — Homer does not mention Chryseis after this.
e(cei/hs: in order, since e(kato/mbhn is collective.
e)/sthsan: 1st aor., trans., cf. bh=san v. 438, a)nasth/seien v. 191.

xerni/yanto: they could not pray to the gods with unwashen hands, cf. *g 270, xersi\ d) a)ni/ptoisin *dii\ lei/bein ai)/qopa oi)=non | a(/zomai (dread) *z 266. — ou)loxu/tas: unground barley corns (ou)=lai kriqai/) which, roasted and mixed with salt, were scattered between the horns of the victim (proba/lonto v. 458) as an initiatory sacrifice, whence they were proleptically called ou)lo/xutai poured out barley corns.
a)ne/lonto: took up, from the basket standing on the ground.
toi=sin: for them, as vs. 68, 247.
mega/la: loudly, cf. polla/ v. 35.

xei=ras a)nasxw/n: the palms were extended towards the gods, the usual attitude in prayer, as is shown by works of art; cf. v. 351, 3.318. So also among the Hebrews; cf. ‘And it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand, that Israel prevailed; and when he let down his hand, Amalek prevailed,’ Exodus xvii. 11.
= 37 f. With the same formula with which he began his prayer for vengeance, he now prays that the punishment may be averted.
453-455 = 16.236-238, in a prayer of Achilles.
h)me/n, h)de/: paratactic const., where the Eng. idiom uses “as . . . so”; see § 3 q.
dh/ pote: once already, correl. with e)/ti v. 455 once more.
Explanatory appos. asyndeton. — ti/mhsas ktl.: i.e. by sending the pestilence which avenged the slight offered to the priest.
kai\ nu=n: contrasted with pa/ros above. — to/de ktl.: as v. 41.
h)/dh nu=n: now at once. — *danaoi=sin ktl.: cf. v. 97.
458 = *b 421, g 447. — In the sacrifice described Od. 3.440 ff., the victim's forelock is cut off and thrown into the fire, before the barley corns are scattered.
au)ta\r e)pei/: repeated in this narrative vs. 464, 467, 469, 484.
au)e/rusan: they drew up (back) the head of the victim, in order to tighten the muscles of the neck. For the form, see § 11 e.
e)/sfacan: i.e. opened the large artery of the neck, to let the blood, cf. 3.292.
mhrou\s e)ce/tamon: instead of the more definite e)k mhri/a ta/mnon g 456, see on v. 40.

kni/sh|: two layers of fat were placed over the thigh pieces; and upon the fat, bits of raw meat from all parts of the body (pa/ntwn mele/wn c 428), symbolizing a sacrifice of the whole animal. These were burned, and thus the gods, according to the Homeric belief, took part in the sacrificial feast. cf. v. 317.
di/ptuxa: sc. kni/shn, equiv. to di/plaki dhmw=| *y 243.
kai=e: sc. the mhri/a with the fat and bits of flesh.
sxi/ch|s: cf. 2.425.
ne/oi: the companions of Odysseus, in contrast with d( ge/rwn, the old priest; cf. 2.789. In the corresponding passage of the Odyssey, the ne/oi are the sons of Nestor.
par) au)to/n: by the priest himself, who is thus marked as the principal, directing person at the sacrifice.
pempw/bola: these bronze forks prob. had bent tines, like some antique Etruscan bronzes that have been found, not unlike a hand with fingers bent in readiness to grasp some object.
kata\ ka/h: these pieces were intended for the gods and therefore were entirely (kata/) con sumed by the fire, cf. o( d) e)n puri\ ba/lle quhla/s *i 220.
pa/santo: in order to have a share in the sacrifice. This was no part of, but only an introduction to, the meal which followed, cf. Od. 3.40 ff.
mi/stullon ktl.: cf. pars in frusta secant, verubusque trementia figunt Verg. Aen. i. 212.
perifrade/ws: i.e. to keep it from burning.
e)ru/santo: drew it off from the spits, after it was roasted.
e)i/shs: equal, of which each has a fair share; the feast was common to all, but the leaders had the better portions, *h 321, *q 161 f.

469 = *b 432, *h 323, *i 92, 222, *y 57, *w 628, and 11 times in the Odyssey. — A set verse to mark the end of a feast, see § 1 w. Vergil imitates in postquam exemta fames et amor compressus edendi Aen. viii. 184.
e)c e)/ron e(/nto: cf. a)nei=san h(donh\n (sc. daito/s) Eur. Ion 1170.
e)/ron: for the form, see §§ 4 i, 18 e. — The previous pouring out of the wine is not mentioned, as might be expected.
470 = *i 175, a 148, g 339, f 271. — kou=roi me\n ktl.: for a solemn libation of the whole company, since only Chryses poured a libation before, v. 462. cf. 9.222-224.

e)peste/yanto: cf. krhth=ras e)pistefe/as oi)/noio *q 232. — This verse seems to have been misunderstood by Vergil (or did he think to improve the description?), cf. crateras magnos statuunt et vina coronant Aen. i. 724, magnum cratera corona | induit, implevitque mero Aen. iii. 525 f.

nw/mhsan: (sc. po/ton), frequentative of ne/mw. The oi)noxo/os dipped (a)fu/sswn v. 598) the wine from the large bowl (krhth/r) into a pitcher (pro/xoos s 397). The kou=roi proceeded from left to right (e)nde/cia v. 597) through the company, distributing to the guests (pa=sin to all), i.e. filling their cups for the libation and the banquet.
e)parca/menoi: thus beginning the religious ceremony, equiv. to a)rca/menoi e)pine/montes. Const. with depa/essin.
panhme/rioi: through the whole day which remained, uninterruptedly till sunset. For the pred. adj. used where the Eng. idiom uses an adv., see on v. 424.
molph=|: song.
kalo/n: cognate acc. with a)ei/- dein, instead of kalw=s, cf. vs. 35, 78.
paih/ona: Att. paia=na, here a song of praise to Apollo as their preserver; in 22.391, it is a psalm of victory. — The verse explains molph=| above.

me/lpontes ktl.: cf. the frag. of an old hymn, me/lpete, w)= pai=des, *(eka/ergon kai\ *(ekae/rghn in Clemens Alex. Strom. v. 8; ‘Hymning th’ eternal Father' Milton Par. Lost vi. 96, ‘singing their great Creator’ ib. iv. 684. — For the quantity of the ultima of me/lpontes, see §§ 14 a, 41 m.
fre/na: see on kh=r v. 44.
te/rpet) a)kou/wn: delighted in hearing. The god hears the song (as he had heard the prayer), although he was far away among the Ethiopians, for du/nasai de\ su\ (Apollo) pa/ntos) a)kou/ein *p 515.
e)pi\ h)=lqen: came on, cf. me/las e)pi\ e(speros h)=lqen a 423.
para\ prumnh/sia: along by the stern hawsers (on v. 436), i.e. on the seashore; cf. e)/nqa ke lecai/mhn (lay myself) koi/lh| para\ nhi\ melai/nh| g 365, i 169. Their boat was not drawn up on land.
r(ododa/ktulos: a notable epithet; the ancients had observed the diverging rays of rosy light before sunrise. cf. *)hw\s kroko/peplos (saffron-robed) *q 1, *t 1, *y 227, *w 695.
kai\ to/te: th=mos is expected after h)=mos, but the rel. is not always followed by the corresponding dem. For kai/ in the apod., see § 3 o.
a)na/gonto: put out upon the high sea, cf. kata/gonto g 10 came to land.

i)/kmenon ou)=ron ktl.: Aeolus was master of the winds (Od. 10.21), but each god could send a favorable breeze; Apollo, here (because of the sacrifice that had been offered to him); Athene, b 420, o 292; Calypso, Od. 5.268; Circe, Od. 11.7; cf. pe/myei de/ toi ou)=ron o)/pisqen | a)qana/twn o(/s ti/s se fula/ssei te r(u/etai/ te o 34 f.
sth/santo: mid. as i 77, m 402; see on v. 433.
i(sti/a: strictly an adj. which has become a subst., what pertains to the i(sto/s. The Homeric boat seems to have had but one sail.
a)mfi/: adv.
porfu/reon: foaming.
mega/la: const. with i)/axe.
nho/s: in the transitional stage from limiting gen. with stei/rh| to the gen. abs.; see § 3 f.
diaprh/ssousa: also with gen., cf. 2.785.
r(a/: refers to the preceding verse.
kata\ strato/n: opposite (off) the camp, i.e. to the landing-place. — The verse closes as v. 478.
nh=a me/n: correl. with au)toi\ de/.
e)p) h)pei/roio: up on land; cf. e)ru/ssate h)peiro/nde k 403.
u(you= ktl.: i.e. so as to rest high on the sands, where it was before, cf. v. 308.
u(po\ de/: adv., beneath, i.e. under the ship.
e(/rmata: as 2.154, props (sometimes stones, 14.410), which were put along the keel on either side to hold the boat steady.
Vs. 488-530. Zeus grants to Thetis the fulfilment of her desire.

au)ta\r o( mh/nie: as his mother had directed, vs. 421 f.; cf. vs. 428 f. — Achilles withdraws from the action for the present. In the Ninth Book, an embassy is sent to him, begging him to give up his wrath and take part in the war (9.119 ff.). In the Eleventh Book, he is roused from his apathy on seeing the rout of the Achaeans (11.599 ff.). In the Sixteenth Book, when Hector reaches the Greek ships and throws fire into one of them, Achilles sends Patroclus and the Myrmidons into the conflict (16.1 ff.). He receives the news of the death of Patroclus in the Eighteenth Book (18.1 ff.), and is reconciled to Agamemnon in the Nineteenth Book and arms himself for battle (19.40 ff., 364 ff.). He takes part in the fourth (and last) great battle of the Iliad, on the 27th day of the action of the Iliad.

ui(o/s: for the short penult, where i has been virtually lost between two vowels, cf. 2.566; see §§ 5 g, 41 o e. — po/das w)ku\s ktl.: as vs. 58, 84, 148, 215, etc. Cf. poda/rkhs di=os *)axilleu/s v. 121. See § 4 c.
For the asyndeton, cf. vs. 117, 255, 288, 363.
pwle/sketo: for the iterative formation, see § 36.
kudia/neiran: elsewhere epith. of ma/xhn. cf. a)gore/wn, i(/na t) a)/ndres a)riprepe/es tele/qousin *i 441.
po/lemon: for the long ultima, see on v. 226.
fi/lon: see on *b 261, *g 138.
kh=r: obj. of fqinu/qeske.
au)=qi: right there, in the same place, i.e. in his tent.
poqe/eske de/: the partic. poqe/wn might have been used in the same sense.
a)uth/n: battle cry; always a trisyllable, and thus never to be confounded with au)th/n herself.

e)k toi=o: the hearer easily recalled the words of Thetis (which form the starting point of the mh=nis), vs. 421 f., and the definite statement of time v. 425, and referred e)k toi=o to that interview between mother and son. cf. the similar indefiniteness in the use of the same expression 24.31, where it does not refer to the day last mentioned, but to the well-remembered day of Hector's death.
h)w/s: day, as *f 80, *w 413.
h)=rxe: led the way, as the highest in rank. cf. 3.420.
h(/ ge: resumes the subj.; see on v. 97.

a)nedu/seto ku=ma: i.e. as she sprang up she left the wave, cf. kate/bain) u(perw/ia s 206 she descended leaving the upper room, a)ndu/etai po/lemon kako/n *n 225 shrinks back leaving the war. Cf. v. 359.
h)eri/h: as v. 557, *g 7, i 52; with emphasis in this position in the verse; “while it was yet early morning.”
ou)rano\n *ou)/lumpo/n te: as 8.394; see on vs. 44, 195.
eu)ru/opa: far sounding, far thundering; for the form, perhaps a stereotyped nom., see § 16 b.
a)krota/th| korufh=|: from which he looks out upon the world again, after his long absence. cf. summo sedet altus Olympo Verg. Aen. xi. 726.

poludeira/dos: (from deira/ neck). Epiths. appropriate to men are often applied to natural objects. cf. karh/nwn v. 44, ‘foothills,’ ‘shoulder of the mountain,’ ‘arm of the sea,’ ‘mouth of the river.’
pa/roiqe kaqe/zeto: cf. 3.162.
gou/nwn: see on v. 407.
skaih=|, decite/rh|: for the adjs. used as substs., see on v. 54.
u(p) a)nqere/wnos: under the chin, as 3.372.
*di/a *kroni/wna: closely connected, cf. 2.375.

*zeu= pa/ter: this address, put into the mouths of gods and men, marks his patriarchal, royal dignity; cf. vs. 534, 544, hominum sator atque deorum Verg. Aen. xi. 725, divum pater atque hominum rex ib. i. 65.
ei)/ pote: cf. v. 394.
ti/mhson: by its position is strongly contrasted with h)ti/mhsen v. 507, cf. vs. 353, 356.
w)kumorw/tatos: into this is condensed the thought of vs. 415 ff.

a)/llwn: of all, lit. in comparison with the rest; ablatival gen., as with the comp. (where it marks the starting point of the comparison). This constr. with a)/llwn is specifically Homeric; cf. *b 674, *z 295, a)/ristoi tw=n a)/llwn *m 104, panu/statos a)/llwn *y 532, o)izurw/taton a)/llwn e 105, ka/lliston e(ptapu/lw| fane\n *qh=ba| tw=n prote/rwn fa/os Soph. Ant. 100, [to\n po/lemon] e)lpi/sas me/gan te e)/sesqai kai\ a)ciologw/taton tw=n progegenhme/nwn Thuc. i. *i, hi ceterorum Britannorum fugacissimi Tac. Agric. 34, solusque omnium ante se principum [Vespasianus] in melius mutatus est Tac. Hist. i. 50, ‘Adam the goodliest man of men since born | His sons, the fairest of her daughters, Eve.’ Milton Par. Lost iv. 323 f. — cf. this const. with meta\ pa=sin a)timota/th v. 516.
e)/pleto: see on v. 418. — a)ta\r ktl.: transition from the rel. to the dem. const., see on v. 79.
su/ per: in contrast with Agamemnon; cf. the force of pe/r in v. 353. — *)olu/mpie ktl.: as she renews her request, she renews impressively her appeal to the might and wisdom of Zeus.
e)pi\ ti/qei: put upon, grant to; cf. *b 39, oi(=sin e)pi\ *zeu\s qh=ke kako\n mo/ron *z 357.

o)fe/llwsin ktl.: only here const. with a person, cf. oi)=kon o)fe/llein o 21, oi)=kos o)fe/lleto c 233. — Thetis as a suppliant presents her request in general terms, while Achilles had spoken more definitely, vs. 409-412. cf. *(/ektori ga/r oi( (Zeus) qumo\s e)bou/leto ku=dos o)re/cai | *priami/dh|, i(/na nhusi\ korwni/si qespidae\s pu=r | e)mba/loi a)ka/maton, *qe/tidos d) e)cai/sion a)rh\n | pa=san e)pikrh/neie *o 596 ff.
th\n de\ ktl.: the reason of this appears from vs. 518 ff.
w(/s: dem. corresponding to the rel. w(s above, cf. *c 294, *t 16, g 424.

e)mpefuui=a: lit. grown into, closely clinging to, cf. pa/nta ku/sen perifu/s p 21 kissed him, throwing his arms about him, and the formula e)/n t) a)/ra oi( fu= xeiri/ *z 253; construed with e)/xeto, as tw=| prosfu\s e)xo/mhn w(s nukteri/s m 433 clinging to this I held on like a bat. Cf. et genua amplexus, genibusque volutans | haerebat Verg. Aen. iii. 607 f. For the form of e)mpefuui=a, see § 31 a.
ei)/reto: asked, as she demanded a ‘yes’ or ‘no.’
deuteron au)=tis: again, a second time, as Od. 3.161; cf. pa/lin au)=tis *b 276, e)mmene\s ai)ei/ *k 364.
nhmerte/s: adv.

u(po/sxeo kai\ kata/neuson: set expression, only at the end of the verse, cf. *b 112, u(pe/sthn kai\ kate/neusa *d 267, u(pe/sxeto kai\ kate/neusen w 335. kataneu/w is the contrary of a)naneu/w nod up (6.311). Thus even now in Greece, negation is indicated by an upward motion of the head, and affirmation by a downward nod (with an inclination toward the left).
a)po/eipe: speak out plainly, as Od. 1.373; refuse is implied in the context.
e)/pi: i.e. e)/pesti, § 37 c. — “Thou hast nothing to fear.”
o)/fr) e)u\ ei)dw=: cf. v. 185.
517 = *d 30, *h 454. — The first hemistich as *q 208, *o 184, *s 97; cf. *p 48, *r 18, *t 419, *x 14, d 30, 332, o 325. The second hemistich is found 23 times in Homer.
o)xqh/sas: inceptive, see on v. 92; but not so violent as “falling into a passion,” or “bursting into a rage.”
loigia e)/rga: sc. e)/stai, as v. 573; there will be dreadful trouble.
o(/te: when, not ei) if, since Zeus sees the inevitable consequence and already has the situation before his mind's eye.
*(/hrh|: emphatic, since Hera desires the most speedy destruction of Troy (4.31 ff.).
kai\ au)/tws: even as it is, without special occasion; see § 24 h.
ai)ei/: exaggerated, cf. vs. 541, 561.
kai/ te/ me/ fhsi: and says too that I; kai/ marks the agreement of this specification with the preceding general remark, cf. 3.235.
ma/xh|: in battle, as *d 400, *e 701, *l 736.
noh/oh|: sc. that Thetis had been with him.
*(/hrh: emphatic as v. 519; here so placed in contrast with e)moi/.
e)moi\ melh/setai: shall be my care. For the subjv. with ke/, cf. v. 139; see § 3 b. The mid. of this tense is found only here in Homer; elsewhere melh/sei (fut.).
o)/fra: cf. v. 82.
ei) d) a)/ge: see on v. 302.
kataneu/somai: shall nod with my head; only here in the mid., see on v. 433.
tou=to ktl.: this answers nhmerte\s ktl. v. 514.
te/kmwr: surety, pledge.
e)mo/n: neut. adj. as subst. (see on v. 539), lit. anything from me, i.e. a promise or purpose; explained by o(/ti ktl.
palina/greton: revocable, from a)gre/w Aeol. for ai(re/w take.
kataneu/sw: aor. subjv.
h)=: he spoke, see on v. 219.
e)pi\ neu=se: nodded thereto, annuit, cf. *i 620, h( d) a)/r) e)p) o)fru/si neu=se p 164, toi\ d) e)pi\ glefa/rois (i.e. eyes) neu=san Pind. Isth. viii. 49 f.
o)fru/si: with his brows. Zeus was represented in works of sculpture with heavy, projecting brows.
a)mbro/siai xai=tai: cf. ambrosiaeque comae Verg. Aen. i. 403.
e)perrw/santo: rolled down at the nod, fell down on both sides of his head. These locks are conceived as long and flowing; see on 2.11.

cf. adnuit et totum nutu tremefecit Olympum Verg. Aen. ix. 106, x. 115. — Phidias embodied in his colossal chryselephantine statue of Zeus at Olympia, the expression of exalted peace and power which lies in vs. 528-530. Zeus's dread of Hera's reproaches is in marked (and almost ludicrous) contrast to this majestic demeanor.
Vs. 531-611. Scene on Olympus. Quarrel between Zeus and Hera.
die/tmagen: dietma/ghsan, § 26 v.
a(/la a)=lto: for the hiatus, see on v. 333.
a)=lto: 2d aor. without variable vowel, from a(/llomai, § 35; for the smooth breathing, see § 12 m; for a_, see § 5 a.

pro\s dw=ma: sc. e)/bh, a general word of motion, implied in a)=lto, cf. *g 327, h)=rxe de\ tw=| au)th\n o(do\n h(/n per oi( a)/lloi q 107 he led him the same way which the others had gone; see § 2 t. — The home of Zeus on the summit of Olympus was not far from the peak on which he had been visited by Thetis; cf. *q 3, g 5, 22.
a)ne/stan: a)ne/sthsan.

e)c e(de/wn: from their seats. Each god had his separate dwelling on Olympus, vs. 607 f., and his special seat in the hall in which they gathered. e(/dos is strictly not seat (e(/drh) but place where the seat stands. — sfou= ktl.: proleptic, with a)/nestan, they rose and went to meet their father. Motion is implied in the connection, as below. — This mark of respect is noted both negatively and affirmatively. — When Hera returns to Olympus, the gods i)do/ntes | pa/ntes a)nh/ican, kai\ deikano/wnto de/passin *o 85 f. — ou)de\ ktl.: a formula occurring nine times at the close of a verse.
a)nti/oi: pred. nom, after e)/stan, cf. 2.185.
e)pi\ qro/nou: makes e)/nqa more definite, cf. e)/nqa ke leczi/mhn koi/lh para\ nhi/ g 365.—ou)de\ ktl.: i.e. nor did she fail to see.
mi/n: proleptic obj., cf. 2.409.—The poet has to inform his hearers whether the gods were acquainted with the boulh/ of Zeus, and what their feelings were concerning it.
i)dou=sa: when she saw him, see on v. 138.
a)rguro/peza: standing epith. of Thetis. The compound adj. contains a comparison, “with feet white as silver.” cf. ‘Thetis' tinsel-slipper'd feet’ Milton Comus 877.
a(li/oio ge/rontos: see on v. 358.
au)ti/ka: straightway; without de/, as v. 386; see § 2 n.
kertomi/oisi: neut. adj. as subst., cf. e)mo/n v. 526, *g 69, meilixi/oisi *d 256, o)neidei/oisin *d 497, e)pe/essi malakoi=sin v. 582; see on v. 54.
ti/s dh\ au)= qew=n: what one of the gods now, this time. This is uttered in a vexed tone; cf. v. 202.
ai)ei/: contrasted with ou)de/ ti/ pw, cf. vs. 106 f.
e)o/nta: naturally would agree with toi/ preceding, but is attracted to the usual case of the subj. of the inf., the poet having the inf. const. already in mind.

krupta/dia . . . dikaze/men: consider and decide upon secret plans; cf. the words of Hera kei=nos (Zeus) de\ ta\ a(\ frone/wn e)ni\ qumw=| | *trwsi/ te kai\ *danaoi=si dikaze/tw, w(s e)pieike/s *q 430 f. let him, considering these his own affairs in his mind, decide between the Trojans and the Danaï, as is seemly.
pro/frwn: see on v. 77.
te/tlhkas: hast had the heart.
path\r ktl.: see on v. 503.
mh\ dh/: see on v. 131.
mu/qous: i.e. thoughts, plans, as the content of speech; cf. mu/qoisin e)/pessi/ te soi=sin a)kou/wn | te/rpomai d 597 f. I delight in thy thoughts and words.

ei)dh/sein: parallel form of ei)/sesqai, § 34 k.—xalepoi\ ktl.: sc. ei)de/nai. The pers. const. is used as v. 589, r(hi/teroi polemi/zein h)=san *)axaioi/ *s 258 the Achaeans were easier to fight with, xalepoi\ de\ qeoi\ fai/nesqai e)nargei=s *u 131. H. 944.
o(/n: sc. mu=qon.
e)pieike/s: sc. h)=|, as ta/ t) e)/ldetai o(/s k) e)pideuh/s (h)=|) 5.481.
a)koue/men: with indef. subj., tina/.
e)/peita: then, since the rel. prot. is hypothetical.
Zeus, in his excitement, passes at once to apply his principle to the present situation, instead of giving to the apod. a general form corresponding to the prot.
tau=ta: refers to Hera's question, v. 540.
e(/kasta: i.e. the details, exaggerated in his anger. —diei/reo ktl.: for the use of two verbs, cf. v. 553, nu=n d) e)qe/lw e)/pos a)/llo metallh=sai kai\ e)re/sqai g 243; see § 1 s.

bow=pis: ox-eyed; with deep, dark, majestically quiet eyes. This epith., like leukw/lenos v. 55, is almost peculiar to Hera; it is applied to two mortal women, *g 144, *h 10, and to one nymph, 18.40,—all in passages suspected of interpolation.
poi=on: pred. Equiv. to poi=os d mu=qo/s e)stin o(\n e)/eipes. This is a mere excl., and expects no answer; cf. oi(=on e)/eipen *b 194.

pa/ros: else, at other times; with the pres. tense; “I have not been wont.” In the same sense the pres. is used with pa/lai, esp. in tragedy.— ou)/te ktl.: emphatic repetition; the idea is negatived in every form, cf. v. 550.
a(/ss) e)qe/lh|sqa: for the cond. rel. sent., cf. vs. 218, 230, 543.
a(/ssa: for the form, see § 24 s.
e)qe/lh|sqa: for the ending, see §26 a, b.

After the rather harsh reply of Zeus, Hera plays one trump card after another, showing that she knew not only the person concerning whom she had asked (v. 540) but also what Thetis had requested, and what Zeus had promised.

parei/ph|: should persuade, i.e. lest it prove true that she has persuaded; anxiety about a fact of the past, for which the aor. ind. is used in dei/dw mh\ dh\ pa/nta qea\ nhmerte/a ei)=pen e 300, but cf. e)celqw/n tis i)/doi mh\ dh\ sxedo\n w)=si kio/ntes w 491.

556 = v. 538.—This is not spoken out of special animosity to Thetis, for whom in fact Hera had special affection; Hera claims Thetis as a sort of foster-child, h)\n e)gw\ au)th\ | qre/ya te kai\ a)ti/thla kai\ a)ndri\ po/ron para/koitin *w 59 f. whom I myself bred and cherished and gave as wife etc. According to a myth found in Pindar (Isth. viii. 30 ff.) and Aeschylus (Prom. 906 ff.), both Zeus and Poseidon strove together as rivals for the love of Thetis, but bestowed her upon Peleus on learning from Themis that this goddess of the sea was destined to bear a son mightier than the father.
h)eri/h: as v. 497.
soi/ ge: emphasized in reference to se/ v. 555.
Asyndeton, since the following is only a more distinct statement of the preceding, vs. 555 f.
e)th/tumon: cf. vs. 514, 526.
w(s timh/seis: that thou wilt honor.

timh/seis, o)le/seis: coincident actions, in chiastic position; for the chiasmus, see § 2 o; for the parataxis, see §3 q, t. Achilles was to be honored by the suffering of the Achaeans, who were to see how necessary he was to their success.
pole/as: pollou/s, see § 20 f.
*)axaiw=n: const. with nhusi/n (not pole/as), as is indicated by the order of words, and by the freq. repetition of the phrase e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n, v. 12, 2.8, 17, 168.
ai)ei\ ktl.: always art thou thinking. An echo of the o)i/w of v. 558, showing vexation; cf. ai)ei/ v. 107.
ou)de/ se lh/qw: “thou art always watching me.”
e)/mphs: in spite of all, nevertheless, like o(/mws which is found in Homer only 12.393.
a)po\ qumou=: far from my heart, affection, cf. a)poqu/mia e)/rdein *c 261, e)k qumou= pese/ein *y 595. For this use of a)po/, cf. *b 162, 292, fi/lwn a)/po ph/mata pa/sxei a 49.
to\ . . . e)/stai: as v. 325.
kai\ r(i/gion: sc. than what now causes her ill humor.
ei) d) ou(/tw ktl.: the reply to v. 555 f. Sic voleo, sic jubeo.
me/llei: impers., cf. 2.116.
a)lla\ ktl.: the English idiom, “sit quiet and obey,” instead of the more usual Greek idiom ka/qhso peiqome/nh, see § 3 t.
a)ke/ousa: see on v. 34.
mh/: threatening, as v. 28.
ou): closely connected with the verb.
xrai/smwsin: ward off.

a)=sson i)o/nta: him who comes near, implying injury or attack. The acc. follows xrai/smwsin on the analogy of xraisme/w tini/ ti, *h 143 f., w(\s a)/ra toi=s ou)/ tis du/natai xraismh=sai o)/leqron *l 120, nh/pios, ou)de/ ti/ oi( xraismh/sei lugro\n <*>)/le- qron *u 296.—o(/te . . . e)fei/w [e)fw=, cf. e)rei/omen v. 62]: this explains a)=sson i)o/nta, cf. potide/gmenon (awaiting) ai)ei\ | lugrh\n a)ggeli/hn, o(/t) a)pofqime/noio pu/qhtai *t 336 f.—For the thought, cf. vs. 588 ff., 15.16 ff., 164 ff.
xei=ras e)fei/w: cf. xei=ras e)poi/sei v. 89.
e)pigna/myasa: cf. 2.14. For the hiatus before it, justified by the caesural pause, see § 9 b.
a)na\ dw=ma: cf. a)na\ strato/n vs. 10, 53.
*ou)rani/wnes: like e)poura/nioi, inhabitants of heaven; see on 2.491; § 21 a.
571-600. Hephaestus reconciles his parents.
toi=sin: as v. 68.—The amusing figure of Hephaestus as butler is introduced in order to give a more cheerful character to the assembly of the gods, after the quarrel.
e)pi\ fe/rwn: generally with a notion of hostility, as v. 89; but here with h)=ra.
ta/de: here. *h. 695 a.
a)nekta/: pred.; from a)ne/xw, cf. a)na/sxeo v. 586.
ei) dh/: if in truth now, as v. 61.
e(/neka qnhtw=n: contemptuously, cf. 8.427 f.; at greater length, 21.462 ff.
kolw|o\n e)lau/neton: carry on a brawl, by wrangling; cf. 2.212.
daito/s: here first do we learn that the gods were feasting at this time.

576 = Od. 18.404.—ta\ xerei/ona ktl.: cf. nika=| d) e)n po/lei ta\ xei/rona Soph. Frag. 194. In such contrasts, the dem. and the adj. have the force of a rel. clause, cf. v. 106. The art. strengthens the contrast, cf. *k 237, r 415, s 229.
kai\ au)th=| per: with Homeric refinement, the speaker intimates that his counsel is not needed.
au)=te: i.e. as often before.
su/n: const. with tara/ch| as 8.86; cf. su/n g) o(/rki) e)/xeuan *d 269, su\n de\ nefe/essi ka/luyen i 68.
h(mi=n: dat<*>. of disadvantage.
ei)/ per: if only.

e)qe/lh|sin: the verb for emphasis here precedes its subj., see § 1 j; or *)olu/mpios ktl. can be taken as in appos. with the subj. of e)qe/lh|sin.—*)olu/mpios ktl.: indicates his exalted power, although in v. 609 this expression is used without special reference to the circumstances of the case.
a)sterophth/s: for Zeus as god of the lightning and storm, see on 2.146.
e)c e(de/wn: see on v. 534.—The conclusion of the sent. is omitted (a)posiw/phsis): “it will be the worse for us,” or “he can, for,” etc. See on v. 136.
kaqa/ptesqai: always metaphorical, as here. Inf. for the imv. as v. 323.
The preceding inf. represents a cond.; hence no conj. is needed to connect the verses, cf. v. 303.
i(/laos: cf. i(lassa/menoi v. 100, v. 147.
e)n xeiri\ ti/qei: placed in her hand; generally used of presenting a cup of wine. e)n xersi\ ti/qhmi is used of gifts or prizes, cf. v. 441.
a)na/sxeo: lit. hold thyself up, endure, be patient.
mh/: on v. 28.
fi/lhn per e)ou=san: very dear as thou art; pe/r strengthens, as v. 352 and freq.
e)n o)fqalmoi=sin: before my eyes, as 3.306, cf. *g 169, *s 135, 190, e)n o)fqalmoi=si noh/sas *w 294, 312; see § 1 v.
xraismei=n: as v. 242.—a)rgale/os ktl.: pers. const. as v. 546, a)rgale/os ga/r t) e)sti\ qeo\s brotw=| a)ndri\ damh=nai d 397 “it is hard for a god to be overcome by a mortal man.”
h)/dh . . . a)/llote: as 14.249.
podo/s: for the gen., see on v. 323.

tetagw/n: redup. 2d aor., see § 25 j; from the root of tangere.— a)po\ bhlou= ktl.: from the mighty threshold of Olympus; cf. 15.23, where Zeus says: o(
 de\ la/boimi, | r(i/ptaskon tetagw
 a)po\ bhlou=, <*>)/fr) a)
 i(/khtai | gh=n o)lighpele/wn (with little strength).

pa=n d) h)=mar: cf. panhme/rioi v. 472, v. 601.—fero/mhn, ka/ppeson [kate/peson]: the impf. is used of the continuance of the motion, the aor. marks the conclusion of it, cf. (i(/ppous) *ou)lumpo/nde di/wke qew=n d) e)ci/keto qw/kous *q 439, *b 94.
fero/mhn: is freq. used of ships driven by the wind, and marks the motion as involuntary.
katadu/nti: the aor. partic. is here used (without reference to time as past, present, or future) of an act coincident with ka/ppeson.

e)n *lh/mnw|: for the dat. of rest after a verb of motion, cf. 3.89; see G. 191, N. 6; H. 788. Hephaestus had his workshop on Olympus, 18.369 ff., but Lemnos was considered his island, —a belief to which the volcanic mountain Mosychlos gave rise.

qumo/s: anima.—At another time, apparently when an infant, Hephaestus was cast out of heaven by his mother, and saved by Thetis, 18.395 ff.—cf. ‘Nor was his name unheard or unador'd | In ancient Greece; and in Ausonian land | Men call'd him Mulciber; and how he fell | From heaven they fabled, thrown by angry Jove | Sheer o'er the crystal battlements; from morn | To noon he fell, from noon to dewy eve, | A summer's day; and with the setting sun | Dropt from the zenith like a falling star, | On Lemnos, the Aegean isle.’ Milton Par. Lost i. 740 ff.
*si/nties a)/ndres: the earliest population of the island; to judge from their name they were marauding (si/nomai) Pelasgians who had emigrated from Thrace.
a)/far: const. with peso/nta, cf. v. 349.
komi/santo: took me up and cared for me, cf. k 73, 298, e)/nqa me *qesprwtw=n basileu\s e)komi/ssato c 316. cf. also *b 183, *g 378.
meidh/sasa: inceptive, smiling, repeats the preceding mei/dhsen; see § 2 q.
paido/s: ablatival gen., from her son, depending on e)de/cato, as ku/pellon e)de/cato h(=s a)lo/xoio *w 305.
xeiri/: local, with e)de/cato, cf. la/zeto xer<*>si/n *e 365 took in his hands.

e)nde/cia: from left to right, through the company, according to established custom, cf. dei=c) e)nde/cia pa=sin *h 184, bh= d) i)/men ai)th/swn e)nde/cia fw=ta e(/kaston r 365, o)/rnusq) e(cei/hs e)pide/cia pa/ntes e(tai=roi f 141. See on v. 471.

oi)noxo/ei ne/ktar: cf. (*(/hbh) ne/ktar e)w|noxo/ei *d 3, ne/ktar oi)noxoeu=sa Sappho Frag. 5; the meaning of the first part of the compound was overlooked; cf. i(/ppoi boukole/onto *u 221, oi)kodomei=n tei=xos, aedificare naves, ‘tin box,’ ‘weekly journal.’
krhth=ros: the red nectar of the gods, like the wine of men, was mixed with water before it was drunk, cf. ke/rasse de\ ne/ktar e)ruqro/n e 93.
a)fu/sswn: see on v. 471.
a)/sbestos: hence the proverbial ‘Homeric laughter.’
dw/mata: palace, hall.

poipnu/onta: a reduplicated collateral form of pne/w.—The laughter arose because of the striking contrast between the puffing, hobbling Hephaestus as cupbearer, and the graceful Hebe (4.2 f.) or Ganymede (20.234) who usually performed that office.
h)=mar: acc. of duration of time.
ou) me/n [mh/n]: as vs. 154, 163.
fo/rmiggos: cf. molph/ t) o)rxhstu/s te: ta\ ga/r t) a)naqh/mata daito/s a 152 song and dance, for these are the accompaniments of the feast, Od. 8.99.

a)meibo/menai: so at the death of Achilles, mou=sai d) e)nne/a pa=sai a)meibo/menai o)pi\ kalh=| | qrh/neon w 60 f. They sing alternately, one relieving the other, as the rhapsodes at the festivals; cf. incipe, Damoeta, tu deinde sequere, Menalca, | alternis dicetis, amant alterna Camenae Verg. Ecl. iii. 59. cf. ‘Divinely warbled voice | Answering the stringed noise,’ Milton Christmas Hymn 96 f.
au)ta/r: correl. with me/n v. 601. —lampro\n ktl.: the verse closes as *e 120, *q 485.
kakkei/ontes: for the form as fut. of kata/keimai, see § 30 h.
e(/kastos: part. app. with oi(, giving prominence to the individual, after the collective expression. cf. 2.775, and 3.1 (where the plural is used).
i)dui/h|si prapi/dessin: as 18.380, 482.
koima=to: was wont to lie.—o(/te ktl.: whenever etc.; the cond. rel. sent. expressing indefinite frequency of past action. This iterative opt. is more freq. after the rel. pron. than with the conj.
kaqeu=de: slept, as *w 675, eu(=de *i 663; cf. e)/nq) a)/ra kai\ to/t) e)/lekto kai\ *)hw= di=an e)/mimnen t 50.
a)naba/s: of ascending a couch, only here and o(mo\n le/xos ei)sanabai/noi *q 291. No special height of couch is to be inferred.
para\ de/: adv., beside him.

xruso/qronos: cf. the similar attributes of the divinities; xrusa/oros with golden sword of Apollo, *e 509; xrushla/katos with golden arrow of Artemis, d 122; xrusope/dilos golden-sandalled of Hera, l 604; xruso/pteros goldenwinged of Iris, *q 398; xruso/rrapis with golden wand of Hermes, Od. 5.87. See on v. 37. The throne was covered with thin plates of gold.

Zeus prepares to fulfil his promise to Thetis (1.509 f., 523) by sending a dream to Agamemnon. The intended battle, which is to be disastrous to the Achaeans, is delayed by a test of the disposition of the army; the Greek and Trojan forces do not advance to meet each other until the close of the book (vs. 780, 809 f.).— The events narrated in B occupy the first part of the 22d day of the action of the Iliad.
Vs. 1-86. The dream of Agamemnon (vs. 1-41) and the council of the chiefs.
r(a/: refers to 1.606-611.—qeoi\ ktl.: appos. with a)/lloi.

pannu/xioi: see on 1.424.—ou)x e)/xe ktl.: i.e. he did not sleep; cf. ou)de\ *poseida/wna ge/lws e)/xe q 344 “but Poseidon did not laugh.” For the contrast of this verse with the preceding, cf. e)/nqa de\ koimh/santo kai\ u(/pnou dw=ron e(/lonto *i 713, a)/lloi me
 para\ nhusi
 a)risth=es *panaxaiw=n | eu(=don pannu/xioi, malakw=| dedmhme/noi u(/pnw|: | a)ll) ou)k *)atrei/dhn *)agame/mnona poime/na law=n | u(/pnos e)/xe glukero/s, polla\ fresi
 o(rmai/nonta *k 1 ff.
fre/na w(s: hiatus allowed at the bucolic diaeresis, see § 9 b.
w(s: how, sc. in accordance with his promise to Thetis.

timh/sh| ktl.: see on 1.559. Deliberative subjv. after a secondary tense in the principal clause, as fra/zeto (sc. Zeus) qumw=| . . . h)\ h)/dh kai\ kei=non (Patroclus) . . . fai/dimos *(/ektwr | xalkw=| dh|w/sh| a)po/ t) w)/mwn teu/xe) e(/lhtai *p 646 ff. The dir. question would be pw=s timh/sw;
h(/de: this. The subj. is attracted to the gender of boulh/, the pred., cf. v. 73, 1.239.
pe/myai ktl.: in appos. with h(/de, cf. to\ me\n ou)de\ no/hsen | mhrou= e)ceru/sai do/ru *e 665 f. but he did not think of this —to draw the spear out of his thigh.

ou)=lon o)/neiron: a baneful dream; a deceptive, illusory vision, instead of a kindly dream of warning. cf. (*zeu\s) e)capata=| to
 *)agame/mnona o)/neiro/n tina yeudh= e)pipe/myas, w(s polloi\ tw=n *)axaiw=n a)poqa/noien Lucian Jup. trag. 40. On the deceitful measures of Zeus, cf. 4.64 ff., where Zeus sends Athene to the Trojan army to incite an archer to wound Menelaus, and break a truce. —Homer elsewhere knows of no dream gods but only individual dreams; cf. 1.63. Not all dreams were thought to be significant. cf. h)= toi me
 o)/neiroi a)mh/xanoi a)krito/muqoi (cf. v. 246) | gi/gnont), ou)de/ ti pa/nta telei/etai a)nqrw/poisin. | doiai\ ga/r te pu/lai a)menhnw=n ei)si
 o)nei/rwn, ktl. t 560 ff.
7 = 1.201; see note.—For the two accs., one of the person (direct obj.) and the other of the thing (cognate acc.), cf. vs. 22, 59, 156, 1.201.

ba/sk) i)/qi: up and go, a formula used by Zeus in addressing his messengers; said to Iris, *q 399, *l 186, *o 158, *w 144; to Hermes, 24.336; cf. vade age, nate, voca Zephyros Verg. Aen. iv. 223. For the asyndeton, cf. 1.99, 363.
ou)=le: sc. for the Achaeans.
ma/la: const. with pa/nta.
a)goreue/men: as imv., cf. 1.582.
ke/leue: note the lack of connectives.

ka/rh komo/wntas: a frequent epith. of the Achaeans. Among them to cut the hair was a sign of mourning, cf. 23.46, 135 f., 141, d 198, w 46. Achilles's hair which he cuts off at the funeral pile of Patroclus is called thleqo/wsa *y 142, luxuriant, and the hair of the other heroes ‘floated in the breeze,’ 23.367. Paris is proud of his hair, 3.55. Apollo is a)kerseko/mhs *u 39 (Milton's ‘unshorn Apollo’). On archaic works of art the men are always represented with long hair. See on v. 872. The Euboean Abantes are o)/piqen komo/wntes v. 542; their back hair only was long, their front hair was ‘banged’ (see on v. 542; of course, no Chinese cue is to be thought of in their case). The Thracians are a)kro/komoi *d 533, with their hair bound in a knot on top of the head; cf. apud Suevos, usque ad canitiem, horrentem capillum retro sequuntur, ac saepe in ipso solo vertice religant Tac. Germ. 38. Thucydides (i. 6) says it was not long since the ‘gentlemen of the old school’ had given up wearing their hair in a knot fastened by a golden cicada. The Spartans retained to a late period the custom of wearing long hair. Before the battle of Thermopylae, the Persian scouts saw the Spartans combing their hair (Hdt. vii. 208), preparing for glorious victory or honorable death. Among the Hebrews, the long hair of Absalom is familiar to us. In the later classical period, fashions changed. Only dandies wore long hair at Athens in the time of Aristophanes; and in the post-classical period St. Paul could write to the Corinthians: ou)de\ h( fu/sis au)th\ dida/skei u(ma=s o(/ti a)nh\r me\n e)a=n koma=|, a)timi/a au)tw=| e)stin 1 Cor. xi. 14.
ni=n ktl.: transition to the dir. const.; see on 1.401.
po/lin *trw/wn: not as 1.164.
a)mfi\s fra/zontai: think two ways, i.e. are divided in mind, sc. about the destruction of Troy. For the s of a)mfi/s, see § 13 o.—*)olu/mpia ktl.: cf. v. 484, 1.18.
e)pe/gnamyen: cf. 1.569. This statement is intended only for Agamemnon, not for the Dream.
e)fh=ptai: are fastened upon; impend.
a)mbro/sios: used like a)/mbrotos and qei=os, of everything attractive and refreshing that comes from the gods; only here, of sleep.

ke/xuto: had poured itself out, like an enveloping cloud; cf. v. 34, u(/pnon | h(du\n e)pi\ blefa/roisi ba/le glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh a 363 f., (u(/pnos) nh/dumos a)mfixuqei/s *c 253, u(/pnon xeu/h| *c 164.

u(pe\r kefalh=s: every Homeric dream appears above the head and takes a familiar form; cf. 23.65 ff., *w 682, d 796 ff., Od. 6.21 ff., Od. 20.32, (Iris) devolat, et supra caput astitit Verg. Aen. iv. 702.

*nhlhi/w| ui(=i: to the son of Neleus. The adj. is equiv. to a gen., cf. vs. 54, 416, 465, 528, 604, 3.180.—The Dream took this form in order not to terrify the king, and to persuade him most readily.
to/n r(a: whom, you know.

gero/ntwn: the nobles without regard to age formed a boulh/ (see v. 53); cf. the Spartan gerousi/a, senatus, aldermen; ‘the elders of Moab’ Numbers xxii. 7 are identical with ‘the princes of Moab’ Numbers xxii. 8, 21. cf. dhmoge/rontes *g 149.
For the order of words, cf. 3.386.
mi/n: const. with prosefw/nee, cf. v. 795, 3.389.
eu(/deis ktl.: a reproach, for which the reason is given by a com monplace remark, v. 24. cf. nate dea, potes hoc sub casu ducere somnos? Verg. Aen. iv. 560.
dai+/fronos: fiery-hearted.
i(ppoda/moio: lit. master of horses, i.e. knight. Horse-tamer gives a false tone in Eng.

cu/nes: give ear, from cuni/hmi. The change from the character of Nestor to that of a messenger from Zeus, is suited to the nature of a dream; cf. the change from the form of Penelope's sister to a messenger of Athene, Od. 4.797, 829.
*dio\s de/: paratactic, instead of a causal clause, cf. 1.200.
toi/: for thee, “you may know”; ethical dat.
27 = 24.174, whence Aristarchus thought that this was borrowed.
seu=: depends on kh/detai, while se/ is implied as the obj. of e)leai/rei. See on 1.196. The care and sympathy of Zeus are motives to prompt Agamemnon to a speedy execution of the command.
28-32 = vs. 11-15, with slight change.

e)k *dio/s: with pass., in the sense of u(po\ *dio/s, indicating Zeus as the source of the woe; cf. fi/lhqen | e)k *dio/s vs. 668. f. they were loved by Zeus, ta\ me\n dh/ toi tete/lestai | e)k *dio/s *s 74 f. This use is freq. in tragedy, cf. Aesch. Prom. 224, 757, Soph. Ant. 63, 180, 207, 210, 293.
e)/xe: hold it fast, followed by a negative form of the same command, cf. 1.363.
a)nh/h|: cf. v. 2, th\n de\ gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ken s 199, o(/ntina/ g) u(/pnos e(/loi t 511, to\n u(/pnos e)/marpte u 56, ou)de/ min u(/pnos | h(/|rei pandama/twr *w 4 f. For the form, see § 34 e.
a)na\ qumo/n: through his heart; kata\ qumo/n is more freq., as 1.136, 193; cf. a)na\ strato/n and kata\ strato/n, on 1.10.
ou) e)/mellon: were not about to be, futed to be. The plural verb is often used in Homer with a neut. subj.; cf. vs. 135, 465; § 3 j.
fh=: i.e. thought, imagined, cf. 3.28. For the accent, cf. bh= *a 34.
o(/ ge: emphasized in contrast with *zeu/s v. 38.
h)/mati kei/nw|: emphatic, even on that day.

nh/pios: blind fool, infatuated, an appos. exclamation; a standing pred. of those who thoughtlessly and fearlessly enter on a course which ends in their ruin. cf. v. 873. It is explained by the following clause, cf. v. 112; see § 1 h. Cf. Vergil's demens! qui nimbos et non imitabile fulmen . . . simularat Aen. vi. 590 f.
e)/rga: attracted into the rel. clause.
qh/sein e)/pi: see on 1.509.
ga/r: for the quantity, see on 1.342.
e)/ti: i.e. before the capture of Troy.
*trwsi/ te ktl.: emphasizes the consequences of the boulh\ *dio/s, disastrous alike to both armies.
dia\ u(smi/nas: through the conflicts, “in the course of the battles.”

a)mfe/xuto: surrounded him, “rang in his ears,” i.e. he remembered it well; cf. v. 19. a)mfi/ seems to be used with reference to both ears, cf. h(/ tis (sc. a)oidh\) a)kouo/ntessi newta/th a)mfipe/lhtai a 352.
o)mfh/: the voice of the Dream.

e(/ceto: the heroes seem to have put on their tunics while sitting on the couch.—e)/ndune ktl.: the Homeric heroes had no special night gear, but slept naked (or at least without their outer garments), like the Eskimos and lower-class Italians of to-day, and like the English of the Middle Ages.—Epic simplicity describes the most trifling acts; see Cowper's note, § 1 a. Introd. p. 4.
kalo\n ktl.: for the epiths. at beginning of verse, see § 1 n.

fa=ros: for the accent, see §§ 2 w, 41 f g. This upper garment was put on when no armor was worn. The skin of some wild beast was sometimes worn in its stead, cf. *g 17, *k 23, 177 (lion's skin), 29 (leopard's skin). The Homeric hero generally carried a lance, even on a peaceful journey, cf. Od. 1.104, 256; but Agamemnon here takes his sword since he could not carry conveniently both lance and skh=ptron. The sword was little used in combat, but often worn, cf. ei(/mata e(ssa/menos, peri\ de\ ci/fos o)cu\ qe/t) w)/mw| b 3.
possi/: for the form, see § 12 e.
a)mfi\ ba/leto: the sword hung not from a belt, but from a strap which passed over one shoulder.
a)/ra: further, cf. vs. 546, 615.

a)rguro/hlon: the hilt is studded with silver nails, as a decoration, cf. *a 219, 246, a)mfi\ d) a)/r) w)/moisin ba/leto ci/fos: e)n de/ oi( h(=loi | xru/seioi pa/mfainon *l 29 f. This epith. is applied also to the qro/nos, *s 389.
a)/fqiton ai)ei/: ever imperishable, as the work of Hephaestus, and as ever in th<*> possession of the same family, cf. vs. 101 ff.; a symbol of their unending rule.
kata\ nh=as: cf. kata\ strato/n *a 318, kata\ lao/n v. 179, para\ nh=as *a 347; i.e. to the a)gora/ which was at the middle of the camp, see on 1.54.
*)axaiw=n xalkoxitw/nwn: used as gen. of e)uknh/mides *)axaioi/ v. 331.

prosebh/seto ktl.: i.e. illuminated the mountain of the gods on whose summit the first beams of light fell; cf. *)hw\s d) e)k lexe/wn par) a)gauou= *tiqwnoi=o | w)/rnuq), i(/n) a)qana/toisi fo/ws fe/roi h)de\ brotoi=sin *l 1 f., *)hw\s me\n kroko/peplos a)p) *)wkeanoi=o r(oa/wn w)/rnuq) (ktl., as 11.2) 19.2.
fo/ws: (fa/os, fw=s); for the form, cf. fo/wsde v. 309; see § 4 i.

e)re/ousa: to herald; cf. h)=mos d) *(ewsfo/ros (Lucifer, the morning star) ei)=si fo/ws e)re/wn e)pi\ gai=an, | o(/n te me/ta kroko/peplos u(pei\r a(/la ki/dnatai *)hw/s *y 226 f., a)sth\r . . . o(/s te ma/lista | e)/rxetai a)gge/llwn fa/os h)ou=s n 93 f.
o(: Agamemnon.
53-86. The Council.

boulh\n gero/ntwn: council of the chiefs (elders, on v. 21) who discussed important questions before presenting them to the popular assembly. Allusions to this council are found in vs. 143, 194. Who constituted it is not clear; prob. not many; perhaps only six besides the Atridae, cf. vs. 404 ff.
megaqu/mwn: in pl. elsewhere only as epith. of peoples, as 1.123.
i(=ze: caused to hold a session, called a council.
basilh=os: in appos. with *ne/storos implied in *nestore/h|, see on v. 20.
55 = 10.302.—pukinh\n ktl.: prepared, formed, the prudent plan, which he afterwards unfolds; cf. mu/qous kai\ mh/dea u(/fainon *g 212.
e)nu/pnion: cognate acc., adv.; equiv. to e)n u(/pnw|. cf. e)fe/stioi v. 125, e)nari/qmios v. 202, e)pixqo/nioi *a 272. H. 588.
a)mbrosi/hn: see on v. 19; stand ing epith. of night as a gift of the gods for the refreshment of man's nature, with special reference to sleep, cf. kai\ u(/pnou dw=ron e(/lonto *h 482.
ma/lista: strengthens a)/gxista, cf. v. 220.
cf. Od. 6.152.—ei)=dos ktl.: see on 1.115.
a)/gxista: nearest, i.e. most exactly, as *c 474, n 80, marks the degree of resemblance.
me\, mu=qon: for the two accs., see on v. 7.
60-70 = vs. 23-33. Epic poetry prefers these verbal repetitions to the use of ‘indirect discourse,’ see § 1 c; cf. 3.71 ff. with 92 ff., 255 ff.
w)/|xet) a)popta/menos: flew away, see on 1.391.
a)nh=ken: as v. 34. cf. nox Aeneam somnusque reliquit Verg. Aen. viii. 67.
a)ll) a)/gete: see on 1.62.—ai)/ ken ktl.: see on 1.66.

peirh/somai: will put them to the test. Agamemnon wished to be assured that the army was still ready for the fray; it had become demoralized by the length of the war, by the pestilence, and by the quarrel and the withdrawal from service of Achilles.

h(\ qe/mis e)sti/n: i.e. as the general has the right. qe/mis is properly what has been laid down, right sanctioned by custom and the law of nature. It is often used in Homer like di/kh, kata\ moi=ran. The rel. is attracted to the gender of the pred., as v. 5.

kai/: introduces a more definite statement of peirh/somai, cf. vs. 114, 132, 251.—feu/gein ktl.: this proposition is intended to touch their sense of honor and rouse anew their martial zeal. ui(=as *)axaiw=n is supplied from v. 72 as the subj. of feu/gein and the obj. of the following e)rhtu/ein.—su
 nhusi/: cf. Nestor's words au	a e)gw\ su
 nhusi
 a)olle/sin (all together), ai(/ moi e(/ponto, | feu=gon g 165 f., 1.170, 179.
a)/lloqen a)/llos: aliunde alius, from different sides, each from his own place; cf. *i 671, i 493, k 442.
e)rhtu/ein: seek to restrain from flight.
76 = 1.68. He had risen to speak at v. 55, though this act is not mentioned as usual.

h)maqo/entos: here as an adj. of two endings, cf. v. 503 and note, vs. 570, 695, 742; see § 20 a. This use of adjs. in -eis, as of two endings, is confined to geographical names; and the gender may have been different in the poet's age and dialect.
See on 1.73.
79 = *i 17, *k 533, *l 276, 587, *r 248, *x 378. Conventional form of address to the princes; the corresponding address to the warriors is w)= fi/loi, h(/rwes *danaoi/, qera/pontes *)/arhos v. 110.
me/dontes: rulers, cf. *)/idhqen mede/wn *g 320 and the proper name *me/dousa, equiv. to *krei/ousa (Creusa).
yeu=do/s ken fai=men: sc. ei)=nai, we might say (potential) that it (i.e. what the Dream promised) was a deceit, cf. v. 349.

kai\ nosfizoi/meqa: and might turn away, i.e. be on our guard against the Dream's questionable counsel to try a decisive battle at this time when the mightiest of the Achaeans held aloof from the fight.
ma=llon: all the more, as 5.208; since they could put no real confidence in the Dream's message.
nu=n de/: see on 1.354.—a)/ristos ktl.: as 1.91; cf. v. 197.
83 = v. 72.—The answer of the generally loquacious Nestor is remarkably brief; he gives courteous assent in the very words of the king, without saying a word about the proposition.
e)pane/sthsan: thereupon rose, i.e. likewise, cf. stena/xwn mete/fh krei/wn *)agame/mnwn | . . . e)pestena/xonto d) e(tai=roi *d 153 f.
pei/qonto: they made no objection but prepared to go to the popular assembly.
poime/ni law=n: Agamemnon, as v. 243.
skhptou=xoi: see on 1.15.
Vs. 87-154. Assembly of the people. Agamemnon's speech and its effect.
h)u/te: introduces a detailed comparison, as v. 455, 3.3; see §2 g, h.
e)/qnea: swarms. For the following weak hiatus, see § 41 f d.
ei)=si: retains its force as a present esp. in comparisons, cf. 3.61.

melissa/wn: i.e. wild bees which live in hollow trees and in holes in the rock.—For the comparison of bees cf. ac veluti in pratis ubi apes aestate serena | floribus insidunt variis, et candida circum | lilia funduntur; strepit omnis murmure campus Verg. Aen. vi. 707 ff.; ‘as bees | In spring-time when the sun with Taurus rides, | Pour forth their populous youth about the hive | In clusters; they among fresh dews and flowers | Fly to and fro . . . So thick the airy crowd swarm'd.’ Milton Par. Lost i. 768 ff.
ai)ei\ ne/on: ever anew, illae (bees) continuo saltus silvasque peragrant Verg. Georg. iv. 53.
botrudo/n: in clusters, like bunches of grapes; cf. lentis uvam demittere ramis Verg. Georg. iv. 558.
e)p) a)/nqesin: to the flowers.
e)/nqa a(/lis: for the hiatus, see §§ 9 f, 14.
pepothatai: from pe/tomai, have taken to flight, are in flight, cf. yuxh\ d) h)u/t) o)/neiros a)poptame/nh pepo/thtai l 222.
w(/s: the point of comparison lies in the coming forth and approach in separate crowds (swarms); botrudo/n v. 89 and i)lado/n v. 93 have the same position in the verse.
propa/roiqe: before, i.e. along.
baqei/hs: deep bayed, extended, cf. baqe/hs e)ca/lletai au)lh=s *e 142 (a lion) leaps out of the deep farmyard; for the form, see § 20 c.
e)stixo/wnto: as 3.266.

o)/ssa: rumor, whose source is unknown and which is therefore ascribed to the gods (*dio\s a)/ggelos), cf. h)/n ti/s toi ei)/ph|si brotw=n h)\ o)/ssan a)kou/sh|s | e)k *dio/s a 282 f., fh/mh e)se/ptato e)s to\ strato/pedon Hdt. ix. 100.
dedh/ein: had blazed forth as a fire; from dai/w.
o)tru/nous) i)e/nai: they conjectured that Agamemnon would propose some important measure.
a)ge/ronto: they came together; the aor. after the descriptive impfs. marks the conclusion of the movement, cf. v. 99, *a 592, *g 78.
tetrh/xei: moved in confusion, was in commotion; from tara/ssw.— u(po/: adv., beneath.
law=n i(zo/ntwn: gen. abs., although it might be affected by u(po/, see § 3 f g.
e)rh/tuon: impf. of attempted action.—ei) po/te ktl.: a wish, on the part of the heralds. “If ever they would stop their clamor.”
a)uth=s: ablatival gen. with sxoi/ato, cf. v. 275.
sxoi/ato: might cease from, as 3.84, cf. v. 275.
diotrefe/wn: as 1.176.
spoudh=|: with difficulty, scarcely.
e)rh/tuqen: e)rhtu/qhsan. For the aor. see on v. 94; for the pl. with the collective lao/s, cf. v. 278, h( plhqu\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n a)pone/onto *o 305, *y 157 (on 1.150).
kaq) e(/dras: along the rows of seats, on the seats, as v. 211; for the use of kata/, cf. v. 47, 3.326.
a)na/: adv. with e)/sth, cf. a)ne/sth v. 76.
to\ me/n: anaphoric, as 1.234.
ka/me teu/xwn: wrought with toil; the principal idea is in the partic. as *a 168, e)/kamon qe/ousai *d 244, and freq. See § 3 v.
dw=ke: for the repetition, see on 1.436.
a)rgeifo/nth|: used of Hermes 27 times in Homer. It is best rendered as a proper name. Its derivation is uncertain. Homer shows no knowledge of the Argus myth.

*(ermei/as ktl.: Hermes, the messenger of the gods, bore the skh=ptron from Zeus to Pelops, as a symbol of empire. The kingdom descended with the sceptre. Pelops, son of Tantalus, went from Lydia to Elis, won the hand of the princess Hippodamia in a chariot race (hence plh/cippos, equiv. to i(ppo/ta, i(ppo/damos, i(pphla/ta), established his rule, and gave its name to Peloponnesus (a name not found in Homer).
o( au)=te: for the hiatus, see on 1.333.
*pe/loy: in app. with d, see § 24 k.
qnh/skwn e)/lipen: cf. moriens dat habere nepoti Verg. Aen. ix. 362, Goethe's ‘dem sterbend seine Buhle | einen goldnen Becher gab.’

*que/sta: *que/sths, for the form, see § 16 b. Thyestes was brother of Atreus, Homer evidently does not know the (later) story of their mutual hatred that was the subject of tragedies by Sophocles and Euripides. The feud became proverbial as a chapter of unrivalled horrors.
lei=pe forh=nai: cf. dw=ke d) *)ereuqali/wni . . . forh=nai *h 149.
forh=nai: for the form, see § 29 j.

pollh=|si, panti/: according to the poet's view of the situation at the time of the Trojan war, cf. 1.78 f., *i 69, i 263, the Pelopidae seem to have had the hegemony in Peloponnesus; Agamemnon ruled over Achaea, Corinth, Sicyon, and part of Argolis, see vs. 569 ff.
*)/argei+: local, cf. e)n *)/argei+ *a 30.
a)na/ssein: to rule over them. For the inf., cf. ma/xesqai *a 8, a)/gein *a 338.
tw=|: local, cf. w)/moisin *a 45.
e)reisa/menos: not an attrib. partic. with o(/ ge, but a pred. partic. of manner; cf. koirane/wn v. 207.
qera/pontes *)/arhos: see on 1.176; cf. o)/zos *)/arhos v. 540.

For this lo/gos e)sxhmatisme/nos, cf. the speeches of Clearchus and his e)gke/leustoi, Xen. An. i. 3. 9 f.
