Agamemnon does not desire his arguments to be convincing; he reminds his men covertly of the promise of Zeus that they should capture Troy, and that nine years of the ten were already past; he calls that man duskle/a who returns to Argos with his end unattained, esp. since they had already remained so long before Ilios; he exaggerates the disparity of numbers of Achaeans and Trojans.

me/ga e)ne/dhse: fast entangled. Agamemnon in testing the temper of his army complains of his infatuation only as a pretence; in v. 114 he utters unconsciously the unpleasant truth, while in the Ninth Book he uses the same words in bitter earnest.
sxe/tlios: terrible, cruel god. See on v. 38.—u(pe/sxeto ktl.: see on 1.514.
e)kpe/rsanta: for the acc., cf. 1.541. The partic. here contains the leading thought; they were to sack Troy before their return; see § 3 v.

a)pone/esqai: always stands at the close of the verse, with lengthened initial syllable (§ 41 g). For the pres. inf. after u(pe/sxeto, cf. u(po/sxhtai to/de e)/rgon | a)/ndras dusmene/as skopiaze/men (spy out) 10.39 f.
nu=n ktl.: “but now I see that he planned” etc.
a)pa/thn: the poet's hearer thought esp. of the deceitful Dream, but this was not in Agamemnon's mind here.
kai/: introduces a specification of his general statement, as v. 74.
keleu/ei: he infers this direction from their lack of success.
duskle/a: emphatic position. The hiatus may be explained as weak (§ 9 d), a_ losing half its quantity (but see § 18 l).—polu\n ktl.: sc. in battle and in the plague.
me/llei: is about to be, doubtless is, cf. *a 564, me/llen me/n pote oi)=kos o(/d) a)fneio\s kai\ a)mu/mwn | e)/mmenai a 232 f. doubtless this house was etc.
dh/: h)/dh as vs. 134 f.
kate/luse ka/rhna: overthrew the heads, i.e. the citadels; cf. o(/te *troi/hs lu/omen lipara\ krh/demna (lit. head-bands) n 388, *p 100.
e)/ti kai/: hereafter also, cf. 1.96. —tou= ktl.: cf. rerum cui summa potestas Verg. Aen. x. 100, a 70, *i 25, 39, *n 484, *w 293, 311.
ga/r: refers to duskle/a v. 115.
to/de ge: “if anything is a disgrace, this is.”—kai\ ktl.: even for future generations to learn, cf. (*)axaioi\) oi)/sousi kle/os eu)ru\ kai\ e)ssome/noisi puqe/sqai g 204.
toio/nde toso/nde: with deictic -de, so brave and so many as we here, cf. v. 799, qualis quantusque Verg. Aen. iii. 641.
a)/prhkton: pred.; lit. unaccomplished, without result, fruitless, cf. v. 452.
po/lemon polemi/zein: cognate acc., cf. ma/xhn e)ma/xonto *m 175.—polemi/zein ktl.: as v. 452, 3.67, 435.

paurote/roisi: cf. *trw=es d) au)=q) e(te/rwqen a)na\ pto/lin w(pli/zonto | pauro/teroi, me/masan de\ kai\ w(\s u(smi=ni ma/xesqai | xreioi= a)nagkai/h| (of stern necessity), pro/ te pai/dwn kai\ pro\ gunaikw=n *q 55 ff., oi( de\ ma/xontai (sc. *trw=es) | pauro/teroi pleo/nessi *n 738 f., 15.407.—te/los ktl.: no end has yet appeared; a fuller expression for a)/prhkton, instead of “without attaining our end,” “without gaining decisive victory.”

ei)/ per ga\r ktl.: in case we should wish, a concessive clause with potential opt. and ke/, of what is conditionally conceivable, cf. *q 205, *n 288, b 246.—The thought is completed in v. 127, “if we should take only one Trojan as cupbearer for a squad of Achaeans.”
ga/r: refers to paurote/roisi.

o(/rkia tamo/ntes: o(/rkion is strictly what belongs to the o(/rkos (cf. i(sti/a *a 480), thus the victim slain to confirm a solemn oath. The victim's throat was cut (*g 292, *t 197, 266), hence o(/rkia tamei=n was to make a solemn treaty, like foedus icere, ferire foedus; cf. *g 73, 94, 105, *d 155, *t 191.
a)/mfw: dual with reference to the two nations.
*trw=es me/n: sc. k) e)qe/loien.— le/casqai: collect themselves, as *q 519, w 108.—e)fe/stioi ktl.: equiv. to oi(\ nai/ousi kata\ pto/lin v. 130.
o(/ssoi: the rel. pron. follows the emphatic word, as *a 32, pa/nta ga\r ou) kako/s ei)mi, met) a)ndra/sin o(/ssoi a)/eqloi (“in all the games of men”) Od. 8.214.

diakosmhqei=men: should be divided and arranged, cf. disponere. For the transition to the finite const., see on 1.401. For kosme/w of marshalling troops, instead of the Attic ta/ssw (§ 2 v), cf. vs. 476, 554, 3.1.
a)/ndra: cf. v. 198.
e(/kastoi: i.e. each squad of ten; in appos. with *)axaioi/. The pl. is used because of the number in each company, cf. 3.1.
deuoi/ato: Att. de/ointo (de/oien), see §§5 f, g, 26 t.

to/sson ple/as: according to 8.562 f., there were 50,000 Trojans and allies. For the numbers of the Achaeans, see on v. 494 ff. For the form ple/as (ple/onas), cf. ple/es *l 395, and see § 22 h. This form is found also in an Aeolic inscription of Mitylene.
e)pi/kouroi: pred., as allies. Obs. the strong contrast with *trw/wn.
polle/wn e)k poli/wn: const. with a)/ndres. For the similarity of sound of the two words (parechesis) see § 2 a.
e)/neisin: are therein, cf. v. 803, oi(/ pe/r t) e)pi/kouroi e)/neimen *e 477, e)n ga/r oi( (Ilios) pole/es te kai\ a)/lkimoi a)ne/res ei)me/n *f 586.
me/ga pla/zousi: drive me far away, i.e. hinder my attaining my end; cf. 1.59. For the adv. use of me/ga, see on 1.78.
ou)k ei)w=si (from e)a/w): do not allow, i.e. prevent, as 11.550.
e)qe/lonta: concessive, in spite of my desire.
dh\ beba/asi: already have past.
*dio\s e)niautoi/: cf. *dio\s w(=rai w 344, o(/ssai ga\r nu/ktes te kai\ h(me/rai e)k *dio/s ei)sin c 93.
dou=ra: timbers, as do/ru nh/ion i 384; for the form, see § 18 f.
spa/rta: ropes, cables, of reeds or rushes. The ship's ropes in Od. 2.426 were of oxhide; a ship's cable at the home of Odysseus, Od. 21.391, was made of papyrus.
le/luntai: plural verb with neut. subj., as v. 36, although dou=ra se/shpe has preceded.
ai( de/: but those others, explained by a)/loxoi ktl.
te/: correlative with kai/, in free position, since h(me/terai a)/loxoi are closely connected in thought with nh/pia te/kna.
ei(/atai potide/gmenai: as 7.414 f., *i 628, b 403, i 545. See on 1.134. For the form ei(/atai, see § 34 j.
potide/gmenai: fem. to agree with a)/loxoi, who were more prominent before their minds than te/kna.
au)/tws: Att. w(sau/tws, in the same way as before, i.e. simply, wholly, (with a)kra/anton), see § 24 h.
a)kra/anton: verbal adj., cf. krh/hnon *a 41, e)pekrai/aine v. 419.
ei)/pw: for the subjv., see 1.137.
feu/gwmen: cf. v. 74.
ou) e)/ti: belongs to the idea of expectation implied in the fut.; “we can no longer hope,” “to capture Troy is no longer a possibility.”
eu)rua/guian: nine times an epith. of Troy, of Athens Od. 7.80, of Mycenae 4.52.
cf. *g 395, *d 208, *z 51, *l 804, *n 468, r 150, f 96, pa=sin o)ri/nqh qumo/s, e)ki/nhqen de\ fa/lagges *p 280.
toi=si: dat. of interest, see § 3 g.—This undersired impulse was called forth by the longing for home awakened by vs. 134 ff.

pa=si meta\ plhqu/n: in appos. with toi=si, in contrast with the ge/rontes who had been present at the council. For the acc. with meta/, cf. kai\ boulh=| meta\ pa/ntas o(mh/likas (of the same age) e)/pleu a)/ristos *i 54, *r 149, p 419; the dat. would be regular.
plhqu/n: “the rank and file of the army,” cf. vs. 278, 488.
kinh/qh: cf. v. 95.
fh/: as, an obsolescent particle, also 14.499; distinguished by its accent from fh= [e)/fh].
ku/mata makra/: long-stretching billows, cf. longi fluctus Verg. Georg. iii. 200.

po/ntou *)ikari/oio: in appos. with qala/sshs, as the part with the whole, cf. skope/lw| v. 396; see § 1 u. The po/ntos is a particular tract of the qa/lassa (see on 1.350). The Icarian high sea received its name from Icaria, a small island off Samos; it was notorious for its frequent storms.
ta\ me/n: anaphoric, cf. v. 101, 1.234.

*eu)=ro/s te *no/tos te: thought of as united, as is shown by e)pai+/cas. “A southeast wind.” A single wind never raises a storm in Homer; cf. w(s d) a)/nemoi du/o po/nton o)ri/neton i)xquo/enta | *borrh=s kai\ *ze/furos, tw/ te *qrh/|khqen a)/hton (blow) 9.4 f.
w)/rore: gnomic aor., freq. in comparisons, § 2 k. For the form, see § 25 k; distinguished from o)/rwren v. 797 (§ 31 f).
e)pai+/cas: rushing upon it, cf. (venti) incubuere mari . . . una Eurusque Notusque ruunt Verg. Aen. i. 84.

*dio/s: he is nefelhgere/ta *a 511, cf. 5.522. Zeus sends rain 16.385, thunder and lightning 8.133, wind and storm 16.365, snow 12.279 f., hail 10.6, meteors 4.75, the rainbow 16.547. cf. *dio\s e)niautoi/ v. 134.

*ze/furos: this was a cold and stormy wind to the people of Aeolis and Ionia, for it came over the mountains of Thrace, cf. 4.276 ff., 7.63 f., 23.200, 208; it is called dusah/s fierceblowing (23.200), and keladeino/s loudroaring (23.208); it is never a gentle ‘zephyr’ in Homer, unless perhaps in the fairy-land Phaeacia (Od. 7.117), and possibly in Elysium (Od. 4.569 f.).
baqu/: lit. deep, i.e. high.
e)lqw/n: see on i)w/n *a 138.
la/bros e)paigi/zwn: violently dashing upon it; la/bros is pred., see § 38 a.
e)pi/ te: and thereupon, i.e. as Zephyrus descends.

h)mu/ei: sc. lh/ion, an independent addition to the picture, without direct relation to the comparison, cf. v. 210; see § 2 e. The const. of the dependent sent. is abandoned.—cf. ‘With ported spears, as thick as when a field | Of Ceres ripe for harvest waving bends | Her bearded grove of ears, which way the wind | Sways them.’ Milton Par. Lost iv. 980 ff.

pa=s) a)gorh\ kinh/qh: a return to v. 144.—Both comparisons are meant to depict the whole scene: the first (vs. 144-146) describes the sudden confusion with which the assembly dispersed; the second (vs. 147 -149), the uninterrupted rush in one direction, toward the ships.
a)lalhtw=|: dat. of manner, in which sense a partic. is often used.
nh=as e)/p): i.e. e)pi\ nh=as, § 37 c b. —e)sseu/onto, i(/stato, ke/leuon ktl.: descriptive impfs., much like the hist. pres. (which is not Homeric).
podw=n d) u(pe/nerqe: from under their feet.
i(/stat) a)eirome/nh: lit. was placing itself as it arose, as 23.366.
e(lke/men ktl.: cf. e)ru/ssomen ktl. *a 141.
ou)rou/s: the trenches, the later o(lkoi/, by which the ships were drawn from the sea upon the land, and from the land into the sea, cf. 1.308.

e)ceka/qairon: some had not been used for a long time and had become filled with sand.—a)uth\ ktl.: as 12.338, 14.60, cf. tw=n u(/bris te bi/h te sidh/reon ou\rano\n i(/kei o 329, kai/ meu kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei i 20.
i(eme/nwn: subjective gen. with a)uth/, not gen. abs.; see § 3 f.
u(po\ d) h(/|reon: they look out from under; the opposite of 1.486.
Vs. 155-210. Interference of Athena. Odysseus brings the people back to the agora.

u(pe/rmora: equiv. to u(pe\r mo/ron a 34. The leaders were so dazed by the sudden and disorderly breaking up of the assembly and by the rush to the boats of the shouting mass of men, that they were unable to follow the plan of Agamemnon. The intervention of a friendly god became necessary to cut the knot of difficulty.
158 = v. 174, Od. 5.204.—ou(/tw dh\ ktl.: thus as it seems etc. An expression of vexation or surprise, in interrogative form.
*)argei=oi: emphatic.—e)p) eu)re/a nw=ta ktl.: over the broad back of the sea. When the waves are at rest the monstrous mass seems to be the top of an arch. Latin poets have dorsum or terga maris.

cf. 4.173.—ka\d de\ ktl.: virtually a conclusion to the cond. implied in vs. 158 f., “if they should thus flee, then they would” etc., cf. (challenge to a conflict) oi( de/ k) a\gassa/menoi (approving) . . . oi)=on e)po/rseian (would urge) polemi/zein ktl. *h 41 f., w(\s e)re/ousin, e)moi\ de/ k) o)nei/dea tau=ta ge/noito z 285.
ka/d: for the apocope, see §11 a, b.

eu)xwlh/n: pred. with *(ele/nhn, as a triumph, a boast; cf. Hecuba's apostrophe of Hector, o(/ moi nu/ktas te kai\ h)=mar | eu)xwlh\ kata\ a)/stu pele/skeo *x 432 f. For the const., cf. *g 50, a)ste/ra h(=ke *kro/nou pa/is . . . h)\ nau/th|si te/ras (as a portent) 4.75 f., 137, 197, *l 28, *m 57, *c 325, *o 646.
*)argei/hn: standing epith. of Helen as a native of Peloponnesus. The word here has considerable emphasis, standing at the head of the verse like *)argei=oi above.
*troi/h| (sc. gh<*>|) the Troad, as v. 237, 3.74.
a)po/: far from, cf. 1.562.
soi=s a)ganoi=s ktl.: with thy winning words. For the short form of the dat., see §§ 17 e, 18 d.—For the asyndeton, cf. v. 10.
e)rh/tue: cf. v. 75.
e)/a: sc. *)axaiou/s, from the preceding verses.
ou)d) a)pi/qhse: cf. 1.220.
a)i/casa: “with a rush.”
e)/peita: thereupon.

*)odush=a: Odysseus was the special favorite of Athene whose care alone secured his return to his home after his long wanderings. Nestor said to Telemachus ou) ga/r pw i)/don w(=de qeou\s a)nafanda\ (openly) fileu=ntas | w(s kei/w| (Odysseus) a)nafanda\ pari/stato *palla\s *)aqh/nh g 221 f., cf. 10.245, 278 f., 23.771 ff., (qea\) h(\ to\ pa/ros per | mh/thr w(\s *)odush=i pari/statai h)d) e)parh/gei 782 f., Od. 13.300 f., Od. 1.48 ff., and the Odyssey passim.

e(stew=ta: Odysseus was not carried along by the rout, and the agora was nearest his own ships (see on 1.54). This partic. has this form in the first foot, but is e(stao/ta in the second foot of the verse.
melai/nhs: cf. 1.300; the ships of Odysseus are called miltopa/rh|oi (vermilion-cheeked) v. 637.
Odysseus with this feeling was the right man for Athene's work.
mi/n: limit of motion, with i(/kanen. —kradi/hn: acc. of the part in appos. with mi/n, cf. 1.362.
prose/fh: sc. mi/n.
This verse is found 7 times in the Iliad (*d 358, *q 93, *i 308, 624, *k 144, *y 723), 15 times in the Odyssey. It is the only conventional verse in which no caesura occurs in the 3d foot (§ 40 c).
diogene/s: Arceisias, father of Laertes, grandfather of Odysseus, was son of Zeus, acc. to a later myth; but this epith. is applied in a general way to princes, see on 1.176.
polumh/xane: for the epiths. of Odysseus, see §§ 1 q, 4 c.

e)n nhusi\ peso/ntes: marking the disorderly flight. This is a standing combination of expressions for motion and rest, cf. e)mba/llw, e)nti/qhmi. No compounds of ei)s with ba/llw, pi/ptw, ti/qhmi, are found in Homer. See on 1.245.
mhde/ t) e)rw/ei: and draw not back, do not rest; as 22.185.
o)/pa: obj. of cune/hke, while qea=s is a limiting gen.

bh= de\ qe/ein: he set out to run, cf. *a 34, bh= d) i(e/nai *d 199. —a)po\ ktl.: in his haste, since it hindered him in running, as Od. 14.500, cf. bh= de\ qe/ein, ta\ de\ teu/xe) a)mu/moni dw=ken e(tai/rw| *r 698, sfai/rh| (ball) tai\ d) a)/r) e)/paizon a)po\ krh/demna (veils) balou=sai z 100.
ko/missen: cf. 1.594.

*eu)ruba/ths: described (Od. 19.244 -248) as slightly older than Odysseus himself, with round shoulders, dark complexion, and curly hair; he accompanies Odysseus to the tent of Achilles, 9.170. Agamemnon has a herald of the same name, 1.320.— The herald here, as usual, serves as the prince's personal attendant.
a)nti/os: for the const., cf. 1.535.
cf. vs. 45 f.
de/cato/ oi(: lit. took for him, received from him, as a sign that he acted in the name and with the authority of Agamemnon.
patrw/ion: see vs. 103 ff.
o(/n tina me/n: correlative with o(\n d) au)= v. 198.—basilh=a ktl.: prince or noble who had not been present at the council of the Gerontes.
kixei/h: iterative opt. with o(/n tina, cf. 1.610.
to\n de\ ktl.: apod. to the hypothetical o(/n tina. For de/ in apod., cf. v. 322; see § 3 n.
a)ganoi=s: cf. vs. 164, 180.
daimo/nie: the connection decides whether this is used in a respectful, a pitying, or a reproving tone, cf. v. 200, *a 561, *w 194 (addressed by Priam to his sorrowing wife).

kako\n w(/s: for the length of the ultima of kako/n, cf. o)/rniqa_s w(/s v. 764, *g 2, pe/leku_s w(/s *g 60, qeo\s w(/s *g 230. Praepositive w(s is not used in Homeric comparisons, and when w(s follows the word to which it belongs, it is accented; cf. 3.196. cf. w(s o(/te v. 209, w(/s te v. 289, w(s v. 326.
kako/n: coward. kako/s and a)gaqo/s have no moral quality in Homer. They are useless and useful, according to the circumstances of the case; here, kako/n is useless in war.
a)/llous laou/s: laou/s is virtually in appos. with a)/llous, see § 1 u. The others, namely the soldiers.
For the ‘sigmatism,’ cf. 1.179 f.
sa/fa: Att. safw=s which is not found in Homer; similarly the adv. of w)ku/s is always w)=ka, ta/xa is freq., taxe/ws only 23.365; see § 38 h.
no/os: mind, purpose.
peira=tai: cf. v. 73.
i)/yetai: cf. 1.454.
e)n boulh=|: const. with oi(=on e)/eipen.
ou) pa/ntes a)kou/samen: the speaker politely includes himself with the persons addressed, as v. 342, Od. 7.307. The 1st pers. is used in a different tone in v. 203.
mh/ ti: beware lest perchance, cf. 1.26.
xolwsa/menos: see on *a 387, *g 413.
kako\n, ui(=as: for the two accs. after r(e/ch|, cf. 3.351, 354.
qumo\s de\ me/gas: terrible is the anger.
timh\ ktl.: “he is king dei gratia; the rest must obey.” cf. v. 205; see on 1.176.
dh/mou a)/ndra: the common people are contrasted with the nobles of v. 188. The ultima of dh/mou remains long, cf. di/skou ou)=ra *y 431, e)pi\ di/frou ei(=san *w 578; see § 41 o.
skh/ptrw|: he uses the staff in a similar way vs. 265 f.
e)la/saske: iterative aor. from e)lau/nw, e)la/w (§ 36 d).
a)/koue: give ear; pres. as a general injunction, “be obedient.”
se/o: not enclitic since there is a contrast in the comparison.
fe/rteroi: cf. 1.281.

su\ se: closely connected with the rel. clause by the anaphoric relation of su/ to se/o, as *d 61, *q 103. The Eng. idiom prefers the subord. const., “while thou art”; see § 3 q. e)ssi/ is to be supplied, as *u 434, *f 439, *x 288, *y 588.
e)nari/qmios: counted, not a mere cipher, cf. in numero nullo Cic. de Or. iii. 56. 213.
boulh=|: as 1.258; not in its technical meaning of council. Here again appears the freq. contrast of strength of body and mind. See on 1.258.
ou) me/n pws ktl.: a drastic form of expression, suited to the common soldiery. “Agamemnon alone commands here, the rest of us must obey.”
For the asyndeton, cf. 1.117.
ou)k a)gaqo/n: as a pred. subst. (not a good thing), cf. triste lupus stabulis Verg. Ecl. iii. 80.
ei(=s ktl.: asyndeton of contrast, see § 2 m.
e)/dwke: granted, sc. basileu/ein, implied in basileu/s (unless v. 206 is read).
sfi/si: for them; *)axaioi/ from v. 203 is before the mind.
di/epe: strode through, cf. 24.247.
h)xh=| w(s: for the hiatus justified by the caesura, cf. v. 211; see § 9 b; for hiatus allowed after the first foot, see on 1.333. cf. qa/lassa h)xh/essa *a 157.—The second hemistich as 1.34.

ai)gialw=| bre/metai: roars on the shore.—smaragei= ktl.: chiastic with the previous clause (§ 2 o); paratactically (§ 3 n) expressing result; “so that the high sea resounds from the noise of the breakers.”
Vs. 211-277. The insolent Thersites and his chastisement.
e(/zonto e)rh/tuqen: for the hiatus, cf. vs. 216, 315; see § 9 b.
kaq) e(/dras: as v. 99.

*qersi/ths: from qe/rsos, the Aeol. form of qa/rsos daring, rashness, see § 4 f. The name (*qersi/tas) appears in a Thessalian inscription of 214 B.C. It is noteworthy that the poet does not say from what country of Greece Thersites came, and thus offends no one by the episode.— Thersites makes his cause odious by his advocacy of it. The vulgar demagogue was intended by the poet to awaken antipathy, and thus is represented to be just as disagreeable and deformed in body as in character. The Greeks always associated a beautiful soul with a beautiful person.
mou=nos: made emphatic by its position before the caesura. For the form, see § 5 e.
a)metroeph/s: pred.
e)kolw/|a: equiv. to kolw|o\n h)/laune, cf. 1.575.

o(/s r(a ktl.: a more explicit statement of a)metroeph/s. —a)/kosma h)/|dh: lit. knew disorderly things, had a disorderly mind; cf. a)qemi/stia h)/|dh i 189 had a lawless heart, kedna\ i)dui=a a 428 trusty-hearted, a)/gria oi)=den *w 41 has a savage heart.
ma/y . . . ko/smon: as *e 759, g 138.
e)rize/menai: the result of a)/kosma ktl., cf. ma/xesqai *a 8.
a)ll) o(/ti ktl.: contrasted with kata\ ko/smon, while e)rize/menai supplies the idea of saying. He was an insolent clown, a gelwtopoio/s.
ei)/saito: from the theme of oi)=da. For the opt. in a cond. rel. sent., cf. vs. 188, 198, o(\n de\ la/boimi | r(i/ptaskon *o 22 f., cf. 1.554. G. 233, H. 914 B. ei)/saito is equiv. to do/ceie.
ai)/sxistos: pred., i.e. “he was the ugliest man who came” etc., cf. v. 673, 1.266.
u(po\ *)/ilion: up under Ilios, i.e. under the walls of Ilios; cf. vs. 249, 492, 673, *y 297, *d 407, *l 181.
folko/s: bandy-legged, cf. falx, falcones.
tw\ de/ oi( w)/mw: cf. tw\ de/ oi( u)/sse *o 607.
kurtw/, sunoxwko/te: in contrast with a broad-shouldered, heroic form. suno/xwka is formed from sune/xw as oi)/xwka *k 252 from oi)/xomai.
sunoxwko/te: au)ta/r: the hiatus is justified by the bucolic diaeresis, §§ 9 b, 40 h.
u(/perqen: as contrasted with folko\s ktl.
yednh\ ktl.: his misshapen, sugarloaf head was not concealed by the thick locks of the ka/rh komo/wntes *)axaioi/, but was covered only by sparse hair.
e)/xqistos: cf. 1.176.
*)axilh=i, *)odush=i: Achilles and Odysseus represented the two cardinal virtues of the heroes, bravery and prudence, in which qualities Thersites was lacking.
ma/lista: potissimum. Const. with e)/xqistos, cf. v. 57.

neikei/eske: was wont to upbraid, contrasted with to/t) au)=te. For the form (from neikei/w the old form of neike/w), cf. e)telei/eto *a 5, neikei/h|si *a 579, neikei/wi v. 243, pnei/ontes v. 536; see § 29 i.
*)agame/mnoni: against Agamemnon; dat. of interest.
o)ce/a keklhgw/s: with discordant cry.
le/g) o)nei/dea: rehearsed, enumerated, reproaches; le/gein in Homer is never strictly equiv. to ei)pei=n. Thersites accused the king of covetousness, sensuality, cowardice, injustice.
tw=|: Agamemnon, at whom the Achaeans were then angry, so that Thersites could be sure of the applause of his audience.
kote/onto: impf. to express a continued state of feeling, while neme/sshqen refers to the occasion which caused their anger, cf. 1.331.
225-242. Speech of Thersites. This assumes a knowledge of Agamemnon's real intention to continue the war. This knowledge might have been gained from the words of Odysseus.
*)atrei+/dh: Thersites gives him no title of honor, but this was not necessary, see v. 284, 1.17.—te/o: ti/nos (§ 24 r) for what. For the gen., see on 1.65.

dh\ au)=te: cf. 1.340.—Instead of inquiring the purpose of Agamemnon, Thersites attributes to the king the most selfish motives (implying that he continues the war only for his own private advantage), and alludes maliciously to the quarrel with Achilles.—“What dost thou lack? Hast thou not enough?”
e)ni\ klisi/h|s: in your quarters.
e)cai/retoi: explained by the following rel. clause, cf. ou)lome/nhn *a 2, kakh/n *a 10.
prwti/stw|: sup. formed regularly from prw=tos which is already sup. in meaning, cf. Eng. chiefest.
di/domen: are wont to give, with a cond. rel. sent., cf. 1.554. For the thought, see on 1.124, 163. Thersites reckons himself among the brave warriors.
ptoli/eqron: as 1.164.
h)= e)/ti ktl.: surely etc. He answers ironically the question which he himself had put; cf. 1.203.

e)/ti kai\ xrusou=: gold also as well as copper and slaves. Gold was rare in Greece before the Persian wars, but was abundant in Asia Minor. Schliemann, however, has found treasures of gold ornaments not only at Hissarlik (which many think to be the site of the ancient Ilios) but also at Mycenae. The latter city is called polu/xrusos, *h 180, *l 46, g 305; for Troy, cf. pri\n me\n (i.e. before the Achaeans besieged the city) ga\r *pria/moio po/lin me/ropes a)/nqrwpoi | pa/ntes muqe/skonto polu/xruson polu/xalkon *s 288 f.
ke oi)/sei: for ke/ with the fut. ind., cf. 1.139, 175, but see § 3 b.
a)/poina: in appos. with o(/n.
o(/n ktl.: whom I shall take captive and lead etc. Empty boasting, as v. 238.

gunai=ka ne/hn: as Chryseis or Briseis. The acc. seems to be caused by attraction to the const. of the preceding rel. clause; or poqe/eis may be in the speaker's mind, a thought carried on from e)pideu/eai.
h(/n te kati/sxeai: rel. clause with subjv. in final sense, cf. 3.287.
au)to\s a)po/nosfi: for thyself alone.
a)rxo\n e)o/nta ktl.: that one who is a leader etc., i.e. that thou who art their leader.
kakw=n e)pibaske/men: bring into misfortune, cf. e)uklei/hs e)pi/bhson *q 285 bring to honor. Reference to the pestilence and the alienation of Achilles.

pe/pones: “my good fellows.” This word is generally used by an elder or superior, either in an affectionate tone as 5.109, or (seldom) in a tone of contemptuous superiority as here. cf. w)= pe/pon, w)= *mene/lae *z 55, krie\ pe/pon i 447 (of Polyphemus to his pet ram).
ka/k) e)le/gxea: in concrete personal sense, coward caitiffs. —*)axaii/des ktl.: as 7.96, cf. gunaiko\s a)/r) a)nti\ te/tuco *q 163, o vere Phrygiae, neque enim Phryges Verg. Aen. ix. 617.
oi)/kade/ per: homeward, at all events.
su\n nhusi/: as 1.179.
to/nde: cf. o(/d) a)nh/r *a 287.
au)tou=: right here, explained as usual by the following words. It often stands as here at the beginning of a verse, cf. v. 332.
ge/ra pesse/men: digest (enjoy) his gifts of honor, i.e. learn and suffer the consequences of his greed. cf. katape/yai | me/gan o)/lbon ou)k e)duna/sqh Pind. Ol. i. 55 f.

h)\ kai\ h(mei=s ktl.: whether we too (the rank and file of the Achaeans) are of use to him or not; as if Agamemnon in his pride trusted to his own might and to that of the other leaders, despising the rest, bereft of whose help, he can do nothing.— For the crasis, see § 8.
h)=e kai\ ou)ki/: cf. vs. 300, 349. The speaker presents the alternatives as open, but still implies a choice between them. cf. vs. 300, 349.
o(/s: excl., he who.
kai\ nu=n: see on 1.109. This introduces an example of Agamemnon's failure to recognize others' services.
e(/o: Att. ou(= (§24 a, cf. se/o for sou=, v. 248). For the length of the ultima before m, see § 41 j.

240 = 1.356, 507.—Thersites who was wont to speak injuriously of Achilles (v. 221), now plays the part of his advocate (and uses his very words) in order to attack Agamemnon in a sensitive spot; but he introduces a fling at Achilles into the next verse.
ma/l) ou)x xo/los: sc. e)sti/, no anger at all.
meqh/mwn: pred., with Achilles as subj. cf. meqe/men xo/lon *a 283.
*qersi/ths: by its position strongly contrasted with *)odusseu/s.
tw=|: for the dat. of rest with pari/stato, cf. v. 175, *a 245, 593, *g 89.
u(po/dra: as 1.148.
xalepw=| mu/qw|: the opposite of a)ganoi=s e)pe/essin v. 164.
h)ni/pape: for the form, see § 25 k.
246-264. Odysseus rebukes Thersites.
a)krito/muqe: thou endless babbler, cf. vs. 212, 796, o)/neiroi a)mh/xanoi a)krito/muqoi t 560. For the opposite, cf. 3.214.
ligu/s per e)w/n: cf. 1.248; recognition of his ability, but sarcastic; cf. Od. 20.274.
i)/sxeo: as 1.214.
mhd) e)/qele: cf. 1.227.
ou): const. with fhmi/.
xereio/teron: for other forms of this comp., cf. 1.80, 114.

o(/ssoi: i.e. of all who; the rel. clause represents a gen., cf. ei) me/n tis qeo/s e)ssi toi\ ou)rano\n eu)ru\n e)/xousin z 150, h)e\ ne/wn a)ndrw=n h)\ (sc. of those) oi(\ progene/steroi/ ei)sin b 29, d 177, e 422.
tw=| ou)k a)\n ktl.: therefore (since thou art the basest of all) shalt (shouldst) thou not. See on 1.301. The speaker returns to the admonition of v. 247.
basilh=as: for the pl., cf. 3.49.
a)na\ sto/ma: i.e. on your lips.
kai/: see on v. 74.
sfi/n: for the dat., cf. *)agame/mnoni v. 221.
no/ston fula/ssois: guard the return, which now threatened (as it were) to escape them.
ou)de/ ti/ pw ktl.: but not at all clearly yet.—o(/pws ktl.: how these matters here (of which they are speaking) shall end. This verse is explained by the following.
nosth/somen: we shall return. Brachylogic for “shall enter upon our return, with good or evil fortune.”

h(=sai: h(=sqai with a partic. often has no thought of contrast of position (as sitting to standing), but denotes self-satisfied continuance in the action of the partic., cf. 1.134. The verb is the more noteworthy here since Thersites is not sitting (cf. v. 268).
didou=sin: as if from dido/w, cf. a)fi/ei *a 25, ti/qei *a 441.
h(/rwes: obs. the contrast with su/.—kertome/wn: cf. 1.539.
257 = b 187, r 229, s 82; cf. 1.204, 212. Formula to introduce a sharp threat.
e)/ti: again.
w(/s nu/ per w(=de: as I did just now. pe/r is to be construed with w(s.

mhke/ti ktl.: apod. in the form of an imprecation: “May destruction come upon me and my house.” cf. au)ti/k) e)/peit) a)p) e)mei=o ka/rh ta/moi a)llo/trios fw/s, | ei) mh\ e)gw\ kei/noisi kako\n pa/ntessi genoi/mhn p 102 f.
*)odush=i: more impressive than the pers. pron. e)moi/, cf. 1.240.
*thlema/xoio: the only child of Odysseus and Penelope. He was an infant when his father embarked for Troy, Od. 11.448. In the Iliad he is mentioned only here and 4.354.
keklhme/nos ei)/hn: being is included in being called, see on 1.293; thus this prayer includes the ruin of Telemachus.
ei) mh\ ktl.: this sent. contains two clauses, connected by me/n . . . de/, preceded by se labw/n which is common to both clauses and which gives to au)to/n v. 263 its personal reference.
labw/n: see on i)w/n *a 138.
a)po\ du/sw: strip off, followed by two accs.

fi/la: often used in Homer in a familiar tone where the less emotional Eng. idiom would not use dear, but it is distinctly more than the possessive pron. and part of the original coloring is lost if it is rendered simply by thy, his, etc. See on 3.138.
ta/ te: combines the objects; whatever covers thy nakedness; cf. gh=ras kai\ qa/natos, ta/ t) e)p) a)nqrw/poisi pe/lontai n 60.—This would be the most bitter disgrace.
au)to/n: thyself; the man in contrast with his clothing, cf. 1.47; see § 1 h.
peplhgw\s ktl.: flogging thee away from the place of assembly. peplhgw/s like keklhgw/s v. 222, tetrigw=tas v. 314, does not imply past time; see H. 849.
a)eike/ssi: a standing epith. of blows, cf. plhgh=|sin a)eikeli/h|si d 244.
skh/ptrw| . . . plh=cen: a heavy blow over the back from one shoulder to the other, as a foretaste of the harder beating which would follow if he continued his insolence.
e)/kfuge; escaped him, against his will.

smw=dic ktl.: a weal rose (a)ne/sth) out of the back (e)c), under (u(po/) the blow of the staff; cf. puknai\ de\ smw/digges a)na\ pleura/s te kai\ w)/mous | ai(/mati foiniko/essai a)ne/dramon *y 716 f.
skh/ptrou u(/po: repeats u(po/ of e)cupane/sth.—e(/zeto: evidently he was not seated at v. 255, cf. vs. 211 f.
a)lgh/sas: seized by pain, cf. ta/rbhsen v. 268, ge/lassan v. 270; see on qa/rshse *a 92.
a)xrei=on: cognate acc. with i)dw/n, casting a silly look, looking foolish, cf. a)xrei=on d) e)ge/lassen s 163.
kai\ a)xnu/menoi/ per: they still sympathized with Thersites; they had not entirely recovered from their homesickness.
h(du\ ge/lassan: burst into a merry laugh. This laughter quiets their excitement, cf. *a 599, pa/ntes e)p) au)tw=| h(du\ ge/lassan | mnhsth=res, kai\ dh\ me/qien xalepoi=o xo/loio f 376 f.
ti/s: represents public opinion.
i)dw/n: not of an action prior to that of the principal verb, but coincident with it; casting a glance.
plhsi/on: as subst.
a)/llon: as v. 191.
w)\ po/poi: the interjection which expressed sorrow 1.254, here expresses pleased surprise.
h)= dh/: verily before now, contrasted with nu=n de/ v. 274. For the paratactic form of expression, cf. v. 798; see § 3 n.
e)/orgen: the perf. marks the character of Odysseus as shown in the past, while e)/recen v. 274 refers to the single act; just as in Eng. “he has done etc., but he never did a better thing.”
e)ca/rxwn: first suggesting, proposing.
me/g) a)/riston: pred. to to/de the obj.; “this is far the best thing that” etc., cf. v. 216. The difference between this and o)/x) a)/riston, cf. 1.69, is simply metrical; see § 4 d.
e)/recen: for the single r after the aug., see § 25 g.
o(\s ktl.: rel. clause with causal force, since he.
to\n lwbhth=ra e)pesbo/lon: for the order of words, see on 1.340.
e)/sxe: checked, equiv. to e)/pausen, coincident with e)/recen v. 274; cf. the explanation of ta/de e)/rga v. 252 by the following verse.
a)gora/wn: speeches before the people, cf. v. 788. For the gen., cf. a)uth=s v. 97.
Inferential asyndeion; see § 2 m.
ou)/ qhn: hardly, I think; qh/n is ironical here, like Att. dh/pou.
pa/lin au)=tis: lit. back again, again, anew. pa/lin marks a return to the same point, cf. 1.116. cf. deu/teron au)=tis *a 513.
Vs. 278-335. Speech of Odysseus before the assembly of the people. He urges the continuance of the war in accordance with the omens sent by Zeus.
h( plhqu/s: the crowd there; with pl. as collective, see on v. 99.
a)na\ e)/sth: shows that Odysseus resumed his seat after chastising Thersites, see on v. 76.

ptoli/porqos: a general title of honor, not simply because *troi/hs i(ero\n ptoli/eqron e)/persen a 2; the same epith. is applied to Achilles *q 372, *o 77, *f 550, *w 108; it is given to Oïleus v. 728, to Ares 20.152, to Enyo (the goddess of war) 5.333. In the Odyssey, it is given only to Odysseus.
para/: adv., by his side.
ei)dome/nh kh/ruki: as Od. 8.8 where Athena calls the Phaeacians to an assembly.
a)nw/gein: Att. h)nw/gei, plpf. as impf.

a(/ma te: the position of te/ is free, cf. *a 417, *i 519; it seems to be intended here to unite the two verbs, and properly has its place after the first of the ideas which it connects. It is the more remarkable here since a combination with te kai/ follows.— oi( prw=toi ktl.: i.e. the most remote as well as the nearest.
See on 1.73.

*)atrei+/dh: Odysseus turns first to the king whose authority has been challenged; he now defends the king's purpose directly, as he had defended it indirectly in his address to Thersites. He then opposes the motives for return which had been advanced.
pa=sin brotoi=sn: lit. for all mortals, in the eyes of all men, cf. *d 95, *i 303, *y 595.
e)le/gxiston: most disgraced, for its formation from e)/legxos, cf. e)/xqistos *a 176; see § 22 b.
qe/menai: make, cf. v. 319; see on 1.2.
mero/pessi: only here with brotoi/, cf. 1.250.
ou)de/ toi ktl.: paratactic for, “since they do not” etc.
h(/n per u(pe/stan: which they surely promised, see v. 339; or the very promise that they made, see on v. 318.
e)nqa/de ktl.: as they were still coming, “as they were on their way to Troy,” cf. Od. 4.351, 736.
*)/argeos: i.e. Peloponnesus, see on 1.30. For the epith., cf. aptum dicet equis Argos ditesque Mycenas Hor. Carm. i. 7. 9.
288 = v. 113.—e)kpe/rsanta: se/ is subj., supplied from toi/ above.
a)pone/ esqai: in app. with u(po/sxesin.
h)=: in truth, as vs. 229, 242, 272.
a)llh/loisin: with each other, to each other.
o)du/rontai: with pregnant force, followed by the inf., mournfully they long; see on 1.22. cf. no/ston o)durome/nw| e 153, o)du/reto patri/da gai=an n 219, o)lofu/reai a)/lkimos ei)=nai x 232.

h)= mh\n kai\ ktl.: concessive and excusing: “our trouble has been enough to make a man return to his home.” The other side of the picture is introduced v. 297 by a)lla\ kai\ e)/mphs. As a wise orator, Odysseus concedes that their longing for home is natural, (many a man is homesick after a single month away from his family), but he emphasizes the motives for continuing the struggle.
a)nihqe/nta: agrees with tina/ implied as the subj. of the inf.
ne/esqai: inf. of result, see on ma/xesqai *a 8.
kai\ e(/na: even a single; this introduces an inference a minori ad maius, cf. 9.632 ff.
ti/s te: many a one.
poluzu/gw|: with many ‘yoketimbers,’ hence strong.
o(/n per: refers to ti/s te.
ei)le/wsin: for the mode, see on 1.554.
o)rinome/nh: when it is excited.

h(mi=n mi/mnontessi [mi/mnousi]: for us remaining here; i.e. we have been here nearly nine years. For the dat. cf. *a 250, dwdeka/th de/ oi( h)w\s | keime/nw| *w 413 f. it is the twelfth day that he has been lying dead, Od. 19.192 f., h)/dh ga/r oi( (Odysseus) e)eikosto\n e)/tos e)sti/n, | e)c ou(= kei=qen e)/bh t 222.
peritrope/wn: rolling, cf. v. 551, peri\ d) e)/trapon w(=rai k 469, periplome/nwn e)niautw=n a 16, volventibus annis Verg. Aen. i. 234, volvendis mensibus ib. 269.
a)sxala/an: for the form, see § 29 c.
e)/mphs: as 1.562.—But even in spite of all that, it is a shame to remain long and yet return unsuccessful.

dhro
 ktl.: equiv. to dhro
 mei/nanta keneo
 ne/ esqai.

keneo/n: empty, i.e. empty-handed, without the booty gained from sacked Troy; cf. the words of Agamemnon, when after Menelaus has been wounded he supposes some Trojan to say kai\ dh\ e)/bh oi)ko/nde fi/lhn e)s patri/da gai=an | su\n keinh=|sin (empty) nhusi/ *d 180 f.; oi)/kade nisso/meqa (sc. the comrades of Odysseus) kenea\s su\n xei=ras e)/xontes k 42.
For the asyndeton, cf. v. 276.
e)pi\ xro/non: for a time, as Od. 12.407.
h)\ e)teo/n: whether in truth. For h)/ . . . h)=e, see § 3 m.
manteu/etai: makes known the will of the gods, i.e. is a prophet.
to/de: refers to vs. 303 ff., and thus to vs. 308 ff.
mh/: as hypothetical. The only instance in Homer of mh/ with the ind. in a cond. rel. clause; cf. v. 143.
e)/ban fe/rousai: see on 1.391, cf. kh=res e)/ban ktl. | ei)s *)ai/dao do/mous c 207 f.
xqiza/ te kai\ prwiza/: proverbial of an event still well remembered. For te kai/, see § 3 s.

*au)li/da: a Boeotian harbor on the Euripus, opposite Chalcis in Euboea, where the Achaean forces gathered, in order to set sail together for Troy. This place and the muster of the troops there received greater prominence in the later stories of this Trojan expedition.
h)gere/qonto: descriptive impf., cf. 1.25.
h(mei=s de/: independent sent. explaining o(/te ktl. v. 303.
a)mfi\ peri/: on both sides around, round about. Such a spring is still shown at Aulis.

kata\ bwmou/s: cf. kata\ strato/n etc., see on 1.318; the numerous altars of the different tribes occupied considerable space. Evidently the Greeks had no temple there, or it would have been mentioned. As in the earliest times of their religion, the woods are their temples.
telhe/ssas: as 1.315.

platani/stw|: the plane tree, highly valued by the orientals, which often shades springs and streams. A fragment of this tree was shown as a holy relic in the temple of Artemis, in the time of Hadrian, see plata/nou de\ h(=s kai\ *(/omhros e)n *)ilia/di e)poih/sato mnh/mhn, to\ e)/ti tou= cu/lou perio\n fula/ssousin e)n tw=| naw=|. . . . dei/knutai de\ kai\ h( phgh\ par) h(\n h( pla/tanos e)pefu/kei, kai\ e)pi\ lo/fou plhsi/on th=s *)agame/mnonos skhnh=s ou)do\s xalkou= Paus. ix. 19. 7.
e)/nqa: then, repeats the idea of xqiza/ te ktl. v. 303.
dra/kwn: appositive asyndeton.

dafoino/s: all blood red. da is a strengthening prefix as in da/skios, dayilh/s, equiv. to the prefix za which is found in zah/s, za/qeos, za/kotos, zatrefh/s, zaflegh/s. cf. foinh/enta dra/konta *m 202.
*)olu/mpios: see on 1.353, cf. v. 324.
bwmou= u(pai+/cas: darting from under the altar.
r(a/: points back to eu)= ga\r dh\ to/de i)/dmen.
nh/pia te/kna: tender children (fledglings), cf. mh/thr v. 313 of the mother-bird; the words of human relationship being used.
u(popepthw=tes: crouched under, cf. kei/mhn pepthw/s c 354.

o)ktw/: part of the wonder, since sparrows generally lay only four or five eggs. The numbers receive prominence since the interpretation of the omen rests only on the equal number of sparrows and years of war. cf. Pharaoh's dream with its seven fat kine for seven years of plenty, and seven lean kine for seven years of famine, Gen. xli.
mh/thr, h(\ te/ke: for the epexegesis, see § 1 t.
e)leeina/: cognate acc., adv. with tetrigw=tas.
tetrigw=tas: for the tense, see on v. 264.
a)mfepota=to o)durome/nh: for the hiatus, see on v. 211.
te/kna: obj. of the finite verb.
e)lelica/menos: coiling itself, in order thus to strike the bird with greater force, cf. kua/neos e)le/likto dra/kwn *l 39.
a)mfiaxui=an: repeats concisely the verb and partic. of v. 315.
kata\ e)/fage: kata/ as in kath/sqie v. 314, katakai/w, katasbe/nnumi, katath/kw.
a)ri/zhlon: neut. adj. as subst., cf. v. 204; pred. after qh=ken. Made this to be something very clear, i.e. a sign from the gods.
o)/s per: the same god who.
e)/fhnen: equiv. to h(=ke fo/wsde v. 309.

la=an ga/r min e)/qhke: made it a stone, turned it to stone; as Zeus did men 24.611 ff., and Poseidon did the Phaeacian ship Od. 13.156 ff. cf. fit lapis et superat serpentis imagine saxum Ovid. Met. xii. 23.

oi(=on e)tu/xqh: what had happened; excl. giving the contents and reason of qauma/zomen, cf. *zeu= pa/ter ou) nemesi/zh| (angry) *)/arei ta/de kartera\ e)/rga; | o(ssa/tio/n te kai\ oi(=on a)pw/lese lao\n *)axaiw=n *e 758, *p 173.
deina\ pe/lwra: dire portents, the serpent with its deeds and its petrifaction.
ei)sh=lqe: followed by an acc. as pei/nh (famine) d) ou)/ pote dh=mon e)se/rxetai o 407.
a)/new| e)ge/nesqe: became mute.
h(mi=n: emphatic.—me/n: mh/n. —to/de: obj., with te/ras me/ga as pred.
o)/yimon o)yite/leston: for the repetition of o)ye/, see § 1 s; for the asyndeton, cf. 1.99, § 2 l.
o(/ou kle/os: because of the fulfilment of the prophecy. For the form o(/ou, see on v. 518, § 17 c.
327 = v. 313.—This verse is repeated since the numeral adjs. are most important for the interpretation of the omen.
ptolemi/comen: Att. polemiou=men, as from a g-stem; see § 30 k.
au)=qi: i.e. before Ilios, like au)tou= v. 237.

tw=| deka/tw|: the art. calls attention to this as the decisive year, on that tenth, “then, in the tenth year.” cf. e)/nqa me\n ei)na/etes polemi/zomen ui(=es *)axaiw=n, | tw=| deka/tw| de\ po/lin *pria/mou pe/rsantes e)/bhmen | oi)/kade su\n nh/essi c 240 f.
tw=s: thus, as 3.415; related to the more usual w(/s, as the Homeric toi/ to oi(, see § 24 i.
ta\ . . . telei=tai: as b 176, e 302, n 178.
a)/ge: as interjection, with pl., see on 1.62.

a)/stu: the po/lin of v. 329. The poet's choice between the two words is often determined by the convenience of his verse, § 4 c f. Strictly a)/stu is the city considered as made up of dwellings, while po/lis is the city as the ‘county seat,’ the central point of the territory.

a)mfi\ de\ ktl.: paratactic clause to express result, see § 3 q; so that the ships resounded etc. Parenthetical as *a 10, *g 134, 410; e)painh/santes v. 335 refers not to *)axaiw=n v. 334 but to *)argei=oi v. 333.
334 = 16.277.—a)usa/ntwn ktl.: from the shout etc. For the gen. see § 3 f g.
e)painh/santes: adds the reason for the shout, cf. *q 29, e)pi/axon ui(=es *)axaiw=n | mu=qon a)gassa/menoi *i 50 f.
*)odussh=os qei/oio: standing verseclose, see §§ 1 q, 4 c.
Vs. 336-393. Nestor's speech and Agamemnon's reply.
kai/: also, with reference to the preceding speakers.

*gerh/nios: so called from the Messenian town where Nestor was bred and which was his place of refuge when Heracles sacked Pylos.—i(ppo/ta: i(ppo/ths, i(ppeu/s, knight; but he was not mounted on horseback like the latter i(pph=s.

a)gora/asqe: with lengthened initial vowel, see § 41 g.—This reproach, though addressed to all the Greeks, is directed only against those who sympathize with Thersites in their longing to return. Nestor speaks more vehemently than Odysseus who had prepared the way with arguments. —For the brief comparison, see § 2 h.
polemh/ia e)/rga: periphrasis for po/lemos, see § 2 s; cf. qala/ssia e)/rga e 67.
ph=| dh\ bh/setai: a rhetorical question, cf. *(/ektor, ph=| dh/ toi me/nos oi)/xetai *e 472, *q 229, *n 219 f., 24.201. “What will become of compacts if no one thinks of keeping them?”

sunqesi/ai te kai\ o(/rkia: i.e. compacts sworn at sacrifices, here referring to the solemn sacrifice at Aulis. Hence Dido says non ego cum Danais Troianam exscindere gentem | Aulide iuravi Verg. Aen. iv. 425 f. Odysseus called it only an u(po/sxesis, v. 286.
h(mi=n: ethical dat.
e)n puri\ ktl.: ironical wish in his indignation. “Let all be thrown into the flames, as worthless.”
e)n puri/: cf. 5.215, where the archer Pandaros, in vexation, vows to break his bow and throw it into the fire, as useless.
spondai\ a)/krhtoi: libations to the gods with unmixed wine, see on 3.270; although no wine was drunk unmixed with water.—deciai/.: see on 1.54, i.e. pledges given by the right hand.
e)pe/piqmen: plpf. with out variable vowel, for e)pepoi/qeimen, see § 31 c.
au)/tws: without change, vainly, cf. v. 138; explained by what follows.
mh=xos: way of relief, from this contest of words to come to deeds and the conquest of Troy.
*)atrei+/dh, su\ de/: as 1.282.

e)/ti: const. with a)/rxeue. “In the future as in the past.”—e)/xwn ktl.: holding firmly to thy determination, sc. to capture Troy. Here begins the direct exhortation to Agamemnon to seize again with decision the reins of his authority.
e)/a fqinu/qein: let them perish!
e(/na kai\ du/o: for the idiomatic use of kai/, cf. 1.128, v. 303, 3.363; see § 3 s. He intentionally depreciates the number of the renegades and mentions no names.
*)axaiw=n: part. gen. with toi/.
no/sfin bouleu/wsi: “plan apart from us, separating their cause from ours, like Thersites.”
a)/nusis . . . au)tw=n: parenthetical, connected with the preceding by the antithesis between bouleu/wsi and a)/nusis.
au)tw=n: neut., of the plans (bouleu/mata) implied in bouleu/wsi.
pri\n i)e/nai: depends on bouleu/wsi. For pri/n, pri/n, see on 1.98.

*dio/s: by prolepsis connected with gnw/menai, and supplied in thought for u(po/sxesis. For the gen. with gnw/menai, cf. w(s gnw= xwome/noio *d 357, gnwso/meq) a)llh/lwn kai\ lw/ion y 109 we shall know each other still better.
ei)/ te, ei)/ te: indir. questions, as 1.65.
kai\ ou)ki/: cf. v. 238.
fhmi/: maintain, assert.
ou)=n: at all events. This particle is not freq. in Homer; it occurs about 60 times in Iliad and Odyssey.
kataneu=sai: intr., gave a promise; see on 1.514.
h)/mati tw=| o(/te: closely connected, as a standing formula; as v. 743, *g 189, *e 210, *z 345.
nhusi\n e)n e)/bainon: cf. vs. 510, 619; *)/ilion ei)s e)u/pwlon e)/bh koi/lh|s e)ni\ nhusi/n b 18, e)s *troi/hn a)nabh/menai a 210 embark and set sail for Troy, *<*>/ilion ei)sane/bainon b 172.
*)argei=oi: for the position, see § 1 h.
fe/rontes: cf. v. 304.
a)stra/ptwn: as if o(/ti kate/neuse *kroni/wn had preceded; an anacoluthon caused by the intervening vs. 351 f. A more violent anacoluthon is 3.211.
e)pide/cia: on our right, i.e. on the propitious side, cf. 12.239 f., Od. 2.154.
e)nai/sima: its contrary is parai/sia *d 381.

fai/nwn: interpretation of a)stra/ptwn, cf. *kroni/dhs e)nde/cia sh/mata fai/nwn | a)stra/ptei *i 236 f., *zeu\s de\ mega/l) e)/ktupe sh/mata fai/nwn f 413. For the chiastic order of words, cf. 1.443, 558 f.

pri\n ktl.: i.e. before the capture of Troy. The women and children of a captured city were treated as slaves, the men were killed; cf. e)k po/lios (sc. of the Cicones) d) a)lo/xous kai\ kth/mata polla\ labo/ntes | dassa/meqa i 41 f., po/rqeon, e)k de\ gunai=kas a)/gon kai\ nh/pia te/kna, | au)tou/s te (the men) ktei=non r 433 f.
tina/: in a collective sense, referring to each individual, as is also *trw/wn a)lo/xw|.

ti/sasqai: chiastic with katakoimhqh=nai, with which it is coincident. The Trojans shall be repaid, like for like.—*(ele/nhs o(rmh/mata ktl.: the longings and sighs of Helen, i.e. those which she felt and uttered. The poet attributes to Nestor a knowledge of Helen's repentance (see on 3.173) and earnest longing to return to Greece (see 3.139 f., and Helen's words h)/dh moi kradi/h te/trapto ne/esqai | a)\y oi)ko/nd), a)/thn de\ mete/stenon, h(\n *)afrodi/th | dw=x), o(/te m) h)/gag) e)kei=se fi/lhs a)po\ patri/dos ai)/hs d 260 ff.). Paris is everywhere in Homer held chiefly responsible for Helen's fault, although she followed him willingly; no unattractive picture of her is presented. Vergil (Aen. vi. 511 ff.) represents Helen in a much more unpleasant light.
e)kpa/glws: as v. 223, cf. ai)nw=s *g 158.

a(pte/sqw h(=s nho/s: cf. v. 171; in a threatening tone. “Only let him prepare to depart! Instead of returning as he wishes, before the rest, he will find death here, before the rest.” For the imv., cf. *a 302, *z 143, *q 18.— e)usse/lmoio ktl.: as v. 170.
o)/fra: in order that; of the natural consequence to be expected.
qa/naton: i.e. the punishment of death.
po/tmon: cf. meq) *(/ektora po/tmos e(toi=mos *s 96 after thou hast killed Hector, death is ready for thee, qa/non kai\ po/tmon e)pe/spon l 389.
a)/nac: Nestor turns to Agamemnon.

pei/qeo/ t) a)/llw|: this is the leading thought, as is shown by what follows, while eu)= mh/deo recapitulates vs. 344 f. “As thou must plan wisely thyself, so also follow another's advice.” cf. 9.100 ff.
a)po/blhton: as 3.65. For the final syllable, long by position before a lost consonant, see § 41 m.
kri=ne: separate, i.e. place in position separately, as v. 446.
kata\ fu=la: distributive, by tribes, the principal division of each Greek people, cf. v. 668.

kata\ frh/tras: by clans, to which the separate families belonged.—cf. ‘According to your tribes, . . . according to the families thereof; and the family which the Lord shall take shall come by households.’ Joshua vii. 14.—This verse suggests such a catalogue as follows, vs. 484 ff.
w(s frh/trh ktl.: expression of reciprocity, instead of using a)llh/lois, cf. oi(=a fi/loi cei=noi cei/noisi didou=sin a 313.
o(/s te law=n: sc. e)/h|si. The clause is rel., not interrogative.
kata\ sfe/as: by themselves, separately; cf. 1.271.
h)\ kai\ qespesi/h|: whether thou hast failed not simply because of the inefficiency of his army, but also by decree of the gods; referring to vs. 111 ff.
a)lapa/ceis: fut. since the success of this measure will not appear until in the future.
h)=: or only, as the Eng. idiom requires to correspond to kai/ above.
369-393. Agamemnon's speech. He calls them to battle.
h)= ma/n: strong asseveration, in very truth.
au)=te: again, “as often before.” Agamemnon's praise is bestowed upon Nestor's whole speech.
371 = *d 288, *h 132, *p 97, d 341, h 311, r 132, s 235, w 376.—This appeal to the three chief divinities is made in the case of ardent wishes; generally, as here, fulfilment is not expected.
sumfra/dmones: equiv. to su/mbouloi, cf. fra/sai *a 83.
xersi\n u(/po: for u(po/ with the dat., in its transition from local to causal sense, cf. v. 860; see § 3 h g.
a(lou=sa: aor. to mark the capture of the city as the decisive moment, while perqome/nh refers to the duration of the work of destruction, cf. 1.331.
*kroni/dhs *zeu/s: closely connected, cf. 1.502. The verses immediately following seem inconsistent with the confident expectation expressed vs. 412 ff.—For the complaint, cf. v. 111.
meta/: into the midst of, cf. 1.222, 423.
a)prh/ktous: cf. v. 121.
ba/llei: casts, is wont to entangle in.
maxhsa/meqa: cf. e)/ridi cune/hke ma/xesqai *a 8.
ei(/neka kou/rhs: here marks the insignificant occasion of the quarrel.
h)=rxon: const. with the partic., as 3.447.
xalepai/nwn: i.e. the quarrel.
e)/s ge mi/an ktl.: sc. boulh/n, see on 1.54; i.e. agree in counsel, the opposite of a)mfi\s fra/zesqai, cf. v. 14.
ou\d) h)baio/n: not in the least.

dei=pnon: the principal meal of the day, no matter when it is taken, see § 2 v. The warriors would have no more food until night. A considerable part of the day had passed during the events narrated since v. 48.
cuna/gwmen *)/arha: i.e. begin the sharp contest, see on v. 426; cf. v. 440, *a 8, *g 70, e)/rida cuna/gontes *)/arhos *c 149, su/nagon kraterh\n u(smi/nhn *p 764, Lat. committere proelium.
ti/s: collective.

eu)=: the anaphora is rhetorical, cf. e)k *a 436 ff.— cf. ‘Arm, warriors, arm for fight! . . . let each | His adamantine coat gird well, and each | Fit well his helm, gripe fast his orbed shield.’ Milton Par. Lost vi. 537 ff.
a(/rmatos a)mfi/s: const. with i)dw/n, looking carefully about his chariot, to see that all was in good condition. The principal idea is in the partic., not in the finite verb.
panhme/rioi: as 1.472.
w(s krinw/meqa: that we may measure our strength.
stugerw=| *)/arhi: dat. of interest, i.e. in dread battle, cf. me/lpesqai *)/arhi *h 241.
mete/ssetai: shall be between, sc. the conflicts; cf. metapauswlh\ pole/moio *t 201, metapauo/menoi de\ ma/xonto *r 373.
me/nos a)ndrw=n: for the periphrasis, cf. v. 851, 3.105; see § 2 s.

teu=: Att. tino/s, many a one's. The strap of the shield ran over the left shoulder and under the right arm, cf. *e 796, *c 404, *p 803, *s 480, l 610. The shield was so heavy that it needed support from the body as well as from the arm.
a)mfibro/ths: man-protecting, cf. (a)spi/da) podhneke/a *o 646; a)mfi/ is connected with a)/mfw, on both sides. Protecting “on left and right” 7.238, “above and below” 6.117, cf. a)mfhrefe/a *a 45.
xei=ra: arm; acc. of specification.
kamei=tai: sc. ti\s from teu=.
e)qe/lonta: inclined, ready.
noh/sw: perceive, see § 2 v.
mimna/zein: obj. of e)qe/lonta. A collateral form of me/nw, mi/mnw, see § 19 a.
ou): by no means, emphatic at the head of the clause, to contrast the following thought with the coward's expectation.
oi(=: pers. pron. instead of a dem. after the cond. rel. sent., as 3.300, cf. 1.218.
a)/rkion: appointed, fated.— “Nothing shall save him from death.” —ku/nas ktl.: see on 1.4.
Vs. 394-440. Breaking up of the assembly. The sacrifice.

w(s o(/te: introduces a comparison, see § 2 j; sc. i)a/xh|.—cf. ‘He scarce had finished when such murmur filled | Th' assembly, as when hollow rocks retain | The sound of blust'ring winds, which all night long | Had roused the sea,’ etc. Milton Par. Lost ii. 284 ff.
kinh/sh|: for the subjv., cf. 1.80. sc. ku=ma as obj.
skope/lw|: locative, in part. appos. with a)kth=|, see on v. 145.
ku/mata a)ne/mwn: i.e. waves roused by the winds; cf. e(/lkei+ u(/drou v. 723, fo/bon *)/arhos v. 767, nou=son *dio/s i 411 disease sent by Zeus.
o(/t) a)\n ge/nwntai: sc. a)/nemoi. This explains pantoi/wn, but the whole sent. is a picturesque decoration of the comparison, see § 2 e.
e)/nq) h)\ e)/nqa: in this direction or in that, cf. vs. 90, 462, 476, 812.
o)re/onto: they hastened away, as 23.212.
kata\ nh=as: cf. v. 47.
e)/reze: for the impf., see on a)fi/ei *a 25.—qew=n ktl.: cf. 1.290. Each of the tribes offered sacrifices to its national god.
bou=n ktl.: as 7.314.
i(e/reusen: sc. as he prepared a feast for the Gerontes. Kings generally sacrificed to Zeus, as their patron, as 8.237 ff., Od. 13.24; see on 1.176.
*)agame/mnwn: in appos. with o(, see § 24 k.
pentae/thron: i.e. full grown; this age was thought to be the best for beef and pork, cf. *h 315, t 420, c 419. —*kroni/wni: dat. of interest, in his honor, with i(e/rensen.
ge/rontas: see on gero/ntwn v. 21. The following seem to be the members of the boulh/ of v. 53.
prw/tista: Nestor has the first place in the regard of Agamemnon, vs. 20, 371 ff; Idomeneus, a high place, cf. 4.257 ff., see on 1.145. Idomeneus is also a great friend of Menelaus, cf. 3.232.
*ai)/ante: see on v. 528.
*tude/os ui(o/n: Diomedes, king of Argos; see on v. 567.
au)to/matos: of his own accord; he needed no invitation. He holds a special relation.

boh\n a)gaqo/s: an important element of influence in battle where trumpets were not used. This epith. is applied to Menelaus 25 times, to Diomedes 21 times; by way of exception to Telamonian Ajax *o 249, *p 102; to Hector *n 123, *o 671; to Priam's son Polites 24.250. See § 1 q.

a)delfeo/n: the subj. of the subord. clause is taken by anticipation (*h. 878) as the obj. of the principal clause, cf. v. 348, *g 192, *e 85, g 86, d 832, 836, ‘I know thee who thou art’ St. Luke iv. 34.—The form a)delfo/s is not Homeric; kasi/gnhtos is found in Homer about twice as freq. as a)delfeo/s.
w(s e)ponei=to: how busy he was in preparing for the feast and the battle.
peri/sthsan: 2d aor., cf. 1.448. —ou)loxu/tas ktl.: as 1.449.

The first hemistich is found also 3.298.—The different attributes are given without conjunctions, see § 2 l.—For the most freq. form of invocation of Zeus, see 3.276.—The elated tone of the prayer, results from the king's infatuation by the dream, cf. vs. 37 ff.
kelainefe/s: (for kelainonefes), since he appears in the dark thunder-cloud.
e)pi/: const. with du=nai, sc. upon the battle.

e)pi\kne/fas e)lqei=n: cf. 1.475. —The infs. depend on do/s implied in the invocation, cf. *g 351, *zeu= pa/ter h)\ *ai)/anta laxei=n h)\ *tude/os ui(o/n *h 179. The opt. follows in v. 418.—The wish reminds of Joshua's words: ‘Sun, stand thou still upon Gibeon; and thou, Moon, in the valley of Ajalon. And the sun stood still, and the moon stayed, until the people had avenged themselves upon their enemies.’ Joshua x. 12 f.
prhne/s: proleptic pred. after kata\ bale/ein, cf. r(wgale/on v. 417, a)li/aston v. 420.
ai)qalo/en: the ceiling-timbers were blackened by the smoke from the fires and torches for which no adequate outlet was provided. The same epith. is applied to the ceiling of Odysseus, Od. 22.239.
prh=sai: const. with the gen., like the allied e)mplh=sai, as *i 242, *p 81.
qu/retra: the double door which with its decorations formed a principal ornament of the palace, cf. Od. 17.268.
*(ekto/reon: equiv. to *(/ektoros, see on v. 20.
xitw=na . . . dai+/cai: as 16.841. cf. 3.359.
xalkw=|: bronze, i.e. sword; see on 1.236. So xalko/s is sometimes used for armor, as v. 578, xalko\n zw/nnusqai *y 130.
pole/es . . . e(tai=roi: as 8.537.—pole/es: polloi/, see § 20 f.
a)mf) au)to/n: about himself, as the chief personage.

o)da\c ktl.: bite the dust, in the last convulsive agony of death, cf. pa/ntes o)da\c e(/lon a)/speton ou)=das x 269, *l 749, *w 738, terram hostilem moriens petit ore cruento Verg. Aen. x. 489, humum semel ore momordit ib. xi. 418, arenas ore momordi Ovid Met. ix. 61. cf. also the similar convulsive movement of the hand, ko/nios dedragme/nos ai(matoe/sshs *n 393, o( d) e)n koni/h|si pesw\n e(/le gai=an a)gostw=| (fist) 13.520.
o)da/c: equiv. to toi=s o)dou=sin, cf. pu/c *g 237 with the fist, la/c *z 65 with the foot; see § 38 g.
e)pekrai/aine: cf. 1.455; coincident with e)/fato.
de/kto: 2d aor., see § 35. The opposite is in o( d) ou)k e)mpa/zeto i(rw=n Od. 9.553, cf. 8.550 f. Zeus gave no sign of displeasure, hence it was inferred that he accepted the sacrifice.
o)/fellen: i.e. he gave them greater labor of war instead of giving them peace, cf. vs. 39 f.

*(hfai/stoio: i.e. blazing fire, cf. tanu/onto (sc. the pigs) dia\ flogo\s *(hfai/stoio *i 468. The god is put for his element; cf. *)/arhs for po/lemos v. 381; *)amfitri/th for qa/lassa m 97; *)afrodi/th for e)/rws x 444; *)axelw=|os for u(/dwr Eur. Bacch. 625; cf. Vulcanum spargere tectis Verg. Aen. vii. 77; Liber and Bacchus for vinum Hor. Carm. iii. 16. 34, Serm. i. 4. 89; Venus for amor id. Carm. i. 27. 14; Neptunus for mare id. Epod. 17. 55.
toi=s: see on 1.68.

cf. Od. 3.240.—mhke/ti ktl.: no longer now let us talk here for a long time. Nestor wished to prevent the conversation that generally followed a feast. He agrees with Agamemnon, vs. 381 ff., in calling for action.
mhde/ ti: and by no means.
a)mballw/meqa: cf. a)na/blhsis v. 380.
dh/: now.
qeo/s: Zeus.
e)gguali/zei: gives into our hands, in so far as the Dream directed the immediate preparation for battle.
a)/ge: here only in Homer with 3d pers. imv.
kh/rukes: i.e. Agamemnon's, as vs. 50, 442.
*)axaiw=n: const. with lao/n, as v. 163.
h(mei=s: i.e. the princes who are named vs. 405 ff.
a(qro/oi w(=de: assembled as we are.
qa=sson: the quicker.—e)gei/romen ktl.: cf. v. 381; as *d 352, *q 531, *s 304, *t 237.
Vs. 441-483. The army goes forth to fight.
au)ti/ka: asyndetic, see § 2 n.
oi( d) a)mf) *)atrei+/wna: the son of Atreus is included; cf. *g 146, *z 436 f., *i 81, *m 139, *o 301, g 163, q 502, x 281.
kri/nontes: following Nestor's advice, v. 362.
meta\ de/: but among them, as v. 477. She is unseen, as Od. 19.33. So Apollo leads the Trojans forward, ei(me/nos w)/moiin nefe/lhn *o 308 with a cloud wrapped about his shoulders. See on 1.198.
*)aqh/nh: sc. qu=ne, which is taken up by die/ssuto v. 450.

ai)gi/da: as goddess of war (on 1.206), Athena wears the Aegis of Zeus to inspire terror, as *e 738, *s 204, *f 400, x 297. The Aegis was a symbol of the thunder cloud, just as the Gorgon's head upon it represented the thunder storm. This is worn by Athena regularly in works of art.—a)gh/raon ktl.: epexegetical of e)ri/timon. a)gh/raos is always associated by Homer with a)qa/natos, and elsewhere in the poems is used only of persons, (excepting the gold and silver dogs that guard the palace of the king of the Phaeacians, Od. 7.94).
th=s: from which. Const. with h)ere/qontai.—The pres. is used of a divine and unchanging quality, cf. Od. 10.350.
e)upleke/es: evidently the art of drawing gold into thin threads was known in the Homeric period.
e(kato/mboios: worth a hundred oxen; cf. v. 649 for the round number. Cattle formed the standard of value in those times, cf. *z 236, *f 79, *y 703, 705, 885, a 431. Coined money was unknown.
paifa/ssousa: cf. e)kpaifa/ssein *e 803.
e)n w)=rsen: cf. th=|si de\ go/on pa/sh|sin e)nw=rsen *z 499, a)na/lkida fu/zan e)no/rsas *o 62.

kardi/h: in partitive appos. with e)ka/stw|, cf. *)axaioi=sin de\ me/ga sqe/nos e)/mbal) e(ka/stw| | kardi/h| ktl. *l 11 f.; see § 1 v. kardi/h is found in Homer only in this verse, elsewhere kradi/h, as v. 171; see § 13.

455-483. Six splendid comparisons, each of which progressively gives prominence to a new point: (1) the gleam of their armor, vs. 455-458; (2) their noisy tumult, vs. 459-466; (3) their multitude, vs. 467 f.; (4) their eagerness for the fray, vs. 469-473; (5) their marshalling leaders, vs. 474-479; (6) Agamemnon as commander-in-chief, vs. 480-483. See § 2 g.
h)u/te: as v. 87.
a)i/dhlon: destructive; from root vid-, as *)ai/dhs.
a)/speton: sc. in extent, essential for the comparison since the extent of the fire is a condition of its brightness as seen at a distance.

e(/kaqen: from afar, where the poet chooses his station with the men who are looking on; cf. e(/kaqen de/ te gi/gnet) a)kouh/ *p 634 and the sound is heard from afar, klisi/hqen a)kou/sas *l 603 hearing from his tent, Od. 1.328.
tw=n: of these, limits xalkou=.
e)rxome/nwn: as they were going forth.
qespesi/oio: because of the throng.

di) ai)qe/ros: i.e. reaches through the aether to the home of the gods, cf. on *a 195, h)xh\ d) a)mfote/rwn i(/ket) ai)qe/ra kai\ *dio\s au)ga/s *n 837, (o)rumagdo\s) xa/lkeon ou)rano\n i(=ke di) ai)qe/ros *r 425.
tw=n: prepares the way for the leading clause; it is taken up by tw=n v. 464, as tou/s v. 474 is taken up by tou/s v. 476; cf. *m 278, 287, *p 633, 635.
e)/qnea: cf. v. 87.

xhnw=n: the specializing of o)rni/qwn forms a concrete picture, of which the definite local designation forms a part, cf. quales Eurotae progignunt flumina myrtus Catull. 64. 89, nemora inter Cresia Verg. Aen. iv. 70 of a doe, saltusque Dictaeos ib. iv. 72 f.
ku/knwn: cf. ceu quondam nivei liquida inter nubila cycni Verg. Aen. vii. 699.

*)asi/w|: for the use of the adj., cf. e)n leimw=ni *skamandri/w| v. 467, Asia prata Verg. Georg. i. 383, quales sub nubibus atris | Strymoniae dant signa grues id. Aen. x. 264 f.—From this plain of Lydia south of Mt. Tmolus, the name of Asia spread to the Persian Empire and finally over the whole continent; as Europe at first was only the Boeotian plain.
e)/nqa ktl.: to this side or to that, cf. v. 397.—a)gallo/mena ktl.: lit. delighting with their wings, i.e. with joyous play of their wings.

klagghdo\n prokaqizo/ntwn: settling (forward) with loud cries, referring to o)rni/qwn v. 459. The flocks with incessant noise fly on again and again to settle in another spot, and the last birds to reach the ground take their places in front of the rest.
smaragei= de/: for the parataxis, see on v. 210.
pedi/on: the plain between the camp and the city.
proxe/onto: cf. ‘Saw what numbers numberless | The city gates outpour'd, light-arm'd troops’ etc. Milton Par. Regained iii. 310 f.
*skama/ndrion: sk here does not make position, cf. vs. 634, 824; see § 41 i. e.
u(po/: adv., explained by the following ablatival gen. podw=n, cf. u(po\ de\ ktu/pos w)/rnuto possi\n | a)ndrw=n *t 363 f.
au)tw=n ktl.: of both themselves and their horses, cf. v. 762; this limits podw=n.
The third comparison is closely connected with the preceding.
e)/stan: halted, stopped, as they came to the field of battle. For the aor., see on v. 94.
w(/rh|: in the season, i.e. in spring.
h)u/te ktl.: protasis to to/ssoi ktl. v. 472. For the omission of the verb in the first member of a comparison, cf. 24.42 f.
muia/wn: the fly has elsewhere also the character of an impudent, eager insect, cf. kai/ oi( mui/hs qa/rsos e)ni\ sth/qessin e)/qhken. *r 570, *d 131; for kuna/muia *f 394, see on 1.159.
a(dina/wn e)/qnea: cf. v. 87.
h)la/skousin: always hover about.
471 = 16.643.—o(/te ktl.: explains w(/rh| e)n ei)arinh=|, cf. w(/rh| ktl. o(/te h)/mata makra\ pe/lontai s 367.
te/: marks the close connection of the clauses; see § 3 o.
e)pi\ *trw/essi: to battle against the Trojans. For e)pi/ with the dat., implying hostility, see § 3 h b.
i(/stanto: were taking their positions.
diarrai=sai: sc. *trw=as, cf. *l 713, *r 727.
plate/a: standing epith., broad, wide-feeding; in contrast with ‘huddling’ sheep.
ai)po/loi a)/ndres: cf. basilh=i a)ndri/ *g 170, a)/ndres strathgoi/, a)/ndres stratiw=tai, a)/ndres a)delfoi/ Acts xxiii. 1.
diakri/nwsin: separate; subjv. of a general supposition, cf. *a 554, *e 161, *i 323, *k 486.
nomw=|: dat. of place.
mige/wsin: sc. ai)po/lia ai)gw=n as subj.
dieko/smeon: cf. diakosmhqei=men v. 126, dia\ tri/xa kosmhqe/ntes v. 655.
i)e/nai: for the inf., cf. ma/xesqai *a 8.
meta/: adv. as v. 446.

*dii\ ktl.: Agamemnon combines the majesty of Zeus with the grace of Ares. These characteristics of the gods seem known to the hearers from works of art. cf. 3.167 ff. Homeric comparisons of men with gods are generally indefinite, not specifying a particular feature.
For the chiasmus, cf. 1.443, 558 f., 3.51, 103 f., 179; see § 2 o.
zw/nhn: waist.
bou=s: made more definite by its appos. tau=ros, see § 1 u.
a)ge/lhfi: in the herd. For the ending, see § 15 a.
me/ga: far, see on 1.78.

e)/pleto: gnomic aor., freq. in comparisons; cf. 1.418.—For the comparison of a hero to a brute, cf. 3.196 (Odysseus compared to a ram), 4.253 and 13.471 (Idomeneus, to a wild boar), 5.782 (the Argives, to lions), 11.558 (Ajax, to a stubbornass), 17.281 (Ajax, to a boar), 17.570 (Hector has a fly's audacity).
ga/r te: always connected, like namque.
toi=on: such a one, sums up the characteristics which have been mentioned. In spite of v. 419, Zeus sustains the royal honor which he himself had granted (on 1.176).
e)kprepe/a: in appos. with toi=on.
e)/coxon: elsewhere followed by the gen. (as 3.227), except Od. 21.266.

div2.head: THE CATALOGUE OF THE SHIPS.
div2.p: Vs. 484-785. The forces of the Achaeans.
484-493. Prooemium: Invocation of the Muses.

484 = *l 218, *c 508, *p 112.—Solemn invocation of the muses where a faithful memory is needed for telling the story, or where the theme taxes the poet's powers. cf. a)/eide qea/ *a 1, a)/ndra moi e)/nnepe mou=sa a 1, pandite nunc Helicona, deae, cantusque movete, | . . . et meministis enim, divae, et memorare potestis; | ad nos vix tenuis famae perlabitur aura, Verg. Aen. vii. 641, 645 f.—For the repetition of the invocation, cf. ‘Descend from Heaven, Urania’ Milton Par. Lost vii. 1.
nu=n: now, closely connecting what follows with the advance of the Achaeans that has been described, vs. 455-483.

mou=sai: pl. as v. 594. Homer does not know the name of any muse, and has their number as nine only Od. 24.60. The muses could not be assigned to different arts and sciences before these arts and sciences existed.—For the rhyme between the words before the caesura and the close of the verse, cf. 3.133; see § 2 a.

pa/reste: sc. pa=sin from pa/nta. —This verse and the next following are parenthetical.—cf. ‘Say first, for Heav'n hides nothing from thy view, | Nor the deep tract of Hell’ etc. Milton Par. Lost i. 27.
h(mei=s: we singers.
kle/os: report, “what people say,” the saga, in contrast with i)/dmen.
a)kou/omen: we hear; equiv. to we have heard, as in the Eng. idiom.
plhqu/n: as v. 143.
an muqh/somai: for the subjv. with a)/n, cf. *a 137, 139, *g 54; see § 3 b.

ou)d) ei): not even if.— cf. non ego cuncta meis amplecti versibus opto, | non, mihi si linguae centum sint, oraque centum, | ferrea vox Verg. Georg. ii. 42 f., Aen. vi. 625, si vox infragilis, pectus mihi firmius aere, | pluraque cum linguis pluribus ora forent Ovid Trist. i. 5. 53 f.
xa/lkeon: epith. of strength and firmness; cf. 5.785, where Stentor is xalkeo/fwnos.
h)=tor: i.e. lungs.
This thought is hard to reconcile with the preceding, which notes the physical impossibility of rehearsing the names of so great a multitude.

*)olumpia/des: not a patronymic here, but a mere adj. of connection, cf. *ou)rani/wnes *a 570; the muses are *)olu/mpia dw/mat) e)/xousai v. 484; see § 21 a.—*dio\s ktl.: cf. v. 598, qea\ [mou=sa] qu/gater *dio/s a 10. The mother, according to the later myth, was Mnemosyne (Memory).
u(po\ *)/ilion: see on v. 216.
This verse promises something different from v. 487.
a)rxou\s au)=: in contrast with plhqu/n v. 488.
propa/sas: all together; as the poet adds a statement of the number of the ships to the names of the leaders of each people.

The Catalogue seems to be prepared for an account of the mustering of the Greeks at Aulis and the embarcation thence (cf. v. 509 f.), and to have been inserted here with divers alterations. We expect here an account of the forces, not of the ships.

The nations, their leaders, and the number of their ships are enumerated in a definite geographical order, in three principal divisions: I. (a) The main land of Greece south of Thermopylae; (b) middle and southern Greece with the islands immediately adjoining. 16 contingents. (Vs. 494644.) II. Insular Greece, from Crete to Calydnae. 4 contingents. (Vs. 645-680.) III. Thessalian Greece, from Mts. Oeta and Othrys on the south, to Olympus on the north. 9 contingents. (Vs. 681-759.)—The Greeks valued this list highly, because of its geographical and statistical information. It was their ‘Domesday Book.’ They looked upon it as a part of history, a versified geography and gazetteer. They appealed to it to settle disputed questions, and the charge of interpolating verses in it was like a charge of falsifying public records. The geographer Strabo bases upon it his account of Greece.

The poet evidently desires to represent this expedition as a great national undertaking. He enumerates even those nations which from their inland position were not likely to have had anything to do with such a war, e.g. the Arcadians (vs. 603-614), who are not mentioned in the rest of the Iliad as taking part in the battles on the plain of Troy. The poet does not seem to exalt one nation at the expense of another, either here or in the other parts of the Iliad. A bard wandering from country to country would acquire a wealth of geographical information, but would form no strong local attachments.

The Achaean ships number in all 1186. The number of men on each ship is stated for only two contingents: each Boeotian ship carried 120 men (v. 510); each of the ships of Philoctetes brought 50 men (v. 719). The ships of Achilles also brought each 50 men (16.170). From the average of the two numbers given for the Boeotians and the ships of Philoctetes, the ancients reckoned the whole number of Achaeans before Troy as about 100,000 (cf. Thuc. i. 10. 33 f.). Others reckoned the ships roundly as 1200, assigned 100 men to each ship, and thus estimated the whole number of Achaeans as 120,000.— *(ella/s and the *(/ellhnes are restricted to a part of Thessaly, vs. 683 f. The Dorians and Ionians are not mentioned. No Greek colonies are known, whether in Asia Minor, in Sicily and the West, or elsewhere. The names Peloponnesus, Attica, Eleusis, Megara, Delphi, Olympia and Pisa, do not appear. Thus this catalogue seems to have been composed before the Dorian migration into Peloponnesus, and the sending forth of colonies to Asia Minor etc.
494-644. I. Greece south of Thermopylae, with the adjoining islands.

494-558. Boeotia, Phocis, Locris, Euboea, Athens, Salamis. The enumeration proceeds from Boeotia in a northerly direction, then to the east, then southward, and so to the west, around Boeotia. Seven contingents; 262 ships.
The poet begins with Boeotia, prob. because the fleet collected at Aulis (v. 303). Because of this beginning, the ancients gave the name *boiwti/a or *boiwtei/a to the catalogue of the ships.

494-510. Boeotia. This document presents a distribution of the Greeks such as existed after the Trojan war. Acc. to Thuc. i. 12, the Boeotians lived in Thessaly until sixty years after the fall of Troy. See on v. 507. More towns are mentioned in Boeotia than elsewhere. This last fact may indicate not a Boeotian poet, but the extent of the culture and history of the country. Thebes is not mentioned; see on v. 505.

me/n: correl. with de/ 511.— The five leaders are all mentioned elsewhere: the two first, *c 487, *r 601 ff.; the other three were killed: Arcesilaus by Hector (15.329), Prothoënor by Pulydamas (14.450), Clonius by Agenor (15.340).
oi(/ te: refers to *boiwtw=n, resumed in tw=n v. 509.
*(uri/hn: not far from Tanagra and Aulis.
*au)li/da: where the Achaean forces gathered before setting sail for Troy; see on v. 339.

*qe/speian: without conj. to connect it with the preceding, in order to mark the beginning of a new series, as vs. 501 f., 560 f., 647, 739. Only the plur. of this word is used by later writers, as for *pla/taian v. 504; but Herodotus has the sing. of both, viii. 50. See § 19 j.—The town lay at the foot of Mt. Helicon. Thespiae and Platea were the only Boeotian cities to refuse ‘earth and water’ to Xerxes.
*grai=an: near Oropus. From this is derived the later name *graikoi/.

eu)ru/xoron: generally of cities (with broad squares for the choral dance), as here. Even now in Greece the villagers assemble on the public square for their dances.—Freq. in Homer are three substs. so placed in a verse that but one has an adj., and this adj. with its noun fills the second half of the verse; cf. vs. 497, 502, 532, 561, 582, 606, 647, 739, etc.
*mukalhsso/n: on the road from Thebes to Chalcis.
a)mfi\ e)ne/monto: dwelt about, inhabited; cf. vs. 521, 574, 585, 634, etc.
*(/arma: near Mycalessus. Here Amphiaraus (the chief hero of the expedition against Seven-gated Thebes) and his chariot sank into the earth.
*(/ulhn: on a hight by lake Copaïs; cf. o(/s r() e)n *(/ulh| nai/eske . . . | li/mnh| keklime/nos *khfisi/di *e 708 f.
*kw/pas: this town gave its name to the lake on which it lay.

*qi/sbhn: between Mt. Helicon and the Corinthian Gulf, not far from the coast. In the holes of the cliffs there, many wild doves now build their nests. cf. h( de\ *qi/sbh *qi/sbai nu=n le/gontai . . . e)pi/neion (roadstead) d) e)/xei petrw=des peristerw=n mesto/n Strabo ix. 411. Shakspere's ‘Thisbe’ was named for the nymph of this place.
poit/enta: here fem., an adj. of two endings; cf. h)maqo/entos v. 77 and note, a)mpelo/enta v. 561.
te/: for the vowel remaining short before two consonants, see § 41 i, b.
*gli/santa: at the foot of Mt. Hypatus. The decisive battle between the Epigoni and Thebans was said to have been fought there.

*(upoqh/bas: Lower Thebes, which lay on the plain; in distinction from Seven-gated Thebes with the Cadmeian citadel which was destroyed in the second Argive invasion by Diomed and his associates (cf. 4.406 ff.), and does not seem to have been rebuilt in the Homeric time.

*)ogxhsto/n: on Lake Copaïs, in the district of Haliartus. It was the chief seat in Boeotia of the worship of Poseidon, whose temple stood on the hight of bare rocks near the lake. In early times, it was the seat of an Amphictyonic league.
a)/lsos: sacred grove; in appos. with *)ogxhsto/n, cf. vs. 592, 696. The name was often applied to a sacred precinct even when no grove of trees existed.

*)/arnhn: to be distinguished from the Thessalian town of the same name, which was the old home of the Boeotians, and gave to this town its name. cf. *boiwtoi/ te ga\r oi( nu=n e(chkostw=| e)/tei meta\ *)ili/ou a(/lwsin a)nasta/ntes u(po\ *qessalw=n th\n nu=n me\n *boiwti/an, pro/teron de\ *kadmhi/da gh=n kaloume/nhn w)/|kisan (h)=n de\ au)tw=n kai\ a)podasmo\s pro/teron e)n th=| gh=| tau/th|, a)f) w(=n kai\ e)s *)/ilion e)stra/teusan, Thuc. i. 12. 6 ff.
*)anqhdo/na: on the Euripus, about seven miles from Chalcis (v. 537).
e)sxato/wsan: at the extremity of the land, cf. v. 616.
ne/es ki/on: cf. nho\s i)ou/shs *a 482.
e)n de\ e(ka/sth| bai=non: in each were sailing, sc. from Aulis; see on vs. 494 ff.
bai=non: cf. vs. 351, 611, 619. —e(/katon ktl.: prob. an unusually large number.
511-516. Orchomenus.

*)orxomeno/n: the rich capital of the famous empire of the Minyae; called *minu/eion in distinction from the Arcadian city (v. 605). Its wealth is mentioned in the same connection as that of Aegyptian Thebes (9.381). Agamemnon in Hades (Od. 11.457 ff.) asks Odysseus whether he had heard of his son Orestes at Orchomenus or Pylus. The so-called ‘Treasury of Minyas’ at Orchomenus resembles the subterranean structures of Mycenae (see on v. 569). Orchomenus was famous for its worship of the Graces, who were said to have been first worshipped there. Both Orchomenus and Aspledon (a small town) lay near Lake Copaïs, on the left bank of the Boeotian Cephisus (see on v. 522), on the fertile plain of Boeotia. The realm of the Minyae did not become Boeotian until later.
h)=rxe: sing., although two personal subjs. follow. cf. vs. 563, 650, 830, 842, 844, 858, 862, 876. See H. 607. The second subj., in many cases, seems to be added as an after thought.
*)aska/lafos, *)ia/lmenos: mentioned among the guards of the Achaean camp, 9.82. Ascalaphus was slain by Deïphobus, 13.518 ff., 15.111 f.
do/mw|: local, in the house.
*)/aktoros: Astyoche's father.
u(perw/ion: this served as the sleeping-chamber for the women, cf. a 328, b 358.
*)/arhi: she bore to Ares. For the dat., cf. v. 658. Ares was the national god of the warlike Minyae. For the long first syllable of *<*>/arhi cf. v. 767, *)apo/llwnos *a 14.
toi=s: const. with the verb; tw=n might have been used with ne/es, see § 3 g.
517-526. The Phocians. These also may be supposed to have fitted out their fleet on the Euripus.
*sxedi/os: dwelt at Panopeus; he was slain by Hector, 17.306 ff.
*)epi/strofos: mentioned only here.

*)ifi/tou: for this traditional form, the metre indicates the truer form to be *)ifi/too, with the last syllable lengthened before the m (§ 41 l). cf. o(/ou (o(o) v. 325, *)asklhpiou= (*)asklhpio/o) v. 731. See § 17 c. Iphitus son of Naubolus was on the Argonautic expedition, Apollon. Rhod. i. 207.
*puqw=na: metaplastic acc. of *puqw/, cf. *puqoi= *i 405, *puqw=de l 581. This was the later Delphi (*delfoi/), seat of the Pythian oracle. The epith. petrh/essan is well deserved.
*kri=san: on the plain, near the gulf of the same name. It seems in early times to have controlled the Pythian sanctuary.
*dauli/da: east of Delphi, on a hill; cf. Daulis quia in tumulo excelso sita est, nec scalis nec operibus capi poterat (sc. by the Romans) Livy xxxii. 18.
*panoph=a: burnt by the Persians under Xerxes (Hdt. viii. 35), as was also Daulis; and again destroyed by Archelaus, the general of Mithridates.
a)/ra: further; uniting the following to form a series with the preceding. cf. vs. 584, 615, 716.
*khfiso/n: the Cephisus takes its rise near Lilaea, on the north slope of Mt. Parnassus; it flows with many windings through Phocis into Boeotia, and empties into Lake Copaïs.
524 = v. 747. cf. v. 534 and note.
a(/ma e(/ponto: accompanied.
oi( me/n: the two leaders mentioned v. 517.
a)mfie/pontes: busily. For the use of the partic., see on i)w/n *a 138.
*boiwtw=n d) e)/mplhn: next the Boeotians. e)/mplhn is found only here in Homer; only twice elsewhere in this sense.
e)p) a)ristera/: to the left of the Boeotians, in the line of the ships and in the line of battle. cf. e)pide/cia v. 353.
527-535. The Locrians.

*lokrw=n: both the Epicnemidian (north of Daphnus on the Euboean Sea) and the Opuntian (so named from Opus the capital, south of Daphnus) Locrians, which are not yet distinguished by Homer. The poet does not mention the Ozolian Locrians (on the Corinthian Gulf).
*)oilh=os: gen of connection, with *ai)/as. See G. 167, 1; <*>. 729 a, 730 a. Cf. *telamw/nios *ai)/as, where the adj. is equiv. to a gen.
