taxu/s: cf. celerem sequi Aiacem Hor. Carm. i. 15. 18. In the funeral games in honor of Patroclus, this Ajax runs a race with Odysseus and would have won the prize, but Athena caused him to slip (23.754 ff.).—He was shipwrecked and drowned on the voyage home from Troy (Od. 4.499 ff.).

*telamw/nios *ai)/as: cf. 1.138, vs. 557, 768. Throughout the battles of the Iliad the two *ai)/ante stand near each other and are often mentioned together; cf. v. 406, *ai)/ant), *)argei/wn h(gh/tore xalkoxitw/nwn *d 285, *ai)/ante du/w, qera/pontes *)/arhos *k 228, *ai)/antes qou=rin e)pieime/noi a)lkh/n *h 164.
o)li/gos: small, like Att. mikro/s which is rare in Homer.

linoqw/rhc: as v. 830, with linen doublet, i.e. in a closely woven, thick linen jacket which came down only to the hips; while the xitw/n in the common epith. xalkoxi/twnes was cuirass and apron in one piece. The linen armor became more common in later times (see Xen. An. iv. 7. 15 of the Chalybes, to\n linou=n qw/raka o(\s e)pixw/rios h)=n au)toi=s Xen. Cyr. vi. 4. 2 of the Susians). This is suited to the leader of the Locrians who are described (13.713 ff.) as having no helmets, shields, or spears, but bows and arrows; but here Ajax is represented as excelling with the spear, and he has e)/ntea daida/lea *n 719.
e)ke/kasto: excelled; from kai/numai (with stem kad-).

*pane/llhnas: the Pan-Hellenes (cf. *panaxaiw=n v. 404), only here. This unites under one name the peoples of Northern Greece, as *)axaiou/s is used of the peoples of Peloponnesus and the adjacent islands. cf. kaq) *(ella/da kai\ me/son *)/argos a 344 through Hellas and the midst of Argos, as including all Greece; ‘from Dan to Beersheba’ Judges xx. 1, ‘from John O'Groat's to Land's End.’
oi(/: refers to *lokrw=n v. 527.
*ku=non: the harbor of Opus, made famous by Deucalion and Pyrrha.
*)opo/enta: the capital of the country, the native town of Achilles's friend Patroclus (*s 326, *y 85).
*ska/rfhn: near Thermopylae.
*boagri/ou: this empties into the sea exactly opposite the northwest corner of Euboea.
*lokrw=n: for its position at the beginning of the verse, see on ou)lome/nhn *a 2.—pe/rhn: opposite, not as v. 626.
i(erh=s: as 1.366. The cult of Apollo and Artemis was esp. prominent there.
536-545. The Euboeans.
me/nea pnei/ontes: as 3.8, cf. me/nos pnei/ontes x 203, pu=r d) o)fqalmoi=si dedorkw/s t 446, quae spirabat amores Hor. Carm. iv. 13. 19. Breathing courage, i.e. inspired with courage and fury.
me/nea: pl. because of the number of men; cf. Shakspere's ‘Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves’ Caesar iii. 2. 241.

pnei/ontes: Att. pne/ontes, cf. e)telei/eto *a 5, neikei/h|si *a 579.—*)/abantes: preHellenic Thracians who from the Phocian town Abae migrated to Euboea, and gave to the island its earlier name. cf. th
 pri
 *)abanti/da ki/klhskon qeoi\ ai)e
 e)o/ntes, | th
 to/t) e)pw/numon *eu)/boian boo\s w)no/masen *zeu/s Hes. Frag. 3.

*xalki/da: the chief town of Euboea, on the strait of Euripus at its very narrowest part; separated from Boeotia by a channel so narrow that plans are making to blast away the rocks, in order to open the way for steamers of ordinary size. In the early times of Greek history, Chalcis exhausted its own strength by sending out colonies,—founding the first Greek settlement in the West (Cumae in Campania), and the first in Sicily (Naxos, about 735 B.C.), and sending so many colonies to the southern shore of Thrace as to give its name to the great promontory of Chalcidice.
*ei)retri/an: the later Eretria. The short quantity of e before tr is unusual in Homer, see § 41 i.

polusta/fulon: cf. *eu)boi/hs a)mpelo/en pedi/on Theognis 784, polu
 piw
 *eu)boi+ko
 oi)=non Alexis Frag. 299.

*(isti/aian: trisyllabic by synizesis; cf. po/lios v. 811, sxetli/h *g 414, see § 7 a. The city was founded by the Hestiaeans (i(sti/h Ion. for Att. e(sti/a) who were crowded out of Thessaly by the Perrhaebians.
*di/ou: on the Euboean Sea, south of Oreos.
*ka/ruston: famed for its marble and asbestos. The Persian fleet touched there on its way to Marathon, Hdt. vi. 99.
au)=te: cf. au)= vs. 618, 678.
o)/zos *)/arhos: only metaphorical in Homer, scion of Ares, to denote bravery; cf. qera/pontes *)/arhos v. 110. Elephenor was slain by Agenor, 4.463 ff.

o)/piqen komo/wntes: see on v. 11; cf. (*qhseu\s) e)kei/rato de\ (in order to sacrifice his hair to Apollo) th=s kefalh=s ta\ pro/sqen mo/non, w(/sper *(/omhros e)/fh tou\s *)/abantas: kai\ tou=to th=s koura=s to\ ge/nos *qhshi+\s w)noma/sqh di) e)kei=non Plut. Thes. 5.—Mark the new thoughts added in this sent. by the adjs. without conjs.
meli/h|sin: i.e. e)gxei/h|si, since the shaft of the lance was of ash wood; cf. Cygnumque petit, nec fraxinus errat Ovid Met. xii. 122.
This verse is composed appar ently of six spondees; see § 39 c.
dhi/wn: const. with sth/qessin.
546-558. The Athenians and Salaminians.

*)aqh/nas: the city here represents Attica. The promontory of Sunium (Od. 3.278) and Marathon (Od. 7.80) are mentioned in the Odyssey. In the line of battle, the Athenians had the Pylians on their left and the Cephallenians on their right, cf. 4.293 ff., 327 ff. They were not prominent in the conflicts, but are mentioned *n 196, 689, *o 337.—e)ukti/menon: cf. ‘Where on the Aegean shore a city stands | Built nobly, pure the air, and light the soil; | Athens, the eye of Greece, mother of arts and eloquence.’ Milton Par. Regained iv. 238 ff.
dh=mon: the country, cf. 3.50.

*)erexqh=os: originally identical with Erichthonius. An old hero of Athens, under whose rule, acc. to Hdt. viii. 44, the people were first called Athenians. Athena herself is here made to be the founder of his cult.

te/ke de\ ktl.: parenthetical clause. Erechtheus is called ghgenh/s by Herodotus (*)erexqe/os tou= ghgene/os legome/nou ei)=nai nho/s viii. 55) and others. The Athenians boasted that they were children of the soil (au)to/xqones).
ka/d [kata/]: const. with ei(=sen, cf. a)na\ ei(=sen *a 310 f.
pi/oni: fat, i.e. rich; with reference to the votive offerings and other treasures stored there. A reference to the wealth of the temple of Apollo at Delphi is found in 9.404 f.

nhw=|: recent excavations indicate that before the Persian invasion, the temple of Athena on the Acropolis stood to the north of the Parthenon (dedicated at the great Panathenaic festival 438 B.C.), with foundations extending under the Hall of the Caryatides of the Erechtheum (completed about 407 B.C.). Columns and other architectural fragments of the pre-Persian Parthenon are found built into the wall of the Acropolis.

mi/n: i.e. Erechtheus who was worshipped with Athena since the two were considered the founders of the civilization of the country. cf. a)pa/cousi e)/teos e(ka/stou th=| *)aqhnai/h| te th=| polia/di (guardian of the city) i(ra\ kai\ tw=| *)erexqe/i+ Hdt. v. 82.
i(la/ontai: cf. (*pa=na) qusi/h|si e)pete/h|si (yearly) kai\ lampa/di (torch race) i(la/skontai Hdt. vi. 105.
peritellome/nwn: see on v. 295.—This then was an annual festival.
*petew=o: for *petea/oo, see § 17 c. The family of Peteos claimed descent from Erechtheus.

tw=| d) ou)/ pw ktl.: acc. to Hdt. vii. 161, an ambassador of the Athenians in the time of the second Persian war referred to these verses with pride before Gelo, tyrant of Syracuse, tw=n (*)aqhnai/wn) kai\ *(/omhros o( e)popoio\s a)/ndra a)/riston e)s *)/ilion a)pike/sqai ta/cai te kai\ diakosmh=sai strato/n. But the Iliad does not elsewhere mention or show this skill of Menestheus.
kosmh=sai: equiv. to the Att. ta/cai, see § 2 v; cf. kosmh/tore law=n *a 16, as an epith. of the generals. The inf. is used here as an acc. of specification.
i(/ppous: i.e. men on chariots, horses and all that went with them.
*ne/stwr: see on 1.247.
*ai)/as: son of Telamon; see on 1.138.

*salami=nos: Salamis forms a sort of stepping-stone in the enumeration, as the poet passes from Middle Greece to Peloponnesus. Telamon had removed to Salamis from Aegina (the home of his father Aeacus), because of the murder of his brother.

a)/gwn: for the use of the partic., cf. a)mfie/pontes v. 525.—Ajax here is brought into such close connection with Athens that he appears as a national hero of Attica. This was in accord with the later Athenian tradition. One of the ten tribes (fulai/) of Attica was named *ai)anti/s, after him.
559-644. Peloponnesus, Western Islands, Aetolia.
559-624. Peloponnesus.
*)/argos: the city, not the country. See on 1.30.

teixio/essan: as of Gortyna v. 646; well walled, lit. rich in walls (cf. teixi/on p 165), since Tiryns was famous for its walls,— the best known and oldest example of the so-called Cyclopean architecture. These walls are thought to have been 50 or 60 feet in hight, and in places are 20 or 25 feet thick. In the time of Antoninus Pius, they were declared to be as great a wonder as the Aegyptian pyramids. Excavations were conducted there by Dr. Schliemann in 1884-85, laying bare the plan of an extensive and elaborate structure.
kata\ e)xou/sas: which occupy.
*troizh=na: famous for the worship of Poseidon, and as the early home of Theseus.
a)mpelo/enta: for the form, see on poih/enta v. 503.

*)epi/dauron: famed for its temple of Asclepius. The theatre (built under the direction of the famous sculptor Polycleitus, with seats and orchestra still well preserved), and other ruins there, were excavated during 1881 and the following years.
*ai)/ginan: this island in very early times was conquered by Epidaurus. In the eighth century B.C., it was ruled by Pheidon of Argos.
kou=roi *)axaiw=n: does not differ materially from ui(=es *)axaiw=n v. 281.
boh\n a)gaqo/s: see on v. 408.

*diomh/dhs: son of Tydeus. Tydeus was son of Oeneus of Calydon, and brother of Meleager (v. 642); having slain some relative, he fled to Argos where he married a daughter (14.121) of King Adrastus (see on v. 572). He fell in the first Argive expedition against Thebes. Diomed took part in the second expedition (that of the *)epi/gonoi) against Thebes. He was one of the bravest and mightiest of the Achaeans before Troy. The Fifth Book is devoted to his exploits, in the course of which he wounds Aphrodite and (aided by Athena) even Ares. He has a famous meeting with Glaucus (6.119 ff.). He visits the Trojan camp in company with Odysseus, and slays the Thracian Rhesus (10.219 ff.). He reached Argos in safety at the close of the war (Od. 3.167, 130 ff.).
*<*>sqe/nelos: often mentioned in Homer as qera/pwn and charioteer of Diomed. The name is a short form of *sqene/laos, and thus corresponds to *dhmosqe/nhs.

*kapanh=os: the most insolent of the ‘Seven against Thebes,’ see 4.404 ff., where Sthenelus says h(mei=s toi pate/rwn me/g) a)mei/nones eu)xo/meq) ei)=nai: | h(mei=s kai\ *qh/bhs e(dos ei(/lomen e(ptapu/loio, | . . . kei=noi (sc. Capaneus and the rest) de\ sfete/rh|sin a)tasqali/h|sin u)/lonto. He boasted that he would capture the city of Thebes, even though opposed by the thunderbolt of Zeus, cf. qeou= te ga\r qe/lontos e)kpe/rsein po/lin | kai\ mh\ qe/lonto/s fhsin, ou)de\ th\n *dio\s | e)/rin pe/doi skh/yasan e)mpodw\n sxeqei=n Aesch. Theb. 414 ff.
*eu)ru/alos: appears in the combat 6.20 ff. He boxes unsuccessfully with Epeüs (builder of the wooden horse), 23.677 ff.
*mhkisth=os: brother of Adrastus, and thus great-uncle of Diomed.
ui(o/s: the first syllable is here short, the i being pronounced much like a y, rather than forming part of a diphthong; cf. 1.489 and note.
*talai+oni/dao: this seems to be formed by a cumulation of suffixes from *ta/laos, cf. *laomedontia/dh *g 250 from *laome/dwn, *(uperioni/dhs m 176 (equiv. to *(uperi/wn); see § 21 j.
o)gdw/konta: only here and v. 652; Ion. for o)gdoh/konta, see § 6 g.
569-580. The realm of Agamemnon.

*mukh/nas: The residence <*>f Agamemnon whose realm lay in Nor<*> ern Peloponnesus (the latter Achaea), extending to Elis. Above the gate of the citadel remains the sculptured representation of two lions, prob. the earliest extant specimen of Greek sculpture on Greek soil. Near the citadel are great subterranean structures, of which the finest and largest is the so-called ‘treasure house of Atreus.’ Mycene (the sing. form also is used, see § 19 j) is called by Homer eu)rua/guia, *d 52, and polu/xrusos *h, 180. The latter epith. was shown to be justified by the discoveries in the excavations by Dr. Schliemann in 1876-77.

a)fneio\n *ko/rinqon: Corinth was made wealthy in early times by its trade, lying as it did between two seas; cf. oi)kou=ntes ga\r th\n po/lin oi( *kori/nqioi e)pi\ tou= i)sqmou= a)ei\ dh/ pote e)mpo/rion ei)=xon, ... xrh/masi/ te dunatoi\ h)=san, w(s kai\ toi=s palaioi=s poihtai=s dedh/lwtai Thuc. i. 13. 15. The old name of Corinth was Ephyra, cf. e)/sti po/lis *)efu/rh muxy= *)/argeos i(ppobo/toio *z 152, and the poet does not put the name Corinth into the mouth of his characters.
*klewna/s: southwest of Corinth, on the road to Argos.
*)orneia/s: on the northern boundary of Argolis, toward Phlius.
*)araiqure/hn: thought to be the later Phlius.

*)/adrhstos: king of Argos, grandfather of Diomed (see on v. <*>63). He was driven out of Argos by <*>mphiaraus, and fled to Sicyon, to his mother's father whom he succeeded on the throne. He was the leader of the ‘Seven against Thebes’; and the only one of the seven who returned home alive.
prw=ta: at first, with reference to his return to Argos.
*(uperhsi/hn: in Achaea, on the Corinthian gulf. For the long penult, see § 41 b.
*gono/essan: from gouno/s, the hilly city (cf. Genoa): it lay on a cape near Pellene.
*pellh/nhn: in Achaea, about six miles from the sea.

*ai)/gion: later the capital of the 12 Achaean cities. Near it was a sanctuary of Zeus *(omagu/rios where Agamemnon was said to have planned the expedition against Troy, with the most honored of the Greeks.
*ai)gialo/n: the district on the north coast of Peloponnesus, east of Elis.
a)na/: cf. a)na\ dw=ma *a 570, a)na\ strato/n *a 10.
*(eli/khn: the principal town (before Aegium) of this district. Here Poseidon received especial honor; cf. 8.203, and ‘Heliconian’ Poseidon 20.404. This city was submerged by an earthquake, 373 B.C.
eu)rei=an: a freq. epith. of a country (as of Crete and the Troad); rarely applied to a city as here, cf. e)ni\ *knw/sy eu)rei/h *s 591.

tw=n [tou/twn]: i.e. the inhabitants of the cities mentioned just before. The gen. depends upon nhw=n, the ships of these, their ships; cf. vs. 509, 685, while in vs. 587, 610, 713, 719, new=n is in appos. with tw=n.

polu\ plei=stoi: since his kingdom was most extensive; thus he had the largest force of ships himself, and could besides these lend 60 ships to the Arcadians (vs. 610-614). The rule of Agamemnon ‘over many islands,’ implying naval power, is mentioned v. 108. — The verse ends like v. 817.
e)n de/: but among them, cf. v. 588; see on *a 142.
xalko/n: see on v. 417.
ou(/neka: because, referring to kudio/wn. — a)/ristos: sc. in kingly dignity and power, as is shown by the next verse. See 1.91 and note.
581-590. The realm of Menelaus.
cf. d 1. — koi/lhn: hollow; the land formed a basin between Mts. Taÿgetus and Parnon.
khtw/essan: the sharply cut ravines of the mountains are one of the most striking characteristics of the Spartan landscape.
*spa/rthn: the home of Menelaus.
*me/sshn: this was thought by some of the ancients to be the later *messh/nh (not mentioned elsewhere in the Iliad), which belonged to Sparta in the heroic period.

*)amu/klas: the seat of Tyndareüs and his s<*>ns. An old Achaean city in the va<*>ley of the Eurotas, about a league south of Sparta. It was one of the most important Laconian cities before the Dorian conquest, and long maintained its independence, by the side of Sparta.
*(/elos: a city on the coast from which the name helot was said to be derived, since its inhabitants were enslaved by the Spartans.
*la/an: for the name, cf. ‘Stone- ham,’ ‘Stonington.’
oi(=: for him, his.
new=n: in appos. with tw=n, see on v. 576.
a)pa/terqe: sc. from the troops of Agamemnon. This marks the political independence of Men<*> laus.
e)n de/: as v. 578.

proqumi/hsi pepoiqw/s: cf. v. 792, (*ai)nei/as) le/wn w(/s a)lki\ pepoiqw/s *e 299. For the long penult of proqumi/h|si, cf. v. 573; see § 41 b. The pl. is used because of the many occasions on which his zeal had prompted him to act.
polemo/nde: to the battle; po/lemos is often used in Homer as synonymous with ma/xh. — qumw=|: local, as 1.24.
591-602. The forces of Nestor.

*pu/lon: Messenian Pylus, on a harbor that is well protected by the island Sphacteria. During the Peloponnesian war (325 B.C.) the Athenians established themselves here and held the position for 15 years. In this harbor (then called Navarino), Oct. 20, 1827, the Turkish fleet was nearly annihilated, and the Greek war for independence virtually decided. — The realm of Nestor was founded by his father Neleus (son of Poseidon), who had been driven from Iolcos in Thessaly by his brother Pelias (cf. v. 715).

*qru/on: thought to be the same as *qruo/essa po/lis (rush-city), ai)pei=a kolw/nh, | thlou= e)p) *)alfeiw=|, nea/th *pu/lou h)maqo/entos *l 711 f.; on <*>he banks of the Alpheüs, near the <*>tier of Elis.
po/ron: ford; in app<*> with *qru/on, cf. a)/lsos v. 506. cf. *)alfeiou= de\ po/ron (d poihth\s) fhsi/n, o(/ti pezh=| perato\s ei)=nai dokei= kata\ tou=ton to\n to/pon Strabo viii. 349.
mou=sai: for the pl., see on v. 484.

to\n *qrh/ika: that Thracian. For the use of the art., cf. 1.11. The Thracian bards, Orpheus, Musaeus, Eumolpus, etc., who were called the fathers of Greek poetry, did not live in historic Thrace but in Pieria, in southern Macedonia, on the east slope of Olympus. Thence the worship of the Muses was brought to Helicon and Parnassus. — Thamyris is here thought of as wandering after the manner of the later bards (a)oidoi/) and visiting the courts of the princes.
*oi)xali/hqen: from Oechalia in Thessaly, cf. v. 730.

*eu)ru/tou: a famous bowman, cf. a)ndra/si de\ prote/roisin e)rize/men ou)k e)qelh/sw (sc. Odysseus), | ou)/q) *(hraklh=i ou)t) *eu)ru/tw| *oi)xalih=i, | oi(/ r(a kai\ a)qana/toisin e)ri/zeskon peri\ to/cwn q 223 ff. The famous bow of Odysseus was one which to\ pri\n me/n r() e)fo/rei me/gas *eu)/rutos f 32.
steu=to ktl.: he asserted boastfully that he would be the victor. Cf. *g 83, steu=tai d) *)odush=os a)kou=sai | a)gxou= r 525 f. he asserts that he heard of Odysseus as near at hand.
eu)xo/menos: for the partic. of manner, see on i<*>w/n *a 138.

ei)/ per a)/n: even granted that, supposing that. Here alone is a)/n found, instead of ke/n, with ei) and the opt., cf. 1.60; see § 3 c; elsewhere ei) a)/n is found with the subjv., as 3.25. The form in dir. disc. would be nikh/saimi a)/n, ei)/ per a)\n au)tai\ mou=sai a)ei/doien.
kou=rai ktl.: cf. vs. 491 f.

phro/n: maimed, here prob. mute (cf. v. 595), though a later tradition represented him as blind. — au)ta\r ktl.: this gives the result of their action, although elsewhere au)ta/r is used to introduce something new.
e)kle/laqon: sc. mi/n. Reduplicated aor., used trans., only here construed like a verb of depriving with two accs.; cf. lela/qh| d) o)duna/wn *o 60 cause him to forget his pains.

603-614. The Arcadians. The Arcadians are not mentioned as taking part in any of the conflicts before Troy. They may be thought of as closely connected with (or included among) the forces of Agamemnon.
e)/xon: cf. *)olu/mpia dw/mat) e)/xontes *a 18.
u(po\ o)/ros: up under the mountain, cf. v. 824, 3.371.

*ai)pu/tion: of Aepytus. For the use of the adj., see on *nhlhi/y v. 20. Aepytus, son of Elatus, was an old Arcadian hero whose descendants reigned long in Arcadia. His mound, which in the time of the early Roman emperors still rested on its circle of stones, reminds scholars of the German graves of the Huns.

i(/na: sc. ei)si/n. For the omission of the copula in a rel. clause<*> cf. *a 547. — a)gximaxhtai/: elsewhere only an epith. of the Dardanians in the formula *trw=es kai\ *lu/kioi kai\ *da/rdanoi a)gximaxhtai/ *q 173. These are combatants with sword, spear, and battle-axe, in contrast with bowmen, slingers, or javelin-throwers. The Arcadians are called e)gxesi/mwroi *h 134.
*)orxomeno/n: to be distinguished from Minyan Orchomenus v. 511.
polu/mhlon: cf. eu)mh/loio *)arkadi/as Pind. Ol. vi. 100.
*tege/hn: one of the most im portant towns in Peloponnesus before the Dorian invasion.
*mantine/hn: on the road from Arcadia to Argos. 500 hoplites from Mantinea and as many from Tegea were among the Greek forces at Thermopylae, to resist Xerxes.
*stu/mfhlon: famous for its lake (which has a subterranean channel that comes to the surface and empties into the sea near Argos), and for the labor of Heracles in killing the birds here.
*parrasi/hn: a district in southwestern Arcadia.
*)agkai/oio: Ancaeus took part in the Argonautic expedition, and afterwards lost his life in the Calydonian Boar-hunt.
*)agaph/nwr: not elsewhere mentioned in Homer.
e)n nhi\ ktl.: cf. v. 509.

qala/ssia e)/rga: cf. polemh/ia e)/rga v. 338, pole/moio e)/rga *q 453, e)/rga ga/moio *e 429. Arcadia, alone of the countries of Peloponnesus, touched the sea at no point. cf. praetor Achaeorum [Philopoemen] ... rudis in re navali erat, Arcas, mediterraneus homo Livy xxxv. 26.
615-624. The Eleans.
*boupra/sion: in northern Elis, cf. 23.631. The ‘whole and part’ are often thus united, cf. v. 632, *trw=a/s te kai\ *(/ektora *n 1, ‘Peter and the Apostles’ Acts v. 29.
*)/hlida: i.e. the country; the town of that name was not founded until after the Persian wars.
o(/sson e)f): i.e. e)f) o(/sson, const. with e)nto\s e)e/rgei encloses, bounds; lit. to as far, i.e. as far as; cf. 3.12.
*)amfi/maxos: slain by Hector, N 185.
*qa/lpios: not mentioned elsewhere.
h(ghsa/sqhn: took the lead; aor. as vs. 678, 864, 867, 870; cf. h)=rxe was leader.
o( me/n: Amphimachus, cf. N 185.
*eu)ru/tou: not to be confounded with Eurytus of v. 596.
*)aktori/wne: here of the grandsons of Actor; so Achil les is called *ai)aki/dhs v. 860, and Priam *dardani/dhs *g 303. See § 21 m.
*au)ghia/dao: Augeas, king of Elis, whose stables have become proverbial, is mentioned also 11.701, and his daughter Agamede 11.739 f. See on v. 660.
625-644. The Western Islands and Aetolia. — 625-630. Dulichium.

oi(\ de/: sc. h)=dan. — The poet places Dulichium and the other Echinades (which lie off the mouth of the Acheloüs) far to the south of their real position, off the coast of Elis. In *doulixi/w| te *sa/mh| te kai\ u(lh/enti *zaku/nqw| a 246, Dulichium seems to be included in the Cephallenian kingdom of Odysseus.
vai/ousi: lie, lit. dwell; cf. e)unaietow/sas v. 648.
pe/rhn a(lo/s: i.e. separated from Elis by the sea.
*me/ghs: appears 13.692 as leader of the Epeans; the inhabitants of these islands were Elean Epeans.
o(/s: Phyleus.
a)pena/ssato: emigrated, from a)ponai/omai.
patri/: King Augeas.
631-637. The forces of Odysseus.

*kefallh=nas: the common name for the subjects of Odysseus, cf. plhsi/on e(sth/kei polu/mhtis *)odusseu/s, | pa\r de\ *kefallh/nwn a)mfi\ sti/xes ou)k a)lapadnai\ | e(/stasan *d 329 ff., Od. 24.355, 378, 429.
r(a/: namely, to wit; the rel. sents. are virtually in appos. with *kefallh=nas. — *)iqa/khn kai\ *nh/riton: see on *boupra/sion v. 615.

ei)nosi/fullon: lit. leaf-shaking, as if the mountain caused what it suffered. — cf. the words of Odysseus: naieta/w d) *)iqa/khn ... e)n d) o)/ro<*> au)th=| | *nh/riton ei)nosi/fullon, a)riprep<*> a)mfi\ de\ nh=soi | pollai\ naieta/ousi mala sxedo\n a)llh/lh|sin, | *douli/xio/n te *sa/mh te kai\ u(lh/essa *za/kunqos i 21 f.
*kroku/leia, *ai)gi/lipa: these names do not appear elsewhere in connection with Ithaca. Perhaps these are districts of the island.
te/: for the vowel remaining short before *za/kunqon, see on *skama/ndrion v. 465. Theocritus has a(/ (Att. h(/) te^ *za/kunqos iv. 32, at the close of a verse.
*sa/mon: *sa/mh is a more freq. form.
h)/peiron: refers to Leucadia and Acarnania; conquered by Laertes, Od. 24.377 f.

a)ntipe/raia: neut. adj. as subst. The opposite coast; in Elis where the Ithacans had herds, Od. 4.635 ff. Odysseus himself had on the mainland twelve herds of cattle, as many flocks of sheep an<*> as many droves of swine, Od. 14.100 ff<*>.
*)odusseu/s: see on *a 138. — *dii\ ktl.: Odysseus is freq. called polu/mhtis and polumh/xanos. See §§ 1 q, 4 c.

duw/deka: a small number in comparison with the 40 ships of Dulichium, v. 630, or the 80 ships of Diomed, v. 568. The same number of Odysseus's ships is mentioned in the Odyssey, Od. 9.159. Eleven of the twelve were destroyed by the Laestrygonians on his voyage home, Od. 10.121 ff., and the remaining ship was wrecked by the thunderbolt of Zeus, Od. 12.415 ff.

miltopa/rh|oi: red-cheeked; their bows (cheeks) were painted with vermilion, cf. ne/as foinikoparh/|ous l 124, to\ de\ palaio\n a(/pasai ai( ne/es h)=san milthlife/es Hdt. iii. 58. On the other hand, cf. v. 170, and Od. 9.482 where the ship of Odysseus is called kuano/prw|ros dark-prowed. — The forces of Odysseus are the fifteenth in the enumeration of the 29 contingents. Corresponding to this position, these ships are said to be at the middle of the line, 8.222.
638-644. The Aetolians.

*qo/as: cf. *qo/as ... | *ai)twlw=n o)/x) a)/ristos, e)pista/menos me\n a)/konti, | e)sqlo\s d) e)n stadi/h|: a)gorh=| de/ e( pau=roi *)axaiw=n | ni/kwn *o 281 ff., *qo/anti, | o(\s pa/sh| *pleurw=ni kai\ ai)peinh=| *kaludw=ni | *ai<*>tw/loisin a)/nasse, qeo\s d) w(\s ti/eto dh/mw| *n 216 ff. Two others of this name are mentioned: one, king of Lemnos 14.230, and a Trojan 16.311.
*kaludw=na: on a shoulder of Mt. Aracynthus; it was famed for the Calydonian Hunt of the boar that was killed at last by Meleager.

ou) e)/ti: the two particles had not yet become welded together to form ou)ke/ti. See § 37 b g. — ga/r: introduces the explanation why Thoas was in command, and not Oeneus or one of his distinguished sons, Tydeus (see on v. 563) or Meleager.
h)=san: were living.
au)to/s: Oeneus.
canqo/s: see on 3.284.
*mele/agros: the most distinguished of the sons of Oeneus. The story of his mh=nis (not unlike that of Achilles) is told 9.529 ff.
tw=|: Thoas.
e)pi/: const. with e)te/talto.
pa/nta: everything, ex plained by a)nasse/men in appos. with it; i.e. the whole command.
*ai)twloi=sin: dat. of interest, cf. 1.180, 231.
645-680. II. The islands in the southern part of the Aegean sea.
645-652. The Cretans.

*krhtw=n: this includes all the mixed population of the extensive island, *krh/ths eu)rei/hs c 252. cf. *krh/th tis gai=) e)/sti, me/sy e)ni\ oi)/nopi po/nty, | kalh\ kai\ pi/eira, peri/rrutos. e)n d) a)/nqrwpoi | polloi\ a)peire/sioi, kai\ e)nnh/konta po/lhes. | a)/llh d) a)/llwn glw=ssa, memigme/nh: e)n me\n) *)axaioi/, | e)n d) *)eteo/krhtes megalh/tores, e)n de\ *ku/dwnes, | *dwrie/es te trixa/i+kes di=oi/ te *pelasgoi/. | th=|si d) e)ni\ *knwso\s mega/lh po/lis, e)/nqa te *mi/nws | ... basi/leue t 172 ff. — The cities here mentioned all lay in the interior of the island, at the foot of Mt. Ida.
*)idomeneu/s: see on 1.145.
*knwso/n: the principal city of the island.
*go/rtuna: the Cretan city next to Cnosus in importance. Here in 1884 was discovered a long inscription (prob. of the fifth century B.C.) containing a code of laws.
teixio/essan: cf. v. 559.
*mi/lhton: this city gave colonists and name to the Ionian Miletus; see Strabo xiv. 634.
a)rgino/enta: cretosum, chalky; as v. 656. The town was situated on chalk cliffs.

*faisto/n: southwest of Gortyna; birthplace of the poet and prophet Epimenides. cf. e)/sti de/ tis lissh\ ai)pei=a/ te ei)s a(/la pe/trh | e)sxati/h| *go/rtunos e)n h)eroeide/i po/ntw|: | e)/nqa *no/tos me/ga ku=ma poti\ skaio\n r(i/on w)qei=, | e)s *faisto/n, mikro\s de\ li/qos me/ga ku=m) a)poe/rgei g 293 ff. There half of the fleet of Menelaus were wrecked.
a)/lloi: made prominent before the rel. clause.

e(kato/mpolin: a round number, cf. v. 449; see Od. 19.174 quoted on v. 645. cf. quae simul centum tetigit potentem | oppidis Creten Hor. Carm. iii. 27. 33 f., centum nobilem Cretam urbibus id. Epod. ix. 29, centum urbes habitant magnas, uberrima regn<*> Verg. Aen. iii. 106.
a)/ra: recurs to v. 645.
*mhrio/nhs: son of Molus; relative of Idomeneus, and generally his companion in arms.
*)enuali/y: properly an epith. of Ares, cf. *)enuw/ E 333. The final vowel of this form is always united (by synizesis) with the initial vowel of the following word. See § 7.
653-670. The Rhodians.
*tlhpo/lemos: killed by Sarpedon, E 659. The other Rhodians are not mentioned elsewhere in Homer. —<*> te me/gas te: as 3.167, 226; two es<*> of a hero; see on me/gas v. 816.

dia/: const. with kosmhqe/ntes, divided in three parts. The Rhodians dwelt acc. to tribes (katafulado/n, v. 668), in their three cities. cf. dia\ gai=an tri/xa dassa/menoi patrwi+/an Pind. Ol. vii. 75, of the founders of Rhodes. Pindar tells in greater detail the story of the settlement of the island, and calls it tri/polis na=sos, Ol. vii. 18.
*li/ndon: famed for its worship of Athena and Heracles; native city of Cleobulus, one of the ‘Seven Wise Men.’ From this name came that of Lincoln (Lindum colonia).
This episode is intended for the glorification of the Rhodians.
*)astuo/xeia: *)astuda/meia is the name given her by Pindar.

bi/h| *(hraklhei/h|: periphrasis for all cases of *(hrakle/hs, which was not suited to the verse; see § 18 m. For the periphrasis, cf. v. 851, 3.105; see § 2 s. — Horace (Carm. i. 3. 36) uses Herculeus labor in another sense.
*)efu/rhs: the seat of King Augeas (see on 624); not to be confounded with *)efu/rh = Corinth, see on v. 570.
pe/rsas: sc. when he made his expedition against Augeas to avenge the wrong done him in withholding the reward for cleansing the stables.
tra/fe: intrans., grew up; const. with e)pei/, when he had grown up.
e)ni\ mega/rw|: i.e. in his father's house at Tiryns.
e)ni/: for the length of the final i before the following m, see §41 k, l g.
au)ti/ka: refers to the preceding e)pei\ ktl.
fi/lon: evidently only as a standing epith. here; see on 3.138, and § 1 p.
mh/trwa: brother of Alcmena, son of Alectryon.
kate/kta: in a burst of anger, says Pindar; by accident, acc. to another tradition.
o)/zon *)/arhos: see on v. 540.
o(/ ge: for its position in the second member of the sent., see on 3.409.

bh= feu/gwn: set out in flight, cf. v. 71; see on 1.391. The partic. indicates the manner of his going; — as a fugitive, since he feared the vengeance of the relatives. ‘A life for a life,’ was the old Greek law; but sometimes a fine was paid, cf. I 632. Flight from the country was frequent, as in the case of Tydeus (see on v. 563), and of Patroclus (see on 1.307).
e)s *po/don i(=cen: this is an anachronism. Even the Dorian migration into Peloponnesus followed the fall of Troy by 80 years (Thue. i. 12).
a)lw/menos: always in this place of the verse.
a)/lgea pa/sxwn: with sorrow. Const. with a)lw/menos.
trixqa/: cf. tri/xa v. 655; see § 12 i.
katafulado/n: equiv. to kata\ fu=la v. 362. See on v. 655. For advs. in -do/n, see § 38 c.
e)k *dio/s: see on v. 33.

kai/ sfin ktl.: an independent sent., illustrating fi/lhqen. — kate/xeue: poured down upon them. This indicates the abundance of their wealth. cf. multaque merces, | unde potest, tibidefluat aequo | ab Jove Hor. Carm. i. 28. 27. This expression seems to have given rise to the later myth that Zeus literally rained gold upon the island, e)/nqa pote\ bre/xe (rained) qew=n basileu\s o( me/gas xruse/ais nifa/dessi (snow-flakes) po/lin Pind. Ol. vii. 34, 50.
671-675. The forces of Nireus. The smallest contingent of all.

*nireu/s: mentioned only here in Homer. He is celebrated as a pattern of beauty. Lucian invents a dialogue between him and Thersites. — For the repetition of his name (‘epanalepsis’), cf. vs. 838, 850, 871; see § 2 p. Such repetitions served to chain the attention of the hearer. — *su/m<*>qen: a small island, off the Carian coast, north of Rhodes; a Dorian colony like the islands of vs. 676 ff.
The names of Nireus's parents are significant.
ka/llistos: pred.; see on v. 216.
a)/llwn: see on 1.505.
a)lapadno/s: the opposite of kratero/s.
676-680. The Sporades.
*kra/paqon: *ka/rpaqon, cf. kardi/h and kradi/h. See § 13. Carpathus is an island between Rhodes and Crete which gave its name to the Ca <*>thian sea.
<*>where *ko/ws in Homer; an island off Cnidus and Halicarnassus. It was the birthplace of Ptolemy Philadelphus, and is celebrated by Theocritus in his viith and xviith idyls.
*eu)rupu/loio: king of Cos. He was slain by Heracles on the latter's return from Troy (14.250 ff.). His daughter Chalciope bore to Heracles a son Thessalus, v. 679.
*kalu/dnas: small islands near Cos.
*fei/dippos, *)/antifos: not mentioned elsewhere in the Iliad.
681-759. III. Northern Greece. See on vs. 494 ff.
681-694. The forces of Achilles.
nu=n au)=: but now; a transition to the forces of Northern (Thessalian) Greece. This verse forms a general prelude and announcement for what follows.
tou/s: e)re/w hovers before the mind, cf. v. 493.
to/: dem., that.
*pelasgiko\n *)/argos: i.e. Thessaly, in distinction from *)axauko\n *)/argos (Peloponnesus). See on 1.30. Thessaly is represented as being more important than it was in historical times.
*trhxi=na: near Thermopylae.
*fqi/hn: home of Peleus and Achilles, cf. 1.169. In the valley of the Spercheüs.
*(ella/da: the country under the rule of Peleus. Thence the name was extended not only to what is known as Greece, but to Greek colonies all over the Eastern world.
kalligu/naika: this epith. appears only in the acc. The inflection of the adj. seems to be attracted to that of the noun gunh/.
*murmido/nes: cf. *a 180, 328. — *(/ellhnes ktl.: the later *)axaioi\ oi( *fqih=tai Hdt. vii. 132.
tw=n: see on v. 576.

penth/konta: Achilles arranged his men in five divisions with five commanders. Each of his ships was manned by 50 men, who (like all the rest) on their arrival at Troy served as soldiers. cf. penth/kont) h)=san nh=es qoai/, h)=|sin *)axilleu\s | e)s *troi/hn h(gei=to dii/filos: e)n de\ e(ka/sth| | penth/kont) e)/san a)/ndres e)pi\ klhi=sin e(tai=roi: | pe/nte d) a)/r) h(gemo/nas poih/sato, toi=s e)pepoi/qein, | shmai/nein, au)to\s de\ me/ga krate/wn h)/nassen II 168 ff.
pole/moio dushxe/os: cf. fremituque sequuntur | horrisono Verg. Aen. ix. 54 f.
ou) ga\r ktl.: for there was no one, etc.

e)pi\ sti/xas: into ranks, so as to form ranks. cf. *g 113. — h(gh/saito: opt. without a)/n, after ou) ga\r ktl.; cf. w(s ou)k e)/sq), o(/s sh=s ge ku/nas kefalh=s a)pala/lkoi *x 348 who should ward off the dogs from thy head.
kei=to: sign of inactivity, in sharp contrast with poda/rkhs. cf. vs. 721, 724, 771; a)ll) a)/na, mhd) e)/ti kei=so *s 178 addressed to Achilles by the goddess Iris.
e)n nh/essi: i.e. in the camp; see on 1.12.
kou/rhs: causal gen., cf. v. 694; see on A 65.
*brishi/dos: see on 1.184, 348.
e)cei/leto: i.e. received as his ge/ras e)cai/reton, see on 1.124.
*lurnhsso/n: in the Troad, not far from Thebes. Briseïs tells of its capture and destruction, 19.290 ff. See on A 125.
*qh/bhs: see on 1.366.
ka\d d) e)/balen: a change to the finite const., after the partic. diaporqh/sas, cf. 3.80; see § 1 e.
*mu/nhta: king of Lyrnessus, and (acc. to the later story) husband of Briseïs.
e)gxesimw/rous: see on v. 604.

ta/xa: Achilles is reconciled with Agamemnon, goes forth to battle, and kills Hector, on the 27th day of the action of the Iliad, five days after the events narrated in this Second Book. In other passages his inactivity is called long, cf. *)axilleu\s | e)cefa/nh, dhro\n de\ ma/xhs e)pe/paut) a)legeinh=s *t 45 f., 18.125, 248.
695-710. The forces of Protesilaus.
*fula/khn: this and the following four cities lay on the eastern coast of Phthiotis.
*pu/rason: named from the wheat (puro/s) which abounded in the region.
a)nqemo/enta: see on v. 503.

*dh/mhtros te/menos: consecrated field of Demeter; in appos. with *pu/rason, cf. vs. 506, 592. This afterwards gave to Pyrasus the name *dhmh/trion. — te/menos: lit. a piece of land set apart (te/mnw) for a divinity or a royal domain. Its use corresponds in some respects with that of templum.
mhte/ra mh/lwn: Mt. Ida is called mhth\r qhrw=n, *q 47.
a)gxi/alon: this epith. would fit the other cities also.
lexepoi/hn: grass-bedded, grassy.

*prwtesi/laos: the first to fall in the war; the name is significant, cf. v. 702. High honors were paid to him at Elaeus in the Thracian Chersonese, down to the time of the Persian wars; Hdt. ix. 116. His ship was the centre of the fiercest conflict when Hector forced his way to the ships of the Greeks, 15.704 ff., II 285, and it was half consumed by fire before Patroclus appeared with the Myr<*>, and repulsed the Trojans.
h(gemo/neuen: was the leader.

e)/xen ka/ta ktl.: held down, covered; cf. ka/texen fusi/zoos (life-giving) ai)=a *g 243. He was in the realm and power of the dark earth. cf. h)= min e)ru/cei (hold him back) | gh= fusi/zoos, h(/ te kata\ kratero/n per e)ru/kei *f 62 f.
me/laina: see on 3.103.
a)mfidrufh/s: women tore their faces in mourning, cf. a)mfi/drufoi pareiai/ *l 393.
*fulakh=|: dat. of place.

h(mitelh/s: half-finished. He left home for the war before he could complete his house. He had hardly begun life for himself when he was killed. cf. th\n oi)ki/an e)ktele/sai moi pro/teron e)pi/treyon h(mitelh\s ga\r o( do/mos katale/leiptai Lucian Catapl. 8.

*da/rdanos a)/nhr: a Dardanian warrior, as II 807. Acc. to the later amplified form of the story, this was Hector; but Homer does not call any Trojan *da/rdanos, though the Dardanians were included among the *trw=es.

ou)de\ me\n ou)de\ ktl.: as v. 726. The repetition of the neg. gives it great weight. The first neg. belongs to the whole sem.; the second is to be const. closely with oi(, — neque vero ne hi quidem. — po/qeo/n ge me/n [mh/n]: lit. they missed him indeed, equiv. to kai\ poqou=nte/s per a)rxo/n. The word before ge me/n is made prominent and always forms an adversative asyndeton (see § 2 m). The Eng. idiom introduces such a clause by yet, but.
a)rxo/n: i.e. their former leader.
sfe/as: monosyllabic, see § 7 a.
*poda/rkhs: leader of the Phthians, N 693, 698, since the cities named vs. 695 ff. were in Phthiotis.
*fu_laki/dao: with u_, but *fu^la/kh| v. 700; cf. *pri_ami/dhs v. 817 with *pr^/<*>amon *g 146; see § 41 g.
au)tokasi/gnhtos: own brother, as 3.238. The tragic poets use also au)ta/delfos, au)tane/yios, au)to/pais.
707 = t 184. — pro/teros: cf. progene/steros v. 555, geneh=| pro/teros *o 182.
Only another form of v. 703.
ou)de/ ti: but in nothing.
711-715. The kingdom of Eumelus.
f. *fera/s, *boi/bhn ktl.: cities on the peninsula of Magnesia and in the southeastern part of Pelasgiotis.
parai/: for the locative ending, cf. u(pai/ v. 824, 3.217; see § 37 d.
*boibhi/da li/mnhn: mentioned also by Pindar Pyth. iii. 34, Hdt. vii. 129; cf. *boibi/an li/mnan Eur. Alc. 590.
*boi/bhn: on the southeastern outlet of the lake to which it gives its name.
*)iawlko/n: famed as the chief seat of the Thessalian Minyae (see on v. 511), the capital of King Pelias, and the native city of Jason, the leader of the Argonautic expedition.
*eu)/mhlos: in the Iliad, only 23.288 ff., as a skilful charioteer. Acc. to Od. 4.797 f., his wife was Iphthime, a sister of Odysseus's faithful wife Penelope.
u(p) *)admh/tw|: const. with te/ke, cf. vs. 728, 742, 820. — For the repetition of the name, cf. vs. 636, 655, 691.
*)/alkhstis: she became proverbial for her devotion to her husband, which led her to die for him. This death is the theme of the Alcestis of Euripides.

*peli/ao: the unjust king of Iolcos who drove from home his own brother Neleus (see on v. 591), and his half-brother Aeson, and sent Aeson's son Jason in quest of the Golden Fleece. — qugatrw=n ktl.: cf. 3.124.
716-728. The forces of Philoctetes.
These places are on the coast of Magnesia.
tw=n de/: anteced. of oi(\ de/ v. 716. When the rel. clause precedes, the apod. often has de/, as here.
to/cwn e)u\ ei)dw/s: as v. 720 and freq. oi)=da am skilled in is followed by the gen.; cf. ma/xhs e)u\ ei)do/te pa/shs v. 823, pole/mwn e)u\ ei)dw/s *d 310, ku/ne ei)do/te qh/rhs K 360.

e)re/tai: the warriors were the oarsmen. cf. au)tere/tai de\ o(/ti h)=san kai\ ma/ximoi pa/ntes, e)n tai=s *filokth/tou naudi\ dedh/lwke (sc. *(/omhros).<*> toco/tas ga\r pa/ntas pepoi/hke tou\s proskw/pous Thuc. i. 10.
e)mbe/basan: had embarked; see on v. 509. The prep. is repeated in e)n e(ka/sth|.
i)=fi ma/xesqai: inf. of result, so as to (so that they could) fight etc. See on 1.8.
721 = Od. 5.13. The last hemistich as e 395, o 232.

*lh/mnw|: the Achaeans landed at Lemnos on their voyage to Troy and received hospitality from King Euneüs, 8.230 ff.; they sent slaves thither for sale, and received wine thence, cf. 7.467 ff., 21.40 ff., 24.753. — The repetition of the prep. gives to e)n *lh/mnw| somewhat more independence from e)n nh/sw|.
o)loo/fronos u)/drou: const. with e(/lkei+, ablatival gen., from the cruel water-snake; see on v. 396. The wound not only disabled Philoctetes but rendered his presence odious to his com<*>des.

<*><*>xa de\ ktl.: the Catalogue contains several such references to events which do not fall within the time of the action of the Iliad, cf. vs. 690 ff., 699 ff. — A prophet declared that Troy could be taken only with the help of the arrows of Heracles that Philoctetes had in his possession. Acc. to Sophocles in his tragedy Philoctetes, the hero was brought from Lemnos to Troy by Odysseus and Neoptolemus (son of Achilles). No other allusion to this story is found in the Homeric poems. Philoctetes reached home in safety at the close of the war, Od. 3.190.
*)argei=oi para\ nhusi/: parenthetical, in a kind of appos. with the subj. of e)/mellon. — *filokth/tao: const. with mnh/sesqai.
*me/dwn: is mentioned N 693, as in command of the Phthians, with Podarces (v. 704). He was killed by Aeneas, O 332 ff.
*)oilh=os: father of the lesser Ajax, v. 527.
r(a/: points back to the preceding verse, cf. vs. 650, 742.
729-733. Forces of the Asclepiads.
*tri/kkhn ktl.: cities in Western Thessaly, in Hestiaeotis. At Tricca was one of the oldest sanctuaries of Asclepius, and the home of the king.
klwmako/essan: rocky; it lay on the steep slopes of Mt. Pindus.
*oi)xali/hn: see on v. 596.
*)asklhpi_ou=: better written as *)asklhpio/o, see on v. 518.
*podalei/rios: mentioned elsewhere only *l 833. — *maxa/wn: heals the wound of Menelaus, 4.200 ff. He was wounded by Paris, 11.505 ff.
734-737. Forces of Eurypylus.

*(upe/reian: this spring seems to be in the mind of Hector when he speaks of the possibility that after the capture of Troy, his wife Andromache will be made, as a slave, to draw water, kai/ ken u(/dwr fore/<*>s *messhi/dos h)\ *(uperei/hs *z 457.
leuka\ ka/rhna: gleaming heights, lit. white heads; cf. v. 739. See on v. 117.

*eu)ru)pulos: a prominent hero. He was among the first to desire to try the single combat with Hector (H 167), and to rally after the rout (8.265). He is to be distinguished from two others of the same name, v. 677 and Od. 11.520.
738-747. The forces of Polypoetes.
*)/argissan ktl.: cities of the Lapithae (see on 1.263), in the western part of what was Perrhaebia in later times.
*)oloosso/na: the most important city in Perrhaebia.
po/lin leukh/n: because of its chalk cliffs.
*polupoi/ths: appears 6.29, with Leonteus M 129 ff. (where they are called Lapithae), 182 ff., 23.836 ff.
*peiriqo/oio: see on 1.263.
te/keto *zeu/s: cf. 14.317 f.
kluto/s: as fem., cf. kluto\s *)amfitri/th e 422. Homer does not use the form kluth/. See on v. 77.
h)/mati tw=| o(/te: see on 351.
fh=ras: see on A 268.
laxnh/entas: cf. h)\n me\n i)/dwsi komh/thn (long-haired man) | a)/grio/n tina tw=n lasi/wn (shaggy) tou/twn ... *kentau/rois h)/|kasan au(ta/s (took the form of centaurs) Arist. Clouds 348 ff.
*phli/ou: Mt. Pelion, south of Mt. Ossa, was celebrated in mythology as the home of the centaurs, esp. of Cheiron (dikaio/tatos *kentau/rwn) who trained the youthful Achilles, *l 832.
*ai)qi/kessi: these dwelt on the slopes of Mt. Pindus, near the sources of the Peneüs.

ou)k oi)=os: const. with h(gemo/neue, v. 740. — a(/ma tw=| ge ktl.: no conj. connects this with ou)k oi)=os, since it is in a kind of appos. with it (see § 2 m), expressing more fully the thought of the first words of the verse (see on A 2).
u(perqu/moio: in a laudatory sense. cf. ui(=as u(perqu/mous *lapiqa/wn ai)xmhta/wn (i.e. Polypoetes and Leonteus) M 128.
*kainei/dao: cf. A 264.
748-755. Aenianians and Perrhaebians.
*gouneu/s: only here in Homer.
*ku/fou: a city in Northern Thessaly, near a mountain and river of the same name.
*)enih=nes [*ai)nia=nes], *peraiboi/: Pelasgian tribes, mentioned only here in Homer. The Aenianians had different abodes at different times.

*dwdw/nhn: in Epirus at the foot of Mt. Tomaros, although the connection here seems to place it in Thessaly. There was the oldest oracle of the Greeks, where ascetic priests interpreted the rustling of the sacred oak; cf. the prayer of Achilles: *zeu= a)/na *dwdwnai=e *pelasgike/, thlo/qi nai/wn, | *dwdw/nhs mede/wn dusxeime/rou, a)mfi\ de\ *selloi\ | soi\ nai/ous) u(pofh=tai (prophets) a)nipto/podes (with unwashen feet) xamaieu=nai (whose beds are the ground) II 233 ff. No oracles are mentioned in the Iliad; in the Odyssey reference is made to the oracle at Dodonn, Od. 14.327 ff., and to Agamemnon's consultation of Apollo at Pytho (Delphi) Od. 8.79 ff.
oi)ki) e)/qento: built their homes.
a)mfi: on the banks of.
*titarh/sion: later called Europus. It rose on Mt. Titarion, near Mt. Olympus. Perrhaebians dwelt there.
e)/rga: tilled fields; cf. hominumque labores Ovid Met. ii. 404.

a)rgurodi/nh|: silver-eddying; because of the white waves and eddies of the turbid Peneüs, where the clear Titaresius empties its stream into it. The swift current makes it possible to distinguish for a time the waters of the two streams.
a)lla/ te: see on 1.82.
h)u/t) e)/laion: refers to the water of the one stream flowing above the other.

o(/rkou deinou=: explained by its appos. *stugo/s. cf. *stugo\s u(/dwr, o(/s te me/gistos | o(/rkos deino/tato/s te pe/lei maka/ressi qeoi=sin e 185 f. — This introduces a mythical explanation that gives a miraculous quality to the water.
*stugo/s: limits u(/datos as in Od. 5.185, just quoted.

a)porrw/c: branch of the water of the Styx, as the Cocytus also is said to be (Od. 10.514). This mysterious connection with the Styx (a stream with a high fall, in Arcadia) was imagined prob. because of its violent current.
756-759. The Magnesians.
*magnh/twn: a tribe in Northeastern Thessaly. They and Pro<*>hoüs do not appear again in the Iliad.
*phneio/n: the most important river of Thessaly. It flows into the sea through the beautiful vale of Tempe, between Mts. Olympus and Ossa.
*pro/qoos qoo/s: the poet puns upon the name, see § 2 c.
760-785. Conclusion of the Catalogue of the Achaean forces.
ti/s t) a)/ra: cf. 1.8.
o)/x) a)/ristos: see on *a 69. — e)/nnepe: see on v. 484.
au)tw=n ktl.: cf. v. 466.
a(/ma e(/ponto: cf. 1.158.

me/ga: adv., see on *a 78. — *fhrhtia/dao: Admetus; cf. vs. 713 ff. Or this name may be given to Pheres's grandson Eumelus, see on v. 621. In the funeral games in honor of Patroclus, these mares of Eumelus would have won the race but for an accident, 23.376 ff., 532 ff. — This statement is subject to qualification below, o)/fr) *)axileu\s mh/nien v. 769, vs. 764-767 being parenthetical.
*)eu/mhlos: see v. 714.

podw/keas: this and the following epiths. are attracted to the construction of the rel. clause; cf. *laodi/khn *g 124, *ai)qi/opas toi\ dixqa\ dedai/atai, e)/sxatoi a)ndrw=n a 23, *ku/klwpos kexo/lwtai, o(\n o)fqalmou= a)la/wsen, | a)nti/qeon *polu/fhmon a 69 f.
o)/rniqas: for the length of the last syllable, see on v. 190. For the comparison, cf. qei/ein d) a)ne/moisin o(moi=oi *k 437, of the horses of the Thracian Rhesus.
stafu/lh| e)i/sas: like to a plumb line, “straight as an arrow.” cf. e)pi\ staqmh\n i)/qunen e 245.
e)pi\ nw=ton: along, over the back, cf. v. 308.

e)n *phrei/h|: prob. the region of Pherae where Apollo served Admetus as herdsman. Angry at the death of Asclepius, Apollo had killed the Cyclopes of Zeus, and as a punishment was sent to serve a mortal; see Euripides's Alcestis ad init. Apollo retained his interest in these mares and sought to secure for them the victory in the chariot race, 23.383 ff.
fo/bon ktl.: the flight of Ares attends them. For the ablatival gen., see on v. 396. fo/bos does not mean mere fright in Homer, see § 2 v.

au)=: marking the contrast with i(/ppoi me/n v. 763; cf. au)=te v. 819, *a 237, *g 241, au)ta/r *a 51, 127, 333, *g 69. — *ai)/as: cf. *ai)/as, o(\s peri\ me\n ei)=dos, peri\ d) e)/rga te/tukto | tw=n a)/llwn *danaw=n met) a)mu/mona *phlei+/wna *p 279 f.
i(/ppoi: these were immortal steeds, sired by Zephyrus, given by Poseidon to Peleus; cf. 16.148 ff., P 443 f.; 23.276 ff.
fore/eskon: drew; the Homeric heroes did not ride on horseback. Thus i(/ppoi often stands for horses and chariots; cf. v. 554, 3.265.
e)n nh/essi: cf. vs. 688 f. This noun receives the epiths. of ships, although it means camp here.
a)pomhni/sas: giving vent to his wrath away (a)po/) from the battle-field, equiv. to a)pew\n kai\ mhni/sas.
laoi/: in contrast with d me/n v. 771, their leader.
774 = d 626, r 168. — di/skoisin: this contest was not unlike the modern ‘putting the shot.’ The prize was given to him who hurled the discus furthest, Od. 8.186 ff.
ai)gane/h|sin: dat. of means with i(e/ntes. The companions of Odysseus have their hunting spears with them, Od. 9.156.

par) a(/rmasin: where they had been tied when released from the yoke, cf. i(/ppous me\n e)/lusan u(po\ cugou= i(drw/ontas, | dh=san d) i(ma/ntessi par) a(/rmasin oi)=sin e(/kastos *q 543 f.; in contrast with u(f) a(/rmasi, where the horses are under the yoke before the chariot, as *q 402. — e(/kastos: appos., as 1.606.

e)leo/qrepton: grown on moist meadows. — The Homeric horses were fed on lwto/n (clover), se/linon (a kind of parsley), ku/peiron (a fragrant marsh plant) Od. 4.603, and on kri= leuko/n (white barley) *e 196, puro/s (wheat) 8.188, and u)/lurai *e 196 or zeiai/ (spelt) Od. 4.604.
eu)= pepukasme/na: well covered (sc. pe/plois, cf. di/froi ... a)mfi\ de\ pe/ploi pe/ptantai *e 193 ff., 8.441), away from the dust.

kei=to: lay. When chariots were out of use, their wheels were sometimes removed, cf. 5.722. But kei=mai is often perf. pass. of ti/qhmi. — a)na/ktwn: of the masters (const. with a(/rmata); Achilles and his lieutenants (see on v. 685). The laoi/ did not fight a)f) i(/ppwn.
oi( de/: the laoi/ and a)/naktes. — a)rhi/filon: only here as epith. of Achilles.
poqe/ontes: cf. v. 703.
foi/twn [e)foi/taon] ktl.: wandered to and fro, cf. 3.449.

Return to the narrative which was interrupted by the Catalogue (v. 484); but while, at v. 476, the leaders are busy in arranging their troop<*>, here they are represented as already moving forward for the attack.

oi( de/: the Achaeans. — w(s ei)/ te ktl.: as if the earth were devoured (lit. pastured off) by fire. ne/momai is used as pass. only here. The opt. is used to express a mere conception of the mind, cf. bh= d) i)/men ai)th/swn ... | pa/ntose xei=r) o)re/gwn, w(s ei) ptwxo\s (beggar) pa/lai ei)/h r 365 f., a)\y e)pe/qhx), w(s ei)/ te fare/trh| (quiver) pw=m) (cover) e)piqei/h i 314. — The comparison relates to the gleam of the armor and weapons, cf. vs. 455 ff.
“The earth trembled as from an earthquake.”
*dii\ w(/s: sc. stenaxi/cei, — groaned as it groans under Zeus, under the power of Zeus. u(po\ possi/ v. 784 corresponds to this.
*dii/: for the length of the ultima, see on o)/rniqas v. 764, and *dii/ v. 636.
xwome/nw|: in his wrath. An instance of the exhibition of this anger follows.

o(/te te: with hypothetical subjv., cf. o(/te te *zeu\s e)n fo/bon o)/rsh| *c 522. — a)mfi\ *tufwe/i: a mighty giant, symbol of volcanic power. He opposed Zeus, but was overcome by the thunderbolt, and was buried under a mountain. From this he belches forth fire. When he attempts to rise, he causes earthquakes; then Zeus smites with his lightning the earth about Typhoeus, i.e. the earth, that which covers him. Pindar, in his first Pythian ode, represents the monster as lying under Mt. Etna, and extending to Mt. Vesuvius. — cf. ‘In bulk as huge | As whom the fables name of monstrous size, | ... Briareos [ A 403] or Typhon, whom the den | By ancient Tarsus held.’ Milton Par. Lost i. 196 ff.
ei)n *)ari/mois: in the land of the Arimi, in Cilicia. This belongs to the so-called ‘earthquake belt.’ cf. durumque cubile | Inarime Iovis imperiis imposta Typhoeo Verg. Aen. ix. 715 f.
eu)na/s: couch.
cf. scuta sonant pulsuque pedum conterrita tellus Verg. Aen. vii. 722.
785 = 3.14. cf. *y 364. — die/prhsson: intrans., advanced.
pedi/oio: local gen., on the plain; cf. v. 801. The acc. is used with no essential difference of meaning, 1.483.
Vs. 786-877. The forces of the Trojans.
podh/nemos: Iris is a)ello/pos *q 409 storm-footed; cf. 10.437 quoted on v. 764. — w)ke/a [w)kei=a]: for the inflection, see § 20 c.
*)=iris: the gods' messenger in the Iliad for all that pertains to war, while Hermes bears the messages of peaceful life. See also 3.121.
pa\r *dio/s: const. with h)=lqe, cf. w)ke/a *)=iris | a)/ggelos h)=lqe qe/ous) a)p) *)olu/mpou *s 166 f., (*)=iris) *dio\s a)/ggelos *w 169, *dio/qen de/ moi a)/ggelos h)=lqen *w 561.

a)gora\s a)go/reuon: were holding an assembly, cf. po/lemon polemi/cein *g 435, boula\s bouleu/ein *k 147. — e)pi\ *pria/moio qu/rh|sin: at the gates of Priam; i.e. before the palace, where acc. to oriental custom the king sat in judgment. cf. (a)gorh\ ge/neto) para\ *pria/moio qu/rh|sin *h 346, ‘Judges and officers shalt thou make thee in all thy gates’ Deut. xvi. 18.
pa/ntes: i.e. all the nobles; it is limited by the circumstances of the case. — No special boulh/ (cf. v. 53) of the Trojans is mentioned. The gathering of chiefs 10.300 was only a council of war.
790 = *g 129, *l 199, *w 87. — prose/fh: sc. mi/n (referring to Priam), as v. 172. cf. v. 795.

fqoggh/n: at first only the similarity of voice receives prominence, as *n 216, *u 81, in close connection of thought with prose/fh. But here, as in the other cases, a transformation of the whole person is to be assumed; hence e)eisame/nh v. 795 without the addition of fqoggh/n. The contents of the speech, however, cause Hector to recognize the goddess, v. 807.
podwkei/h|si ktl.: equiv. to posi\ kraipnoi=si pepoiqw/s *z 505. For the plural, cf. proqumi/h|si v. 588.
tu/mbw| ktl.: on the top of the mound. This mound of Aesyetes was at the extremity of the ridge south of Ilium Novum. His son Alcathoüs married the daughter of Anchises (N 427).
de/gmenos o(ppo/te: exspectans dum, generally followed by the aor. opt., as de/gmenos ... o(po/te lh/ceien a)ei/dwn *i 191, cf. potide/gmenoi o(ppo/t) a)/r) e)/lqoi | *)idai=os *h 415 f.
nau=fin: ablatival gen. with a)formhqei=en. For the form, see § 15, a, b.
tw=| min e)eisa/menh: cf. v. 22, *p 720, *r 326, 585, *u 82, z 24. — mi/n: i.e. Priam; const. with prose/fh. This verse repeats the sum of vs. 790 f., because of the interposed clauses.
w)= ge/ron: as 24.411, 460, 683, in addressing Priam. Elsewhere this beginning of the verse is addressed to Nestor.
fi/loi: pred.
a)/kritoi: cf. v. 246. Iris blames Priam's untimely unconcern.
po/lemos de\ ktl.: contrast (paratactic, § 3 q) with e)p) ei)rh/nhs in time of peace.
a)li/astos: cf. v. 420.

dh/: equiv. to h)/dh. — polla/: cognate acc. with ei)sh/luqon. It does not differ greatly from polla/kis. — For the form of the contrast, cf. 3.184 ff., ai)ei\ me\n *trw/ess) e)pimi/sgomai ... a)ll) ou)/ pw toi/ous i(/ppous i)/don *k 548 ff., Od. 4.267 ff., Od. 11.416 ff.

e)oiko/tes: sc. in number. cf. v. 468. — cf. ‘I will multiply thy seed as the stars of the heaven, and as the sand which is upon the seashore,’ Genesis xxii. 17. — h)/: in a comparison where the poet leaves the choice open; cf. *phnelo/peia | *)arte/midi i)ke/lh h)e\ xruse/h| *)afrodi/th| r 36 f.
proti\ a)/stu: const. with e)/rxontai.

*(/ektor: Iris turns to address Hector as the commander-in-chief, on whom above all others depends the weal of the state; cf. oi)=os ga\r e)ru/eto (guarded) *)/ilion *)/ektwr *z 403, oi)=os ga/r sfin e)/ruso pu/las kai\ tei/xea makra/ *x 507, o(/ moi (sc. Hecuba) nu/ktas te kai\ h)=mar | eu)xwlh\ kata\ a)/stu pele/skeo, pa=si/ t) o)/neiar | *trwsi/ te kai\ *trwh=|si kata\ pto/lin, oi(/ se qeo\n w(\s | deide/xato *x 432 ff. Hector was the mightiest of the fifty sons of Priam, 24.495 ff. In Z is the account of an affectionate meeting of Hector and his wife Andromache; in H, Hector fights in single combat with Telamonian Ajax; he breaks his way through the gates of the Greek camp, M 445 ff.; he is grievously wounded by Ajax, 14.402 ff., but Apollo restores his strength, and he returns to the conflict, 15.246 ff., and advances to the very ships of the Achaeans, 16.114 ff.; he slays Patroclus, the friend of Achilles, 16.818 ff.; he is himself slain by Achilles, 22.330. The Twentyfourth Book tells the story of Priam's visit to the Achaean camp to ransom Hector's body. The last verse of the Iliad is w(\s oi(/ g) a)mfi/epon ta/fon *(/ektoros i(ppoda/moio *w 804. — de/: for the order of words, see on A 282.
w(=de/ ge: const. with r(e/cai. It refers to what follows; cf. 3.442.
polloi\ ktl.: explanatory preparation for v. 805. For the thought, cf. vs. 130 f.

cf. ou) ga\r pa/ntwn (sc. *trw/wn h)d) e)pikou/rwn) h)=en o(mo\s qro/os (shout) ou)d) i)/a gh=rus (voice), | a)lla\ glw=ss) e)me/mikto, polu/klhtoi d) e)/san a)/ndres *d 437 f., Od. 19.175 (quoted on v. 645).
poluspere/wn: wide-spread, far-scattered, like polu/klhtoi of 4.438.

toi=sin: to these; antec. of the following rel. No conj. is used to connect this with what has preceded, since this is in a kind of appos. with w(=de/ ge r(e/cai. For the dat., cf. *trwsi/ v. 816. Each is to give orders to his countrymen, as usual. This indicates the separation into tribes (accomplished v. 815) corresponding to that of the Greeks, vs. 362 f.
tw=n d) e)chgei/sqw: and let him lead these forth, sc. from the city to the field of battle.
polih/tas: his fellow-citizens; without any political meaning; equiv. to oi(=si/ per a)/rxei. This measure is intended esp. for the great number of Trojan allies.
ou)/ ti ktl.: by no means failed to recognize (i.e. he recognized clearly) the speech of the goddess, he recognized the goddess herself. For the litotes, see on 1.220, § 2 r.
e)pi\ teu/xea: to fetch their arms; like Att. meta\ teu/xea, cf. e)pi\ bou=n i)/tw g 421 fetch a heifer.

pa=sai pu/lai: the whole gate, — the Scaean (3.145) or Dardanian (5.789) gates, leading from the city to the plain. Homer does not mention any other gates of the city. pu/lai is always plural in Homer, of one gate with two wings or doors (sani/des).
810 = *q 59, w 70. The second hemistich also *d 449, *q 63. — i(pph=es: cf. i(ppo/ta v. 336; not mounted like the Attic i(pph=s.

e)/sti de/ tis: a favorite Epic beginning of a description, cf. e)/sti de/ tis *qruo/essa po/lis *l 711, e)/sti de/ tis potamo\s ktl. *l 722, e)/sti de/ ti spe/os *n 32, cf. e)/sti po/lis *)efu/rh *z 152, urbs antiqua fuit Verg. Aen. i. 12.
po/lios: disyllabic by synizesis; see § 7. The ultima is long before the caesural pause; see § 41 p.
a)pa/neuqe: aside, sc. from the principal road.
peri/dromos: i.e. freelying, lying in an open place. cf. peri/dromoi a)mfote/rwqen *e 726. — e)/nqa ktl.: see on v. 397.
*bati/eian: rubeta, Thornhill.
a)qa/natoi ktl.: for the language of the gods, see on *a 403. — sh=ma: such a tomb as that of v. 604.
poluska/rqmoio: agile, sc. in battle; cf. e)u/skarqmoi fe/ron i(/ppoi *n 31.
*muri/nhs: perhaps one of the Amazons mentioned 3.189.
die/kriqen: see on v. 805; cf. vs. 475 f.

816-877. The Trojans and their Allies. The force opposed to the Achaeans is composed of sixteen contingents: I. five contingents from Trojan peoples (vs. 816-839), and II. eleven contingents of allies (e)pi/kouroi, vs. 840-877). Of the allies, three divisions come from Europe, and eight from Asia. I. Trojans from (a) Ilios, (b) Dardania, (c) Zelea, (d) Adrastea, (e) Percote etc.; II. Allies (from Europe), (a) Thracians, (b) Ciconians, (c) Paeonians; (from Asia), (a) Pelasgians, (b) Paphlagonians, (c) Halizonians, (d) Mysians, (e) Phrygians, (f) Maeonians, (g) Carians, (h) Lydians.

The catalogue of the Trojans is far less exact and detailed than that of the Achaeans; it contains no definite statements of number. The total number of Trojans and allies was 50,000, acc. to 8.562 f.: ‘A thousand fires were kindled on the plain, and by each sat fifty men.’ Of these about 12,000 were Trojans, if vs. 123130 are to be interpreted literally. The Catalogue does not name the *le/leges and *kau/kwnes (*k 429, *u 329, *f 86). In *k 434, l 519-522, other troops are mentioned as reinforcements.
816-839. The Trojans.
*trwsi/: in the narrower sense, the inhabitants of the city *)/ilios. — me/gas: of stature. The Greeks were prone to believe that no man could be physically small, but mentally great. cf. v. 653.

koruqai/olos: as epith. of Ares, 20.38; elsewhere only of Hector, as 3.324. Helmet-waving, a mark of martial activity, cf. et cristam adverso curru quatit aura volantem Verg. Aen. xii. 370. — The last half of this verse is found twelve times in the Iliad.
plei=stoi ktl.: as the flower of the whole army.
mema_o/tes: as *n 197, *p 754, elsewhere mema^w=tes as v. 543; see § 41 d. Only here with the simple dat., striving forward with the lance, i.e. eager for the fray.

*dardani/wn: adj. as subst.; “inhabitants of the district Dardania,” cf. (*da/rdanos, ui(o\s *dio\s) kti/sse de\ *dardani/hn, e)pei\ ou)/ pw *)/ilios i(/rh | e)n pedi/w| pepo/listo *u 216 f. Dardanus was grandfather of Tros, who gave his name to the district *troi/h (v. 162, 3.74); while Tros in turn was the father of Ilus, who gave his name to the city *)/ilios and was father of Laomedon and grandfather of Priam. See 20.215 f. The Dardanians are second in rank to the Trojans; cf. *trw=es kai\ *da/rdanoi h)d) e)pi/kouroi *g 456. Elsewhere they are called *da/rdanoi, but only in the two oft-recurring verses, *g 456, *trw=es kai\ *lu/kioi kai\ *da/rdanoi a)gximaxhtai/ *q 173; they are also called *dardani/wnes, as 7.414; the women are called *dardani/des, as 18.339. The name is preserved in the modern ‘Dardanelles.’
au)=te: correl. with me/n v. 816, see on v. 768.
*)agxi/sao: Anchises is nowhere referred to by Homer as alive at the time of this war.

*ai)nei/as: the hero of the Aeneid. He is a third cousin of Hector. He was severely wounded by Diomed, E 305 ff., but was rescued by his mother Aphrodite, and healed by Apollo in his temple, 5.445 ff.; he led one of the battalions against the wall of the Achaeans, 12.98; he met Achilles, and would have been slain by him, but for the intervention of Poseidon, who saved him that the race of Dardanus might not be entirely destroyed, nu=n de\ dh\ *ai)nei/ao bi/h *trw/essin a)na/cei | kai\ pai/dwn pai=des *u 307 f.
*)afrodi/th: in this word fr cannot be allowed to make the preceding vowel long by metrical position; for it would give ¯ ˘ ¯ ¯, which could not be introduced in dactylic verse. See §41 i a.
*)/idhs: a lofty mountain-chain in the Troad, stretching from northwest to southeast, with many projecting shoulders.

e)n knhmoi=si: where Anchises had charge of the herds and herdsmen; cf. h(/ min (Aeneas) u(p) *)agxi/sh| te/ke boukole/onti *e 313. It was one of the patriarchal customs of those times that kings and kings' sons tended their flocks on the slopes of the mountains, cf. 6.25, 424.
qea\ brotw=|: for the antithesis, cf. oi(=on dh/ nu qeou\s brotoi\ ai)tio/wntai a 32.

*)anth/noros: Antenor was the Trojan Nestor, and father of many doughty sons, of whom nine are mentioned in the Iliad, besides the two following. Seven of the eleven sons were slain in the battles of the Iliad. He advocated the restoration of Helen and her treasures, 7.350 ff.; he received Menelaus and Odysseus at his house when they came to Troy as embassadors, 3.205 ff.; he accompanied Priam to the field to strike a truce, 3.262. cf. 3.148.
*)arxe/loxos: slain by Ajax, 14.463 ff.
*)aka/mas: slain by Meriones, 16.342 ff.
ma/xhs pa/shs: every kind of battle, — on foot or in the chariot, with lance or sword. For the gen., see on v. 718.
de/: for the short vowel before following z, see on v. 465.
*ze/leian: also called *ze/lh (cf. *)aqhnai/h and *)aqh/nh), on the frontier of Mysia.
u(pai/: see on parai/ v. 711.
po/da nei/aton: i.e. the northern slope. For the acc., cf. v. 603.

a)fneioi/: because of the welltilled farms, acc. to Strabo. — pi/nontes ktl.: this expression was often imitated; cf. ta=s (*qh/bas) e)rateino\n u(/dwr pi/omai Pind. Ol. vi. 85, extremum Tanain si biberes, Lyce Hor. Carm. iii. 10. 1, non qui profundum Danubium bibunt | edicta rumpent Iulia id. iv. 15. 21 f., exsul | aut Ararim Parthus bibet, aut Germania Tigrim Verg. Ecl. i. 62 f.
me/lan: this epith. is applied to springs and rivers, as well as to the sea, when the surface is disturbed by breezes in such a way as to prevent a clear reflection of the sun's light.
*trw=es: in the broader sense, the inhabitants of the country.
*pa/ndaros: he broke the truce of the Third Book, by shooting an arrow at Menelaus, 4.89 ff.; he was slain by Diomed, 5.290 ff.

kai/: see on *a 249. — to/con ktl.: i.e. Apollo gave him skill with the bow; cf. to/con o(/ toi (Teucer) po/re *foi=bos *)apo/llwn O 441, laetus Apollo | augurium citharamque dabat, celeresque sagittas Verg. Aen. xii. 393 f. The ancients believed that the bow of an excellent archer must be the gift of the god of the bow. The making of the bow of Pandarus, from the horns of a wild goat shot by himself, is described 4.105-111.
*)adrh/steian: received its name from Adrestus, v. 830. Like the following cities, it lay in what was Mysia in later times.
dh=mon: the country, as v. 547.
*)apaisou=: seems to be the *paiso/s of 5.612.
*pitu/eian: received its name from the neighboring pine forests; as the neighboring Lampsacus was called *pituou=sa. — *threi/hs: a mountainous region near Cyzicus.
*)amfi/os: the penult is long also 5.612. Amphius and Adrestus were slain by Diomed, 11.328 ff.
linoqw/rhc: perhaps as an archer; see on v. 529.
*perkwsi/ou: he seems to have lived formerly in Percote (v. 835); or Adrastea may have been a colony from Percote.
peri\ pa/ntwn: see on A 258.

h)/|dee ktl.: Homer knows of no professional soothsayers: Calchas (A 69), Helenus (Z 76), Ennomus (v. 858), Melampus (Od. 15.225), Halitherses (Od. 2.157), — all are introduced as busy in different ways, in war and in peace.
ou)de/: for the lengthened ultima before the possessive pron., see § 41 m.
ou)de\ e)/asken: ‘resistance to pressure’ is implied in the impf.; he continually refused his consent.
fqish/nora: a standing epith. of the battle, as *i 604, *l 331; only in the acc. cf. ma/xh fqisi/mbrotos *n 339, *)/arhs brotoloigo/s *e 518.

kh=res ga\r ktl.: cf. a)lla/ e( moi=ra | h)=g) e)pikourh/sonta meta\ *pri/amo/n te kai\ ui(=as *e 613 f., to\n d) a)/ge moi=ra kakh\ qana/toio te/losde *n 602, to\n kh=res e)/ban qa/natoio fe/rousai | ei)s *)ai/dao do/mous c 207 f.

me/lanos: cf. qana/tou de\ me/lan ne/fos a)mfeka/luyen *p 350, to\n de\ sko/tos o)/sse ka/luyen *d 461, a)mfi\ de\ o)/sse kelainh\ nu\c e)ka/luyen *e 310, tw\ de/ oi( o)/sse | nu/c e)ka/luye me/laina *c 438 f., e)rebennh\ nu\c e)ka/luyen *n 580, stugero\s d) a)/ra min sko/tos ei(=len *n 672.
a)/ra: as v. 522.
*perkw/thn: Percote, Abydus, and Arisbe, were cities on the south side of the Hellespont.
*pra/ktion: a stream which empties into the Hellespont between Lampsacus and Abydus.

*shsto/n: on the Thracian Chersonese, opposite Abydus. Here Xerxes bridged the Hellespont, Hdt. vii. 33. Here, too, Leander of Abydus swam the Hellespont to visit his love, Hero, the priestess of Sestus.

*)/asios: one of the leaders in the attack on the Achaean camp, 12.95 ff.; slain by Idomeneus, 13.384 ff. He is to be distinguished from his ‘homonym’ Asius, a Phrygian prince, brother of Priam's wife Hecuba.
*)/asios: for the repetition of the name, see on v. 671.
840-877. The Allies of the Trojans.
*(ippo/qoos: slain by Ajax, 17.288 ff.

*pelasgw=n: a part settled in Greece proper, a part must have remained in Asia Minor. They gave to many of their towns the name Larisa (rock-citadel). The geographer Stephanus of Byzantium enumerates ten towns of this name, besides the citadel Larissa of Argos. Strabo (xiii. 620) enumerates three in Asia Minor: one in sight of Ilios, another near Ephesus, and a third near Cyme; he holds the last to be the one in the poet's mind here, because of 17.301 where Ilippothous falls th=l) o)po\ *lari/shs e)ribw/lakos.
*pulai=os: mentioned only here in Homer.

The following enumeration of allies has a radial arrangement, preceding from Troy as the centre and starting-point. Each radius ends with a thlo/qen (vs. 849, 857, 877) or th=le (v. 863) for the most distant point from Troy. I. European line, (vs. 844-850). II. Northeast of Troy, on the southern shore of the Euxine sea (vs. 851-857). III. Southeast of Troy (vs. 858-863). IV. South of Troy (vs. 864-877).
*qrh/ikas: European Thracians, dwelling between the Hebrus and the Hellespont.
h)=ge for the sing., see on v. 512.
*)aka/mas: slain by Ajax, 6.8 ff.
*pei/roos: slain by Thoas, 4.527 ff.
*(ellh/spontos: the Hellespont in Homer includes also the neighboring waters.
a)ga/rroos: with strong stream. It is called a potamo/s in Hdt. vii. 35. No current of the Mediterranean compares with that of the Hellespont.
e)nto\s e)e/rgei: as v. 617.
*eu)/fhmos: mentioned only here. Mentes is leader of the *ki/kones, *p 73.
*kiko/nwn: Odysseus destroyed their city, after leaving Troy, Od. 9.39 ff. They are mentioned among the Thracian nations through whose country Xerxes passed, Hdt. vii. 110.
*kea/dao: patronymic from *ke/as.

*purai/xmhs: (with lance of fire), slain by Patroclus, 16.287 ff. Elsewhere *)asteropai=os (the man of lightning) is named as leader of the Paeonians, as *p 351. — *pai/onas: akin to the Trojans; cf. ei)/h de\ h( *paiwni/h e)pi\ tw=| *strumo/ni potamw=| pepolisme/nh, ... ei)/hsan de\ *teukrw=n tw=n e)k *troi/hs a)/poikoi Hdt. v. 13.

a)gkuloto/cous: as 10.428 (also of the Paeonians), cf. *mh/deioi a)gkulo/tocoi Pind. Pyth. i. 78; a)gku/la to/ca *e 209. Elsewhere the Paeonians are called i(ppokorustai/ (21.205) or dolixegxe/es (21.155).

850 = *f 158. — *)aci/ou: for the repetition, see on v. 671. The Axius is one of the chief rivers of Macedonia, west of the Strymon. Homer applies to it the epiths. eu\rure/eqros *f 141 and baqodi/nhs *f 143.

ka/lliston: pred. “Whose water is the most beautiful that” etc. A similar expression is used of the Enipeus, o(\s polu\ ka/llistos potamw=n e)pi\ gai=an i(/hsin l 239. The water of the Axius is now muddy.

Here the poet returns to Asia. See on 816-877. — *pulaime/neos ktl.: equiv. to “the shaggy-breasted Pylaemenes.” For the periphrasis, cf. v. 387, *g 105, w)=rse *patroklh=os la/sion kh=r *p 554. He was slain by Menelaus, 5.576 ff., but nevertheless follows the corpse of his son from the battle-field, *n 658! — la/sion kh=r: see on 1.189. Here the epith. is transferred to the heart itself.

e)c *)enetw=n: out of the midst of the Enetians, where he dwelt; equiv. to *)eneth/ios. In later times these *)enetoi/ were called Veneti; they were said to have wandered to the coast of the Adriatic sea.
a)grotera/wn: for the comparative ending, with no thought of greater or less degree, see § 22 c.
*ku/twron: in later times the mart of Sinope.
*sh/samon: afterwards called Amastris, a small river on the coast of Paphlagonia.
kluta/: magnificent; a standing epith.
*krw=mnan: the later Amastris in Paphlagonia, on a river of the same name.
*)eruqi/nous: the city received its name from its two red cliffs, see on v. 647. The red chalk of this region was much prized in ancient times.
*(alicw/nwn: only here and E 39, where Odius is slain by Agamemnon. They were called *xa/lubes (cf. *)alu/bh, see v. 857) in later times; to the east of Pontus.
*)epi/strofos: only here.

*musw=n: south of the Propontis, east of the Aesepus, towards Bithynia. They are mentioned as Trojan allies, *k 430, *c 512, *w 278. Thracian Mysians are mentioned *n 5. — *xro/mis: called also *xro/mios, *p 218 etc., just as Alcimedon is called also Alcimus, see § 21 e.

ou)k: placed emphatically before oi)wnoi=sin, with reference to the preceding oi)wnisth/s. cf. (ui(e/as o)neiropo/loio ge/rontos) toi=s ou)k e)rxome/nois o( ge/rwn e)kri/nat) o)nei/rous *e 150, *)/idmona, mantosu/nh|si kekasme/non| a)lla/ min ou)/ ti | mantosu/nai e)sa/wsan e)pei\ xrew\ h)=ge damh=nai Ap. Rhod. ii. 818 f., gratissimus augur; | sed non augurio potuit depellere pestem Verg. Aen. ix. 327 f.
oi)wnoi=sin: by omens, from the flight of birds. See on 1.69.
u(po\ xersi/: u(po/ with the dat. is freq. used by Homer where the Attic used u(po/ with the gen., cf. 3.436. See § 3 h.
*ai)aki/dao: for the use of the patronymic, see on v. 621.
e)n potamw=|: as v. 875. The story of the general slaughter by Achilles in the bed of the Scamander is told 21.17 ff., but the names of the slain are not given there.
o(/qi per: just where.
*fo/rkus: appears again 17.218; he is slain by Ajax, P 312 ff.

*fru/gas: on the river Sangarius. They were famed for their chariots and their vineyards, 3.184 ff.; they had commercial relations with the Trojans, 18.291 f. Vergil calls the Trojans Phrygians, but this is not Homeric, cf. alma Venus Phrygii Simoentis ad undam Verg. Aen. i. 618.

*)aska/nios: to be distinguished from the Ascanius of N 792, who arrived at the scene of the war a day or two later than the events recorded in this Second Book. Homer knows of no son of Aeneas. The boy Ascanius was invented later as a companion-piece to Hector's son Astyanax.
*)askani/hs: in Bithynia, on a lake of the same name on which lay also the later Nicaea.
me/masan de/: instead of a partic. or rel. clause, see § 3 q.
u(smi=ni: local dat. Synony-<*> mous with ma/xh, po/lemos, dhioth/s.

*mh/osin: later called Lydians. They inhabited an attractive land, 3.401; they were equipped with chariots, 10.431; they traded with the Trojans, 18.291 f.; their women were skilled in purple dyeing, 4.141 ff.
*me/sqlhs: appears again 17.216.
*)/antifos: only here; another Antiphus, v. 678.
h(ghsa/sqhn: see on v. 620.

*gugai/h li/mnh: i.e. the nymph of that lake, cf. nu/mfh nhi/s *z 21, *c 444, *u 384. All of these nymphs belong to Western Asia Minor, which was thought to be the favorite abode of the nymphs. — cf. li/mnh de\ e)/xetai tou= sh/matos (sc. of Alyattes) mega/lh, ... kale/etai de\ au(/th *gugai/h Hdt. i. 93.
kai/: also, marks the agreement with v. 864, see on v. 249.
*na/sths: he and his brother and their father are mentioned only here.

*karw=n: mentioned only incidentally, *k 428. — barbarofw/nwn: rough-voiced, refers to the harshness of their dialect, as a)griofw/nous q 294. The word ba/rbaros for non-Greek, foreigner, is not found in Homer, just as the poet has no one word for ‘all Greece.’
*mi/lhton: this old Carian city became the largest Ionian city and the mother of 80 colonies, but lost much of its importance in the insurrection against the Persians, 494 B.C.
*muka/lhs: at the foot of this mountain the Persians were defeated, 479 B.C.
a)/ra: so, as I said, refers back to v. 867.
*na/sths ktl.: repeated from the preceding verse, in the reverse order; see on v. 671.
os: refers to the principal person, *na/sths v. 867.
kai/: marks the agreement with a)glaa\ te/kna v. 871, cf. v. 866.

xruso\n e)/xwn: with gold ornaments, prob. the gold spirals used in fastening his long hair, cf. ploxmoi/ q) (braids of hair) oi(\ xrusw=| te kai\ a)rgu/rw| e)sfh/kwnto (were gathered up) 17.52. See on v. 11. cf. xruse/h as an epith. of Aphrodite, *g 64. xruso/n here cannot refer to gold armor such as that of Glaucus (6.236), Nestor (8.193), or Achilles (18.475), since that was an honor and no reproach. Nastes was the Trojan Nireus (vs. 671 ff.).
h)u/te kou/rh: like a vain girl.
nh/pios: see on v. 38. — ou)de\ ktl.: cf. nh/pios, ou)de/ ti/ oi( xraismh/sei lugro\n o)/leqron *u 296.
e)ko/misse: carried off as booty, cf. 3.378.

*sarphdw/n: second only to Hector; the bravest leader of the allies, regarded by the Trojans as e(rma po/lhos *p 549 prop of the city. He was son of Zeus and Laodamia, Bellerophon's daughter, 6.198 f. He led in the attack on the Achaean camp, M 101, 292 ff., 397 ff. He was slain by Patroclus, 16.480 ff. At the command of Zeus, Apollo bathed his corpse, anointed it with ambrosia and gave it to the twin brothers, Sleep and Death, to convey to Lycia, 16.667 ff.

*glau=kos: Glaucus tells of his race, Z 145 ff. He was first cousin of Sarpedon and grandson of Bellerophon, descended from Sisyphus of Corinth. He is associated with Sarpedon in the battles. He has a famous meeting with Diomed, 6.119 ff. He was wounded by Teucer, 12.387 ff. The honors received by the two Lycian heroes at home, are enumerated by Sarpedon, 12.310. — The name ‘Lycia’ is given by the poet also to the district from which Pandarus (v. 827) comes, cf. 5.105. From those Trojan Lycians, the Southern Lycians of Sarpedon are to be distinguished.
*ca/nqou: mentioned also *e 479, *m 313; to be distinguished from the Trojan river o(\n *ca/nqon kale/ousi qeoi/, a)/ndres de\ *ska/mandron *u 74

Instead of the general battle which was to be expeeted from the preparations of the Second Book, a duel is fought between Menelaus and Paris. This duel is intended by the combatants to put an end to the entire war.
In the Third Book, the poet gives to his hearers a view of the state of affairs in Troy, as the preceding Books had taught of the relations existing between the Achaeans, both leaders and men.
Vs. 1-75. The advance of both armies. Paris and Menelaus meet. Hector's rebuke and the answer of Paris.
1-14. A transition to the scene of the approaching conflict.
This verse refers to 2.476, 815.
e(/kastoi: i.e. the separate divisions of each army. The sing. would have been used of individuals; see on A 606.

*trw=es: i.e. Trojans and their allies; as 2.826, not as *b 816. — klaggh=| ktl.: with clamor and outcry; one idea, expressed for emphasis by two synonymous nouns; cf. *a 492, *b 339, v. 242, kako/thti kai\ a)/lgesi u 203, e)/ris kai\ nei=kos o)/rhtai u 267, sqe/neo/s te kai\ a)lkh=s peirh/tizen x 237; see § 1 s.

o)/rniqes w(/s: cf. 2.764, see on 2.190. This comparison is made definite by a special illustration.—The Achaeans silent in the consciousness of their power are contrasted with the noisy Trojans. Elsewhere also the Trojans are represented as exercising less selfrestraint, as less disciplined than the Greeks. When the strife is renewed, 4.429 ff., the Achaeans advance in solemn silence, while the Trojans come to meet them with the noise of a flock of sheep. The Achaeans shout once, in panic flight, 17.759.
h)u/te: see on 2.87.

ou)rano/qi pro/: the adv. pro/ makes ou)rano/qi more definite. To the observer, the sky seems to be behind the cranes in their lofty flight, see on 2.456. — cf. quales sub nubibus atris | Strymoniae dantsigna grues, atque aethera tranant | cum sonitu, fugiuntque notos clamore secundo Verg. Aen. x. 264 ff., ‘As multitudinous on the ocean line | As cranes upon the cloudless Thracian wind,’ Shelley, Hellas.

e)pei\ ou)=n: as *a 57. — xeimw=na: cf. ge/ranoi de\ feu/gousai xeimw=na to\n e)n th=| *skuqikh=| xw/rh| gino/menon, foite/ousi e)s xeimasi/hn (winter quarters) e)s tou\s to/pous tou/sde (of the Nile) Hdt. ii. 22, quam multae glomerantur aves, ubi frigidus annus | trans portum fugat, et terris immittit apricis Verg. Aen. vi. 311 f.
fu/gon: for the gnomic aor. in comparisons, cf. vs. 10, 23, 33; see § 2 k.
