klaggh=|: contains the real point of the comparison; vs. 6 f. are added simply to complete the picture, see § 2 e.
tai/ ge: repeats the subj., ai(/ te v. 4. See on *a 97. — e)pi\ ktl.: toward the currents etc., i.e. toward the South; see on 1.423.
a)ndra/si: made prominent in contrast with the cranes. a)nh/r often stands in attributive connection with nouns, cf. a)/ndres stratiw=tai, a)/ndres a)delfoi/, ktl. See § 1 u.

*pugmai/oisi: these Liliputians (lit. Fistlings) on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, were attacked yearly by the cranes, acc. to the common story. For the mythical trait in a comparison, cf. B 782. — cf. ‘that small infantry | Warr'd on by cranes’ Milton Par. Lost i. 575. — fo/non ktl.: cf. *b 352, i(/khtai dhioth=ta fe/rwn z 203, *p 757.
h)e/riai: see on 1.497; i.e. on the day after their arrival in the land.
kakh/n: destructive, as 1.10; sc. to the Pygmies. — e)/rida ktl.: offer (lit. bring forward) strife; cf. e)/rida profe/rousai c 92 “in rivalry,” e)/ridu probalo/ntes *l 529.
oi( d) a)/ra: correlative with *trw=es me/n v. 2.
i)/san sigh=|: cf. ou) ga\r kraugh=| a)lla\ sigh=| ... kai\ h(suxh=| ... prosh=|san Xen. An. i. 8. 11.
me/nea pnei/ontes: see on 2.536. — cf. ‘Thus they | Breathing united force with fixed thought | Moved on in silence,’ Milton Par. Lost i. 559 ff.
e)n qumw=|: emphatic; in heart, though they did not shout. cf. 2.223.
eu)=te: generally a temporal particle; here and 19.386, a comparative conj., as, like h)u/te v. 3. “As the South wind veils the mountain tops with mist.”
ou)/ ti fi/lhn ktl.: since the shepherd on the mountains in a thick mist cannot easily watch and guard his flock.
nukto\s a)mei/nw: perhaps because the sheep were usually shut up in their fold at night.

to/sson, o(/son: acc. of extent, with e)pi/, cf. *b 616. — te/, te/: these mark the correlation of the clauses; see on 1.82. — Distances are thus measured in Homer: as the cast of a spear (dourhneke/s *k 357, douro\s e)rwh/ *o 358), or of a discus (di/skou ou)=ra *y 431), or of a shepherd's crook (23.845), or a bow-shot (Od. 12.83 f.), or a furrow's length (10.351), or the reach of the voice (Od. 9.473).
w(\s a)/ra ktl.: as B 784.
15 = *e 14, 630, 850, *z 121, *l 232, *n 604, *p 462, *u 176, *f 148, *x 248, *u 816. A formula which, in close connection with what has preceded, introduces the single combat of two warriors.
sxedo\n h)=san: were near each other. For the use of the adv., see on 1.416.
e)p) a)llh/loisin: const. with i)o/ntes. For e)pi/ in hostile sense, cf. v. 132; see on 1.382.

*trwsi/n: for the Trojans, cf. toi=si d) *)ereusali/wn pro/mos i(/stato (equiv. to proma/xizen) *h 136. — *)ale/candros: the Greek name of Paris, and used four times as freq. as the other. The dat, of *pa/ris is not used, *pa/rios only v. 325, *pa/rin but thrice.
qeoeidh/s: this epith. is given him because of his personal beauty; cf. vs<*> 39, 44 ff., 55, 64.
pardale/hn: adj. as subst.; see on A 54. As a light-armed warrior (he was eminently a bowman, 11.369 ff), he wore no armor, and thus has a panther's skin on his shoulders. See on B 43.
au)ta/r: on the other hand; this gives prominence to dou=re, since the spears do not belong properly to the archer's equipment, which has just been described.

dou=redu/w: as *m 298, *f 145, a 256; i.e. one in either hand. cf. v. 338. For du/w with the dual, see on *a 16. — kekoruqme/na ktl.: helmeted with bronze, i.e. bronze pointed. For the pl. in agreement with the dual, cf. *a 200, o)/sse faeina/ *n 435. — cf. bina manu lato crispans hastilia ferro Verg. Aen. i. 313, laeva duo forte gerebat | praefixa hastilia ferro ib. xii. 488 f.
pa/llwn: parallel with e)/xwn v. 17.

prokali/zeto: challenged; by his mien rather than by words, cf. v. 21. prokalizo/menos would give a smoother const. here, but the finite verb is used in order to give it more prominence; cf. e)/ballon v. 80. Thus e)/xwn and pa/llwn seem to be related to both imperfects.

pa/ntas a)ri/stous: in marked contrast with his yielding before Menelaus, who was not distinguished in battle (malqako\s ai)xmhth/s *r 588). — Here the period returns to v. 16, since this verse explains proma/xizen. — Paris and Menelaus are introduced first in the action, since the two are the prime cause of the war. Their feud is private as well as public. The description of the two foes is made specially effective by the contrast of their characters.
a)nti/bion: cf. a)ntibi/hn *a 278; used only of the hand to hand conflict.
maxe/sasqai: inceptive aor.
de/: correl. with me/n v. 16.
w(s: for its position, see on 1.32.
a)rhi/filos: this epith. is generally (21 times) applied as here to Menelaus. The epith. and the name form a convenient close to the verse, see on 1.7, § 40 d.

propa/roiqen o(mi/lou: sc. as pro/maxos. — makra\ biba/nta: with long strides. This gives the manner of e)rxo/menon. It is here a sign of courage, for Paris was no coward; cf. *h 213, *n 809, *o 307, 676, 686, longe gradientem Verg. Aen. x. 572, ‘Satan with vast and haughty strides advanced’ Milton Par. Lost, vi. 109, and (as a sign of pride) Od. 11.539.

w(/s te le/wn ktl.: a comparison instead of the apod., which (with o)fqalmoi=sin i)dw/n as a repetition of w(s e)no/hsen) follows at v. 27. The gnomic aor. e)xa/rh contains the point of comparison; but peina/wn also receives emphasis from its position and corresponds to fa/to ga\r ti/sasqai v. 28, i.e. joy at the promised satisfaction of a passionate desire.

e)pi\ sw/mati ku/rsas: as he happened upon the carcass of a beast just slain in the chase (cf. v. 26). sw=ma is used in Homer only of a dead body, see § 2 v.—Cf. impastus stabula alta leo ceu saepe peragrans, | suadet enim vesana fames; si forte fugacem | conspexit capream aut surgentem in cornua cervum | gaudet Verg. Aen. x. 723 ff. Similar comparison is found 11.474 ff. The aor. is gnomic, like eu(rw/n below.
eu(rw/n: as he found; explaining ku/rsas, and in appos. with it.
a)/grion ai)=ga: cf. ai)=gas o)reskw/|ous (“of the mountain”) Od. 9.155.
ma/la katesqi/ei: eagerly devours, as *f 24. — ga/r te ktl.: explains peina/wn. — ei)/ per a)/n: see on *b 597. — au)to/n: himself, in contrast with the goat or deer.
ku/nes ktl.: “hounds and hunters,” as *l 414, *r 282.
qeoeide/a: with synizesis of the last two vowels of the verse, as vs. 237, 450; see § 7 c.
ti/sasqai: for the aor. inf. after a verb of expecting, cf. vs. 112, 366; see G. 203 N. 2.
29 = *e 494, *z 103, *m 81, *n 749; cf. *d 419, *l 211. The close of the verse also *e 111, *p 733, 755, *w 469. — Paris was on foot, see v. 22.
e)c o)xe/wn: equiv. to e)c i(/ppwn v. 265.

kateplh/gh: “was filled with dismay”; not from natural cowardice (cf. Hector's words to Paris, e)pei\ a)/lkimo/s e)ssi *z 522), but his guilty conscience robbed him of courage, at sight of Menelaus. ‘Conscience does make cowards of us all.’
fi/lon: see on v. 138, 1.491.
h)=tor: see on 1.44.
w(s d) o(/te: introduces a comparison, with the gnomic aor., as *d 275, *e 902, *l 558, *p 823. — te/, te/: as v. 12. For the e remaining short before dr, see § 41 i b.

pali/norsos a)pe/sth: stepped back again, sc. in terror; in this lies the point of the comparison. For the pred. adj. used as an adv., cf. h)e/riai v. 7, a)nti/oi *a 535. —cf. improvisum aspris veluti qui sentibus anguem | pressit humi nitens, trepidusque repente refugit | ... haud secus Androgeus visu tremefactus abibat Verg. Aen. ii. 379 ff., ‘False Sextus saw and trembled, | and turned and fled away; | As turns, as flies the woodman | In the Calabrian brake | When thro' the reeds gleams the round eye | Of that fell speckled snake, | So turned, so fled false Sextus | And hid him in the rear,’ Macaulay Lays, Battle of Regillus xv.
u(po/: below, referring to the weakness of his knees; cf. *d 421, *c 506, *u 44. Const. with e)/llabe.
pareia/s: in appos. with mi/n, as a ‘part’ with the ‘whole’; cf. vs. 438, 442.
w)=xros: cf. tou\s de\ xlwro\n de/os h(/|rein *h 479.
kaq) o(/milon: into the throng.
a)gerw/xwn: prob. courageous, impetuous; also B 654.
*)ale/candros: in appos. with the subj. of e)/du, expressed here for the sake of the contrast with *)atre/os ui(o/n.
38 = *z 325. — ai)sxroi=s: i.e. reproachful, cf. o\neidei/ois *b 277.

*du/spari: a determinative compound (G. 132. 2; H. 590), stronger than “Unhappy Paris”; cf. mh=ter du/smhter y 97, *kakoi+/lion ou)k o)nomasth/n *y 19, *du/sparis, ai)no/paris, kako\n *(ella/di bwtianei/rh| Alcman 40.
ei)=dos a)/riste: as v 124; in contrast with *du/spari, cf. v. 45, ka/k) e)le/gxea, ei)=dos a)ghtoi/ *e 787, *p 142. Thus the excellence that is granted is made a reproach.
h)peropeuta/: cf. v. 399.
ai)/q) o)/feles ktl.: closely connected with the reproaches of the preceding verse.

a)/gonos, a)/gamos: childless, unmarried; two ideas that are proverbially connected in this passionate wish, although Paris is not known to have had children. Elsewhere, also, Hector uses strong language to Paris and about him, cf. 6.281 ff., 325 ff.; see on v. 454.
41 = l 358, u 316. — kai\ to/: even this, referring to the preceding verse.
ke bouloi/mhn: potential; I should prefer, cf. 1.112.
ken h)=en: as contrary to fact in present time.
polu/: cf. 1.91, 112, and notes.
h)/: follows the comparative idea in bouloi/mhn, as *a 117, kai/ ken polu\ ktl. being parenthetical.
lw/bhn: concrete, a shame, opprobrium; cf. *b 235. — u(po/yion ktl.: an object of contempt to others.
ka/rh komo/wntes: see on 2.11.
fa/ntes: imperf. partic., they who believed; of an incorrect view, as B 37 and freq.

kalo/n: seldom is an adj. at the close of one verse in close connection with a noun at the beginning of the next, § 1 g. Many apparent exceptions to this rule can be explained, as 1.78, 156, 283. This arrangement of words may have been chosen here in order to give increased prominence to ei)=dos.

e)/pi: for e)/pesti, as 1.515; attends thee. — a)ll) ou)k ktl.: the contrast with fa/ntes calls strictly for a partic. denoting the Achaeans' recognition of the truth; instead of this, Hector states the fact from his own standpoint.
bi/h: might, for attack.
fresi/n: local, see on 1.24.
a)lkh/: strength, for defence.
“Can such a coward have dared to meet the dangers involved in the rape of Helen?”
toio/sde: with deictic -de, cf. v. 157, 2.120.
e)ri/hras: for the (metaplastic) form, see § 19 b.
a)gei/ras: subord. to e)piplw/sas [Att. e)pipleu/sas].
a)llodapoi=si: masc. adj. as subst., cf. *dardani/wn *b 819. See on A 54, 539.
a)nh=ges: didst lead (bring) home to Troy, cf. *(ele/nhn per a)nh/gagen (sc. Paris) *z 292, oi(/ meu (sc. Menelaus) kouridi/hn a)/loxon kai\ kth/mata ... oi)/xesq) a)na/gontes *n 626 f.
a)pi/hs: cf. 1.270.
nuo/n: sisterin-law of Agamemnon, who is implied in the more general a)ndrw=n ktl. — ai)xmhta/wn: cf. 1.290; important for the thought here. For the pl., cf. 2.250, v. 106.
ph=ma: as a bane. This acc. and the two following are in appos. with the whole of the preceding sent., marking the result of the action; cf. B 160; see G. 137, N. 3; H. 626.
dh/mw|: country, as B 547. — For the (prob. accidental) alliteration of p, see § 2 a.
dusmene/sin ktl.: for the chiastic order of words, cf. A 443, 558 f., vs. 103 f., 179; see § 2 o.
kathfei/hn: humiliation, shame. cf. o( *kike/rwn e)/fh ... ge/lwta me\n toi=s e)xqroi=s, ai)=sxos de\ toi=s oi)kei/ois pare/xonta Dio Cass. xxxviii. 23. 1.

ou)k a)
 dh\ ktl.: a question in the sense of an energetic but sarcastic exhortation: couldst thou not then withstand, etc.? stand to meet, etc. Cf. ou)k a)
 dh\ *trw=as me
 e)a/saimen kai\ *)axaiou\s | ma/rnasqai; 5.32 f., Od. 6.57. The way for this question has been prepared by vs. 50 f.: “If thou hadst the courage to bring Helen to Troy, if thou didst bring war upon thy native land, then have the courage” etc.
gnoi/hs ke: then wouldst thou be made aware. The cond. ei) mei/neias, is easily supplied, cf. *a 232, *b 242.
e)/xeis: hast to wife, as v. 123, 6.398.
ou)k a)/n toi xrai/smh: “will not help thee (A 28);” more definite than the opt. with a)/n, to be expected after gnoi/hs ke. See § 3 b. o(/te migei/hs is stated as a mere conception of the mind.
ki/qaris: without the art., although the other nouns here have it. Achilles, also, had a cithara; he sang, however, not love-songs but kle/a a)ndrw=n, *i 189.

ta/: these, thy; deictic like the following h( and to/. cf. the words of Nereus to Paris: nequiquam Veneris praesidio ferox | pectes caesariem grataque feminis | inbelli cithara carmina divides | ... heu serus adulteros | crines pulvere collines Hor. Carm. i. 15. 13 ff.
h(/ te ktl.: among the gifts of the goddess of love, two are made prominent. Obs. the explanatory appos.
migei/hs e)n: cf. v. 209; generally the simple dat. is used with mi/gnumi.
ma/la: altogether, cf. 2.241.
deidh/mones: i.e. since Paris belonged to the royal family.
h)= te/ ken e(/sso: the cond. idea (Eng. else) is implied as in v. 53.
la/inon ktl.: put on a stone tunic; a grim expression of popular speech for death by stoning, the customary method of capital punishment in heroic times (as in the laws of Moses).
e(/sso: from e(/nnumi (e(snumi). cf. ku=m) a)li/aston e)fe/ssato neio/qi (deep) du/yas (diving) Ap. Rhod. i. 1326, ga=n e)piesso/menos Pind. Nem. xi. 16.
*(/ektor: const. with v. 64, where the principal thought begins.
e)pei/: follows the voc. as A 352. This clause has no grammatical conclusion; the virtual conclusion is vs. 67 f.
ai)ei/ toi: this thought is resumed in v. 63 with an accented soi/, because of the contrast.
a)teirh/s: unwearied; pred. of kradi/h, cf. kh=r a)te/ramnon (unyielding) e)/qhkan y 167.
ei)=sin: goes; always used as pres. in Homeric comparisons, cf. B 87.
dia\ douro/s: through the trunk of a tree.
u(p) a)ne/ros: driven by a man; for the passive sense in ei)=sin, see H. 820. — o(/s r(a/ te ktl.: hypothetical, “when he hews out” of the felled tree etc.
te/xnh|: with skill. For the dat., cf. klaggh=| v. 2, sigh=| v. 8.
o)fe/llei ktl.: the axe by its weight increases the force of the man's blow. o)fe/llei has the same subj. as ei)=sin, which shows the intervening clause to be parenthetical.
a)ta/rbhtos: attrib. with no/os.
mh/ moi: adversative asyndeton, see § 2 m. “I acknowledge my lack of thine unyielding courage, but do not cast in my teeth the gifts of Aphrodite.”
pro/fere: cf. 2.251.
xruse/hs: equiv. to xrusofo/rou, adorned with gold; see on 2.872, cf. Venus aurea Verg. Aen. x. 16. Similarly, Ares is xa/lkeos *e 704, 859, because of his bronze armor.
Causal asyndeton.
a)po/blhta: abiecta, to be cast off, as 2.361; cf. pa=n kti/sma (creature) qeou= kalo/n, kai\ ou)de\n a)po/blhton 1 Tim. iv. 4.
o(/ssa ... dw=sin: for the cond. rel. sent., see on A 554. Explanatory of dw=ra, adding the essential mark of the gods' gifts, i.e. that they are of free choice.
au)toi/: i.e. without act and thus without responsibility of the receiver.
e(kw\n e(/loito: this forms an independent contrast to the preceding rel. clause. For the thought, cf. a)ll) ou)/ pws a(/ma pa/nta dunh/seai au)to\s e(le/sqai *n 729.
e(kw/n: at pleasure, by his own powers.
nu=n au)=te: transition from the preceding general considerations to the work before them.
a)/llous: the others.
ka/qison: bid to sit down.
au)ta/r: see on 2.768.

e)n me/ssw|: between the two armies, cf. v. 77, e)s me/son a)mfote/rwn suni/thn *z 120, in medium inter duas acies procedunt Livy i. 25. 1. e)/geire kai\ sth=qi ei)s to\ me/son St. Luke vi. 8. For the neuter adj. as a subst. (not very freq. in Homer), see on 1.539.

sumba/lete: bring together, cf. cune/hke *a 8, w(\s tou\s a)mfote/rous ma/kares qeoi\ ... su/mbalon *u 54 f. The pl. is used, since the consent of the Achaeans also was necessary for the single combat.

kth/masi pa=si: i.e. those which Paris carried away with Helen from the house of Menelaus; cf. v. 282, 7.350, (363, 389), *n 626, *x 114 ff., in all of which cases ‘Helen and her treasures’ are united in thought.
ma/xesqai: as A 8.
nikh/sh|: shall gain the victory; as fut. perf.
e)u/: seems to strengthen pa/nta, as Od. 18.260; cf. ma/la pa/nta b 306. — a)ge/sqw: mid., take as his own.

oi( d) a)/lloi: but you, the rest. Elsewhere, when at the beginning of the verse, but they, the others; as vs. 94, 256. oi( d) a)/lloi includes both Trojans and Achaeans, and a division into oi( me/n, oi( de/ might be expected; but instead of this the 2d pers. (vai/oite) appears in the first member, and toi\ de\ nee/sqwn in the second. cf. vs. 256 ff., Od. 24.483 ff.
filo/thta: zeugmatically connected with tamo/ntes which is construed strictly only with o(/rkia. — tamo/ntes: see on B 124.
nai/oite: may ye continue to dwell. Note the opt. between two imvs. This is a mere incident to the proposition.
e)ribw/laka: epith. of Phthia, 1.155, and Larisa, 2.841.
toi\ de/: but those, the Achaeans.
*)/argos, *)axaii/da: i.e. Peloponnesus (as A 30) and Northern Greece, i.e. all Hellas. See on 2.530.
kalligu/naika: see on 2.683.
Vs. 76-120. Hector and Menelaus. Preparations for the truce and single combat.
a)kou/sas: gives the cause of e)xa/rh.
e)s me/sson: see on v. 69.
me/ssou douro/s: part. gen. i.e. holding the spear horizontally with both hands, crowding the Trojans back.
i(dru/nqhsan: were brought to a halt; this gives the result of a)ne/erge, see on B 94.
e)petoca/zonto: conative impf., they were bending their bows at him.
e)/ballon: transition from the participial to the finite const., in order not to subordinate this idea to e)petoca/zonto, although the te\ ... te/ would make ba/llontes natural here. See §§ 1 e, 3 t.
makro/n: aloud, lit. afar, over a great space.
cf. w 54. — i)/sxesqe, mh\ ba/llete: note the asyndeton (§ 2 l) where the second imv. explains the first; and the double address, *)argei=oi, kou=roi *)axaiw=n.
steu=tai: cf. 2.597.
e)/pos: for the length of the ultima, see §§ 14 a, 41 m.
koruqai/olos: see on B 816.
ma/xhs: for the gen., cf. v. 112, a)uth=s *b 97. — a)/new/| te ktl.: cf. 2.323; sc. in order to hear Hector's speech.
e)ssume/nws: made emphatic by its position; adv. formed from the adjectival e)ssu/menos (11.554); this and e)pistame/nws (H 317) are the only advs. from partics. in Homer. See § 38 h.
met) a)mfote/roisin: between both armies.
ke/klute meu=: hear from me. The gen. is ablatival.
mu=qon: proposition, plan; as oi)=sqa kai\ a)/llon mu=qon a)mei/nona tou=de noh=sai *h 358, u 326.
ka/l): for the accent of the ultima (kala/) thrown back upon the preceding syllable, cf. v. 192, 1.105; see § 10 d.
a)poqe/sqai: i.e. they were to be mere spectators.
e)pi\ xqoni/: for the dat. of rest, cf. 1.593.
90-94 = vs. 69-73, with necessary changes.
au)to/n: intensive, himself. au)to\s bou/letai would be natural here, but the acc. is used, correlative with a)/llous me/n above.
92 = v. 71. — Transition to direct disc., see § 1 c.
95 = *h 92, 398, *q 28, *i 29, 430, 693, *k 218, 313, *y 676, q 234, l 333, n 1, p 393, u 320. — a)kh/n: equiv. to a)ke/wn *a 34; originally a cognate acc. with e)ge/nonto, cf. § 38 c.
siwph=|: dat. of manner, equiv. to siwpw=ntes. — cf. dixerat Aeneas, illi obstupuere silentes Verg. Aen. xi. 120, tenuere silentia cuncti Ovid Met. i. 206.
qumo/n: acc. of limit of motion.

e)mo/n: made emphatic by its position before the caesural pause. — frone/w ktl.: “My mind is that we now (h)/dh) are to separate in peace.” frone/w is nearly equiv. to dokei= moi. For the aor. inf., cf. v. 28.
*)argei/ous kai\ *trw=as: has more feeling than u(ma=s kai\ h(ma=s, see on 1.240.
pe/posqe: Att. pepo/nqate. The speaker returns to the address begun with ke/klute.
e)mh=s e)/ridos: my strife with Paris.
a)rxh=s: the beginning, cf. v. 87, 2.377 f.; a mild expression for the guilt of the first breach of the peace.
o(ppote/rw|: the anteced. is the subj. of teqnai/h.—qa/natos kai\ moi=ra: cf. qa/naton kai\ po/tmon *b 359, moi=ra qana/toio b 100, fo/non kai\ kh=ra v. 6.
te/tuktai: is prepared, appointed.

teqnai/h: let him be dead, let him lie among the dead, cf. *z 164, au)ti/ka teqnai/hn *s 98, teqna/men p 107 to be dead, paradoqei\s toi=s e(/ndeka teqna/tw au)qhmero/n (on the same day) Aeschines i. 16.
diakrinqei=te: repeats diakrinqh/menai v. 98.
oi)/sete: aor. imv., as a)/cete v. 105, u)/rseo v. 250; but oi)/somen v. 104 is fut.
a)/rne: cf. a)/rnas v. 117.

leuko/n, me/lainan: the white male lamb was to be sacrificed to the gleaming Helios, while the dark ewe lamb was for *gai=a me/laina (2.699). Odysseus sacrifices a black ewe to Persephone, k 572, l 45 ff. The sex of the victim was generally that of the divinity; thus a cow is sacrificed to Athena, but a bull to Poseidon, 11.728 f. — The order of words is chiastic with the following verse. — For the divinities to whom this sacrifice is to be offered, see on v. 276.
*pria/moio bi/hn: for the periphrasis, cf. 2.387, 658, 851; see § 2 s.
o(/rkia ta/mnh|: may conclude the treaty, as vs. 73, 94. The victims are slain by Agamemnon, not by Priam.

au)to/s: in person; the old king being contrasted with his sons. The poet forgets the periphrasis and proceeds as if he had said *pri/amon, cf. e)lqw\n e)ka/kwse bi/h *(hraklhei/h *l 690. — e)pei/: this introduces the first reason; the second follows with ai)ei\ de/ v. 108.
oi)=: for him, his; see § 3 g.
pai=des: this refers primarily to Paris; for the pl. cf. v. 49.
mh/ tis ktl.: let no one etc.; expression of anxiety connected immediately with his opinion of the sons of Priam.
*dio\s o(/rkia: Zeus watches over solemn treaties and punishes whoever breaks them; cf. vs. 280, 288, *d 160, 166, oi( qew=n o(/rkoi Xen. An. ii. 5. 7.
h)ere/qontai: are flighty, unsteady, untrustworthy. For the unfigurative use of this verb, see 2.448.
oi/=s: personal. It has no corresponding toi=s in the apod.
o( ge/rwn: the old man (generic art.), in contrast with o(plote/rwn v. 108.
mete/h|si: Att. me/th|, from me/teimi. For the subjv., cf. *a 554. —pro/ssw ktl.: cf. 1.343.
o(/pws: how; indirect question, cf. au)toi\ de\ frazw/meq) o(/pws o)/x) a)/rista ge/nhtai n 365. — o)/x) a)/rista: cf. 1.69.
met) a)mfote/roisi: “for both sides.”
cf. *t 74. — *)axaioi\ ktl.: in appos. with oi(.

pau/sasqai: for the aor. inf. after e)lpo/menoi, see on v. 28; to free themselves from, be freed from, with ablatival gen. ai)/ k) e)qe/lwsin | pau/sasqai pole/moio dushxe/os, ei)s o(/ ke vekrou\s | kh/omen *h 375 ff. is different.
kai/ r(a: and so.
e)pi\ sti/xas: cf. *b 687. — e)k d) e)/ban [e)/bhsan]: sc. from their war chariots.
kate/qento: sc. *)axaioi/ te *trw=e/s te. cf. a)poqe/sqai v. 89.
plhsi/on a)llh/lwn: refers to ta\ me/n. This thought is stated in different form by the rest of the verse: little ground was round about each suit of armor.

du/w: this numeral is const. with the pl. where the two persons are not necessarily and closely connected, as *e 10, du/) *ai)/antes *q 79, *m 127. — kh/rukas: the heralds were the only official members of the king's household; cf. 1.320 ff., 2.183 f. Thus the service of the heralds, v. 268 ff., is because of their relations to the king's person.
*talqu/bion: see on 1.320.
oi)se/menai aor. inf., cf. v. 103.
a)/ra: then, so; the immediate result of the commission.
ou)k a)pi/qhse: followed by a dat. of the person.
Vs. 121-244. The view from the walls. Helen, questioned by Priam, tells him about some of the Achaean heroes.

*)=iris: Iris, elsewhere the messenger of the gods (see on 2.786), here of her own accord (cf. *e 353, *y 198 ff.) brings into the action Helen, the cause of the war and the prize of the expected single combat. The following scene (*teixoskopi/a) which occupies the time necessary for the preparations for the principal action (see on 1.318), introduces the hearer to the Trojans and their relations to each other.
leukwle/nw|: see on 1.55.

galo/w|: husband's sister. The Greeks were not restricted to such a clumsy and indefinite expression as sister-in-law; cf. galo/w| kai\ ei\nate/res (husband's brothers' wives) *x 473, dah/r v. 180, e(/kure v. 172.
ei)=xe: cf. v. 53.
*(elika/wn: he does not appear elsewhere in Homer.

*laodi/khn: attracted to the case of the rel. th/n, see on *b 764. — ei)=dos a)ri/sthn: lit. most excellent in appearance, most beautiful. The same expression is used of Laodice again Z 252, of Cassandra N 365. cf. v. 39, B 715, N 378.
e)n mega/rw|: in her chamber, cf. v. 142, a)ll) h(/ g) (sc. Andromache) i(sto\n u(/faine muxw=| do/mou u(yhloi=o | di/plaka porfure/hn, e)n de\ qro/na (flowers) poiki/l) e)/passen *x 440 f.

i(sto/n: web. Weaving was the most honorable employment of Homeric women; it occupied queens and goddesses. So Hector, on parting from Andromache, says a)ll) ei)s oi)=kon i)ou=sa ta\ s) au)th=s e)/rga ko/mize (care for), | i(sto/n t) (loom) h)laka/thn te (spindle) 6.490 f. cf. the web of Penelope Od. 2.94 ff., of Circe Od. 10.221 ff., the looms of the Ithacan nymphs Od. 13.107 f., the robes made by Athena 8.385 f., 14.178 f., the robe woven by Helen and given to Telemachus Od. 15.123 ff.

di/plaka: fem. adj. as subst., see on 1.54; sc. xlai=nan, cf. xlai=nan diplh=n t 225, di/ptuxon lw/phn n 224. A double cloak (cf. doublet); so large that it could be thrown twice (or double) about the body. It is contrasted with a(ploi+/das xlai/nas *w 230. — porfure/hn: of purple, while the interwoven scenes (poiki/lmata, o 107) were of some other color. For this artistic working in colors, cf. *c 179, *x 441 (quoted on v. 125). This art was prob. still dependent on oriental patterns, but evidently had advanced to the representation of persons.
pole/as: as 1.559.
e)ne/passen: wove in.

a)e/qlous: battles, fought on the plain of Troy, before the action of the Iliad. Other allusions to these conflicts are found v. 132 f., 1.520 f., 2.29 f., *e 788, *h 113 f., I 352 ff., 13.101 ff. But most of the earlier fighting seems to have been done at a distance, as Achilles pursued Aeneas not on the Trojan plain, but on Mt. Ida, 20.188 ff.
e(/qen: not enclitic, since it is reflexive, referring to the subj. of the principal sent. — u(p) *)/arhos ktl.: by the hands of Ares. u(po\ xersi\n ktl. is more freq. in similar expressions.
See on 2.790.
deu=r) i)/qi: cf. ba/sk) i)/qi *b 8, deu=t) a)/ge q 11.
nu/mfa fi/lh: dear lady, as d 743. — qe/skela e)/rga: an indefinite expression, to excite Helen's curiosity.
See on v. 127.
oi(\ pri/n: who before, i.e. until now. The antec. of the rel. follows, oi( dh\ nu=n v. 134. — e)pi\ ktl.: see on v. 15.
polu/dakrun: i.e. causing many tears, cf. v. 165, po/lemon dakruo/enta *e 737, ma/xhs dakruoe/sshs *n 765, lacrimabile bellum Verg. Aen. vii. 604.
For the rhyme between the two halves of the verse, cf. 2.484.
dh\ nu=n: already now. — e(/atai [h(=ntai] sigh=|: with the collateral notion of inactivity. See on B 255. — po/lemos ktl.: parenthetical; see on 2.333.
a)spi/si keklime/noi: leaning on their shields, as they stood; cf. vs. 231, 326, keklime/noi kalh=|sin e)pa/lcesin (battlements) 22.3.
para/: adv., by their side.
pe/phgen: i.e. with the saurwth/r (bronze point of the butt, 10.153) fixed in the ground. cf. defigunt telluri hastas et scuta reclinant Verg. Aen. xii. 130, stant terra defixae hastae ib. vi. 652.
= vs. 253 f., mutatis mutandis.

tw=| ke vikh/santi: him who gains the victory. For the dem. art. with the partic., cf. tw=| me\n nikh/santi ... a)ndri\ de\ nikhqe/nti *y 702 ff., to\n a)/gonta *f 262, o( nikhqei/s *y 663. — ke/: const. with nikh/santi, as is shown by its position and by o(ppo/teros de/ ke nikh/sh| v. 71. So v. 255. No other example of this const. is found in Homer.

fi/lh: standing epith., esp. with words which denote relationship (as tokh=es, path/r, pa/is, te/knon, cei=nos, e(tai=ros) or a part of the human body (as kefalh/, xei=r, gui=a), or mind (kh=r, h)=tor). See on A 491, § 1 p.
keklh/sh: thou shalt be called. See on *a 293, *b 260.
ei)pou=sa: coincides in time with e)/mbale.
gluku\n i(/meron: cf. v. 446.
prote/roio: Helen was no longer wife of Menelaus; so she says of Agamemnon, dah\r (husband's brother) au)=t) e)mo\s e)/ske v. 180, while her dae/res, *w 769, are Priam's sons.
a)/steos: used of the native city, as po/lis, v. 50.
tokh/wn: Tyndareüs and Leda were thought of as alive. Tyndareüs is called Helen's father, just as Heracles is called son of Amphitryo, 5.392; this is not inconsistent with vs. 199, 418.

a)rgennh=|si ktl.: cf. v. 419, a)po\ de\ liparh\n e)/rriye kalu/ptrhn *x 406, a\/nta pareia/wn (cheeks) sxome/nh lipara\ krh/demna (veil) Od. 1.334. In accordance with oriental custom, women and maidens were veiled when they went on the streets or came into the presence of men who were not immediate relations.
qala/moio: the apartments of the women in the rear part of the house. There Helen sits and spins with her maids, Z 321 ff.

143 = a 331, s 207; cf. z 84, t 601. — a(/ma th=| ge ktl.: in appos. with ou)k oi)/h, cf. 2.822. — Princely ladies generally are attended by two maids, cf. *x 450, 461, s 182 ff. But Andromache goes to the Tower (6.389) attended only by one maid, who carries the infant Astyanax.

*ai)/qra: Pittheus, king of Troezene, was son of Pelops. His daughter Aethra bore Theseus to Aegeus, king of Athens. She, living in Athens, had under her care Helen whom Theseus had carried off from Sparta, until Castor and Polydeuces freed their sister Helen and captured Aethra at or near Athens. So Aethra was made Helen's slave, first in Sparta and afterwards in Ilios. But this seems to be a post-Homeric story.
*klume/nh: likewise a slave brought with Helen from Sparta, cf. vs. 386 ff.
bow=pis: see on A 551.
o(/qi: thither where.
*skaiai\ pu/lai: see on 2.809.
oi( d) a)mfi\ ktl.: see on v. 148, 2.445.

*pa/nqoon: an aged Trojan, husband of Phrontis (17.40), father of the seer Polydamas (18.249 ff.), Euphorbus (16.808, in whose body the soul of Pythagoras claimed to have lived), and Hyperenor (*c 516, *p 23 ff.). From 15.521 f., Panthoüs is inferred to be a priest of Apollo, cf. Panthus Othryades, arcis Phoebique sacerdos Verg. Aen. ii. 319.
*qumoi/thn: only here in Homer. Vergil uses the name: primusque Thymoetes | duci (sc. wooden horse) intra muros hortatur Aen. ii. 32 f.
147 = 20.238, where it is said that these three heroes were sons of Laomedon, and brothers of Priam. All these had sons in the Trojan army, 15.526, 419, 546.
o)/zon *)/arhos: see on 2.540.

*ou)kale/gwn ktl.: these two receive prominence from the use of the nom. The change from the const. of vs. 146 f. is not bold since oi( a)mfi\ *pri/amon is essentially equiv. to *pri/amos kai\ oi( a)mfi/ min. — Ucalegon (ou)k a)le/gwn) is mentioned only here in Homer. cf. jam proximus (sc. to Deïphobus) ardet | Ucalegon Verg. Aen. ii. 311 f.
*)anth/nwr: see on 2.822. He is esp. prominent in the following scene, vs. 203-224, 262.
ei(/ato: h(=nto, see § 34 j.

dhmoge/rontes: in appos., as elders of the people; title of the nobles as leaders and counsellors, see on 2.21. This epith. is applied to Ilus, son of Dardanus, *l 372. — e)pi\ *skaih=|si pu/lh|sin: i.e. on the tower above the Scaean Gate, from which the Trojan elders and women were wont to watch the battles on the plain; cf. vs. 153, 384, *z 373, 386, 431, *p 700, *f 526, *x 447, 462 f., 24.735; cf. also illum ex moenibus hosticis | matrona bellantis tyranni | prospiciens et adulta virgo Hor. Carm. iii. 2. 6 ff., spectaverant enim e moenibus Pergami non viri modo sed feminae etiam Livy xxxvii. 20.
gh/rai+: equiv. to dia\ to\ gh=ras. — dh/: already.
pepaume/noi: the perf. indicates the continuance of the state brought about by the action of the verb.
a)gorhtai/: cf. 1.248.

tetti/gessin: cicadae. The males sit on sunny bushes and during the longest days make, by rubbing their wings, a clear chirping noise which the Greeks of all times admired greatly. They are not mentioned elsewhere in Homer. — The comparison refers only to the tone of voice; cf. h)xe/ta (loud-singing) te/ttic | dendre/w| e)fezo/menos ligurh
 kataxeu/et) a)oidh
 | pukno
 u(po\ pteru/gwn, qe/reos (summer) kamatw/deos w(/rh| Hesiod Works 582 ff., makari/zome/n de, te/ttic, | o(/te dendre/wn e)p) a)/krwn | o)li/ghn dro/son (dew) pepwkw/s | basileu\s o(/pws a)ei/deis: | . . file/ousi me/n se *mou=sai, | file/ei de\ *foi=bos au)to/s, | ligurh
 d) e)/dwken oi)/mhn Anacreontea 32.
dendre/w|: a trochee. For the synizesis, cf. *a 15, *b 651; see § 7 d.

leirio/essan: from lei/rion, lily-like, i.e. tender and delicate like the color of the lily; a)po\ tw=n o(rwme/nwn e)pi\ ta\ a)kouo/mena Schol. B. cf. i(/esan (sc. *seirh=nes) e)k stoma/twn o)/pa lei/rion Apoll. Rhod. iv. 901.
i(ei=sin: from i(/hmi, see § 34 e.
toi=oi: such, pred. with h(=nto. “Such were they who sat” etc.; see on 1.266.
a)/ra: recapitulates the comparison, cf. v. 161.
cf. *w 142, n 165. — h)=ka: for the short ultima, not lengthened before pr, see § 41 i b.

ou) ne/mesis ktl.: “we cannot blame” etc. — The beauty of Helen could not be praised more delicately or effectively than by this exclamation that she drew from the aged counsellors of Troy. cf. non putant indignum Troiani principes, Graios Troianosque propter Helenae speciem tot mala tanto temporis spatio sustinere: quaenam igitur illa forma credenda est? non enim hoc dicit Paris, qui rapuit, non aliquis iuvenis aut unus e vulgo, sed senes et prudentissimi et Priamo adsidentes. Quintilian viii. 4. 21.
toih=|de: such a one as that, as she stood before their eyes, with deictic -de, cf. v. 46. This is explained by the following verse.
a)mfi/: for the sake of, as vs. 70, 91.
ai)nw=s: marvellously, mightily.
ei)s w)/pa: lit. into the face, when one looks in the face, in countenance; cf. Od. 1.411.
This is a general remark and assumes no knowledge of the proposition of Paris.
o)pi/ssw: for the future.
ph=ma: see on v. 50.
e)kale/ssato: called to him.
fwnh=|: is used much like fwnh/sas. It is contrasted with h)=ka v. 155. — The three following speeches are of nine verses each, cf. the symmetry in the prayers (on v. 301).
deu=ro: cf. v. 130, a)ll) a)/ge teu/xea deu=ro labw\n i)/qi *n 235.
e)mei=o: const. with pa/roiqe, cf. A 360.
i)/dh|: Homer prefers the mid. forms of ei)=don, except in the partic. See on A 56.

ou)/ ti/ moi ktl.: Priam, as well as the poet, recognized the war as appointed and caused by the gods. He desired to remove the feeling of dread with which Helen, conscious of guilt, approached him. She appreciated his kindness, saying that Priam ‘was always kind as a father,’ *w 770. — moi/: in my eyes. This is expressed in both clauses.
qeoi/ nu/ moi: for the asyndeton, cf. A 107.
nu/: I think. — cf. the words of Venus: non tibi Tyndaridis facies invisa Lacaenae | culpatusve Paris; divum inclementia, divum | has evertitopes, sternitque a culmine Troiam Verg. Aen. ii. 601 ff.
oi(: dem.
polu/dakrun: cf. v. 132.
w(s ktl.: a second final clause depending on v. 162.
kai/: belongs to the whole clause, and indicates that another final sent. preceded.
e)conomh/nh|s: mayst name.
o(/s tis: pred.

o(/de: obs. the regular interchange of the prons. o(/de and ou(=tos in question and answer, here and v. 178, vs. 192 and 200, 226 and 229; both prons. are deictic, but o(de indicates simply what is before the eyes, while ou(=tos has reference to the question.
h)u/s te: cf. 2.653.
h)= toi me/n: correl. with de/ v. 169. It is true indeed; cf. h)= toi me\n oi)ke/oito po/lis *pria/moio a)/naktos, | au)=tis d) *)argei/hn *(ele/nhn *mene/laos a<*>/goito *d 18 f., 537.
kefalh=|: in stature; cf. v. 193.
kai/: still.
i)/don o)fqalmoi=sin: cf. ou)/asi pa/ntes a)/kouon *m 442, Launcelot's ‘running with thy heels’ Shakspere Merchant of Venice ii. 2. 10; see on A 587.
geraro/n: stately, cf. v. 211. See B 478, and note.
basilh=i a)ndri/: as Od. 24.253; cf. boulhfo/ron a)/ndra *b 24, and see on v. 6.
gunaikw=n: the gen. is partitive with the superlative idea in di=a, cf. *kaluyw\ di=a qea/wn a 14.
ai)doi=o/s te deino/s te: revered and dreaded.
fi/le, e(kure/: for the two ultimas lengthened by position, see §§ 14 c, 41 l b.
w(s: introduces a wish; cf. ai)/q) o)/feles ktl. *a 415. — o)/felen: see on 1.353.

kako/s: the standing epith. of death; it is contrasted with a(dei=n. “Would that I had chosen death rather” etc. Helen rarely misses an opportunity to express penitent consciousness of her guilt, cf. vs. 404, 412, 6.344 ff., o(/s m) a)/gage *troi/hnd): w(s pri\n w)/fellon o)le/sqai *w 764. See on 2.356. Her penitence always wins indulgence and sympathy.
qa/lamon: marriage-chamber; hence no special mention of her husband is needed.
gnwtou/s: brothers; see vs. 236 ff.
pai=da: Hermione, who afterwards married Neoptolemus, son of Achilles, Od. 4.5 ff.
o(mhliki/hn: abstract expression for o(mh/likas, companions.
to/: therefore; adv. acc. with te/thka.
kai/: also, marks klai/ousa te/thka (melt away in tears) as the expected effect.
177 = h 243, o 402; cf. t 171. — a)nei/reai: followed by two accs. cf. 1.550.
*)atrei+/dhs: see on A 7.
The favorite verse of Alexander the Great, acc. to Plutarch, de fortuna Alex. 331 c. — For the thought, see 1.258 and note.
a)mfo/teron: both; with the two parts added in appos. — Obs. the chiasmus.
au)=te: on the other hand.
kunw/pidos: see on 1.159, cf. v. 404. The gen. is in appos. with e)mou= implied in e)mo/s, see on 2.20.
ei)/ pot) e)/hn ge: if ever he was, “if it was not all a dream.” Helen speaks with mournful recollection of the happier past.
ma/kar: blessed.
moirhgene/s: child of fortune, blest by *moi=ra at his birth; the opposite is found in 1.418.
o)lbio/daimon: god-favored; contrast dai/monos ai)=sa kakh/ l 61, e 396.
h)= r(a/ nu ktl.: in truth then were subject to thee. The plpf. (= impf.) is used with reference to the previous perception of the numerous throng.
dedmh/ato: from dama/w.
kai/: also, i.e. as well as to other countries; cf. v. 205.
*frugi/hn: see on B 862.
e)/nqa: there.
*fru/gas a)ne/ras: closely connected, cf. basilh=i a)ndri/ v. 170. Whenever a)/ndres is added to an ethnic name, the words are not separated. For the diaeresis after the third foot, see § 40 l.
ai)olopw/lous: with swift steeds.

Otreus and Mygdon were Phrygian kings. Acc. to the later story, Otreus was brother of Hecuba. Aphrodite in visiting Anchises introduces herself as the daughter of Otreus, Hom. Hy. iv. 111. Mygdon was father of Coroebus (Cassandra's bridegroom), acc. to Verg. Aen. ii. 341 ff.
e)strato/wnto: were encamped, were on an expedition. cf. oi(/ r(a to/t) e)strato/wnq) i(era\ pro\s tei/xea *qh/bhs *d 378.

*saggari/oio: the largest river in Asia Minor, except the Halys. It rises in Galatia and empties into the Black Sea in Bithynia; cf. Sangarius ex Adoreo monte per Phrygiam fluens miscetur ad Bithyniam Tymbri fluvio; inde maior iam geminatis aquis per Bithyniam fertur et in Propontidem sese effundit, non tamen tam magnitudine memorabilis, quam quod piscium accolis ingentem vim praebet. Livy xxxviii. 18. cf. (*)/asios) au)tokasi/gnhtos (own brother) *(eka/bhs, ui(o\s de\ *du/mantos, | o(\s *frugi/h| nai/eske r(oh=|s e)pi\ *saggari/oio *p 718 f.
kai/: const. with e)gw/n.
e)le/xqhn: I was numbered; cf. meta\ toi=sin e)le/gmhn i 335.

*)amazo/nes: these were thought to live on the east of Phrygia. They carried on a war for booty against the Phrygians to whose assistance Priam went. cf. 2.814. Bellerophon was sent to overcome the Amazons, as his third task, Z 186.
a)ntia/neirai: cf. bellatrix! audetque viris concurrere virgo Verg. Aen. i.493.
a)ll) ou)d) oi(: but not even these; i.e. the Phrygians of v. 185.
e(li/kwpes: cf. A 98.
deu/teron: neut. acc. as adv. with e)re/eine, cf. v. 225.
ei)/p): for ei)pe/, with the accent thrown back after elision, cf. v. 89.
to/nde: anticipated from the rel. clause, see on 2.409.
mei/wn me\n ktl.: more exactly describing o(/de. — kefalh=|: as v. 168.
i)de/sqai: to look upon.
kti/los w(/s: cf. B 480, laoi\ e(/ponq) w(s ei)/ te meta\ kti/lon e(/speto mh=la *n 492. The syllable preceding w(/s is not lengthened as is usual, see on B 190.
e)pipwlei=tai sti/xas: comes up to the ranks; in order to review them, as 4.231, 250; with hostile intent, 11.540. Acc. to another figure, he was poimh\n law=n.
a)rneiw=| ktl.: a detailed explanation of kti/los w(/s.
pw=u: flock; always of sheep.
e)kgegaui=a: for e)kgegonui=a, the short form of the stem appearing in the fem. perf. partic.; see § 31 g.
ou(=tos d) au)=: contrasted with ou)=to/s ge v. 178; cf. v. 229.
*)odusseu/s: see on 1.138.
e)n dh/mw|: cf. 2.547.

kranah=s: cf. (*)iqa/kh) trhxei=) a)ll) a)gaqh\ kourotro/fos (nurse of men) Od. 9.27, scopulos Ithacae, Laërtia regna Verg. Aen. iii. 272, Ithacam illam in asperrimis saxulis tanquam nidulum affixam Cic. de Orat. i. 44.
pe/r: as A 352.
cf. ei)/m) *)oduseu\s *laertia/dhs, o(\s pa=si do/loisin | a)nqrw/poisi me/lw, kai/ meu kle/os ou)rano\n i(/kei i 19 f. For the epiths. of Odysseus, see § 1 q.
h)= ma/la: yes, in truth.
kai/: as v. 184.

deu=ro/ pot) h)/luqe: sc. before the beginning of open hostilities, in order to demand the restitution of Helen and the treasure. Odysseus as the most ready in speech and counsel was sent (cf. A 311 and I, where he is sent to persuade Achilles to return to the conflict) with Menelaus who had the greatest interest in the decision. Antimachus urged the killing of the embassadors and prevented the success of their embassy. cf. (*)anti/maxos) o(/s pot) e)ni\ *trw/wn a)gorh=| *mene/laon a)/nwgen | a)ggeli/hn e)lqo/nta su\n a)ntiqe/w| *)odush=i | au)=qi kataktei=nai mhd) e)ce/men a)\y e)s *)axaiou/s *l 139 ff.
a)ggeli/hs: equiv. to a)/ggelos, as embassador; cf. *d 384, *l 140 (quoted above), N 252, O 640.
e)cei/nissa: received hospitably.
fi/lhsa: entertained. This shows the beginning of a law of nations by which embassies enjoy the rights of guests. For the attitude of Antenor toward the errand of this embassy, see on 2.822.
fuh/n: as 1.115, cf. vs. 210 f.
e)da/hn: I learned to know.
mh/dea: cf. vs. 212 ff.
a)ll) o(/te dh/: the same beginning of the verse as vs. 212, 216, 221.

e)n a)grome/noisin: among the assembled, cf. v. 55. This was on the occasion when the Trojans discussed the demand made by the embassy. The poet does not raise the question why Priam did not then make the acquaintance of Odysseus.

sta/ntwn: sc. to address the people, cf. 1.58, 68, etc. The gen. is part., of Menelaus and Odysseus, but is not unlike a gen. abs., see §3 e, f. — u(pei/rexen [u(per-]: “towered above” Odysseus, cf. v. 168. cf. umeris extantem Verg. Aen. vi. 668.
w)/mous: acc. of specification, cf. v. 227.

a)/mfw d) e(zome/nw: i.e. as listeners; nom. of the whole, almost a nom. abs., since only one of the two persons comprised is mentioned in what follows. The sent. begins as if *)odusseu\s me/n, *mene/laos de/ were to follow. cf. *k 224, *m 400; and for other examples of change of const., see E 27, H 8, 306.
gerarw/teros: cf. v. 170. Menelaus had a short trunk but long legs, and appeared shorter only when they were seated.
pa=sin u(/fainon: wove for all, set forth before all; cf. toi=s o( ge/rwn ... u(fai/nein h)/rxeto mh=tin *h 324.
e)pitroxa/dhn: from tre/xw, see § 38 c, trippingly, fluently; in contrast with the cautious, slow beginning of Odysseus.

pau=ra me/n: correlative with ou)d) a)famartoeph/s. a)lla\ ma/la lige/ws is shown to be parenthetical by e)pei\ ou) polu/muqos which explains pau=ra. “Few words but to the point.” “Saying little indeed (although very clear, 2.246), for he was not a man of many words; but saying nothing which failed to hit the mark.” A Spartan king ought to be laconic! — cf. et Homerus brevem quidem cum iucunditate et propriam (id enim est non deerrare verbis) et carentem supervacuis eloquentiam Menelao dedit, quae sunt virtutes generis illius primi, et ex ore Nestoris dixit dulciorem melle profluere sermonem [A 249], qua certe delectatione nihil fingi maius potest: sed summam expressurus in Ulixe facundiam, et magnitudinem illi vocis et vim orationis nivibus hibernis copia verborum atque impetu parem tribuit. cum hocigitur nemo mortalium contendet, hunc ut deum homines intuebuntur. Quintilian xii. 10. 64 f.
a)famartoeph/s: cf. kai\ ou)x h(ma/rtane mu/qwn l 511, *ai)=an a(martoepe/s *n 824.

ei) kai/: even if, although he was younger than Odysseus. Reference is made to the age of Odysseus in 23.790, where he is said by Nestor's son to be prote/rhs geneh=s prote/rwn t) a)nqrw/pwn.—ge/nei: only here for geneh=|, in birth, in age.
a)nai+/ceien: for the opt. expressing indefinite frequency of past action, cf. v. 233. G. 233; H. 914 B.

u(pai\: [as 2.824] i)/deske: he always looked down; with the more definite statement kata\ xqono\s ktl., — a sign of meditation; cf. e)pi\ xqono\s o)/mmata pa=cai Theoc. ii. 112, as a sign of embarrassment. cf. non protinus est erumpendum, sed danda brevis cogitationi mora: mire enim auditurum dicturi cura delectat et iudex se ipse componit. hoc praecipit Homerus Ulixis exemplo, quem stetisse oculis in terram defixis immotoque sceptro, priusquam illam eloquentiae procellam effunderet, dicit. Quintilian xi. 3. 157 f.
skh=ptron: see on 1.58, 234.
a)stemfe/s: cf. 2.344. Odysseus made no gesture.

fai/hs ke: potential of the past, crederes, as v. 223; Att. e)/fhs a)/n. cf. v. 392. — Obs. the asyndeton. — za/koton ktl.: a sullen, ill-natured kind of a fellow. za- is a strengthening prefix, as in za-qe/hn *a 38; see on *b 308. — a)/frona ktl.: a mere simpleton. For au)/tws, see on 1.133; cf. pa/is d) e)/ti nh/pios au)/tws (a mere infant) 22.484.
dh\ o)/pa: the hiatus is merely apparent, since u)/y is from the same root as the Lat. vox; cf. e)/pos, and see § 14 a.
See Quintilian quoted on v. 214.
e)/pea: for the length of the ultima, see § 41 j. — nifa/dessin ktl.: in contrast with v. 214.
ou)k a)\n ktl.: “no other mortal could have vied.”
e)/peita: lit. after that.
*)odush=i: for the use of the name instead of a pron., see on A 240. Obs. the repetition of the name in the same position in the following verse, cf. vs. 430, 432, 434.
to/te: refers to o(/te v. 221, made more definite by ei)=dos i)do/ntes. — w(=de: so much as before. They were so moved by his eloquence that they forgot his unusual manner.
*)odush=os: const. with ei)=dos.
*ai)/anta: Telamonian Ajax, see on 1.138.
ti/s t) a)/ra: as *a 8, *b 761.
e)/coxos: cf. 2.480.
*)argei/wn: differing mainly in metrical form from *)axaio/s above: see on 1.79.
ou(=tos: see on v. 167.
pelw/rios: an epith. of Ajax also H 211, P 174, 360.

e(/rkos *)axaiw=n: see on 1.284; as *z 5, *h 211. cf. ou)=ros *)axaiw=n *q 80, of Nestor; e(/rma po/lhos *p 549 prop of the city, of Sarpedon; e)/reism) *)akra/gantos Pindar Ol. ii. 6, of Thero; *troi/as ki/ona ib. 81 pillar of Troy, of Hecotr; ‘pillar of state’ Milton Par. Lost ii. 302.

*)idomeneu/s: see on *a 145, *b 645. Idomeneus is named by Helen without any question of Priam; at sight of him she cannot suppress the memory of a happy past, and hence the longing for her brothers. A more mechanical reason for the change in the form of question and answer, is that the repetition of Priam's inquiry would become monotonous.
qeo\s w(/s: equiv. to qeoeidh/s v. 16, qeoei/kele *a 131, qew=| e)nali/gkios b 5.
h)gere/qontai: cf. B 304. The pres. serves to paint a picture.
polla/ki: generally appears in Homer without the final s, see § 12 o.
i(/koito: for the opt., cf. v. 216 where the iterative aor. sta/sken in the principal clause corresponds to the aor. with polla/ki in v. 232.
ken gnoi/hn: potential opt., sc. if you should ask me.
e)u/: well, clearly.
kai/ te: cf. 1.521.
ou)/noma: sc. the gen. of the pron. from ou(/s.
doiw/: for this form of the numeral, see § 23 b.
kosmh/tore: cf. v. 1, 1.16.
237 = Od. 11.300. — Castor and Poly deuces are mentioned only in this verse in Homer.
pu/c: with the fist, i.e. in boxing. See on 2.418.
au)tokasignh/tw: see on *b 706. — tw/ moi ktl.: develops the thought of the first word of the verse, cf. 1.2.
moi/: dat. of likeness with mi/a, “the same who bore me.”
gei/nato: for the omission of the augment, see § 25 e.
mh/thr: Leda. Acc. to the later story, Clytaemnestra also was Leda's daughter; see on 1.113.
e(spe/sqhn: cf. *a 158, *b 524.
deu/rw: only here for deu=ro, of which this seems to be the original form, cf. du/w and du/o, *diw/nusos and *dio/nusos.
au)=te: correl. with me/n, see on B 768, § 3 r.
ai)/sxea: insults.
deidio/tes: sc. that they must hear them. cf. Hector's words to Paris, to\ d) e)mo\n kh=r | a)/xnutai e)n qumw=|, o(/q) u(pe\r se/qen ai)/sxe) a)kou/w | pro\s *trw/wn *z 523 ff.
o)nei/dea: reproaches. For the use of two nearly synonymous words, see on v. 2.
a(/ moi e)/stin: which are mine, heaped upon me.
ka/texen: see on 2.699. A euphemism for death. “They were dead and buried.”

fusi/zoos: lifegiving. The epith. seems out of place here, but is used only in this connection. — Acc. to this story, both Dioscuri (*dio\s kou=roi) were dead. The later form of the story made Castor mortal, but Polydeuces immortal; but after the death of Castor, Zeus granted the prayer of Polydeuces that both brothers should be together alternately in heaven and in Hades. cf. Od. 11.299 ff. In post-Homeric times, they became the patron saints of sailors.
*lakedai/moni: for the following hiatus, see §§ 9, 18 a.
au)=qi: here follows the word that explains it. — The grave of the Dioscuri was shown at Therapnae, near Sparta.
e)n patri/di: obs. the repetition of the prep. in this appos. clause. cf. 2.722.
Vs. 245-313. Priam drives to the field, concludes the treaty with Agamemnon, and returns to the city. — This continues the story that was interrupted at v. 121.
kh/rukes: see vs. 116 f.
a)na\ a)/stu: up through Ilios, cf. 1.10.
qew=n: those named vs. 103 f.
fe/ron: in order to take them to the plain.
o(/rkia pista/: cf. v. 269, 2.124; faithful, trustworthy pledges of the oath.
a)/rne ktl.: in appos. with o(/rkia. — oi)=non ktl.: equiv. to eu)frai/nonta ktl. cf. ‘wine that maketh glad the heart of man’ Psalms civ. 15.
a)skw=| ktl.: the usual means of carrying wine on journeys, cf. e 265, z 78, i 196. Wine was stored at home in great jars (pi/qoi b 340).
karpo\n a)rou/rhs: elsewhere only of grain.
*)idai=os: the most honored of Priam's heralds and his personal attendant; cf. 7.276, 372, 381 ff., 24.282, 325. For the quantity of the ultimate, see § 41 p.
ge/ronta: Priam, whom they were sent to summon.
parista/menos: sc. after ascending the tower by the Seaean gate (v. 149).
o)/rseo: see on v. 103; arise. Obs. the following asyndeton.
*laomedontia/dh: for the formation of the patronymic, see § 21 j.
a)/ristoi: the princes, as v. 274.
ta/mhte: sc. thou and the Achaean princes. — See on v. 105.
253-255 = vs. 136-138, mutatis mutandis.
maxh/sontai: will fight; this marks simply the future fact.
e(/poito: the opt. here, as v. 74, expresses a wish. The imv. is used in the corresponding passages, vs. 72, 93, 282, because this thought is presented there as a demand or condition.
256-258 = vs. 73-75, with slight changes.
ne/ontai: fut., cf. v. 138. The fut. is better suited than the imv. to the lips of the herald.
r(i/ghsen: he feared for his son's life, cf. vs. 306 ff.
e(tai/rois: his attendants; the king was never unattended.
e)pi/qonto: i.e. they hastened to the palace, harnessed the horses, and brought them to the Gate. Priam descended from the tower to mount the chariot. We miss here the usual epic fulness of detail.
a)/n [a)na/]: const. with e)/bh. — kata\ ktl.: as v. 311, 19.394. The reins were tied to the front rim of the chariot, cf. 5.262, 322; the king now untied these and drew them back toward himself.
pa\r de/ oi(: lit. at his side for him, pa/r being adv.; i.e. so as to stand beside him.
di/fron: acc. of limit of motion, cf. v. 407, see on 1.322.
*skaiw=n: only here as subst., without pu/lai, see on 1.54.
e)/xon: held, guided.
meta/: see on 1.222.
e)c i(/ppwn: from their chariots; equiv. to e)c oxe/wn v. 29. cf. w)=se d) a)f) i(/ppwn *e 19, ei)s i(/ppous a(/letai (leaps into the chariot) *l 192, i(/ppwn | w)kupo/dwn e)pe/bhse *q 128 f.
e)s me/sson: see on v. 69.
e)stixo/wnto: went, as B 92.
w)/rnuto: arose, hastened to greet the Trojan princes, cf. o)/rseo v. 250.
au)ti/k) e)/peita: follows the verb, as Od. 17.120.
a)/n [a)na/]: sc. w)/rnuto, cf. e)/lipon ... ka\d de\ (sc. e)/lipon) ktl. *e 481.
kh/rukes: sc. of both armies, cf. v. 274.
o(/rkia: see on v. 245.

mi/sgon: not like kero/wnto (q 470, o 500, u 253), but mingled the wine of both parties to the libation. In solemn sacrifices, the wine was not mixed with water, hence spondai\ a)/krhtoi *b 341. When mi/sgw oi)=non is used like temperare vinum, u(/dwr is added, cf. oi( me\n oi)=non e)/misgon e)ni\ krhth=rsi kai\ u(/dwr a 110. — basileu=sin: for the princes of Trojans and Achaeans. Obs. that no priests are mentioned in this connection.
e)pi\ xei=ras: see on A 449.
xei/ressi: xeiri/ would be more exact.
pa\r kouleo/n: along by the sheath.
ai)e/n: as commander and high-priest of the army, Agamemnon used this knife often at sacrifices.
a)/wrto: from a)ei/rw, cf. a)/or sword, a)orth/r sword-strap.
a)rnw=n: as the principal idea, it is placed before kefale/wn which it limits. See vs. 103 f.

nei=man: sc. tri/xas. They distributed the wool cut from the victims' heads as a symbol that all the chiefs present took part in the treaty, swearing by the victim. This sacrifice was without fire, as was most freq. in the case of treaties and reconciliations. g 446, c 422, are different.

276 = v. 320, *h 202, *w 308. — Agamemnon invokes the divinities of the heavens, the earth, and the regions beneath the earth. cf. i)/stw *zeu\s nu=n prw=ta, qew=n u(/patos (most exalted) kai\ a)/ristos, | gh= te kai\ h)e/lios kai\ e)rinu/es (furies), ai(/ q) u(po\ gai=an | a)nqrw/pous ti/nuntai ktl. T 258 ff., esto nunc Sol testis, et haec mihi Terra vocanti, | ... et pater omnipotens, et tu Saturnia coniux, ... tuque inclute Mavors, | ... fontesque fluviosque, voco, quaeque aetheris alti | religio, et quae caerulio sunt numina ponto. Verg. Aen. xii. 176 ff.

*)/idhqen: Zeus had a sacred grove and an altar on Mt. Ida (8.48), and ruled thence as god of the country. The pious soul sought and found the divinity near at hand, esp. on mountain summits. — ku/diste ktl.: cf. Iupiter optimus maximus. See on B 412.

h)e/lios: nom. as voc. This const. is rare. — pa/nt) e)fora=|s ktl.: Helios, accomplishing daily his course in the heavens, is fitted to be a witness to solemn compacts. cf. o)/mnumi/ soi qeou\s, oi(/ kai\ s(rw=si pa/nta kai\ a)kou/ousi pa/nta Xen. Cyr. v. 4. 31, qui pervidet omnia, Solem Ovid Met. xiv. 375.
potamoi/: the Trojan rivergods (Scamander and Simoïs), as near at hand, are invoked as witnesses; cf. Soph. Aj. 862. A priest (a)rhth/r) of the Scamander is mentioned E 77 f.

kai\ oi(/: const. with ti/nusqon. The dual is used with reference to Hades and Persephone, cf. *zeu/s te kataxqo/nios kai\ e)painh\ (dread) *persefo/neia *i 457. — kamo/ntas: who have become weary; euphemism for qano/ntas.
o(/ tis: obs. the distributive sing., after the pl. For the form, see § 24 s.
o)mo/ssh: for the aor. subjv., cf. 1.554.
ma/rturoi: as *a 338, *b 302.
au)to\s e)xe/tw: let him keep; cf. i(/ppous d) au)to\s e)/xe f 30, *e 271. — kth/uata: see on v. 70.
new/meqa: the subjv. expresses the speaker's resolve, not unlike the ordinary hortatory subjv.
canqo/s: from the color of his hair; cf. ka/rh canqo\s *mene/laos o 133. See on 1.197.
*trw=as ktl.: then shall the Trojans restore etc. a)podou=nai is parallel with e)xe/tw, cf. 2.413.
timhn. equiv. to poinh/n recompense; cf. 1.159.
h(/n tina: sc. a)potine/men.

kai/: also; const. with e)ssome/noisin. — pe/lhtai: shall be. This is strictly a final clause. — This exemplary penalty was to serve as a precedent in later times and warn men against committing such deeds.
*pri/amos ktl.: as 1.255.
ou)k e)qe/lwsin: ou)k is used, not mh/, though in a cond. clause, since the neg. and verb form but one idea, are unwilling, refuse; cf. ou) xrai/smh| *a 28.
*)aleca/ndroio: prob. gen. abs.; although it could be construed with timh/n, see § 3 f b.
au)ta/r: on the other hand, introduces the adversative apod., cf. 1.133, si tua re subita consilia torpent, at tu mea sequere Livy i. 41; see § 3 n.
te/los pole/moio: i.e. the victory, see on 2.122; cf. e)n ga\r xersi\ te/los pole/mou *p 630. — kixei/w: see on A 26.
h)=: see on 1.219.
stoma/xous: obj. of a)po\ ta/me, cf. a)pe/koye te/nontas (sinews) g 449. — xalkw=|: equiv. to ma/xairan v. 271.
qumou=: life, as *a 593. — deuome/nous: gives the reason for a)spai/rontas. — me/nos: force, cf. me/nea v. 8.
a)fusso/menoi: drawing (dipping) for themselves. The act of dipping and pouring continued until each had poured his libation. Elsewhere drawing wine was part of the herald's office. See on 1.471.
e)/kxeon: sc. out of their cups, upon the ground, cf. oi)=non d) e)k depa/wn xama/dis xe/on *h 480. — ai)eigene/th|sin: cf. qeoi\ ai)e\n e)o/ntes *a 290.
pro/teroi: comp., for only two parties are in question, cf. v. 351.

u(pe\r o(/rkia: “contrary to the compacts.” cf. *d 67, 236, 271. — phmh/neian: intrans.; “commit an act of hostility.” The opt. is used in the subord. clause, with the opt. of wishing in the principal clause, to express a mere conception of the mind.

w(=de/ sfi ktl.: thus may for them, etc. The pers. pron. is used instead of the dem., since the protasis has hypothetical force; see on *b 392. — w(s o(/de oi)=nos: symbolical actions were customary in curses and conjurations; cf. (fetialis) ‘si prior defexit publico consilio dolo malo, tum illo die, Iuppiter, populum Romanum sic ferito ut ego hunc porcum hic hodie feriam.’ ... id ubi dixit, porcum saxo silice percussit Livy i. 24, (Hannibal) eaque utrata scirent fore agnum laeva manu dextera silicem retinens, si falleret, Iovem ceterosque precatus deos, ita se mactarent, quem ad modum ipse agnum mactasset, secundum precationem caput pecudis saxo elisit ib. xxi. 45, ‘As sinks that blood stream in the earth, | So may his heart's blood drench his hearth’ Scott Lady of the Lake iii. 1.

au)tw=n kai\ teke/wn: the gen. depends on e)gke/falos, although sfi/ (not sfe/wn) has preceded; see § 3 g g. This clause forms an extension of the original thought; cf. di/dwqi de/ moikle/os e)sqlo/n, | au)tw=| kai\ pai/dessi kai\ ai)doi/h| parakoi/ti (spouse) Od. 3.380 f.
a)/lloisi damei=en: “may they be made the slaves of others,” cf. 6.454 ff., 9.594; unlike 2.355. — This prayer contains four verses, like the prayers of vs. 320 ff., 351 ff., 365 ff. See on v. 161.
toi=si: const. with meta\ e)/eipen, cf. v. 96.

*dardani/dhs: Priam was in the fifth generation from Dardanus, 20.215 ff. The line of descent was: Zeus, Dardanus, Erichthonius, Tros, Ilus, Laomedon, Priam. For the use of the patronymic, see § 21 m.

h)nemo/essan: the epith. is well deserved acc. to Dr. Schliemann, who in his excavations at Hissarlik was much disturbed by the constant winds which drove the dust into the eyes of the workmen. He thinks that such continual wind-storms are known nowhere else on earth. ‘The winds blew about us with such force that we often felt as if our whole settlement might be hurled down the precipice.’
a)/y: const. with ei)=mi. — ou)/ pw: in no way. For pw/ as pw/s, see § 12 o.

tlh/somai: cf. te/tlhkas *a 228. — e)n o)fqalmoi=sin: see on A 587. — Priam fears the death of his son, as v. 259. — Vergil imitates: non pug<*>am aspicere han<*> oculis, non foedera, possum Aen. xii. 151.
308 = c 119. — *zeu\s ktl.: “Zeus doubtless knows, but I do not.”
qana/toio te/los: a periphrasis for qa/natos, cf. tw\ d) au)=qi te/los qana/toio ka/luyen *e 553, and distinguish fa/nh bio/toio teleuth/ *h 104.
peprwme/non e)sti/n: equiv. to pe/prwtai *s 329, cf. tetelesme/nos e)sti/n *a 388.

a)/rnas qe/to: sc. in order to take back with him the two slaughtered lambs which he brought. The flesh of the victim sacrificed to confirm an oath was not eaten, since a c<*>rested upon it, but was buried. P<*> the Achaeans cast their victim i<*> the sea, being unable to bury it in their own land, cf. 19.267 f.
e)/baine: for the impf., see on a)fi/ei *a 25.
a)/yorroi: as 21.456, cf. pali/norsos v. 33; elsewhere a)/yorron is used adv., with sing. or pl.
a)pone/onto: see on 2.113.
Vs. 314-382. The duel. Paris is rescued from death by Aphrodite, and carried to his home.

dieme/treon: they measured off the ground for the combat, and the distance at which they were to have their spears, cf. v. 344. cf. campum ad certamen magnae sub moenibus urbis | dimensi Rutulique viri Teucrique parabant Verg. Aen. xii. 116 f.

316 = 23.861, cf. k 206. — klh/rous pa/llon: “they arranged the casting of lots.” This is expressed more definitely in v. 324. The klh=roi were bits of wood or stone, marked with some sign so as to be recognized, 7.175 ff. The prayer was offered while the lots were shaken.
pro/sqen: before, first; cf. v. 346, B 359, pro/teros v. 351.
a)fei/h: opt. in indir. disc., representing the subjv. of deliberation in direct disc., cf. 1.191.
xei=ras a)ne/sxon: equiv. to xei=ras a)nasxo/ntes, see § 3 t. For the attitude, cf. 1.450.
ta/de e)/rga: these troubles here, i.e. this war.
e)/qhken: caused, as 1.2. — This close of the verse is found also g 136, w 546. — Both armies seem to unite in wishing the death of Paris.

do/s: for do/s with the inf. in prayers, cf. v. 351, do\s de/ te/ m) a)/ndra e(lei=n *e 118, *z 307. — a)pofqi/menon du=nai: equiv. to a)pofqi/sqai kai\ du=nai. For the epic fulness of expression, see on 1.88.
*)/ai+dos: see on 1.3.
koruqai/olos: see on B 816.
a)/y o(ro/wn: with averted face, in order to escape the suspicion of favoring his brother.
*pa/rios: see on v. 16.
e)k o)/rousen: the lot was not drawn, but cast, thrown out. Cf. e)k d) e)/qore (leaped) klh=ros kune/hs *h 182, *y 353.

oi( me/n: Trojans and Achaeans, who had stood during the sacrifice. Perhaps they had not been seated before (see on v. 78, cf. vs. 84, 113 f., 231, 250, 267), although they long ago had dismounted from their chariots and laid their armor upon the ground.
kata\ sti/xas: according to ranks, in ranks.

e)/keito: grammatically and in sense, const. only with teu/xea, although kei=mai often is the pass. of ti/qhmi. For the zeugma, see on pro\s dw=ma *a 533, cf. o(/qi tou= ge do/moi kai\ kth/mat) e)/keito c 291.
a)mf) w)/moisin: standing expression in the case of the principal parts of the warrior's equipment: breastplate, sword (as v. 334), and shield.
e)du/seto: Paris had entered the conflict as a light-armed warrior, see on v. 17.

330-338. cf. 11.17 ff., *p 131-139, *t 369 ff. — The poet presents a picture of the preparations for battle. The complete armament of the Homeric warrior consisted in the six pieces here enumerated, which are always mentioned in the same order before an important conflict.
knhmi=das: see on 1.17.
kala/s: for the order of words, see § 1 n. — e)pisfuri/ois ktl.: furnished with buckles, by which they were fastened at the ankle.
oi(=o kasignh/toio: since he himself had appeared without a cuirass.

*luka/onos: Lyeaon had been captured by Achilles and sold as a slave to the king of Lemnos; being ransomed thence, he returned to Troy a week before the events narrated in this book; but twelve days after his return, he met Achilles again and was slain by him, 21.34 ff.
h(/rmose d) au)tw=|: but he fitted it to himself; he changed the length of the straps, buckling it to suit his own form.

335 = *p 136. — xa/lkeon: prominence is given to an epith. of the whole sword, after the decoration of the hilt has been mentioned in a)rguro/hlon <*> *t 373. — sa/kos: the strap which ded the arm in supporting the hea<*>y shield was thrown over the shoulder, see on 2.388. Thus the shield was taken up before the plumed helmet was donned.

336-338 = 15.480-482; cf. x 123125. — kune/hn: originally a head-covering of dogskin, then helmet; cf. ktide/hn (weasel-skin) kune/hn *k 335, kune/hn taurei/hn *k 257 f.; old Laërtes wore ai)gei/hn (goat-skin) kune/hn w 231.

337 = *l 42. — i(/ppourin: cf. i(ppodasei/hs v. 369, i(ppo/komoi ko/ruqes *n 132, lo/fon i(ppioxai/thn *z 469, i(/ppeion lo/fon *o 537, aere <*>aput fulgens, cristaque hirsutus equina Verg. Aen. x. 869.
deino/n: cognate acc., adv. with e)/neuen, cf. v. 342.
338 = Od. 17.4; cf. *p 139. — pala/mhfin: here dat.; it is in the gen. v. 368; see § 15 a.
a)rh/rein: for the n-movable, cf. h)/skein v. 388; see § 12 n.
w(\s d) au)/tws: and thus in like manner; see § 24 j.
*mene/laos: Menelaus came forth to battle equipped with armor (v. 29), but put it off as the rest did, v. 114.
a)rh/ios: a short form of a)rhi/filos, see on v. 21.
e)/ntea: equiv. to teu/xea, chiefly of defensive armor.
340 = *y 813. — e(ka/terqen o(mi/lou: on either side of the throng.
cf. *y 815. — deino/n: cf. v. 337.
diametrhtw=|: see on v. 315.
kote/onte: subord. to sei/onte.
pro/sqe: as v. 317.

cf. v. 356, *h 250, *r 517, *u 274. — pa/ntos) e)i/shn: a standing formula, at the close of the verse; alike on every side. Strictly used of the smaller circular shields (a)spi/das eu)ku/klous *e 453), in distinction from the large oval sa/kos. But the shield of Paris is called sa/kos v. 335, and a)spi/s, v. 356; and thus also the shield of Achilles is a)spi/s, *s 458, and sa/kos *s 478.
ou)de/: but not.
e)/rrhcen: broke through the shield.
xalko/s: the bronze point of the lance, cf. xalkw=| below.
oi(=: refers to xalko/s.

w)/rnuto xalkw=|: arose with his lance, “raised himself to hurl his lance”; cf. a)nasxo/menos v. 362, altior exurgens Verg. Aen. xi. 697, corpore toto | alte sublatum consurgit Turnus in ensem. ... at perfidus ensis | frangitur ib. xii. 728 ff.
e)peuca/menos: “uttering a prayer as he did so.”

*zeu= a)/na: as *p 233, r 354. The vocative form a)/na is found in Homer only in this phrase; elsewhere, a)/nac, as B 284, 434. — do\s ti/sasqai o(\ ktl.: equiv. to do/s moi ti/saoqai tou=ton o(\s ktl. The rel. clause o(/ me ktl. represents a noun as the obj. of ti/sasqai. — pro/teros: cf. v. 299.

si=on: a standing epith., denoting nobility of descent and beauty; it is here used without any special reference to the circumstances of the case, see on 1.7. These ‘ornamental epithets’ are sometimes put into the mouth of a foe, as X 393.
*)ale/candron: is the obj. of ti/sasqai. This makes the preceding rel. clause more parenthetical than if this proper name had been attracted to the const. of the rel. clause, as *laodi/khn v. 124.
kai\ ... damh=nai: a more definite expression of the thought of ti/sasqai.
ti\s: many a one, cf. 2.271.
kai/: as v. 287.
o(/ ken ktl.: explanatory of ceinodo/kon.—filo/thta: hospitality, cf. v. 207.

355 = *e 280, *h 244, *l 349, *p 516, *x 273, 289, cf. w 519, 522. — a)mpepalw/n: reduplicated aor. (§ 25 j) from a)napa/llw. After he had swung back, i.e. had drawn back for the throw; cf. adducto contortum hastile lacerto | immittit Verg. Aen. xi. 561 f.
dia/: with long i at the beginning of the verse; see § 41 q.
faeinh=s: the outer layer of the shield was a plate of brass, cf. 7.223.
o)/brimon: weighty, mighty.
h)rh/reisto: was thrust, by the force of the throw; plpf. from e)rei/dw, used almost like an aor.
a)ntikru/s: const. closely with what follows, cf. a)ntikru\s de\ di) w)/mou xa/lkeon e)/gxos | h(=lqen *d 481 f., 5.67, 74, 189.
dia/mhse: mowed its way through, cut through.
e)kli/nqh: he bent aside.
h)leu/ato: for the 1st aor. without tensesign, see § 30 i.

a)nasxo/menos: drawing up his arm, in order to give a heavier blow; cf. v. 349, c 425, s 95. — fa/lon: the metal ridge in which the horsehair was arranged like a mane. cf. kune/hn ... a)/falo/n te kai\ a)/llofon *k 257 f., ko/ruqos fa/lon h)/lasen ... a)/kron u(po\ lo/fon *n 614 f.
a)mfi\ au)tw=|: const. with diatrufe/n, about itself, i.e. about the fa/los.
trixqa/ te kai\ ktl.: a descriptive expression, see § 2 b.
te kai/: cf. *a 128, *b 346 and notes.
diatrufe/n: from diaqru/ptw. cf. Verg. Aen. xii. 730, quoted on v. 349.

365 = Od. 20.201, cf. *y 439. — sei=o o)low/teros: Zeus cei/nios, the guardian of hospitality (cf. Od. 9.270 f.), had not avenged the privileges that Paris had abused. — Such reproaches of the divinity are uttered only in outbreaks of momentary vexation, as M 164, N 631 f. cf. B 111.
e)fa/mhn ktl.: see on 2.37.
kako/thtos: causal gen.; for the wrong which he did me.
nu=n de/: see on 1.354.
a)/gh: from a)/gnumi. — e)k: const. with h)i/xqh.
e(tw/sion: pred. nom., cf. x 256. — ou)de\ da/massa: marks the result of both preceding clauses.
ko/ruqos: for the gen., cf. e(anou= v. 385, gou/nwn *a 500.
e(/lke ktl.: “he seized Paris by the helmet, turned him about, and strove to draw him into the midst of the Achaeans.” Of course the helmetstrap (i(ma/s) under the chin of Paris, choked him.
polu/kestos: richly embroidered, cf. kesto\n i(ma/nta *c 214.
This verse explains u(po\ deirh/n. — u(p) a)nqere/wnos: as 1.501.
o)xeu/s: as holder; pred. with o(/s.
374 = *e 312. — ei) mh\ ktl.: the first hemistich, as *e 680, *q 91, 132, *u 291.
h(/: in the rapid narration, the rel. const. is used here, where a new sent. would be expected. Or this h(/ may be called dem., with no conj. to connect with the preceding verse.
i)=fi ktame/noio: such leather would be stronger than that from a diseased animal. For the aor. mid. used as pass., see § 32 d.
trufa/leia: the following hiatus is justified, as falling at the fem. caesura of the third foot, see § 9 b. — a(/m) e(/speto ktl.: i.e. it remained in his hand.
paxei/h|: thick.
r(i=y) e)pidinh/sas: as 19.268, cf. h(=k) e)pidinh/sas *h 269, peristre/yas h(=ke q 189. He swung the helmet before he threw it.
ko/misan: cf. 2.875.
o( a)/y: for the hiatus, see on 1.333.

e)/gxei ktl.: emphatic at the beginning of the verse, and the close of the sent., cf. ba/lle *a 52. Const. with e)po/rouse. — e)ch/rpace: the poet recognizes no chance rescue; see on 1.8; cf. 5.314 where Aeneas is saved by Aphrodite, and 20.325 where the same hero is rescued by Poseidon.
381 = 20.444, cf. *l 752, *f 549, 597. — r(ei=a ktl.: “easily, as only a god can.”
e)ka/luye de/: “and made him invisible.” cf. sa/wse de\ nukti\ kalu/yas *e 23, pollh\n h)e/ra xeu=e h 15.
ka\d ei/=se: cf. ka/qison v. 68.
e)n qala/mw|: in his chamber, cf. v. 391.
Vs. 383-420. Aphrodite conducts Helen from the Scaean Gate to her home and Paris.
kale/ousa: fut. partic., expressing purpose.
*trwai/: women who had come to view the combat, as v. 420; see on 149.

nektare/ou: used like a)mbro/sios as divine, heavenly, of charming grace and beauty. cf. Achilles's nekta/reos xitw/n, *s 25, Artemis's a)mbro/sios e(ano/s *f 507. — e(anou=: always of a woman's garment. Distinguish from this the adj. e(a_no/s. — e)ti/nace: plucked.
mi/n: const. with prose/eipen, cf. v. 389. For the quantity, before a lost consonant, see § 41 m.

palaigene/i+: the adj. strengthens the noun; cf. grhu=s palaih/ t 346, grh=u palaigene/s x 395. — prose/eipen: always used of words that follow immediately, or separated only by a parenthetical clause.
ei)roko/mw|: explained by the following clause.
h)/skein: contracted from h)/skeen. cf. ei)/ria/ te cai/nein (card) x 423. — ma/lista ktl.: the rel. const. is abandoned, cf. A 79, 162. — This shows why Aphrodite took the form of this old woman.
file/esken: sc. *(ele/nh. For the change of subj., cf. o(/s oi( plhoi/on i(=ze, ma/l<*>ta de/ min file/<*>sken h 171.
th=| min ktl.: cf. B 22, 795.
deu=r) i)/qi: see on v. 130.
kei=nos: there, as *e 604, *t 344.
o(/ ge: is he.
cf. ka/llei kai\ xa/risi sti/lbwn z 237. — ou)de/ ke fai/hs: potential, nor would you think; not as v. 220.
a)ndri\ maxhsa/menon: equiv. to e)k ma/xhs. — xoro/nde: at the close of the verse in contrast with maxhsa/menon.
e)/rxesqai: “ready to go to the dance,” so beautiful and vigorous is he. — ne/on ktl.: i.e. he is in as merry a humor as if he had just enjoyed a dance. The partic. has the principal thought.
qumo\n o)/rinen: aroused her anger, by the unworthy suggestion.

kai/ r(a: and so. This r(a/ is resumed by the a)/ra of the apod., v. 398; cf. the repetition of dh/ w 71 f. — deirh\n sth/qea ktl.: these parts were unchanged by the transformation (vs. 386-389); the divinities retained their characteristics even under a disguise, except when they desired to make themselves entirely unrecognizable by mortals. cf. w(s de\ i)/den (sc. *)agxi/shs) deirh/n te ka<*>i\ o)/mmata ka/l) *)afrodi/ths Hom. Hy. iv. 181. — All but Helen saw only the old woman.
qa/mbhsen: cf. 1.199. Wonder mingled with dread came over her, fearing some new device of Aphrodite who had already led her far from her Spartan home. — e)/pos ktl.: as 1.361.
daimoni/h: cruel divinity. See on 2.190.
tau=ta: cognate acc. with h)peropeu/ein which takes me/ as dir. obj. “To trick me with these deceits”; cf. tou=to u(ma=s e)capath=sai Xen. An. v. 7. 6.
h)=: surely; with mocking irony.
prote/rw: still farther from Lacedaemon.
poli/wn: const. with ph/|, “into any one of these cities.” G. 168; H. 757.
cf. *s 291. — *frugi/hs: const. with poli/wn.
kai\ kei=qi: there also; just as Alexander in Ilios.
mero/pwn: as 1.250.
ou(/neka dh\ nu=n: this introduces sarcastically the reason for the conjecture of vs. 400 f. “Since now, as it seems, I cannot remain longer with your favorite Paris.”
stugerh/n: see on v. 173.
tou/neka dh\ ktl.: again a sarcastic tone. This is closely connected with the causal rel. sent., as is shown by the repetition of the particles dh\ nu=n. Thus the thought returns to v. 399.
dolofrone/ousa: in pretending that Paris summons her, v. 390.

par) au)to/n: by himself; contrasted with deu=ro v. 405. “Leave me alone.” The asyndeton marks her excitement. — qew=n ktl.: abandon the path of the gods, “give up thine immortality.” cf. ei)=ke, *dio\s qu/gater, pole/mou kai\ dhio/thtos (conflict) E 348. The expression is suggested doubtless by the following verse which was already before her mind.
*)/olumpon: the limit of motion.
peri\ kei=non: about him, at his side.
o)i/zue: endure woe, “bear all the troubles of human life.”
e( fu/lasse: watch him, sc. that he does not escape thee or prove unfaithful to thee.
poih/setai: aor. subjv. with ei)s o(/ ke, cf. B 332.

o(/ ge: see on A 97; for its position in the second member of the sent., as 2.664, cf. polla\ d) o(/ g) e)n po/ntw| pa/qen a)/lgea a 4, nunc dextra ingeminans ictus, nunc ille sinistra Verg. Aen. v. 457, nec dulces amores | sperne puer neque tu choreas Hor. Carm. i. 9. 15 f.
dou/lhn: this word is found only here and Od. 4.12; the masc. dou=los is not found in Homer. See § 2 y.
nemesshto\n ktl.: parenthetical; cf. *c 336, *w 463, x 489. — nemesshto/n: cf. v. 156, B 223.
kei/nou: indicates contempt or abhorrence.
porsune/ousa: to prepare, to share.
de/: the clause is causal in effect.
o)pi/ssw: hereafter; cf. meto/pisqe *i 249.

mwmh/sontai: sc. if I give myself to this frivolous coward after the decision by the duel. The fut. is used (more definite than the potential opt.) although the supposition at the basis of this expectation is negatived (ou)k ei)=mi v. 410). — e)/xw ktl.: as 24.91. “And yet I have already” etc.
xolwsame/nh: falling into a rage, cf. o)xqh/sas *a 517. The mid. does not differ greatly from the pass., cf. xolwqei/s *a 9; see § 32 d.
sxetli/h: disyllabic, with syn izesis of ih, see on *(isti/aian *b 537.
meqei/w: for the subjv., cf. 1.28; for the form, (Att. meqw=), cf. kixei/w *a 26.
tw=s: see on 2.330.
a)pexqh/rw: aor. subjv.; conceive violent hatred.
nu=n: opposed to the future, till now.
e)/kpagla: furiously; cf. ai)nw=s v. 158.
fi/lhsa: came to love you, “bestowed my love upon you.”

a)mfote/rwn: explained by *trw/wn kai\ *danaw=n. — mhti/somai: aor. subjv., still dependent on mh/. — e)/xqea lugra/: grievous hates, which would be destructive to Helen. — cf.
illa (sc. Helen) sibi infestos eversa ob Pergama Teucros
et poenas Danaum, et deserti coniugis iras,
praemetuens Verg. Aen. ii. 571 ff.
su\ de\ ... o)/lhai: an independent addition, as is shown by ke/n, in order to explain the effect of e)/xqea lugra/. For the subjv. with ke/n, see on A 137.
oi)=ton: cognate acc.
e)/deisen: see on 1.33. Helen does not yield until after the sternest threat.
katasxone/nh: wrapping herself, cf. kaluyame/nh v. 141.
*trwa/s: see on v. 384.
la/qen: sc. ba=sa, as she departed with her two maids (cf. vs. 143, 422). — Helen, in her shame, veiled herself silently, and followed the goddess without attracting attention.
h)=rxe: as *a 495. — dai/mwn: nowhere else in Homer of a definite divinity.
Vs. 421-447. Helen and Paris.
do/mon: on the citadel of Ilios, near the dwellings of Priam and Hector, cf. 6.313 ff.
a)mfi/poloi: the two who had accompanied her, v. 143.
ki/e: i.e. following Aphrodite, cf. v. 420.
th=|: for her.
di/fron: a low seat without a back.
e(lou=da: prior in time to kate/qhke fe/rousa. Obs. the distinction between the aor. and pres. partics.
a)nti/) *)aleca/ndroio: acc. to v. 391, Alexander was on the bed, but this is disregarded in the following narration, cf. a)/rxe le/xosde kiw/n v. 447.
qea/: added to give prominence to her condescension in performing a maid's duties.
fe/rousa: for the use of the partic., see on i)w/n *a 138.
kou/rh *dio/s: generally of Athene, but of Artemis *i 536, z 151, and of Aphrodite 20.105; cf. kou/rhn *brish=os *a 392.
pa/lin: back, away from Paris, here as a sign of her displeasure; cf. pa/lin tre/pen o)/sse faeinw/ *n 3, talia dicentem iamdudum aversa tuetur Verg. Aen. iv. 362.
h)ni/pape: for the form, cf. 1.245.
h)/luqes: an excl. She reproaches him for his return, cf. 1.23.
au)to/qi: there, see § 15 d.
damei/s: with dat. of the agent, as v. 301.
pro/teros: see on 140.
h)= me\n dh\ ktl.: with disdainful mockery; truly thou wast wont to boast etc.
sh=|: added with emphasis, as B 164.
bi/h| kai\ xersi/n: thus united also *m 135, *o 139, m 246 etc.
a)ll) i)/qi nu=n: an ironical exhortation. The following asyndeton is usual, cf. 10.53, 175 f., *l 611. — proka/lessai: challenge, call forth to meet thee. Mid., as v. 19, 7.150, 285.
*mene/laon: obs. the emphatic repetition of the name with the same epith., in the same position in the verse as v. 430. See on v. 223.
a)lla\ ktl.: Helen now speaks in earnest. cf. *p 30, *u 196. — e)gw/ ge: cf. A 173. — “But I advise you” etc.
pau/esqai: cease for ever. Pres. infs. are used also to explain this injunction.
canqw=|: cf. v. 284.
a)nti/bion: for the const. cf. 2.121, 452.
po/lemon: for the cognate acc., see on 2.788.
mh/ pws ta/xa: lest in some way, soon.
u(p) au)tou= douri/: by the spear of this very man, cf. 11.821. For the dat. with u(po/, cf. 2.860 and note.
cf. *y 794. — mu/qoisin: const. with prose/eipen.
qumo/n: in partitive appos. with me/, cf. vs. 35, 442; see on 1.362.
me\n ga/r: always in this order; never ga\r me/n. — su\n *)aqh/nh|: by the aid of Athene. This diminishes the personal credit of Menelaus for his success.
au)=tis: another time, as *a 140. — e)gw/: sc. nikh/sw. — para\ ei)si/: more freq. in this sense is pari/stasqai. — h(mi=n: i.e. with Paris and his countrymen.
trapei/omen: aor. pass. subjv. from te/rpw, see §§ 13, 32 d, f.
eu)nhqe/nte: in the Eng. idiom, this would be in the same const. as trapei/omen, see on 2.113.
w(=de: so completely, sc. as now (v. 446); cf. 2.802.
e)/ros fre/nas a)mfeka/luyen: as 14.294, cf. qumo\n e)ni\ sth/qessi periproxuqei\s e)da/massen (sc. e)/ros) *c 316, *ku/klwpa peri\ fre/nas h)/luqen oi)=nos i 362. See on 1.103.
ou)d) o(/te: not even then when.
e)/pleon e)n nh/essi: “was on the voyage.”

*krana/h|: perhaps this name was invented for the situation, cf. v. 201; at least the ancients were completely at a loss concerning it. Strabo thought it was the small island Helena between Attica and Cos. Others thought it to be Cythera, south of Sparta. In the second century of our era, with reference to this passage, the name *krana/h was given to a small island in the Laconian gulf.
446=*c 328. — w(s: refers to w(=de v. 442.
a)/rxe: made the beginning, began; with a supplementary partic., kiw/n, as B 378.
ei(/peto: the fear of Aphrodite's anger had its effect, in spite of vs. 428 ff. — The whole scene, from v. 382, characterizes the sensual frivolity of Paris.
Vs. 448-461. Menelaus seeks Paris in vain. Agamemnon claims the victory and demands the restitution of Helen.
tw\ me\n a)/ra: so these two.
The story returns to the point where Aphrodite interposed, v. 380.
a)n) o(/milon: sc. *trw/wn. — qhri\ e)oikw/s: as *l 546, *o 586; like to a wild beast in fury and power.

ei)/ pou e)saqrh/seien: for the opt., see G. 226, 4 N. 1; H. 907. If he but might catch sight of him somewhere, cf. *pa/ndaron dizhme/nh (seeking), ei)/ pou e)feu/roi *d 88, *n 760. — qeoeide/a: for the synizesis, cf. v. 27.
ou)/ tis du/nato dei=cai: the logical proof of this statement is given below. “They would have pointed him out, if they could.”
kleitw=n ktl.: cf. thlekleitoi/ t) e)pi/kouroi *z 111.
to/te: i.e. when he sought him.
“They did not conceal him through love (cf. vs. 321 ff.), nor would they have concealed him if any one had seen him.”
khri/: dat. of likeness with k)=son. For the comparison, cf. *a 228, r 500, e)xqro\s o(mw=s (like) *)ai/dao pu/lh|sin 9.312
melai/nh|: cf. morti atrae Hor. Carm. i. 28. 13, post equitem sedet atra cura ib. iii. I. 40.
kai/: also. A standing expression, generally referring to previous speakers.
*da/rdanoi: see on B 819.
dh/: as you see, surely.
fai/netai: belongs evidently. Cf. the words of Zeus, a)ll' h)= toi ni/kh me\n a)rhifi/lou *menela/ou (sc. e)sti/n) 4.13.
*)argei/hn: as 2.161; cf. ornatus Argivae Helenae Verg. Aen. i. 650.
timh\n ktl.: cf. v. 286.
e)pi\ h)/neon: cf. e)peufh/mhsan *a 22. — The poet does not tell how Hector and the other Trojans received this demand, but implies that they allowed it as just.

The beginning of the next Book transports the hearers to Olympus, where Hera contrives a breach of the treaty. She cannot consent to any peace that would return Helen and the treasures to Menelaus but would leave unsacked the city that she hated. The Trojans discuss among themselves the return of Helen, 7.345 ff. — The Lycian archer Pandarus (2.827) shot an arrow and wounded Menelaus at the suggestion of Athena (4.116 ff.) Agamemnon thereupon roused the Greek forces, and the opposing armies meet in battle near the close of the Fourth Book (4.446 ff.). Most of the Fifth Book is devoted to the exploits of Diomed (*diomh/dous a)ristei/a). In the Sixth Book, Hector visits the city, tells the matrons to pray to Athena, and bids farewell to Andromache. In the Seventh Book, Hector and Ajax meet in single combat but night separates them, and the 22d day of the action of the Iliad ends.
